Title: Healthcare shape shifter.
Subtitle: Written by Carine De Potter
Author: Carine De Potter
Article: Sign up Sign in Sign up Sign in Carine De Potter Follow -- Listen Share When i received a proposition from Umut Elestekin ‚Äì the co-founder of Turk Noya Entreprise ‚Äì to join the team of Sharpsurgeon project, i had the feeling it could whirl into a spectacular like none before way of learning and practice surgical procedure ‚Äì but not only! Being in this industry for 20 years, the education and training needs a healthy dose of digital medicine. A dose of digital reality but how? For who? Let s start with who? Are we talking about the patient themselves ? The nurses? doctors? Students? Researchers? Surgeons? Physiotherapist ? Neuro-scientists ? You can find a enormous amount of literature talking about why XR is the new shit and how it will disrupt ‚Äì already- the medicine and change the way we take care. Yes, but‚Ä¶ this is not what am i talking about. I am talking about a full system where every action is interdependent on each other and the chain reaction more than ever can solve, effect or transform the system itself : healthcare. Health ‚Äì Care. While you decided to study any profession on healthcare based, you most probably like to deal with human being and you like to take care, the way this transformation is entering is for me one of the difficulties. Not taking care of this multiple entries while you pressing the base and give them the feeling of not taking care, you can‚Äôt end up with satisfaction because you just show that you are not taking care. Some will say: ‚Äúwhat else?‚Äù Having a new technology for MR, diagnosis, anesthesia, devices, yes‚Ä¶. It still technology for itself. A digital tool that empower and facilitate the profession we choose. But this is also about providing a value ‚Äì the highest possible outcome at the lowest possible cost ‚Äì for the healthcare system within the population health and in this case, the users are not the buyers. As caretakers, we need to touch and are not virtual! But if you show, you make them experience, learn and share, if you give that accessibility to the base and you encourage such a vision than you reach the disruptive change we are talking about. This accessibility is priceless. The base does not know less, they know how. That was probably my motivation to work with Noya because this is the question that Ufuk Aydinli ‚Äî co-founder and surgeon ‚Äî sought to answer when he launched Sharpsurgeon. A simulator who offer a highly realistic hand-based interactions in an immersive training environment for residents and spine surgeons. A repeatable, affordable, accessible, mesearable solution for surgeons education. The rise of interest as been great in a lot of ways and the one who experienced it showed a real added value for the field. We can only get better by using it and experience it but it only make sens if we get feedback on what we do and if we improve through studies, user-cases and give accessibility to the users. -- -- Help Status About Careers Press Blog Privacy Terms Text to speech Teams

Title: Why You Should Build Every New Product Feature Like an MVP
Subtitle: Soft Launching and A/B Testing
Author: Joe Procopio
Article: Sign up Sign in Sign up Sign in Member-only story Joe Procopio Follow -- 3 Share Making a mistake launching a new product feature is costly, and I‚Äôve done it at least a dozen times. Never again. We‚Äôre all familiar with the Minimum Viable Product (MVP) strategy. It mandates that we ‚Äúfake‚Äù components of a new product by making many of its processes manual at first release. We do this for a few reasons: There are other valid reasons for adopting an MVP strategy, like getting to revenue as quickly as possible, but those are the big three. MVP isn‚Äôt a new concept, per se, but its adoption has exploded with the lowered barriers of entry brought about by the Internet and Software as a Service (SaaS). What‚Äôs gaining traction now is the strategy of repeating the MVP process with every new feature, even down to every new version. How do we do that? -- -- 3 I'm a multi-exit, multi-failure entrepreneur. AI pioneer. Technologist. Innovator. I write at Inc.com and BuiltIn.com. Title: Think Artificial Intelligence is Superhuman? Here is it‚Äôs Kryptonite
Subtitle: Written by Shadow of the Valley
Author: Shadow of the Valley
Article: Sign up Sign in Sign up Sign in Member-only story Shadow of the Valley Follow -- 1 Share HAL 9000, C3PO, The Terminator, Ava from Ex Machina, David from Prometheus, or TARS and CASE from Interstellar. These are usually what we think of when we think of Artificial Intelligence. Though certainly not human, these fictional computers are what we would call a Artificial General Intelligence (AGI). They think and communicate in a human-like way. It can learn and do lots of things ‚Äî not just a single repetitive and limited task. It‚Äôs intelligence is seemingly superhuman, threatening to replace or overtake us in some instances. But for now, at least, these are strictly science fiction. The AI we have today is classified as Narrow Artificial Intelligence (NAI). Think of Deep Blue ‚Äî the chess-playing computer that beat Gary Kasparov, Watson, the Jeopardy playing computer that beat Ken Jennings, or Alpha Go, the Go-playing computer that been grandmaster Lee Sedol. These hyper-complex collections of matrices and algorithms are designed to perform very specific operations extremely well. When the tasks given to them have well-defined goals and desired outcomes they easily outperform human counterparts. But for all their power and utility, Narrow AI‚Äôs have some very crucial weaknesses and shortcomings: Let‚Äôs start with data. -- -- 1 The official blog of the podcast that explores how technology disrupts society. https://shadowofthevalley.com https://shows.pippa.io/shadowofthevalley/ Help Status About Careers Press Blog Privacy Terms Text to speech Teams

Title: This WiFi Packet Injector Is Built Into a Literal Syringe
Subtitle: Written by Cameron Coward
Author: Cameron Coward
Article: Sign up Sign in Sign up Sign in Cameron Coward Follow -- Listen Share ‚ÄúHacking,‚Äù at least as the word is used by the general populace, covers a huge range of attacks. The only thing those really have in common is that they involve electronics in some way ‚Äî and even that has an exception if you count social hacking. But for infosec experts at conferences like DEF CON, wireless hacking is often the most fun. You don‚Äôt have to have physical access to the device, and you can utilize a number of known WiFi exploits. For the Hacker Summercamp, El Kentaro decided to build a WiFi packet injector inside of a literal syringe. This project was constructed mostly as a gag to take advantage of the play on words, but it‚Äôs still a real tool. It uses an ESP8266, so a number of different WiFi hacks are possible, but El Kentaro is using it for beacon flooding. Beacon flooding doesn‚Äôt give the attacker access to anything, but it does disrupt WiFi access for other people in the area. It works by rapidly creating a large number of fake wireless network SSIDs (Service Set Identifiers). In a black hat attack, the large number of networks can make it difficult for users to find a real network, and could potentially crash some systems. In this case, however, it‚Äôs just done for laughs to display song lyrics or whatever else the ‚Äúattacker‚Äù wants. To build the Packet Injector, El Kentaro used a large 150ml syringe, an Adafruit Feather HUZZAH ESP8266, an Adafruit NeoPixel Ring, an MPL3115A2 barometric pressure sensor, and a LiPo battery. The ESP8266 is running FakeBeacon8266 for the attack, and that code is triggered by the barometric sensor when the syringe‚Äôs plunger is depressed and the air pressure increases. The NeoPixel LED Ring is just there to add some nifty lighting effects. Those parts are mounted on a 3D-printed frame inside of the syringe to keep everything stable. It may be a novelty, but the Packet Injector would certainly get a laugh from most hackers. -- -- Author, writer, maker, and a former mechanical designer. www.cameroncoward.com @cameron_coward Help Status About Careers Press Blog Privacy Terms Text to speech Teams

Title: US incorporation? Just do it.
Subtitle: Pros, cons, and red herrings.
Author: Gil Dibner
Article: Sign up Sign in Sign up Sign in Gil Dibner Follow Angular Ventures -- 2 Listen Share In over 15 years of enterprise tech investing across Europe and Israel, the question of where to incorporate the ultimate parent company (the ‚Äútopco‚Äù) comes up regularly. When it doesn‚Äôt come up ‚Äî and if it‚Äôs not too late (see below) ‚Äî I usually bring it up. To cut to the chase ‚Äî the answer is (almost) always Delaware, if you can (and if it‚Äôs not too late). Let me start off with some data points: The answer, at least in my mind and based on my experience, is clear as day: whether you come from Tallinn or Tel Aviv, London or Lisbon ‚Äî incorporate in Delaware. But founders are surrounded by advisers and there is a lot of contradictory advice swirling around. Below, we‚Äôll take a closer look at the arguments surrounding where to incorporate ‚Äî and we‚Äôll break it down into cons (legit reasons to not incorporate in Delaware), red herrings (false reasons to not incorporate in Delaware), and pros (the real reasons why incorporating in Delaware usually makes sense). To the inevitable critics of this approach: European tech is having a moment now: it‚Äôs here to stay, and we are building big companies in Europe. Israel has been a powerhouse for some time. So it‚Äôs tempting to argue that focusing on success in the US is no longer necessary. I think that‚Äôs the wrong conclusion to draw. We may one day get to a point when its easier to get to a big enterprise tech exit in Europe than in the US, but we are not there yet ‚Äî not even close. I am among the biggest cheerleaders for European tech, but this post is not about cheerleading. It‚Äôs about how non-US enterprise tech CEOs should go about configuring their enterprise tech companies for success by removing friction. Advocating for Delaware incorporation is not advocating against Europe or Israel ‚Äî it‚Äôs just recognizing that in the real world some paths are easier than others. Caveat: I am not a tax lawyer, so this post is neither tax advice nor is it legal advice. This is business advice. You should always consult with a lawyer before making these decisions‚Ä¶ Caveat to the caveat: ‚Ä¶but make sure you are talking to the right lawyer! As I‚Äôll argue below, it really matters which lawyer you consult with. Asking a local lawyer who realizes that if you flip he/she will eventually lose all your business is not a good way to get unbiased advice. Pros: Why Delaware Ultimately, the reason to incorporate in the US is the same reason that US-based companies from New York to New Mexico end up incorporating in Delaware, a relatively small state on the East Coast known mostly for the fact that everyone incorporates there. The reason is alignment with expectations. It‚Äôs just easier to do what everyone else does. There is more precedent. The majority of your employees, customers, investors, partners, and acquirers are just going to be more familiar and comfortable with a Delaware topco than anything else. You can conquer the world from anywhere‚Ää‚Äî‚Ääbut your job is hard enough. Alignment of the topco jurisdiction is one way to make your life as a founder that much easier. While the pros are not easily quantifiable, they are very real. If a flip can be done without severe tax consequences for the founders, it‚Äôs almost always the right call for an enterprise tech company. A few additional points: Timing. The cost, complexities, and tax implications of a flip are always minimal at the beginning and just get worse with time. In my experience, it is a complete fiction to think that flipping later is possible. It is not. Thus, founders are making a decision early on that is basically irreversible. My strong advice to any enterprise tech founder is to bite the bullet and flip the US as soon as possible. Day one. The absolute best way to do this, of course, is to incorporate in Delaware from the get-go. I don‚Äôt care about the ‚ÄúI don‚Äôt cares.‚Äù A lot of smart investors are increasingly saying that they ‚Äúdon‚Äôt care‚Äù about where a business is incorporated. Angular is the same. We will invest wherever it makes sense, and jurisdiction won‚Äôt stop us. This growing investor flexibility is good news, but it shouldn‚Äôt guide your decision-making. First, you have to make this decision based on the people that do care or will care (rightly or wrongly). You may not always be dealing with people who don‚Äôt care. Second, even if someone says they don‚Äôt care, that doesn‚Äôt mean they are not subject to subconscious biases. Remember that a lot of this is about signaling. Get advice. These are complex and consequential decisions. I am not arguing that US incorporation is optimal in all cases ‚Äî but to me, it‚Äôs the starting point for any enterprise tech company with global ambition, the default choice from which a founder will need good reasons to deviate. Before making this decision consult with investors, with lawyers, and with advisers ‚Äî but be very aware of biases. The worst advice will come from firms or individuals that only operate in one market. They will inevitably find reasons to convince you to take steps that benefit them (i.e. incorporating in a jurisdiction where they operate). This is not malice, but it is a mix of habit and bias, and it can be suboptimal. Many lawyers only work in one jurisdiction and many investors (especially with government backing) are limited to investing only in one preferred jurisdiction. That is their world ‚Äî but it‚Äôs not yours. Geographically flexible investors (like Angular Ventures) and law firms with truly global operations (that will make a fee no matter where you are incorporated) are a much better source of perspective here. -- -- 2 Early stage. Enterprise Tech. Europe & Israel. A global venture investor. Fascinated by the finance of innovation. Trying to help the few to do the impossible. Investing across Europe + Israel. Title: How many bugs were in The Lion King? Here are 5 fun VFX facts about the movie
Subtitle: Written by The Focus
Author: The Focus
Article: Sign up Sign in Sign up Sign in The Focus Follow -- 1 Listen Share By Jane Bracher One of the most popular fun facts from The Lion King thus far has been director Jon Favreau‚Äôs revelation that there was one real shot in a film that‚Äôs entirely CG. Title: Meet our Students: Matias Barrios
Subtitle: Written by ConsenSys Academy
Author: ConsenSys Academy
Article: Sign up Sign in Sign up Sign in ConsenSys Academy Follow -- Listen Share Have you met Matias? Our Blockchain Developer Bootcamp students all have stories to share & we want you to hear them! The Fall 2019 cohort is currently open, so if you‚Äôre keen on learning how the foundations of blockchain technology come together to allow us to build the next generation of web applications, this course is for you. Register soon üöÄ Matias is based in Santiago, Chile and is currently a full-stack developer and IT architect. He works at Wenu Work. Check out Matias‚Äôs interview below: What were your skills before the Blockchain Developer Bootcamp? I had gone through a blockchain certification program last year, but I was really keen on refreshing my Solidity knowledge this year. I proceeded to take the Blockchain Developer Bootcamp which really helped me stay updated on the space. Through the program, I was able to create my own instance of a private Ethereum blockchain and write smart contracts to store critical data for the startup I‚Äôm currently working at. This allowed us to notarize the data we are processing. What did you think of the program? The cohort model of the program works great! I have the chance to speak to mentors 24/7 on the Academy Slack channels. This allowed me to learn in real time and feel supported through the duration of the program. Do you have any advice for future Blockchain Developer Bootcamp students? Start your project early (3 months sounds like a lot of time but, of course, the more time you use studying, the more you can learn and apply to practice.) My project in the Bootcamp was a decentralized lottery system. The project gave me the flexibility to additionally invent my own hash function which used a provable oracle to call on the Wolfram API. -- -- Join us on our mission to develop the global blockchain ecosystem by bridging the Ethereum knowledge gap and revolutionizing education through blockchain tech Help Status About Careers Press Blog Privacy Terms Text to speech Teams

Title: Edward Traylor Explains Recent Advancements In Aviation Technology
Subtitle: Written by Edward Traylor
Author: Edward Traylor
Article: Sign up Sign in Sign up Sign in Edward Traylor Follow -- Listen Share Ever since its inception in the early 20th century, air travel represents a cornerstone in the transportation industry. Whether it‚Äôs personal sightseeing, business trips, or family vacations, the aviation industry is heavily depended on by our modern society. As it has developed over past decades, innovations have slowly but surely enhanced the customer experience, and this trend continues today. Edward Traylor, the owner of an Aviation and Maritime Technology Consulting Firm based in Palm Beach County, Florida, has the latest scoop on the most recent and exciting advancements in aviation technology. Artificial Intelligence The emergence of computer systems and artificial intelligence has resulted in many tasks and procedures transitioning from being done by hand to being semi or even fully automated, in order to cut costs and in many cases accelerate the process. Edward Traylor notes that one such change under development relates to how aircraft inspections are undertaken: Drones are capable of fully automating the process. Hovering around the aircraft before takeoff, they can analyze and assess far more quickly than human eyes, freeing up precious time for engineers. Additionally, artificial intelligence is also used for other reparations, being capable of predictive maintenance that not only prevents problems before they ever start, but also removes the need for scheduled maintenance thanks to the more perceptive eyes of digital systems. Lastly, the analysis of aircraft systems is being enhanced by a new concept called digital twins, virtual recreations of the different components within a plane allow for a real time view into how a system is performing at any given time; this drastically increases safety and stability for each individual flight. Connectivity The need for accessible Wi-Fi is only getting more prevalent with each passing year, and the aviation industry is trying its hand at providing this service mid-flight. Not only that, but the implementation of streaming services is also underway, allowing customers access to services such as Netflix mid-flight, allowing them to choose the in-flight movie that‚Äôs just right for them. Edward Traylor explains that the increase in wireless connectivity also extends to employees, as now cloud computing is being used to provide improved accessibility of critical information such as predictive maintenance and digital twins to everyone who needs to view the information at a moment‚Äôs notice, regardless of where they are. Contingency Planning The caveats of air travel are all too familiar: lost luggage, delays, and so on. Whereas in previous times they would have a significant impact on customer experience, technology is being used to soften the blow as much as possible. Luggage can now be tracked in real-time, and there are apps currently in development that can provide instant reimbursement in the case that it is permanently lost. In the case of delays, flight simulations now provide the most accurate means of predicting delays, and new programs are capable of automatically adjusting reservations and appointments in the case of a delayed flight. Customer Service There is a plethora of innovations underway for airline customer service. One such example is a change in methods for boarding ‚Äî ‚Äî ‚Äî the implementation of facial recognition technology for faster wait times. Voice recognition technology is also being used to the same effect, providing a faster means of checking in. Accessibility is always important, and technology is readily able to fill in the gaps for any customers with additional needs. Edward Traylor states that one such example is the current development of an app that allows customers to specify what they need extra assistance with before they arrive, making it that much easier and faster when they get there. In the case of customers with low-vision or blindness, smart glasses are a tool being used to aid in order to ensure a positive experience. Finally, for customers who need to eat in a hurry there are now food delivery services that will bring meals directly to the airport, alleviating the need for them to settle with whatever food vendors are physically present in the terminal, as well as plan meals to be ready in advance so they can eat in record time when every second counts. In the end, technology will always be further developed in order to provide an optimal customer experience that is safer, easier and more efficient. Edward Traylor concludes that exciting new concepts are being created each year, and it‚Äôs safe to say that the flying experience is only getting better as a result. -- -- Edward is an I.T. professional and entrepreneur currently residing in Palm Beach, Florida. He runs his own Aviation and Maritime Technology consulting company. Help Status About Careers Press Blog Privacy Terms Text to speech Teams

Title: 10 Invaluable Lessons on Digital Transformation in 2019
Subtitle: To wrap up, I‚Äôd like to share a point made by PLDT chairman Manuel V. Pangilinan that deeply resonated with me:
Author: Charu Misra
Article: Sign up Sign in Sign up Sign in Charu Misra Follow John Clements Lookingglass -- Listen Share Real talk: every company is currently tackling digital transformation in their own way. Love it or hate it, it‚Äôs happening. In fact, chances are that the company you work for, or want to work for, has plans for it. This is an exciting time to see these technologies play out, and last month, I got to see it first-hand at PLDT‚Äôs Philippine Digital Convention 2019. The energy at the event was infectious and I found myself marveling at the pioneering digital solutions and innovative business concepts shared by industry leaders and digital experts. Envisioned with the theme ‚ÄúCome to the Edge‚Äù, the convention was all about the impact of technology on businesses, the state of communication, and ideas that unlock the doors to a successful digital transformation. I personally found the idea to be very thought-proving, so I asked myself, ‚ÄúWhat does it mean to come to the edge?‚Äù. Based on the speakers and delegate-discussions, this is what I gleaned: Tech has accelerated the pace of change and brought us to the edge. What does this entail? High performance, low latency, edging out competitors, bolder decisions, focusing on proximity, pushing the limits, living on the edge. Now, coming down to the meat and potatoes of it all ‚Äî here are the 10 invaluable lessons I picked up at #PHDigicon2019: 2. ‚ÄúWith 2019 forecasted to see huge milestones in the tech and business landscapes, many analysts predict that this year will be the beginning of the 4th Industrial Revolution.‚Äù (due to advancements in AI, IoT, machine learning etc.) ‚Äî Jovy Hernandez, SVP & Head, PLDT & Smart Enterprise Business Groups 3. Tech is not designed to replace face-to-face interaction. It‚Äôs to help when time and distance are an issue. 4. Job Displacement: Cisco conducted a study based on 275 million full-time equivalent workers employed in the six largest ASEAN economies and found that 28 million of those workers are going to be displaced. Innovations in digital technology will move workers from what they are currently doing to what is required in the future. 5. Word of Mouth is now World of Mouth. The businesses of yesterday had to rely on customers spreading their message via verbal waterfall. Increased communication and the internet have allowed that process to occur on a global scale, at lighting speed. What was once word of mouth, is now world of mouth. We actually have that speed! 6. Gone are the days of photo copies and binders stuffed in chunky drawers and cabinets. Currently, we‚Äôre in a situation where we‚Äôre seeing everything move to the cloud. In order for enterprises to keep up, you absolutely need software-defined WAN (SD-WAN). 7. Did you know that it would take Niagara Falls 210,000 years to use up one quintillion gallons of water? If that surprises you, get this: there are 2.5 quintillion bytes of data being generated every single day(!!) So what we need is an edge in analytics to compete and succeed in the digital age. 8. Trans-humanism: the possibility of fundamentally improving the human condition beyond its current physical and mental limitations, especially by means of science and technology. 9. Fun-fact on the state of digital: more people now own a mobile device than a toothbrush!! 10) ‚ÄúEven with all these advances in technology, let‚Äôs not forget to keep in touch with our humanity.‚Äù In the last few years, when we think of the (broad) term digital transformation, we‚Äôve mostly been hearing about the cloud, augmented reality, and ioT. However, at this event, we explored a fresh new batch of technologies such as 5G, AI and next-generation cybersecurity. Although these are exciting developments, the highlight for me was definitely the focus on analytics. On a personal note, when I create a digital marketing strategy, that strategy is data-driven. I spend a fair chunk of my time looking at the analytics and numbers of our previous campaigns, mix that with the current market research, audience-data and industry trends (to begin with) to derive actionable insights and begin the process of coming up with my new strategy. At work, I always stress the importance of being data-driven and data-directed with our marketing efforts. I was ecstatic to see the same importance stressed on analytics at this convention. Think about it ‚Äî we have more data now than ever before. Instead of being scared by it, use it to your benefit! If you want to succeed and are looking for a competitive edge, analytics is your best friend. Please visit and join the John Clements Talent Community. About the author: Charu Misra works in the Recruitment and Corporate Learning industry as a Digital Marketing Consultant. Holding a Bachelor of Science (B.S.) degree in Advertising & Marketing Communications, her professional career originated in New York City where she chose her niche in Content and Social Media Marketing. Charu is currently based in Manila, Philippines. Title: Harness Solar Energy to Recharge Li-Ion Batteries with AEMLION
Subtitle: Written by Cabe Atwell
Author: Cabe Atwell
Article: Sign up Sign in Sign up Sign in Cabe Atwell Follow -- Listen Share IoT hardware engineer Jasper Sikken designed his AEMLION Solar Powered Li-Ion Charger for his entry in the Hackaday Prize 2018 (Power Harvesting Challenge), and is now available for purchase on his Tindie page and Amazon as well. The board is outfitted with an E-peas‚Äô AEM10941 photovoltaic solar harvesting IC, capable of extracting DC power from up to seven different solar panels and can store the energy while also supplying a system with two independent voltages. The AEMLION works with both outdoor and indoor lighting, and offers 3.3V and 1.8V regulated outputs, which are enabled when the battery has enough charge. Additionally, it features a low-charge warning when the battery is near depleted, and the system is about to shut down. According to Jasper, the AEMLION has an ultra-low power startup with the boost converter starting at a very low 380mV input voltage and 3uW input power. The IC also gets the most power it can grab out of whatever solar cell/s you integrate by implementing maximum power point tracking (MPPT) every 5-seconds. As far as the specs are concerned, the AEMLION has a solar input voltage of 50mV to 5V, a solar input current of 110mA, 3.3V/80mA and 1.8V/20mA regulated outputs, reverse voltage protection, and a 3.3V status output pin that warns the host MCU if the power drops below 3.60V. Interesting enough, Jasper designed another version of the solar charger, dubbed the AEMSUCA, which uses a pair of supercapacitors to store that harvested solar energy rather than relying on a battery. Other than the storage medium, both boards appear to be identical with the same spec set and the same price-point, $24.90, which gets you either solar harvester and a pair of 5-pin male headers. -- -- Help Status About Careers Press Blog Privacy Terms Text to speech Teams

Title: Flutter for Web : Building a Portfolio Website
Subtitle: Configuration and Models
Author: Aditya Gurjar
Article: Sign up Sign in Sign up Sign in Aditya Gurjar Follow Flutter Community -- 12 Listen Share My portfolio website was pending for updates for quite sometime now. Also with Flutter 1.9 web support was also integrated into the main Flutter repository. So I decided to give it a try. Knowing the fact that its still in Technical Preview, I was expecting some issues and roadblocks but to my surprise everything worked just as well as it did for mobile. Let me walk you through how I did it. The portfolio website we‚Äôre building will have three tabs: about, blog and projects. It‚Äôll also have a dark mode and links to all the my social media accounts. First switch to master channel, upgrade Flutter, and enable web support. Now run And you should see chrome in the list of available devices. This means you‚Äôre good to go. (Note: You need to have Chrome installed for live reloading and running your code.) Create the project using flutter create . I used my name for my project since it‚Äôs a portfolio website. Feel free to use your name instead. I don‚Äôt need support for Android and iOS so I got rid of them. This is how my project directory structure looks like. First let‚Äôs edit the pubspec.yaml and add the assets and fonts for our project. I won‚Äôt be going over the configuration and model classes for the sake of keeping the article concise. The names pretty much explain what they contain but feel free to check the github repo if you wish to check them. Create the Home Page. Our Home Page will have three tabs and a AppBar (with the toggle for Dark Mode which we‚Äôll add at the end). The about tab would have the avatar, name, a short bio and links to all social media accounts. We‚Äôll be using Dart HTML Library for opening the links in new tabs. I‚Äôm loading the latest blogs from my medium profile in this tab and showing them in a ListView. The ApiProvider for the blog tab. And the Widget for each individual Blog. The Project Tab would use a ResponsiveWidget and show the projects in a ListView or a GridView based on the screen size. The Widget for each individual Project. Now that we have our basic website done. We‚Äôll use InheritedWidget to add a Dark Mode to our app. InheritedWidget helps in propagating information down the Widget Tree of the app. In our case this information will be a boolean for turning Dark Mode On/Off. Check code comments to understand what every line in our ThemeSwitcherWidget does. Next update your main.dart to wrap your Top-Level Widget with the ThemeSwitcherWidget we just created. And in your home_page.dart update the AppBar to add the toggle for dark mode. To generate the release build, run This should output your release build inside the build/web folder. You can serve the website to your browser using any http server to see your see your website in action. I recommend using http-server. Or you can host it wherever you want! I have hosted mine at www.adityag.me. Check it out. Checkout the complete code at github.com Have any questions? Reach out to me on Twitter. twitter.com medium.com www.twitter.com -- -- 12 Articles and Stories from the Flutter Community Mobile Engineer. Writing Mostly about Mobile Dev, Mobile DevOps, and a lil bit of life. Help Status About Careers Press Blog Privacy Terms Text to speech Teams

Title: Using AI to Clean up Your Grainy Photos!
Subtitle: Good Audience
Author: Albert Lai
Article: Sign up Sign in Sign up Sign in Home About Follow publication The front page of Deep Tech. Don't miss the latest advancements in artificial intelligence, machine‚Ä¶ Follow publication Albert Lai Follow Good Audience -- 1 Listen Share Have you ever taken a really blurry grainy picture and wished it could be cleaner? Wouldn‚Äôt you REALLY LOVE IT if you could remove the noise from the photo to clean it up? I think I might have the solution for you! üòè Meet Noise2Noise: a machine learning model that can denoise your images! Researchers at Nvidea, MIT, and Aalto University were able to develop a denoiser that could remove noise, grain, and even watermarks from photos! The crazy thing is that it doesn‚Äôt even need clean data to train it ‚Äî it only requires other noisy images! So how in the world does this even work?? ü§î I‚Äôll be explaining the model the team used and the amazing theory of only using grainy images as the training data! In order to denoise the data, a U-Net with skip connections was implemented (Ronneberger et al., 2015). A U-net contain two parts: downsampling the image into a smaller form, and then upsampling it back into its original size. It uses convolution and max pool layers to downsample it from a 572x572 image into a 28x28 layer, and then deconvolution layers to upsample it back to a 388x388 image! This works because it‚Äôs downsampling the image to retain the important pieces of the original image and discarding the noise. Then, it‚Äôs upsampling to amplify the important parts to generate a clear image! Of course, to generate a clean image, the model must have the correct weights and biases to be able to extract the important parts from the orginal image. So the question is: what should we train the network on? In classic supervised learning, we map features to labels. For example, if we‚Äôre predicting the price of the house, we use the features (size, number of rooms, location) to determine the label (the price). In classifying an image, we use a CNN to find its features to determine its label (dog or cat). In our scenario of cleaning images, we would want the features from the noisy images, and the labels be the clean images, so our network can take a grainy image and generate a clean version! But what if we don‚Äôt have the clean version of the images to train the network on? In, we don‚Äôt have the camera quality to take super high res images yet. For brain scans, we can‚Äôt retain a version without the noise. Sooo what can we do?? ü§î Here‚Äôs where the amazing part comes in: we train the model by mapping noisy images to noisy images (as the target). Before I explain how in the world this works, I‚Äôll explain how clean images are taken. To obtain a clean image, a good exposure (amount of light in the image) is needed, which is determined by shutter speed, among other factors. Shutter speed is the length of time the shutter is opened, allowing light into the camera. A noisy image is produced with a lower shutter speed, not allowing much light in, while a clean image requires a higher shutter speed. However, in areas like space or low-light photagraphy, it‚Äôs difficult/expensive to have a high shutter speed. To overcome this, we use the property that a long exposure image can be retained by taking the averages of infinitely many noisy/short exposure images! üí°üí° So, we can actually train the model with low exposure images mapping to low exposure images! How? As stated before, supervised learning maps features to labels through some distribution. Therefore, the distribution taken from the average of distributions will be the correct one! So, we just need to take a couple more short exposure images to be used as the labels! According to the researchers, this method can work just as well as having the clean image to use as the label! ü§Ø A denoiser like this has a ton of applications! Say goodbye to your terrible low-light photos! Removing watermarks or words on the images? No problemo! It could be used to clean up MRI scans: How about space? With satellites pointing their cameras at galaxies millions of light years away, you can bet that the pictures can get a bit noisy! Alright, so this model is really cool and all, but what impact will it have? First off, it can help improve a bunch of existing technologies as mentioned beforehand, like space and brain imaging. It can also improve camera footage to help photographers and videographers. However, this raises the question: how will the AI extrapolate data? In a scenario when the model is used to enhance grainy security footage in low-light, can it improperly generate the face of the fugitive? How can we be 100% sure the AI cleans up the images properly when lives are on the line? That will definitely be up for debate! I hope you enjoyed this article on a new and revolutionary idea! If you liked this article, please connect with me on linkedin and follow me! Credits go to (Lehtinen et al., 2018) for the paper and images! -- -- 1 The front page of Deep Tech. Don't miss the latest advancements in artificial intelligence, machine learning, and blockchain. Straight from practitioners. I‚Äôm an 18-year-old student who loves technology and life, and trying to get better at both! I mainly write about ML, but also books and philosophy :) Help Status About Careers Press Blog Privacy Terms Text to speech Teams

Title: How AI Empowers Your Chatbots
Subtitle: Published in Chatbots Life
Author: Shelf
Article: Sign up Sign in Sign up Sign in Shelf Follow Chatbots Life -- Listen Share Chatbots are quickly becoming an essential part of delivering customer service. According to a study by IT experts Spiceworks, up to 40% of businesses with 500 or more employees will have active chatbot or AI assistants by the end of 2019. These businesses have discovered the incredible benefits of using AI-related technology in their daily tasks. The right system improves customer interactions without investing in expensive overhead like manpower and training. While the installation of chatbots won‚Äôt eliminate the need for human agents, this technology does lighten the burden on existing workers. By decreasing simple and repetitive tasks, AI assistants minimize the number of routine calls agents need to take, which frees their time to concentrate on more complex issues. For call center managers, chatbots are a cost-effective way to positively impact both customer and agent satisfaction rates. In the past, consumers have angrily rebelled against automated systems. The confusing tangle of questions, menus, and options often fueled aggravation and led to irate customers taking out their negative emotions on exhausted agents. Older IVR systems are notorious for not accurately recording information, having problems with picking up voice signals, and lacking useful information and functions. However, the new age of AI-powered chatbots is changing the way consumers and agents see their potential. 1. Five Inspirational Startups Using AI and Chatbot Technology 2. Twelve Amazing AI Chatbot Trends for Business in 2019 3. The road to a conversational banking future 4. Chatbot Conference 2019 in NYC To be its most effective, chatbots should add value to the customer‚Äôs experience. When a customer calls a help center, they are looking for the fastest and most advantageous solution to their problem. If an IVR demands too much interaction, customers are likely to lose patience and demand a live operator. Therefore, systems that support fast, efficient, and useful interactions are necessary to satisfy client needs. Some of the most important functions of a chatbot system that enables superior customer interactions include: Features like natural language processing (NLP) allow chatbots to answer questions, provide a verbal summary for customer interactions, and notate accounts after phone calls. The ability to detect and analyze speech patterns is another useful aspect of NLP. Chatbots can assess the stress patterns in customer interactions. When they sense the customer getting upset, the AI system can transfer the chat to a live agent to help diffuse the situation. AI-powered chatbots are so much more than a money-saving strategy for businesses that rely on contact centers. These systems are becoming a vital part of regular customer interactions for a variety of reasons. With the continued development of NLP-based technology, chatbots will become even more important for daily business operations. By supporting common customer care activities with voice-to-text dictation, simple customer service tasks like paying bills and viewing balances, and directing callers to most relevant sources for information and assistance, chatbots are able to directly contribute to higher rates of customer satisfaction. Chatbots go beyond simple customer service tasks too. Analytics and reporting capabilities give businesses a new source of information on what makes their customers happy. The information gathered by chatbots can be used to improve agent training, revamp automated systems, produce more relevant self-help options, or even sharpen messages for more effective marketing campaigns. In the social media sphere, AI is being used to supplement human interactions by adding appropriate data and suggestions based on the content of ongoing conversations. Once again, it‚Äôs highly unlikely that chatbots and AI systems will replace human agents any time soon. However, AI-augmented service does facilitate a more positive experience for both callers and agents. For this reason, AI-based systems need to be as intelligent, intuitive, and comprehensive as possible. Despite popular beliefs, AI can‚Äôt think for itself. Chatbots are powered by a sophisticated web of algorithms. The AI follows the most logical path based on the information it is provided. Connecting an AI system to a knowledge base provides a link to important data the system can use to answer questions and resolve issues. Filtering this information through a digital AI ensures that the right solution is found quickly and efficiently. In fully integrated systems, customers often can‚Äôt tell if they‚Äôre being helped by a human or an AI-based entity. Shelf is an AI-powered knowledge management system designed specifically for call center environments. This unique platform improves customer interactions, agent satisfaction, and call center metrics without a heavy investment of cash or human resources. Contact us to learn more about this exciting system or if you want to see Shelf in action! -- -- Best place to learn about Conversational AI. Title: Day 4: Recover Passcode (attackdefense.com)
Subtitle: Written by Atumcell Labs
Author: Atumcell Labs
Article: Sign up Sign in Sign up Sign in Atumcell Labs Follow -- Listen Share Using static analysis, figure out the passcode to run challenge successfully i.e. ./challenge CORRECT_PASSCODE . If you get the right passcode, a flag will be printed. First things first, let‚Äôs fire up gdb and disassemble main‚Ä¶ We think the password is ‚Äúhardbuteasy‚Äù, right? Ok, let‚Äôs try. Damn, no luck here, but wait, it must be this password so what the hell is going on? Let‚Äôs go back and look at the disassembly. The CMP instruction compares two operands. It is generally used in conditional execution. This instruction basically subtracts one operand from the other for comparing whether the operands are equal or not. It does not disturb the destination or source operands. It is used along with the conditional jump instruction for decision making. Let‚Äôs look at the disassembly for any CMP instructions. We found the culprit, if the password is any longer than 9 bytes it will fail. So let‚Äôs try our theory and only supply 9 bytes of the ‚Äòcorrect password‚Äô value. Nice, it worked! This is a great example of how CTF style challenges and real world bugs may expect certain conditions to be true even if you do have the value the program expects, or at least the value it told you it expected. A good example of this are truncated passwords, they won‚Äôt fail but let‚Äôs say it‚Äôs truncated at 5bytes and that‚Äôs the only part compared, then even users with 6+ byte passwords are no safer. -- -- Security Research Team @ Atumcell Help Status About Careers Press Blog Privacy Terms Text to speech Teams

Title: CallStop is a 100% effective robocall blocker ‚Äî and it can protect any phone number.
Subtitle: Written by CallStop
Author: CallStop
Article: Sign up Sign in Sign up Sign in CallStop Follow -- 1 Listen Share Maybe it‚Äôs 10PM and you‚Äôre settling down after a long day. Suddenly, your phone rings by your bed. It‚Äôs not a number you recognize, but it‚Äôs from your area code. It might be a friend you haven‚Äôt chatted with in a while, so you pick it up. Big mistake. It‚Äôs a call from someone pretending to be from the IRS. They‚Äôre threatening to come after you for taxes you don‚Äôt owe. You quickly tell them to f*** off, or if you‚Äôve been the more polite type, you say ‚ÄúTake me off of your list‚Äù like I was taught when I was young. But by picking up the phone, you‚Äôve already made your first mistake. They now know you‚Äôre a great target for future scams ‚Äî because you‚Äôre listening. Hang on, though. What list were you asking them to take you off of? Maybe you meant the ‚ÄúDo Not Call List‚Äù, a federal registry is the United States. You do some digging and find this on the FCC website. ‚ÄúEven if your number is registered, some organizations may still call you, such as charities, political organizations, and telephone surveyors. For a full description of who may still call you, please consult our Consumer FAQs. ‚Äú You realize the ‚ÄúDo Not Call List‚Äù doesn‚Äôt even work. A phone call about a political organization at any time of day feels like spam to you. It doesn‚Äôt matter whether they‚Äôre selling paper or political agendas ‚Äî it‚Äòs spam to you. The federal list does nothing to block calls from an engineering standpoint: instead, it trusts that scammers and spammers won‚Äôt call those numbers out of fear of a fine or litigation. It‚Äôs too easy for spammers and scammers to switch numbers and create fake Caller IDs. Moreover, it‚Äôs so easy to hide behind spoofed or foreign numbers, the spammers couldn‚Äôt care less about a list that relies on trust. Most of these calls are from shady foreign numbers or numbers with no Caller ID. Good luck tracking down that person from a number in Liberia or Ukraine‚Ä¶ chances are, they don‚Äôt even live there. What would have happened if you hadn‚Äôt picked up the phone? Those scammers might have called you again at a different time of night. As you lay awake unable to sleep, infuriated by another obnoxious phone call, you realize you have to solve this problem to keep from going crazy. You talk to your friends the next day and they mention a few apps that block spammy numbers. But they also tell you that those apps let calls through that haven‚Äôt yet been marked as spam. You tell them that‚Äôs not what you‚Äôre asking for ‚Äî you want something that can block 100% of spam calls. What you really need is an app that: 3. Blocks everyone else You‚Äôve just described CallStop. CallStop is like Adblock but for phone calls. My Story A few months back I was hanging out with my parents when we got a call. I only had a few minutes to chat with my dad before I had to hit the road. The call was a robocall ‚Äî one of those tax scams. My dad listened for a few seconds, realized the call was a waste of time and hung up the phone. We completely lost our train of thought in the conversation we were having. So much for quality family time, for reasons out of everyone‚Äôs control. But it did get me thinking: was there a way to solve this problem for myself? As an engineer and entrepreneur with experience building mobile apps and websites for startups, I wondered if the problem could be solved. I started doing research, and the results shocked me. I learned it costs 1¬¢ to make a robocall, and a single robocall center can make up to 16 million calls a day from purchased listed of hundreds of millions of numbers. The economics are totally broken. I spent some time looking into existing solutions. T-mobile had a spam blocking app I found like many others on the App Store. But it could only find spam numbers after they were already spammy, which wasn‚Äôt what I was looking for. I wanted to be certain I wasn‚Äôt going to be called in the first place. I realized how bad existing solutions were when I came across this contradictory suggestion by T-mobile. The carrier suggests changing your number if you keep getting unwanted calls! In my mind that‚Äôs giving up ‚Äî and I like to think I‚Äôm not a quitter. No one is going to make me change my phone number, and no one is going to call me if I don‚Äôt want them to. But that product didn‚Äôt exist when I looked for it, so I would need to build my own. 1‚Äôs & 0‚Äôs Don‚Äôt Cut It I realized the problem with existing solutions is they‚Äôre all binary. These products have assumed numbers are either ‚Äòspam‚Äô or not, but the real world isn‚Äôt like that at all. You might want to only allow a business to reach you during business hours and prevent calls from coworkers on the weekend. You might want to restrict your pesky internet provider from bothering you by restricting the number of times they can call you in a month (that should teach them to tell you only the most important updates!). You might also want to prevent a delivery driver from texting you the night after they dropped off food by only allowing them to reach you before dropping off your food. Building CallStop Whilte burning the midnight oil, I prototyped the first version of CallStop. In those early days I was free to let my imagination roam. Most of all, I wanted to build a product that would solve the problem for everyone I knew. I came up with the name CallStop and got to work. Goodbye, Spam Calls Here‚Äôs what I came up with. CallStop automatically imports your contacts into a whitelist and forwards your device number to your CallStop number. Unknown callers will hear the following message when they call your number: You have reached a phone number protected by CallStop. If you know this person, press 1 to send a whitelist request with a quick note. If you have a PIN to reach this person directly, press 2 and enter the PIN. Listen to that recording here. It‚Äôs professional, succinct and guides callers clearly. If the caller presses 1, they receive a text where they can add a note to their whitelist request. The person with the CallStop app gets a push notification, and when they open the app they see a note. It‚Äôs an effortless way to let new people reach you, but only when you want to be reached. Unknown callers can only send one whitelist request; they have to wait until you decide whether you want to respond and whitelist them. You‚Äôre in control. The rejected calls section shows a list, updated instantly, of all callers that have heard your message. You can even call them back directly from that page. You can also optionally receive push notifications for rejected calls so you know instantly when you‚Äôre rejecting a call. Customizing Your Voice Message You can customize your voice message by recording a short, customized snippet similar to the one above. It makes your voice message slightly more personal. You can always update it or switch back to using the default voice message at any time. Oh, and at any time if you‚Äôd like to let all calls through, just toggle ‚ÄúAccept All Calls‚Äù under the Settings section of your app. CallStop takes less than 1 minute to set up, but protects against 100% of spam calls forever. Does the app sound too good to be true? It‚Äôs not‚Ä¶ it was a lot of work to build. Many late nights, stress and a ton of caffeine went into this product. But since I was solving the problem for myself and people I knew, I had a lot of motivation. Now, I need your feedback and ideas on how to make it better. My hope is the app can become the Adblock for phone calls, allowing people like myself to have full control over their phones. CallStop Is Currently Free CallStop is currently free. It‚Äôs a way to thank anyone who is an early user or anyone who finds this post. I need to learn more about how to improve the product, and for that I need users. I need to talk to people about what features they want, and how they use the product. It‚Äôs exactly what I love about working on startups: you get to meet interesting people and help them. If this sounds like it solves a problem for you, try out the app here. It will save you a world of trouble. If you have any feedback, say hello to me at david@callstop.com I no longer get any spam calls, and can confirm I am much happier because of it. There‚Äôs a certain peace of mind of knowing I‚Äôll never be bothered by spam callers. I know that every call I receive is someone who actually knows me. Yesterday, I received 12 spam calls. Totally I installed CallStop, and I‚Äôll never get any more ever again. Follow us here on Medium and send a few claps our way to stay updated on everything CallStop! Check out our website at callstop.com. -- -- 1 Block 100% of spam and robocalls with CallStop. Learn more at callstop.com Help Status About Careers Press Blog Privacy Terms Text to speech Teams

Title: Iranian Girl Wins AIAA‚Äôs Top Aircraft Design Award
Subtitle: Published in IFP News ( Iran Front Page )
Author: Maryam Khy
Article: Sign up Sign in Sign up Sign in Maryam Khy Follow IFP News ( Iran Front Page ) -- Listen Share An Iranian girl has made her childhood dream come true by presenting a plan for building some kind of airplane which earned her a prestigious title. Mina Khalilzadeh Fat‚Äôhi, a student of the Aerospace Engineering Faculty of Sharif University of Technology, has participated individually in the competitions held by the American Institute of Aeronautics and Astronautics (AIAA) and won the first title in the Undergraduate Individual Aircraft Design Competition. Mina was born in the city of Bonab in East Azarbaijan province in 1978. She studies aerospace at Sharif University of Technology and plans to go to a foreign country to receive a master‚Äôs degree because ‚Äúthis field in Iran is not suitable for women.‚Äù ‚ÄúAt high school, I participated with my classmates in glider competitions at Sharif University of Technology and got acquainted with the aerospace at this great university,‚Äù Mina told Fars News Agency. ‚ÄúOf course, many people consider this field as male-oriented, but I disagree with it. I thought about everything, including the job market before choosing the major. I came to the conclusion that if I cannot find a job in Iran, I will not feel down and will go to other airlines to find a job.‚Äù ‚ÄúLast year, as part of a team from Sharif University, we participated in the AIAA competitions, but could not win any title; however the competition had three other sections that people can take part individually. Therefore, I participated individually in these competitions and submitted the necessary reports to them in May. I eventually received an email after being judged by expert engineers from major companies in the world announcing that my proposal has ranked first,‚Äù she added. ‚ÄúWhen I received the email it was mentioned at the end that they could not send me the 1,000 USD prize because of the sanctions and I was upset. Of course, they had announced that team members could travel to the United States to elaborate on their plan, but I have not received such an email yet.‚Äù Referring to the benefits of the proposed plan, she said the plan proposed in this section was to design an unmanned aerial system for inspection of 150 miles of power transmission lines in one day. For a brief review of Iran‚Äôs achievements in various fields of science and technology, check the book ‚ÄúScience and Technology in Iran: A Brief Review ‚Äî 2019‚Äù ‚ÄúThe system to be designed should have lower costs than current methods for conducting higher power lines and more security in comparison with other unmanned aerial systems.‚Äù Fat‚Äôhi said that although sanctions have created a lot of problems for Iranian airlines, there are still many experts who put the airlines in good and safe conditions. The American Institute of Aeronautics and Astronautics (AIAA) is a professional society for the field of aerospace engineering. The AIAA is the US representative on the International Astronautical Federation and the International Council of the Aeronautical Sciences. In 2015, it had more than 30,000 members among aerospace professionals worldwide. The AIAA annually holds design competitions and Design/Build/Fly competitions to provide a real-world design experience for engineering students, both undergraduate and graduate, by giving them the opportunity to validate their analytic studies. https://ifpnews.com/iranian-girl-wins-aiaas-top-aircraft-design-award -- -- Latest news and views from Iran, Middle East and the World Help Status About Careers Press Blog Privacy Terms Text to speech Teams

Title: No Title
Subtitle: Written by Person x
Author: Person x
Article: Sign up Sign in Sign up Sign in Person x Follow -- Listen Share Diversity or Racism in Tech If you work in the software company like myself and you haven‚Äôt been living under a rock you may have heard about the war about hiring practices in top tech companies like Google or Microsoft. James Damore of google was fired from his job, for his opinions and now there is an internal debate raging on internal message boards in Microsoft about how they actively encourage racism with monetary rewards. This post isn‚Äôt meant to take either side of the argument, it simply exists to present facts and present a background of where these arguments originate from. Before you read any further dear reader, I just want you to ask yourself one thing, what gender did you assign my voice to? Chances are it was a white male voice. This isn‚Äôt racism or sexism, this is implicit racial bias. Implicit bias is the unconscious attribution of particular qualities to a member of a certain social group. I am not saying I am not a male, nor I am saying that I am. When reading it is easy to assign a gender that seems appropriate to the material, it is hard to hear a voice without allocating it a gender. It is also hard to correct for implicit bias‚Äôs even if you know that you have them, this is simply an evolutionary trait. The problem is it can have negative consequences on hiring practices, where hiring managers hire candidates that are close to what they become accustomed to. Diversity for the sake of diversity is stupid. Do I think my workplace should have a diverse group of employees from all genders, races, creeds, socio-economic group, heights, religions and music tastes? Absolutely. Not because for the sake of diversity, but because our customers are diverse, having a diverse group of individuals allows us build better apps for all. The best ideas are drummed up when people from different walks of life interact. In a perfect world you would be able to hire the best candidate for the role and naturally end up with a diverse workforce simply because the candidates are diverse. This simply not the case, most graduating engineers are either Asian or White males. We aren‚Äôt going to really touch on why this is in this article because that‚Äôs a big can of worms, but the result means we cannot rely on natural diversity due to statistics. The problem today however is companies sought to create a more diverse workforce and rectify implicit biases by incentivizing hiring a more diverse workforce. The problem is this is racism and sexism because by definition you are actively discriminating against someone based on their sex or race. So therein lies the problem dear reader, we want a more diverse workforce, we want to balance for implicit biases but our methods and tools that we use today are racist or sexist. Can we fix this? Not in a day, or a year, maybe in a generation. We need to create a more diverse set of students one where the people who apply for admissions into engineering are just as diverse as the general population. Until this happens, there will always be a winner and a loser in our hiring practises. -- -- Help Status About Careers Press Blog Privacy Terms Text to speech Teams

Title: SlothBot Takes Its Time to Monitor Jungle Canopy Environments
Subtitle: Written by Cameron Coward
Author: Cameron Coward
Article: Sign up Sign in Sign up Sign in Cameron Coward Follow -- Listen Share Sloths are famous for living life slowly, and that certainly isn‚Äôt an unfounded stereotype. Modern tree sloths survive mostly on leaves found in the jungles of South America and Central America ‚Äî a diet that offers very few calories. Because they consume so few calories, they need to expend as little energy as possible throughout the day. That results in the slow movement that sloths have become known for. A team of engineers from Georgia Tech have applied that same ‚Äútheory of slowness‚Äù to a robot for environmental monitoring, and have appropriately named it SlothBot. Most of the robots that make the headlines end up there because they do something physically impressive. That could be object manipulation that approaches the dexterity of human hands. Or, it could be the ability to move extremely quickly over uneven terrain. But, while those robots may be impressive, that doesn‚Äôt mean they‚Äôre suited to every task. Many jobs require a more subtle approach. In the case of SlothBot, that job is environmental monitoring of jungle canopies. To do that job, a robot needs to be able to stay up in the treetops for months at a time. That requires energy efficiency, which is why the engineers from Georgia Tech turned to the humble sloth for inspiration. SlothBot is made up of two body sections that meet in a single articulated joint. The structure of the robot is 3D-printed, and houses the electronic components. Those include sensors for monitoring environmental conditions, solar panels to recharge the robot‚Äôs batteries when needed, and the motors and control components that allow it to move. SlothBot is designed to hang suspended from wires for long periods of time while consuming very little power. When necessary, it can slowly drive along those wires. The robot is even capable of moving from one wire to another intersecting wire, so it can navigate through the treetops. That makes SlothBot uniquely capable of monitoring conditions in the very same jungle canopies that sloths themselves inhabit. -- -- Author, writer, maker, and a former mechanical designer. www.cameroncoward.com @cameron_coward Help Status About Careers Press Blog Privacy Terms Text to speech Teams

Title: Scope of Artificial Intelligence
Subtitle: Written by BeSingular
Author: BeSingular
Article: Sign up Sign in Sign up Sign in BeSingular Follow -- Listen Share Every business big or small is going digital, there is no other way but to swim with the waves. Emerging technologies have brought about a sea change in the way businesses were conducted. The biggest achievement of the evolving technologies so far is the advent of intelligent machines on the world stage. Hence, in recent years demand for AI professionals has increased exponentially. However, current top tech talent lacks the skills required for the job. According to Indeed, demand for AI skills has increased manifold in the last three years and the job postings for the same is up by 119 per cent. This shows that there is an exponential demand for AI professionals in the job market. While the demand for this role is high there is a considerable shortage in the AI talent pool. As per statistics, the demand for AI jobs will keep increasing with the offset of newer technologies coming into play in the market sphere. Artificial Intelligence is the next big thing in the job market. It has a lot of scope for students who are pursuing a course in this field. Let‚Äôs look at the careers you can pursue if you are an AI expert. Machine Learning EngineerMachine learning is the most significant aspect of AI hence the role of Machine Learning Engineer is at the heart of AI projects. These engineers are in high demand and can command a lucrative pay scale. Their job is to mostly build and manage platforms for machine learning projects. An ML engineer should be proficient in Java and Python Programming languages. Data ScientistData Scientists job profile customarily consists of collecting, analysing, and interpreting large, complex datasets by leveraging both machine learning and predictive analytics. They are also responsible for developing algorithms that enable the collection and cleaning of data for analysis. Students looking at a career in data science need to understand and be at ease with big data platforms and tools like Hive, Hadoop, MapReduce, Pig and Spark. They should also have experience in programming languages like Perl, Python, Scala and SQL. Business Intelligence DeveloperWith the emergence of AI in the current work scenario, this role is growing rapidly and is quite in demand. This role demands an engineer to be able to analyse complex data sets to identify business and market trends. Experts in this field are responsible for designing, modelling and maintaining complex data in cloud-based data platforms. They play a pivotal role in improving the efficiency and profitability of a business. This role demands strong technical and analytical skills. Other than that they should know about data warehouse design, data mining, SQL queries, SQL Server Integration Services, SQL Server Reporting Services, and BI technologies. Research ScientistResearch Scientist is one of the most sought after career for an Artificial Intelligence expert. An individual seeking this role should be proficient in various AI disciplines, which include applied mathematics, machine learning, deep learning, and computational statistics. This role commands an extensive knowledge and experience in computer perception, graphical models, reinforcement learning, and natural language processing. Big Data Engineer/ArchitectOne of the best paying jobs in the computer engineering field, big data engineers and architects are indispensable when it comes to developing an ecosystem that enables business systems to communicate with each other and collate data. It is a more involved role as engineers or architects of this field are tasked with planning, designing, and developing the big data environment on Hadoop and Spark systems. This role also demands knowledge of programming languages like C++, Java, Python, and Scala. They should also have experience in data mining, data visualization, and data migration. Many top companies are on a lookout for AI experts; Amazon, Microsoft, Accenture, Facebook, Intel, Samsung, IBM, Uber, Adobe are the top recruiters of this field. If you are serious about a career in AI then it‚Äôs time to decide where to begin. Students should start by joining a small course in an institute that teaches emerging technologies like Artificial Intelligence, Augmented Reality, Virtual Reality, Machine Learning, Programming, Robotics, 3D Printing etc. About BeSingular: BeSingular is a learning platform to skill the next generation to create real and responsible impact working with the technology of the future. The innovative and well-researched curriculum imparts skill set based in exponential technologies which will benefit them in every aspect of their lives. The well-designed programs are age-appropriate and are made to engage the natural curiosity of a child. -- -- BeSingular is a learning platform that activates young minds to a future full of possibilities. Title: Spot Lyte On: Food, wine, commentary ‚Äî and more
Subtitle: Published in Lyte
Author: Maggie O'Brien
Article: Sign up Sign in Sign up Sign in Maggie O'Brien Follow Lyte -- Listen Share When people think of in-demand tickets, festivals and concerts often come to mind. And while helping more fans attend festivals and concerts is a huge part of what we do at Lyte, we‚Äôre also putting tickets to culinary experiences, speaking engagements, and other great unexpected live events back in the hands of rights holders and away from the secondary market. Check out all of our event listings here. How Lyte Works Lyte‚Äôs platform makes it safe and easy for fans to find tickets to sought-after live events simply by joining our waiting list. Meanwhile, fans who already have tickets but can‚Äôt go can return them on the Lyte exchange. New, valid tickets are issued by the primary ticketer for the next fan in line, who receives them for a fair price. Simple. There‚Äôs no risk of price gouging or fake tickets. It‚Äôs all part of our efforts to help rights holders regain control of the secondary market. Lyte and our partners (ticketers, venues, promoters, and artists) are working together to save fans money and protect them from . Visit lyte.com to learn more about our technology platform. The Latest Events to Hit the Lyte Exchange We‚Äôve got a handful of events to highlight that are happening now through March. Check them out ‚Äî and get on our waiting lists (links are highlighted). If you have tickets but can‚Äôt go, click on the same links to return them for a fair price. girl in red @ Sartain & Saunders, Nashville 9/20/19 Papas Beach Bash @ Rosarito Beach, Mexico 9/20/19 PYGMALION 2019 @ Krannert Center for the Performing Arts, Urbana 9/26/19 CRSSD Festival @ Waterfront Park, San Diego 9/28/19 An Evening With Al Franken @ Revolution Hall, Portland 10/2/19 Aldous Harding @ Larimer Lounge, Denver 10/19/19 mxmtoon ‚Äì the masquerade tour @ Larimer Lounge, Denver 10/23/19 Tropicalia Music & Taco Fest @ Pico Rivera Sports Arena, Long Beach 11/9/19 Courtney Bennett @ Levon Helm Studios, Woodstock 1/25/20 Wood & Grain Wine Lunch @ Charleston Wine + Food, Charleston 3/5/20 White Wines of Italy @ Charleston Wine + Food, Charleston 3/7/20 Sea Island Lunch at Wild Olive @ Charleston Wine + Food, Charleston 3/7/20 About Lyte Lyte makes it easier for fans to go to more live events. Founded in New York City and San Francisco by CEO Ant Taylor, our killer fan feature is returnability. In an industry where a ‚Äúno refunds and no cancellations‚Äù policy is the standard, Lyte enables fans to return their event tickets, no questions asked, to the official point of purchase. Lyte also provides a safe and official reservation booking system, offering fans who sign up a fair price for in-demand tickets. One hundred percent of the tickets bought and sold through Lyte are issued through our ticketing partners and delivered directly to fans. Lyte has delivered millions in fan savings ‚Äî $1.8 million in 2018 alone. It‚Äôs only getting better from here, thanks to our growing partnerships with bands, venues, promoters, ticketers and festivals. For the industry, we function as a full inventory management solution, including a private-label secondary market to optimize event yield for event producers. Visit lyte.com. -- -- Company blog for Lyte, a service to get or return tickets to sold out shows. Maggie is a writer for Lyte, a technology platform that puts the secondary market back in the hands of rightsholders and fans. Visit Lyte.com. Title: Surprising Stats on the Demand for Product Manager Roles in the US
Subtitle: Published in Agile Insider
Author: Neal Iyer
Article: Sign up Sign in Sign up Sign in Neal Iyer Follow Agile Insider -- 5 Listen Share I recently conducted a study on Product Management hiring in the US. We‚Äôve all heard hand-wavy statements about Product Management growing, so I was curious to know how much is it really growing and what‚Äôs actually responsible for the growth? I looked at publicly available data from Indeed and LinkedIn, using the Wayback Machine and Google Search to answer these questions. What I found out was interesting, as well as surprising. Product Management roles in the US have grown an astounding 32% over just a two year period, from August 2017 to June 2019. While a lot of conversation around Product Management seems to center around ‚ÄòBig Tech‚Äô firms, most of the growth in the demand has come from firms outside the traditional boundaries of ‚Äòtech.‚Äô The top three factors driving increase in demand for Product Management professionals over the last two years have been: A micro-trend that is small right now but could become significant in the future is the rise of PM roles for ‚ÄòAbuse‚Äô and ‚ÄòPrivacy‚Äô functions especially with products that attract a substantial amount of user-generated content. This unprecedented rate of growth has seen Product Management outpace the average rise in demand for other roles in the US by over five times. For example, the growth in demand for PMs has been substantially higher than that for Software Engineering roles. On an absolute scale though, Software Engineering roles outnumber Product Management roles by a large margin. As of September 2019, there were 14 Software Engineering roles being hired for every PM job. Interestingly though, only one UX designer was being hired for every two Product Managers. Dedicated UX designers for a product appear to still be a rarity. PMs at early-stage startups reported being expected to shoulder a substantial portion of UX responsibilities, while those at large companies reported sharing UX resources between products or having a centralized UX function across the business. My research also extended to looking at top US cities for PM roles. Contrary to popular expectation, the San Francisco Bay Area and New York are not the cities with the most growth in PM opportunities over the last two years. I also examined the number of hires made over the last two years for all PM positions, including entry-level Associate Product Manager roles, all the way to executive positions like Senior Vice Presidents of Product Management and Chief Product Officers. If you would like to know the top cities for PMs as well as hiring patterns and career paths, please let me know in the comments‚Äô section on this LinkedIn post and I‚Äôll message or email you the full 17-page report. Know somebody that could benefit from this information? Please feel free to share this article with them. -- -- 5 Exclusive and practical insights that enable the agile community to succeed. Summer Product Manager at Proofpoint | Product at Class Central | CMU | IIT Bombay Help Status About Careers Press Blog Privacy Terms Text to speech Teams

Title: Tricky Closure in JavaScript
Subtitle: Closures
Author: Nikhil karkra
Article: Sign up Sign in Sign up Sign in Nikhil karkra Follow Code To Express -- Listen Share Most confusing topic in Javascript is Closure. So let‚Äôs try to understand what it is. A closure is an inner function that has access to the outer enclosing function‚Äôs variables ‚Äî scope chain. The closure has three scope chains: - it has access to its own scope (variables defined between its curly brackets).- it has access to the outer function‚Äôs variables.- it has access to the global variables. Closure means that an inner function always has access to the vars and parameters of its outer function, even after the outer function has returned. Example ‚Äî getSum() is the outer function that has a variable num1 and return the calculate() inner function. Function Execution steps- As we know the inner function preserves the scope chain of the enclosing function at the time the enclosing function was executed, and thus can access the enclosing function‚Äôs variables. Reason for this strange behavior is that the time we executed the Outer function(createArrFunction) the last value of variable i was 5 which get persevered by the inner function.so it‚Äôs returning 5 instead of 0. a) Solution 1 ‚Äî use let instead of var in for loop we can solve this issue. let allows you to declare variables that are limited in scope to the block, statement, or expression on which it is used. This is unlike the var keyword, which defines a variable globally, or locally to an entire function regardless of block scope. b) solution 2 ‚Äî Use ‚ÄòImmediately Invoked Function Expression‚Äô (also known as an IIFE) An IIFE (Immediately Invoked Function Expression) is a JavaScript function that runs as soon as it is defined. I hope these step-by-step explanations helped you to understand the concept of closures in JavaScript! Title: How to Run a Quick Accessibility Audit
Subtitle: Written by Ben Robertson
Author: Ben Robertson
Article: Sign up Sign in Sign up Sign in Member-only story Ben Robertson Follow -- Share I‚Äôve said this before, but I remember learning very little about web accessibility when I was first entering the front end developer ranks. And then one day at work, somebody asked me to put together an accessibility audit for a client. The conversation was probably something like this: Cool agency office, circa 2016: Project manager: Hey Ben, can you put together an accessibility audit for the website we built a while back? Our client is asking for it. Me: What‚Äôs accessibility? Project manager: Not sure, but I think it has something to do with Section 508. Me: has no idea what that means Sure, I‚Äôll put something together. And so I started googling about web accessibility and consuming all the resources I could find. That‚Äôs really how I got into accessibility work. It was like I was suddenly introduced to a whole new layer of web development I had never encountered before, and I found it so interesting. And as I learned more, I realized that a large portion of the work I had done in my career up to that point was inaccessible in some fashion. Oops üò¨. -- -- I write about front end web development, accessibility, and remote work. ‚úçÔ∏è Writing at: https://ben.robertson.is. üõ† Working on: https://colorbliss.com Help Status About Careers Press Blog Privacy Terms Text to speech Teams
