Title: Museums and Technology: Moving Forward into the Digital World
Subtitle: Written by Lindsey Steward
Author: Lindsey Steward
Article: Sign up Sign in Sign up Sign in Lindsey Steward Follow -- 1 Listen Share Technology is continuing to be innovative, and museums do what they can to catch up with the latest to attract more visitors. Museum visitors have tons of access to technological items including but not limited to phones, computers, iPads, and laptops. There is also a number of technological advances that we don‚Äôt even realize we use on a regular basis such as radio frequency identification (RFID) found on E-Z Passes that help make commuting faster and non-humanoid robots. As our society makes technological advances, museum professionals need to educate themselves about what is out there for their own benefit and for the visitors they serve within their museums. Museums have varying budgets and spaces available to use on technology. To take advantage of the ever changing technology, we need to figure out what interactive technology should be add to the museum and used by the visitors. There are advantages and challenges museums need to consider when integrating technology and interactive media. In American Alliance of Museums‚Äô article ‚ÄúNew Directions in Interactive Media for Museums‚Äù it stated that The challenges of integrating interactive media into the museum experience are manifold. New technologies can engage but also potentially alienate museum visitors who have different cultural backgrounds and varying degrees of knowledge about the art form, history, and ideas involved. But at its best, interactive media that balances the creativity of right-brain thinking with the deductive logic of left-brain analysis can help with the intuitive discovery of unexpected connections and create newfound meaning. As museum professionals, we should consider the advantages and challenges of incorporating interactive media in our museums and figure out how the technology will benefit potential visitors. Technology literacy is important for museum professionals not only to help visitors engage with programs, exhibits, and what else our museums have to offer but it is important for promotions and other important administrative work to keep our museums running. The article ‚ÄúMuseums and AI: Could Robots Be Your New Coworkers?‚Äù gave a couple of reasons why it is important for museum professionals should understand the landscape of Artificial Intelligence: First, these corporate tools affect every patron of every museum, so ignorance of AI is poor business practice. Museum professionals can make exemplary exhibitions and labels, but without understanding the impact of AI systems on patrons accessing information, we could find ourselves with a dampened reach. Every moment, from the first awareness of the museum, to walking into the building, to likes on the patron‚Äôs Facebook post, is affected by AI. If we remain ignorant of technology, museums will not be able to remain relevant in a changing society. Museum professionals should take the time to learn about how to utilize the available technology, and when we have professional development programs we should take advantage of learning from these programs as we move forward in museums‚Äô futures. Professional development opportunities not only help museum professionals learn about recent innovations but museum professionals also utilize new innovations to participate in professional development opportunities. For instance, there are podcasts about museums and historic sites from the American Association for State and Local History (AASLH); they have recordings from past conference sessions and livestream current conference sessions. American Alliance of Museums has Museopunks, a podcast for the progressive museum. Each month, host Suse Anderson investigates the work and personalities in and around the museum sector. I will leave these questions up for discussion: How do you feel about the digital world in the museum? Are we too dependent on technology or are we not taking enough advantage of it? Resources: https://www.aam-us.org/2019/01/11/interactive-media-for-museums/ https://soundcloud.com/aaslh-podcasts https://www.aam-us.org/programs/about-museums/museopunks/ https://hhethmon.com/2018/08/31/3-reasons-your-museum-should-start-a-podcast/ https://www.aam-us.org/2018/12/26/museums-and-ai-could-robots-be-your-new-coworkers/ https://www.geniusstuff.com/blogs/10-everyday-technologies-you-dont-realize-you-use.htm -- -- 1 She is a museum education professional with seven years experience in the field. She has a Master of Arts in Public History from Central Connecticut State. Help Status About Careers Press Blog Privacy Terms Text to speech Teams

Title: Morpheus Labs and Waves Announce Partnership To Gear Up for Blockchain Adoption
Subtitle: Published in Morpheus Labs
Author: Morpheus Labs Team
Article: Sign up Sign in Sign up Sign in Morpheus Labs Team Follow Morpheus Labs -- Listen Share In the past year, a shift has taken place in the Blockchain space, where more and more companies are switching their focus from concept to creation. This shift is deemed crucial to uncover the credible projects that will pave the way for the global adoption of the innovative technology. Enterprises are actively working towards the adoption of new technologies for their existing business models however they face considerable challenges on the resources and the tedious process of digital transformation using blockchain and other technologies. Morpheus Labs is actively seeking partners that can accelerate and improve the wide range of services that they provide for enterprises seeking to adopt blockchain technology and Waves Platform is a natural choice due to their innovative approach, core competency technology and the common goal to simplify blockchain dApps development. The partnership involves working together to improve on all verticals, with the priority to integrate Waves core expertise and technology onto Morpheus Labs‚Äô Blockchain Platform-as-a-Service (BPaaS), and other areas such as public relations, branding, and marketing. Sasha Ivanov, CEO of Waves Platform, underlines that, ‚ÄúThe integration of Waves onto BPaaS will streamline the progress to gain access to Waves‚Äô technology into a convenient, user-friendly service, allowing students, developers and businesses to enhance and simplify dApp development without having to develop their own solutions from the ground up.‚Äù The partnership will be beneficial as it will expand the adoption of both Waves‚Äô and Morpheus Labs‚Äô services on a global scale, and pledge the commitment to enrich and build the community through various channels, as well as collaborate on business development and community-centric initiatives. Both parties will also look into organising of online/offline events such as AMAs, hackathons at the later part of the year. Chuang Pei-Han, CEO of Morpheus Labs, shared that, ‚ÄúIn this partnership, Morpheus Labs and Waves Platform will explore ways to enhance the technology to create a fuss-free and better user experience; adding value to enterprises around the world while gearing up for mass adoption. Integrating Waves‚Äô focus on dApp development with their wallet/payment features onto the Morpheus Labs platform not only creates value for our AppLibrary, but will also provide us with the opportunity to expand our presence within the European market.‚Äù Waves (https://wavesplatform.com) is an open source platform and decentralised environment for Web 3.0 applications, offering a wide range of purpose-designed tools for making the process of creating and running dApps easy and accessible. Launched in 2016 by Sasha Ivanov and a core development team, Waves has since released numerous successful blockchain-based solutions and has steadily developed into a rich and constantly-growing technological platform. Waves‚Äô technology is designed to address the needs of businesses and technology companies that want to leverage the properties of blockchain systems ‚Äî including their security, auditability, verifiability and the trustless execution of transactions and business logic. Waves Platform provides everything required to support the backend of Web 3.0 services. In 2017, Waves successfully launched its mainnet with LPoS, its decentralised exchange DEX and later the Waves-NG protocol. In 2018, the Waves development team delivered the first implementation of smart contracts. This was followed by the release of the RIDE programming language in 2019, a simple and powerful language for programming logic. All of this is complemented with a broad infrastructure: an IDE for sandbox development, tools, SDKs, libraries, frameworks and protocols for convenient and easy integrations. Title: Millennials And Their Ability To Usher Changes In The Real Estate Industry
Subtitle: Written by Leax Foundation - Leaxcoin (LEAX)
Author: Leax Foundation - Leaxcoin (LEAX)
Article: Sign up Sign in Sign up Sign in Leax Foundation - Leaxcoin (LEAX) Follow -- Listen Share Millennials are well known for their ability to alter the status quo and usher in change. In the job market, they‚Äôve demanded, and increasingly obtained, the option to work remotely from home or a nearby coffee shop and enjoy more flexible hours. Rather than settling in the suburbs, many of them have chosen to live in city environments. Unlike previous generations, Millennials love living in urban centers. And when it comes to buying a home, this generation is also redefining what home-ownership and luxury mean to them ‚Äî and what they‚Äôre willing to pay for. Many Millennials chose to rent while they were in their twenties instead of investing in starter homes. Now in their thirties, they can afford higher-priced options. Because Millennials comprise a significant percentage of high-end home buyers, real estate agents need to be aware of the selling points that appeal to them ‚Äî and how to market to them effectively. Here are a few of the luxury home features Millennial homebuyers desire: Smaller Footprints. Millennials are forgoing larger houses with a lot of square footage in favor of smaller luxury homes that make smart use of space and are filled with high-end amenities and furnishings. Some of the most in-demand features include open concept living areas with plush living rooms and showcase kitchens, spa-like bathrooms, and multi-use rooms. Millennials desire functional layouts for entertaining and the flexibility to alter spaces to fit their needs, such as a yoga studio that can also be easily converted into a bedroom for overnight guests. Their preferred lifestyle and personal interests inform what they most want in a home. Smart Homes. Constant connectedness, both personally and professionally, has become the norm for Millennials. Fast internet access for telecommuters who work from home is a must. Another characteristic of Millennial daily life? Embracing the Internet of Things (IoT) to create a smart home filled with connected devices. This can include items like smart appliances, smart speakers, networked whole-house audio systems, smart thermostats to automatically adjust the temperature, voice-controlled lighting, and monitoring systems so homeowners can keep an eye on their dwelling whenever they‚Äôre away. If you‚Äôre selling a home with smart features, make sure potential buyers are aware of all its bells and whistles. If possible, have the homeowner set up a tablet with instructions so visiting guests can experience hands-on demonstrations. Green, Energy Efficient Homes. Millennials care about preserving the environment ‚Äî and simultaneously saving money doesn‚Äôt hurt, either. Energy-efficient and green homes are very desirable to this generation of homebuyers. These earth-friendly features can include items like solar power, indoor air purification systems, geothermal energy systems, and tankless water heaters. Because these types of apparatus are usually hidden behind walls or other barriers, they can be easy to overlook during a home tour. Highlight any green or energy-efficient assets in your marketing materials and be sure to do the same thing in the house itself. Print flyers or cards outlining green or energy-efficient features and position them where potential home buyers will see them, on a central table or even temporarily mounted on walls. Don‚Äôt forget to point out and educate prospective buyers on the tax benefits and ROI of these features. Location and Walkability. As Millennials flock to urban areas, walkability and proximity to public transportation are highly sought-after attributes. Many Millennials are interested in living in neighborhoods where they can mingle with like-minded individuals and have the option to stroll (often with their families or dogs) to local amenities. For longer treks, they may also prefer to commute via public transportation or use rideshare services. Some Millennials are eschewing car ownership completely in favor of using these modes of travel. Being able to navigate an area by foot or via public transportation is also desirable for out-of-town guests ‚Äî or renters. If a Millennial buyer is considering the possibility of renting out their home or listing it online to help finance their mortgage or generate extra income, walkability and convenient transportation options will help boost its popularity. Also, you may encounter urban-based Millennials who don‚Äôt want to buy a primary residence in the city; instead they‚Äôre choosing to rent there and purchase a vacation home elsewhere. No matter whether a luxury home is located in an urban center or a vacation hotspot, real estate agents should always be aware of the importance of walkability and easy access to transportation when it comes to Millennial buyers. Indoor/Outdoor Living Spaces for Wellness and Entertaining. Millennials want the option to stretch their living areas beyond the walls of their homes to include outdoor spaces. This is particularly true for those who live in cities, where green space is at a premium. Balconies, decks, or rooftop gardens are all excellent spots to take advantage of fresh air and offer additional places for entertaining, relaxing, and practicing mindfulness. High-end condo developers have started adding lush outdoor amenities meant to encourage wellness. There is no doubt that Millennials are having a profound effect on the world of luxury real estate. As they continue to purchase high-end homes, savvy real estate agents who take note of their unique buying behaviors and lifestyle preferences will be well-positioned to support them in their home buying endeavors. Agents who can become trusted collaborators will reap the benefits of assisting this increasingly affluent demographic, both now and in the future. -- -- www.leax.io Help Status About Careers Press Blog Privacy Terms Text to speech Teams

Title: Nature over nurture: How our brains are wired to react to a different world
Subtitle: Darwinism 2.0
Author: Alessandro Penno
Article: Sign up Sign in Sign up Sign in Alessandro Penno Follow The Startup -- 3 Listen Share Across many studies of mammals, from the smallest of rodents all the way to apex of humanity, exists a common understanding. Mainly, that intelligent life is wired to connect and communicate. Pat yourself on the back. Your unique existence on this Earth is the trickle down product of innumerable generations of behavioral engineering and social development. From early Sumerians evolving their primitive grunts into unique and complex languages to medieval societies inscribing their knowledge into tomes and stories, the progress of humanity can largely be interpreted as a social feat. Yet, it isn‚Äôt surprising to discover that other complex organisms, primarily but not limited to mammals, have also perpetuated generations of existence through the development of their own social mechanisms. From Dr. Alexander‚Äôs ‚ÄòRat Park‚Äô exploring how rats within social communities are better equipped to tackle opiate addictions to Cynthia Moss‚Äôs study of the elephant matriarch Echo and his parades‚Äô capacity for future planning and teamwork, the animal kingdom has by and large shown that it too has the capacity to develop unique evolutionary advantages through social development. All this speaks to the wider point about complex life gradually wiring itself to seek connection and communication, not just for the pleasure of conversation but in a more dire sense, for survival. This line of thinking enters a space known as evolutionary psychology or modern Darwinism. The discipline argues that although human beings today inhabit a thoroughly modern world filled with revolutionary innovations and technologies, they do so with the ingrained mentality of Stone Age hunter-gatherers. Recent DNA analyses have strongly suggested that the closest evidence to the modern human sprung from a small population (1,500 or so individuals) on the west coast of Africa about 60,000 years ago. Theoretically that group rapidly expanded to the Middle East and Far East, Europe and Southeast Asia, replacing or absorbing the Stone-Age Neanderthal populations of the time. Modern humans have proved to be sophisticated generalists, adapting through technology and culture to environments as varied as the Kalahari deserts, the Pacific Islands, and the icescapes of the north polar regions. In other words, these Homo sapiens that emerged on the African Savannah Plain thousands of years ago are seen to have developed and passed on traits that made their survival possible such as our instinct to fight furiously when threatened or our propensity to drive trade and share secrets. It‚Äôs important to note that I am not trying to overemphasize the nature over nurture side of evolutionary debate. As fellow Medium writer John Griswold reminded me, identifying ‚Äúhardwired‚Äù human behaviors is tricky and while there is extensive evidence about our prenatal ability to learn and use language for pair-bonding and community building, there are widespread cultural exceptions. Now consider your capacity for emotions like social anxiety and self-comparison, feelings that can often leave you hesitant and on edge. These emotional responses you experienced aren‚Äôt modern day flukes designed to make you feel bad but rather a hardwired Darwinian nudge to what your brain interprets as a ‚Äòred flag‚Äô environment. Remember that ill-feeling you got when you had to go to that party filled with people you didn‚Äôt know? That can basically be surmised as your inner caveman sensing a threat in the unknown. As the Harvard Business Review eloquently puts it ‚ÄúYou can take the person out of the Stone Age, but you can‚Äôt take the Stone Age out of the person‚Äù. Harvard professor and psychologist Steven Pinker once claimed ‚Äúthinking is computation but that does not mean the computer is a good metaphor for the mind‚Äù. Pinker‚Äôs assertion invites us to consider the extent to which our mind truly functions as a pre-programmed entity. I recommend readers interested in the ‚Äòsoftware‚Äô side of the debate do some further reading on the Dichotomized Operating System Model (DOS Model), a theory which attempts to demonstrate how the entire brain may function as one integrated system with the purpose to help us make decisions on an ongoing basis to reach our goals. For now, I‚Äôll summarize the main process the theory supposes. According to the DOS Model, the evolutionary process has divided our brain into two sections, each dealing with information in a particular way. One section is used for logical information processes and the other section for storage and retrieval of experiences. Dialogues within and between these two components are the birthplace of our verbal and non-verbal thoughts and communication. Such dialogues help us make decisions for our current and future experiences like that particular decision we discussed earlier about going to that party with people you don‚Äôt know. Through the dichotomy of these components, the model explains mechanisms and processes underlying fundamental mind phenomena under a single framework, making it a comprehensive albeit simplified account of the inner workings of the human mind. Consider how feelings of anxiety can vary from person to person, with some people experiencing it more than others. Using this theory as a thought framework, we can see one side acting as the particular processor or ‚Äòprogram‚Äô for anxiety, while the other side can be seen as the storage or ‚Äòinput‚Äô necessary for program to execute its original function. Most of us will experience forms of anxiety but the potency largely depends on our experiences or past traumas for which the processing side communicates with as its input. It‚Äôs the reason why depression and other social disorders have been historically misdiagnosed ‚Äî we failed to see the mind as a mechanism that can break rather than an irregularity we can quickly fix back into standard function. Although Pinker warns of using this comparison, comparing the brain to a computer is an increasingly tempting way to break down the mystery of the mind and its functionality. I can‚Äôt help but wonder how this will apply to the neural interfaces of the future. The simplicity of frameworks like the DOS model are important because they help us better understand the evolutionary logic that defines ourselves, our actions and our interpretation of the world around us. So far, we have discussed how the brain via natural selection has evolved both behaviorally and systematically to empower humans to fear, prevent and process threats in their surroundings. We also discussed earlier, how the brain of our hunter gatherer ancestors, through an immense amount of time, has wired itself to process information and experiences in a particular way for survival. However, it‚Äôs also important to be mindful that these reactions aren‚Äôt just limited to a handful but to a myriad of unique feelings and situations. By being more mindful about your thoughts, you can begin to identify why you feel a certain way. For instance, the reason we harbor negative feelings from social isolation can largely be interpreted as a defense mechanism our caveman ancestors developed at the early stages of human social development. Without the protection of the collective, separation from the tribe or village of the past most likely translated into imminent death by predation or starvation. Similarly, without our compulsive need to compare ourselves to one another, humans wouldn‚Äôt feel compelled to compete, work hard, and strive for the success of themselves and their families. It‚Äôs good psychology nowadays for one to avoid comparing herself to her peers yet with science we can interpret this inherent need to do so as another of the many survival mechanisms hardwired into our minds. These reactions might not always help us but its important to understand their inherent purpose through evolutionary design. Next time you feel anxious, take a step back and rationalize the emotion within the wider space it inhabits. Which are the conditions that can be interpreted as evolutionary threats? You might find this approach helpful in calming your nerves before your next big date or job interview. As the evidence in this blog post suggests, the brain we have today hasn‚Äôt changed much in the last 10,000 years. Moreover, up until the industrial revolution, human civilization trotted somewhat consistently down a developmental path. However, its difficult to dispute that in in just 200 years, humans have achieved more progress than ever previously imagined. Today, disease and predation have by and far been eliminated from the modern environment. Once small villages are now large bustling metropolises accompanied by a globalized transportation network that can traverse previously unsurpassable oceans and mountain ranges. Moreover, our ability to communicate with one another is no longer reserved to the physical realm with interconnected devices shuttling digital information to the heavens and back. We dream of multi-planetary space travel and strive for the ultimate wedding between mind and machine. Pat yourself again on the back, this time for your ancestors that paved the way through research, innovation and implementation. Large swathes of people no longer need to worry about the unknown because the unknown has largely been illuminated and conquered. You would think that with all this progress comes a utopic sense of emotional relief for our historically wired brain, yet the statistics tell an increasingly different story. People today are more anxious, lonely, and depressed than in any other generation. Previous generations fought global wars, deadly diseases, and the looming risk of famine. Today, the struggles of the modern world are largely defined as social issues and still we suffer. As we venture into the world of ever-more technological advancement, we must not forget the bindings of our past. I fear our brains will be geared for a race they are not prepared to compete in ‚Äî a techno-evolutionary treadmill that is simply too fast for the slow and naturally selective processes that have formed our brains thus far. As more abnormal, godlike technology descends upon us, we must ask ourselves how obsolete are we prepared to make the subconscious mind? Yet, this is a topic for another day. Alessandro is an aspiring product & UX designer with a passion for tech and gaming. Subscribe for more coverage on his latest insights and curiosities. ‚ÄúThinking is computation, I claim, but that does not mean that the computer is a good metaphor for the mind. The mind is a set of modules, but the modules are not encapsulated boxes or circumscribed swatches on the surface of the brain. The organization of our mental modules comes from our genetic program, but that does not mean that there is a gene for every trait or that learning is less important than we used to think. The mind is an adaptation designed by natural selection, but that does not mean that everything we think, feel, and do is biologically adaptive. We evolved from apes, but that does not mean we have the same minds as apes. And the ultimate goal of natural selection is to propagate genes, but that does not mean that the ultimate goal of people is to propagate genes.‚Äù‚Äï Steven Pinker, How the Mind Works -- -- 3 Get smarter at building your thing. Title: T√§ysin automatisoitu pakofantasia
Subtitle: Written by Ilja Lehtinen
Author: Ilja Lehtinen

Title: Genaro Network (GNX) Bi-Weekly Tech Report
Subtitle: Published in Smart Data Ecosystem by Genaro Network
Author: Genaro Network (GNX)
Article: Sign up Sign in Sign up Sign in Genaro Network (GNX) Follow Smart Data Ecosystem by Genaro Network -- Listen Share Public chain layer ‚Ä¢ Quickly redeem GNX project. Quickly acquire the GNX in a one-stop manner, so that the swap account can be automatically generated to prevent malicious attacks; ‚Ä¢ Fabric project research. The fabric alliance chain is connected via cross-chain technology with the Genaro public chain; ‚Ä¢ Quorum project research. The quorum alliance chain is connected via cross-chain technology with the Genaro public chain; ‚Ä¢ The main chain operation and daily basis maintenance. Maintain the operation of the public chain, updated the relevant mirror code, and ensured the stable functioning. Storage layer ‚Ä¢ Genaro breakpoint design and research on implementation methods; ‚Ä¢ Updated the libgenaro2.0 fast upload interface. The client retrieves the same hashed file from the server before calling storeFile. If it exists, there is no need to call storeFile. ‚Ä¢ Updated the libgenaro2.0 quick download interface to update whether the file is encrypted or not. If there is no encryption, no decryption is required. ‚Ä¢ The libgenaro2.0 design adds multi-threaded transfers for each shard of files: a. The shard strategy remains the same. b. Add a strategy for blocking the same shard. Created a thread for each block to transmit (if you download it, set it by setting the Range field of the HTTP request header and upload it). c. Since multiple Shards are transmitted in parallel, if multiple parallel transmissions of Blocks are added, the number of threads will be large, so the maximum number of modified parallel download Shards is 10 (it was 24). Version 1.0 does not limit the maximum number of uploaded Shards, consider adding restrictions. ‚Ä¢ Researched Genaro network disk technology, mainly to study how to achieve the linkage between the web page version, file upload and download and other functions. X-pool mining section ‚Ä¢ The mine pool menu page is modified, the style is changed, and it is unified with the browser and official website; ‚Ä¢ Added super administrator function, could watch and operate, audit deposit, audit mining, audit cash withdrawal, audit end mining, audit cash withdrawal and other related functions; ‚Ä¢ Modified the miner‚Äôs block list api and the front page. It is possible to authorize calls and calls are flexible. Breaking News: The first edition of the GSIOP protocol is officially released On February 20, 2019, Singapore time, Genaro Network, the world‚Äôs first smart data ecosystem with a Dual-Strata Architecture, integrating a public blockchain with decentralized storage officially released the first version of the GSIOP protocol. This is not only the product of nearly a year hard work of the Genaro entire team of engineers, but it also marks Genaro‚Äôs new milestone in the practical application of cross-chain technology. Breaking News: G.A.O. (Genaro Alpha One) is officially launched Genaro Network, the future of Smart Data Ecosystem for DApps, invites you to witness the new era of smart data, empowered by the revolutionary serverless interactive system! Recommended reading: Genaro public network mainnet officially launched | Community Guide Download Technical Yellow Paper Genaro‚Äôs latest versions, Genaro Eden and Genaro Eden Sharer, will allow you to store your files in a more secure way and share your unused storage to earn GNX. Get your Genaro Eden/Sharer for Linux, Windows and MAC OS right now from the official website: Git source repository is on GitHub>> Important: Warm reminder to our community members, please download Genaro Eden ONLY from our official website/GitHub and DO NOT trust any referral links and reposts from anyone, otherwise, we won‚Äôt be able to guarantee privacy and security of your data and protect you from scammers. Genaro Eden ‚Äî The first decentralized application on the Genaro Network, providing everyone with a trustworthy Internet and a sharing community: Related Publications: Genaro‚Äôs Core Product Concept Genaro Eden: Five Core Features How Does Genaro‚Äôs Technology Stand Out? Genaro Eden Application Scenarios and User Experience The Genaro Ecosystem Matthew Roszak Comments on Release of Genaro Eden About Genaro Network The Genaro Network is the first smart data ecosystem with a Dual-Strata Architecture, integrating a public blockchain with decentralized storage. Genaro pioneered the combination of SPoR (Sentinel Proof of Retrievability) with PoS (Proof of Stake) to form a new consensus mechanism, ensuring stronger performance, better security and a more sustainable blockchain infrastructure. Genaro provides developers with a one-stop platform to deploy smart contracts and store the data needed by DAPPs simultaneously. Genaro Network‚Äôs mission is to ensure the secure migration of the core Internet infrastructure to the blockchain. Title: Top 3 Trends disrupting recruitment industry!
Subtitle: Written by Siddhi Thakkar
Author: Siddhi Thakkar
Article: Sign up Sign in Sign up Sign in Siddhi Thakkar Follow -- Listen Share The talent acquisition industry has never been shy about embracing innovation. The internet arrived and soon after, online job search portals were all over the place; LinkedIn launched in 2003 and is now lookup guide of every recruiter. Continuing the trend, here are the top 3 technology advancements recruitment industry is looking up to: 1) Big Data ‚Äî It can help to predict hiring needs of companies in real-time. A specific branch of it called People Analytics can further help a recruiter to analyse the data of great talent already existing in the company in order to predict the skills needed to succeed in a specific role. This approach is ought to be much better than the hard skills focused job descriptions we have today. 2) Contextual search- It refers to searching and analysing what the candidate is looking for ‚Äî much beyond what they type. A great opportunity is often missed since search function of the tools we use today rely solely on limited boolean criterias. New age tools like Textkernel and Spotle are much more smarter in understanding what the candidate wants to convey. 3) Gamification- It is the process of adding game mechanics to non-gaming contexts. By integrating gamification in common interview processes, a recruiter has the opportunity to introduce fun games and interactive quizzes. This approach has the potential of making the screening mechanism more conversational, entertaining and meaningful. Originally published at https://siddhithakkar.com on October 4, 2019. -- -- www.siddhithakkar.com Help Status About Careers Press Blog Privacy Terms Text to speech Teams

Title: How to Manage Someone Who Used to Be Your Peer
Subtitle: Forge
Author: Jessica Powell
Article: Sign up Sign in Sign up Sign in Home Newsletter About  A former publication from Medium on personal development. Currently inactive and not taking‚Ä¶  Member-only story Jessica Powell Follow Forge -- 3 Share Jessica Powell, the former Google vice president who wrote The Big Disruption and told you how to quit your job, is here to answer your common but tricky work questions. Check back every other week for more management advice with a tech inflection. I just started managing someone who used to be my peer and it‚Äôs awkward. I‚Äôm trying to act like everything‚Äôs normal, but I think they resent that I‚Äôm now their manager. What should I do? Congrats on your promotion! That secret sense of superiority you‚Äôve long harbored has now been validated by your company! Now you get to spend your days hiding in a big office and never interacting with anyone! Joking aside, I get it. This is awkward, particularly if you were friends with your former peer. But in my experience, the biggest mistake newly minted managers make is trying to pretend that nothing has changed. As a manager, I have screwed this up a number of times. One time I was so worried about my former peer‚Äôs reaction to my new boss-dom that, in our first meeting, I told her she was so good at her job that I was going to spend less time with her than my other‚Ä¶ -- -- 3 A former publication from Medium on personal development. Currently inactive and not taking submissions. Technophile, technophobe. Music software start-up founder. Former Google VP. Author, The Big Disruption. Fan of shochu, chocolate, and the absurd. Title: Why Push-back Against the Gillette Ad Also Comes From Troll Farms
Subtitle: Mark Greene makes the case for why online male rage is intentionally manufactured.
Author: Mark Greene
Article: Sign up Sign in Sign up Sign in Mark Greene Follow -- 8 Listen Share Some percentage of the ‚Äúmen‚Äôs voices‚Äù attacking the #GilletteAd is the work of troll farms, driving divisions. Many of the accounts I have seen attacking the ad on Twitter over the last few days have 30 followers and no histories. A friend of mine, Natasha Stromberg of GenderBuzz tweeted this: ‚ÄúBe aware of trolls around the #GiletteAd. Just talk to the wonderful men in your own lives and trust that they ARE the change. Positive change IS happening for men & for women, & fortunately there are more of us who support it than don‚Äôt.‚Äù https://twitter.com/genderbuzz/status/1085540915186409474 This tweet from Natasha is the central thrust of my article, so you can stop here if you like. We already know about Russian troll farms attacking the 2016 and 2018 U.S. elections, Brexit and the French elections and so on, driving targeted messages of bias and anger at millions of accounts in the US and overseas. These operations don‚Äôt stop just because there is no pending election. Why wouldn‚Äôt they seek to shore up political divisions around volatile public debates like those with the Gillette ad? And manhood is a particularly volatile space for sewing divisions. Those of us working in the manhood space have already come to understand that radicalized masculinity dialogues are a gateway into white nationalist recruitment and so on. All which serves to create political instability. And if you remain skeptical that foreign troll farms are working full time to tip the scale of our political and social landscape, how about this article at Slate? From the article:Forget the 2016 presidential election, Russia may have interfered in something far more serious: the discourse surrounding The Last Jedi, the Star Wars movie directed by Rian Johnson. A new study by researcher Morten Bay examines online discussion of the film and finds that on Twitter, the discourse was affected by ‚Äúdeliberate, organized political influence measures disguised as fan arguments,‚Äù including by possible Russian trolls. In ‚ÄúWeaponizing the Haters: The Last Jedi and the strategic politicization of pop culture through social media manipulation,‚Äù Bay collected and analyzed tweets that directly addressed Johnson and were sent over a period of eight months, beginning with the day of the movie‚Äôs European release. Bay found that just 21.9 percent of the 967 tweets he examined were negative, suggesting that the movie may not be nearly as divisive as the backlash made it seem. More disturbingly, Bay also found that of that more than half of the negative tweets may have come from ‚Äúbots, trolls/sock puppets or political activists using the debate to propagate political messages supporting extreme right-wing causes and the discrimination of gender, race or sexuality.‚Äù Until we wake up and realize how deeply into our social fabric these foreign and domestic political agents are drilling down, they will continue to use social media to poison our perception of our politics, our culture and each other. My background in dealing with volatile online dialogues goes way back. I have been writing about fatherhood and manhood for the Good Men Project for a decade. The Good Men Project remains one of the leading voices in the conversation about manhood. Millions of men and women are there every month, having ‚Äúthe conversation no one else is having.‚Äù When I first starting writing there, the conversation now one else was having often got very binary and very, very nasty. As early members of the GMP writers community, we spent our days in the binary crossfire of the gender wars, responding to the comments of angry people, men and women alike. Many of us carry a form of PTSD, having been accused, attacked, and threatened by the most aggressive voices the net has to offer for years on end. To this day, whenever I see a new comment on my posts, I reflexively steel myself for a possible onslaught. Writers for the GMP, especially women, often got burned out, drawing back from the public conversation about masculinity, because they could no longer take anonymous online abuse that often included threats of rape and assault against them or their families. Fast forward to now. Things remain volatile. I am not without my own sins and my own expressions of frustration and anger. But while my expressions of rage have typically been spontaneous outbursts, generated in the back and forth heat of the moment, there is something new going on these days. Something much more calculated and manufactured. As of the last couple of years, the GMP no longer allows open commenting. If you want to join the conversation, you have to become a member. You have to be an identified participant in the conversation. And‚Ä¶ eureka, the nasty, abusive, threatening voices are gone. As if they never existed. When I asked GMP publisher Lisa Hickey about the choice to end open commenting, she told me something interesting. She said that she no longer wanted to provide a platform where white supremacists could come and recruit. ‚ÄúThey look for angry male voices in comment threads and then white nationalists reach out and say, ‚Äòyes, you should be angry and here‚Äôs some other things you should be angry about,‚Äô‚Äù she said. For me, this casts a new light on the angriest voices commenting on my own articles. When they call me a cuck, a traitor, a liberal pussy and what not, I raise my eyebrows, aware now that they either may be at risk for being recruited, or, depending on how the comments are worded, they may be baiting a hook for others. Sometimes, I‚Äôm not sure what‚Äôs going on when someone is melting down online, but other times it is quite clear. This comment I am about to share with you, which arrived as a result of an article I wrote about mansplaining? This right here? This is boilerplate white racist recruitment. I‚Äôm posting this person‚Äôs comments as a jpeg so it won‚Äôt come up in text searches. I will restrict myself to my comments here, not posting any pull quotes. But I am going to share this person‚Äôs words in this limited way. I think it is important for us to deconstruct how calculated performances of anger (right down to all caps) are used as a recruitment tool everywhere from our social media streams to our U. S. Senate hearings. Here is the post. I would like to make a few observations about this post. The author doesn‚Äôt acknowledge the theme of my article at all. It‚Äôs likely they didn‚Äôt read it. What they do is use what seems to me to be a boilerplate, angry, emotional message to deliver in a very calculated way, themes of white nationalism. What we have here is a calculated performance of rage, designed to create the impression of a deeply personal emotional response while delivering talking points that are coldly calculated. This use of emotion to invite assimilation of political ideology is nothing new. We‚Äôve seen it before. Always in totalitarian states. Always from tyrants. Here‚Äôs the screen grab of my commenter‚Äôs profile on Medium. They have zero followers and are following no one. They had only two comments, one directed at me. Perhaps they came and started a new account just for little old me? This commenter is clearly advocating for the very issues which drove the the approval of Brexit, and current anti immigrant feeling in the US, thus improving the likelihood that this voice could be associated with a foreign power who is seeking to destabilize western nations by stoking racist sentiments. I have blocked this person from my Medium account. According to Medium ‚ÄúIf you block the author of a response, it will not be linked from anywhere on your post, for anyone.‚Äù Twitter says, ‚ÄúTweets from blocked accounts will not appear in your timeline.‚Äù More importantly, when we block angry voices, we insure we won‚Äôt be tempted to respond, spreading them into our stream. Facebook has plenty of tools for managing rageful voices. Hide is one of my favorites, block is even better. The performance of male rage around issues of masculinity, gender and equality is tied to racist recruitment across social media. Racists are casting a net for those who might be susceptible to recruitment into white nationalism, their vulnerability fostered by uncertainty, anger and fear. Along with the press and the larger media, we all have to be very mindful when rage and anger are being used in calculated ways to suppress more civil discourses or to co-opt the news cycle. We have to understand how abuse online is used to exhaust and deplete us. To get us to say, ‚Äúoh the hell with it, I don‚Äôt want to challenge this stuff any more.‚Äù Meanwhile, the next time you‚Äôre tempted to engage a troll on the internet, ask yourself, am I talking to a white nationalist recruiter? Am I talking to someone on a troll farm seeking to grow divisions between us? We have to use our judgement in terms of who we engage and who be block. I spend a lot of time engaging on the net in an attempt to create a better conversation about manhood, but when someone comes at me with no interest in dialogue, clearly just performing rage and anger? I think block is the gold standard for those folks. Don‚Äôt feed the trolls is actually don‚Äôt feed the white nationalists. Don‚Äôt feed the troll farms. Because every raging voice we respond to is extended by our social network, giving them an opportunity for recruitment or to stoke more division. I take this position not because I‚Äôm obsessed with some conspiracy theory about trolls. I actually take it as a frame by which I to encourage us to not think ill of our fellow human beings. When someone posts something particularly cruel or nasty about something as seemingly hopeful as the Gillette Ad, and then I visualize a living breathing person who could be living a few blocks from me, it is deeply alarming. ‚ÄúWhat is WRONG with people?‚Äù I might ask. But when I visualize some operative at a troll farm working off a spread sheet of approved comments for the issue of the day, I feel much better. ‚ÄúSome of the online rage is just manufactured. It‚Äôs not a real human being. It‚Äôs fake.‚Äù In this way we can resource ourselves and grow our sense that our fellow human beings are on the right side of history. So, fake news? How about this. Fake rage. -- -- 8 Working toward a culture of healthy masculinity. Links to our books, podcasts, Youtube and more: http://linktr.ee/RemakingManhood. Title: Make Augmented Reality Talk !
Subtitle: Is a voice user interface a good fit in industrial augmented reality ?
Author: Deepak George
Article: Sign up Sign in Sign up Sign in Deepak George Follow -- Listen Share Since my younger days, I have been greatly intrigued with acoustics. This fascination has led me to pursue music, experiment with Chaldni plates and work on developing pro audio and acoustic noise cancellation systems as a hobby in my undergraduate years. At Siemens, my current organization, we work on developing cutting edge digitalization solutions for industry. Our teams develop predictive and prescriptive analytic solutions for the plant floor while also integrating it with state-of-the-art technologies such as Augmented and Virtual reality. Indeed, the ‚ÄúSound‚Äù bug bites me again! What better application than Industrial Augmented reality to implement voice user interfaces?. As a product owner though, it is a part of my job to ensure that such decisions are not taken on gut feeling but rather, a clear analytical approach that is data driven. So, is a voice user interface really the next big thing on the plant floor? Let‚Äôs read on to find out! Augmented reality has existed for the past 30 years or so, taking off in the late eighties, but, Industrial Augmented reality has always been a path which was tread upon cautiously. The hardware has traditionally been fragile, bulky and cumbersome and was poorly suited to a plant floor routinely exposed to harsh environmental conditions. The latest generation AR devices are compact and well suited for industrial applications. There are several manufacturers whose AR offerings include IP 66 rated as well as intrinsically safe AR devices for hazardous environments. In terms of convenience, Augmented reality hardware has sure come a long way. From this study by PTC, the developers of the Vuforia augmented reality platform, it is seen that the major attractions to the industrial customer are applications that involve augmented operator assistance in carrying out complex procedures such as equipment servicing, maintenance and assembly or disassembly. For an industrial environment, and applications listed above, lets apply classic design thinking principles to evaluate whether a voice user interface would be the right fit here. But before that, lets briefly talk about interacting with Augmented reality. ‚ÄúHuman-computer interaction‚Äù is the field that focuses on the interaction between humans (the target user) and the computer. Much of the research in ‚ÄúHuman-computer interaction‚Äù deals with improving the usability of computer interfaces. We see how this evolved from interaction methods such as Punched cards in the earlier days to keyboards and mice, to touch based systems that are all the rage now. Similarly, there also exists interaction methods such as voice user interfaces and gesture control which is often also referred to as a touch-less user interface. In this excellent study by PwC, they quote that the dominant interaction methods for Augmented reality and Virtual reality are yet to be established. As we are now briefly acquainted with human-computer interaction methods, lets dive straight away into our analysis without further ado. For this, I started with interviewing maintenance technicians at my previous organization, Jindal Power limited which is a record setting thermal power plant with 3400-Megawatt total power generation capacity. As the inputs received from each of them were essentially the same, I have consolidated these inputs to create a persona of the target user for our AR solution. Here is what it looks like below. ‚ÄúPeople don‚Äôt want quarter-inch drill bits. They want quarter-inch holes‚Äù ‚Äî Leo McGinneva. Putting it another way, People don‚Äôt just buy stuff. They buy what stuff does for them. With this in mind, and the persona template compiled earlier, lets list down the jobs to be done. We can do this using a simple sentence structure that reads, ‚ÄúWhen/While _________I want________So that I can_______. 1) ‚ÄúWhile I am servicing field equipment in a physically tough location, I want a hands-free method of referring to service manuals So that I can continue working on the equipment without having to come down to a more conducive environment or lay my tools down‚Äù. 2) ‚ÄúWhen I am performing an equipment start up procedure, I want to have guided step by step instructions in a hands-free environment So that I can perform the procedure quickly with minimized chance of errors‚Äù. 3) ‚ÄúWhen I am performing instrument calibration online, I want to be able to see the readings at the control room on my device So that I don‚Äôt have to contact the operator at the control room to tally the field readings with him‚Äù. The third step towards finalizing the best mode of interaction with the AR device in an Industrial environment would be to chalk out our value proposition. This is also known as the ad-lib elevator pitch format and goes like this ‚ÄúOur____Helps____Who want to_____by____and_____unlike______‚Äù As we are not clear yet, which interface method would be the best fit in an Industrial AR solution, I will modify this statement to read as follows:- ‚ÄúOur AR interface method Should help maintenance technicians Who want to easily interact with the AR device by using a hands-free method of interaction and increase their convenience unlike existing interface methods‚Äù. As all data is compiled now, decision making should be a piece of cake. As ‚ÄúHands-free‚Äù is a recurring requirement, lets eliminate touch-based interfaces for now. We are now left with two modes of interaction, touch-less user interface also called gesture control and voice user interface. Lets quickly weigh the pros and cons of each against each other. From a user‚Äôs perspective, a voice user interface seems a good fit for industrial augmented reality applications such as these. The advanced reader will immediately note that this was a very basic assessment and several functional and non-functional requirements like security, scalability, extensibility, etc. were left out in this comparison. I leave it to the reader to take this article as a starting point while deciding on the best user interface for industrial augmented reality. The best solution could very well be a combination of two-three different types of user interfaces. For example, a voice user interface combined with a touch-based interface. I would love to hear about your journey with industrial AR. Drop your thoughts in the comment box below. Also do visit us during one of our many demos and conferences across the globe to find out more üòä. -- -- Passionate about all things Tech ! | Product Owner at Siemens Help Status About Careers Press Blog Privacy Terms Text to speech Teams

Title: Three Forces Set To Change Marketing
Subtitle: Published in Signal or Noise
Author: Bradley Elliott
Article: Sign up Sign in Sign up Sign in Bradley Elliott Follow Signal or Noise -- Listen Share Yes, this is a piece about predictions. If you think this is just a ploy to get your attention, please give me a minute. I‚Äôm hoping this piece will be a little different from the other predictions you‚Äôve read recently. Today humans live in a hyper-connected matrix that is always on, regardless of what device they use. Technology drives human advancement, and the rapid pace of change is blurring the lines between the ‚Äúdigital‚Äù and the physical world. Every facet of our lives has some form of technological foundation that is becoming smarter and/or more powerful. In business terms, this change is called ‚Äòdigital transformation‚Äô. Essentially it is a foundational transformation that is disrupting the way business, society and economies interact. The biggest change is that digital transformation puts customers at the epicentre of business. Today consumers enjoy more power and influence than they‚Äôve ever had before. At this transformative time, research shows that humans are becoming a lot less trusting. The 2019 Edelman Trust Barometer reveals a crisis of ‚Äúfaith in traditional authority figures and institutions‚Äù. This at a time when technological development brings with it significant opportunities but is not without risk. Trust is important because it enables faster innovation, and increased human adoption of technology. Trust is the enablement of progress, but one in which all players need to assess and contribute to the building of trust. At a time when trust is declining and is simultaneously a key future driver, the big questions marketers need to ask themselves is what they‚Äôre doing to break, or build, trust with the people who matter to them most. 2. Consultancies Will Dominate Everyone‚Äôs talking about the death of advertising and big agencies, but this doesn‚Äôt reveal what comes next. The recent acquisition of Droga5 by Accenture Interactive has caused quite a stir, but has been a long time coming. I‚Äôd say that Droga5 won with this one, getting a pretty good deal! I‚Äôve always maintained that consultancies could wipe out agencies by simply offering the same services at a heavily discounted fee ‚Äî they have the resources to do this, but not necessarily the talent, which is why an acquisition like Droga5 makes sense. I believe consultancies will win the race because of how digital transformation is increasing the rapid rate of innovation. The big consulting firms have had huge experience in change management at a time when most CMOs have lost their way, thanks to ad agencies that are failing because they‚Äôve failed to transform their own business models. Marketing is automating while becoming more fluid and pivotal in the overall business strategy. It‚Äôs no longer about unmeasurable and fluffy metrics like ‚Äúbrand equity‚Äù, ‚Äúengagement‚Äù or ‚Äúeyeballs‚Äù. The role of marketing now is understanding customers like never before, through data and insights. And, of course, by building personalised communications with the aim of garnering trust and further understanding. Companies that do this well will become the customer-centric leaders of tomorrow. Consultancies tend to be more insights-driven. They facilitate change easily and are abreast of emerging developments. The big consultants ‚Äòhold‚Äô their client‚Äôs business strategy, a role that agencies have failed to conquer. But where consultancies fall short is in execution, often leaving this up to the clients themselves. That‚Äôs why the Droga5 acquisition makes perfect sense for Accenture Interactive ‚Äî it shores up a dominant position. The logical next step for them would be to acquire data companies and platforms, as well as employ deeper technological, analytical and creative thinking skills. 3. The return of Google Not that Google has gone anywhere, but its advertising revenue has definitely been affected by the big social media companies. Yes, I know their ad spend is increasing, but this is due to clients spending larger portions of their budgets online. Budgets that, less than a decade ago, Google could have captured almost entirely. Social media ad spend will decrease, in proportional terms (that is as a percentage of online ad spend), in the coming years. Why? Given this, it is only natural that social budgets will shift back to performance marketing platforms like AdWords, where a return is more measurable, more real, and audiences are more engaged. Unlike social media companies, Google has such a strong moat as a business ‚Äî there are few, if any, search businesses that can compete with it (in the Western world). The bottom line? The marketing sector is going through a time of unprecedented change. But with this comes great opportunity. The level of change we are experiencing will recreate marketing for the better. A transformed business lives in service of its customers, and so too should marketing. Basically, technology is just helping us humanity hit the reset button. Advertising is responsible for a lot of damage to human trust. Now‚Äôs the opportunity to put things right, put customers at the centre of everything, and now to treat humans like humans. -- -- Signal or Noise is a monthly publication by marketing & technology entrepreneur Bradley Elliott which focuses on insights, technology and creativity and how they relate to business, marketing, money and the future. Marketing and technology entrepreneur. Founder @platinumseed, Founder @continuon Help Status About Careers Press Blog Privacy Terms Text to speech Teams

Title: Keeping up with AI in 2019
Subtitle: What is the next big thing in AI and ML?
Author: Max Grigorev
Article: Sign up Sign in Sign up Sign in Member-only story Max Grigorev Follow The Launchpad -- 9 Share The past year has been rich in events, discoveries and developments in AI. It is hard to sort through the noise to see if the signal is there and, if it is, what is the signal saying. This post attempts to get you exactly that: I‚Äôll try to extract some of the patterns in the AI landscape over the past year. And, if we are lucky, we‚Äôll see how some of the trends extend into the near future. Confucius is quoted saying: ‚ÄúThe hardest thing of all is to find a black cat in a dark room, especially if there is no cat.‚Äù Wise man. Make no mistake: this is an opinion piece. I am not trying to establish some comprehensive record of accomplishments for the year. I am merely trying to outline some of these trends. Another caveat : this review is US-centric. A lot of interesting things are happening, say, in China, but I, unfortunately, am not familiar with that exciting ecosystem. Who is this post for? If you are still reading, it is probably for you: an engineer, who wants to widen their horizons; an entrepreneur, looking where to direct their energy next; a venture capitalist, looking for their next deal; or just a technology cheerleader, who can‚Äôt wait to see where this whirlwind is taking us next. -- -- 9 The Launchpad is a resource for applied-Machine Learning (ML) best practices from the trenches. Our goal is to help AI-first companies innovate & thrive, sharing knowledge & insights from our community:startups, mentors & Googlers https://developers.google.com/programs/launchpad/ better AI systems Help Status About Careers Press Blog Privacy Terms Text to speech Teams

Title: Zipline: Saving Lives with Autonomous Drones
Subtitle: Catalyst for Change
Author: Angela Loh
Article: Sign up Sign in Sign up Sign in Home About  This is a series about game changers‚Ää‚Äî‚Ääcompanies and individuals who are redefining what it means‚Ä¶  Angela Loh Follow Catalyst for Change -- Listen Share Disclaimer: Article written with Connie Zheng for our series called Catalysts for Change. Interviewed Justin Hamilton, who does public relations for Zipline. High maternal and child mortality rates, severe malaria, and anemia are only a portion of the problems that result from the blood shortage in Ghana. Currently, countries in Africa collect ‚Äúless than half of the blood needed to make transfusion requirements for their populations.‚Äù Access to blood remains a challenge in these countries. Zipline‚Äôs approach is to use autonomous electric drones to deliver medicine to hospitals and health centers on demand. Think of Uber or Lyft, but instead of transporting humans with cars, Zipline is flying packages of blood with drones. Doctors place their orders by messaging Zipline on Whatsapp, and within 30 minutes, medical supplies packaged from Zipline‚Äôs distribution centers are floating in the sky above the hospital by parachute in a hard-to-miss bright red box. So far, Zipline has set up its distribution centers in Ghana and Rwanda, but Justin Hamilton claims that Zipline‚Äôs ultimate goal is to ‚Äúprovide every human on Earth with instant access‚Äù to these medical supplies. In 2014, co-founder and CEO Keller Rinaudo visited the Ifakara Health Institute in Tanzania. Hamilton states that in the health institute, Rinaudo ‚Äúmet a graduate student who had built a mobile alert system for health workers to text emergency requests for medicine and vaccines.‚Äù Despite allowing health workers to make thousands of emergency medical requests, the system was unable to actually fulfill these requests due to the lack of medical resources. Determined to make a difference, Rinaudo was committed to building a system where the urgent need for blood and medicine could finally be fulfilled. Having majored in Biotechnology and Economics as an undergraduate, it seems like Rinaudo‚Äôs vision to create a company that focuses on delivering medicine was planted as early as his early university years. Along with his co-founders, Keenan Wyrobek and William Hetzler, Rinaudo was able to create a system that took medical deliveries to the next level by using autonomous drones. Since its establishment, Zipline has delivered 16,000 and counting lifesaving packages by drone. According to Hamilton, building the autonomous is ‚Äúonly 10% of the complexity of the [entire] system.‚Äù He continues, ‚Äúsome of the biggest challenges of setting up a national drone delivery service involves integrating a public health supply chain and building all the infrastructure and equipment necessary to do 150 flights per day, reliably and routinely.‚Äù Hamilton claims, ‚Äúit‚Äôs actually very easy to build a quadcopter off the shelf and then make a delivery of a candy bar over 2‚Äì4 km in perfect weather. It‚Äôs really hard, however, to build a system that can operate at a national scale, fly in heavy wind and rain, and integrate with a much larger supply chain.‚Äù One question still lingers within my mind about Zipline. Zipline has made an undeniable impact on Ghana and Rwanda, however, it encounters the same questions that many Silicon Valley startups are facing. It seems as if the world is growing increasingly dependent on these tech startups, and the global wealth distribution is clustering around Silicon Valley. Rather than relying solely on Zipline‚Äôs beneficial services, developing countries like Ghana must also improve their own sustainable methods to solve the country‚Äôs deeper issues, like an efficient healthcare system. These problems require long-term investments in local infrastructure and human capital, rather than complete reliance on Silicon Valley companies. Although unintended consequences may arise in developing countries in the future, the work that Zipline is doing remains highly inspirational and undoubtedly, for a lack of better terms, cool and edgy. Rather than pondering on how to solve problems in first-world countries, Zipline is making an extraordinary step to bring innovative technologies to places that truly need it. To all the individuals who are seeking to find their place in the world, Zipline‚Äôs founders leave you with one line of advice: ‚ÄúTo solve global problems, we have to look outside our own experiences and ask, ‚Äòwhat kind of world do we want to live in?‚Äô‚Äù -- -- This is a series about game changers‚Ää‚Äî‚Ääcompanies and individuals who are redefining what it means to change the world. Title: Is It Too Late to Get Into Trading?
Subtitle: Published in Tech Trends
Author: Alice Bonasio
Article: Sign up Sign in Sign up Sign in Member-only story Alice Bonasio Follow Tech Trends -- Share Technology gives everyone the opportunity to trade online. When it comes to technology, it can often feel that by the time we hear about something, it‚Äôs already too late to get ourselves involved. Indeed, sometimes this can be true. Those who invested early in Bitcoin are now seeing huge payouts, sometimes 1000x what they invested. Whereas to get involved now wouldn‚Äôt be nearly as lucrative. But there are some trends in tech that are open at any time for anyone to get involved with. One of these is trading online. While the currencies you may trade and the companies‚Äô stocks may have been around forever, each day is a new day in trading and could be the day that you make a name for yourself as a trader. But how can you be a good trader online at this stage? Do Your Research Due diligence is the key to being a good trader. Spending hours poring over trading forecasts and past trading information could help you see patterns and anticipate what comes next. Even when the market throws you a curveball, it‚Äôs still better to be prepared to deal with it than to trade blindly. Researching the current climate of economics is also important. You don‚Äôt need to know the‚Ä¶ -- -- Showcase for the latest disruptive technology that is changing the education landscape globally Technology writer for FastCo, Quartz, The Next Web, Ars Technica, Wired + more. Title: How a healthy culture can lower the cost of employee training
Subtitle: The Startup
Author: Aytekin Tank
Article: Sign up Sign in Sign up Sign in Home Newsletter About  Get smarter at building your thing. Follow to join The Startup‚Äôs +8 million monthly readers & +772K‚Ä¶  Member-only story Aytekin Tank Follow The Startup -- 7 Share $90 billion. That‚Äôs how much US-based companies spent on employee training and development in 2017. I was astonished by this figure ‚Äî and it made me think about how we can all improve our training and employee retention. In my experience, it always comes back to company culture. For example, I recently discovered Etsy School. Employees at the e-commerce company run a series of courses where they teach each other new skills. And they‚Äôre not just work-related activities, either. The courses include everything from coding and sewing to dancing the tango and mixing cocktails. I love this idea. Not just because staff can learn a variety of skills, but also because it brings people together in a light-hearted, yet informative setting. When employees are engaged with their workplace, studies have shown that productivity increases and the costs associated with training and employee turnover drop dramatically. And these costs are some of the most challenging for businesses to overcome. That‚Äôs because training programs are difficult to get right. Programs often face time constraints, limited budgets, and a lack of enthusiasm, particularly when they‚Ä¶ -- -- 7 Get smarter at building your thing. Title: Double 3 Telepresence Robot Makes It Easy to Navigate Office Space
Subtitle: Written by Cabe Atwell
Author: Cabe Atwell
Article: Sign up Sign in Sign up Sign in Cabe Atwell Follow -- Listen Share Double Robotics has recently announced their new telepresence robot Double 3, which brings a host of new features over the previous robot that was released back in 2016. The earlier models had a steep learning curve when it came to piloting the robot around, especially when trying to avoid obstacles. This time around, navigation is a breeze as the Double 3 takes advantage of 3D sensors and cameras that allow users to point and click to their destination. The robot packs an integrated 9.7-inch integrated touch screen (gone is the iPad 2), and a wealth of other technology ‚Äî including six beamforming microphones, a pair of front-facing 13-megapixel cameras (one super wide-angle lens, one super zoom lens), and an 8-watt full-range speaker. On the sensor side, the Double 3 packs two Intel RealSense stereovision depth sensors, five ultrasonic range finders, two wheel encoders (2048 PPR each), and one 9-DOF IMU, all powered by an NVIDIA Jetson TX2‚Äì4GB SoC. The Double 3 robot uses that sensor array to provide users a slick mixed reality overlay of the environment, presenting a dot grid on the floor that enables users to click to where they want to go, much like the Sims video game. The robot can then proceed to the chosen destination while avoiding any obstacles in its path, which eliminates that strict piloting learning curve that came with the previous models. Another great feature lets users take control of the front-facing cameras that can pan, tilt up and down, and zoom in/out, making it easy to read documents on a desk or zooming in on presentations. The self-balancing mobility system with lateral control remains the same, which is excellent for Double 2 owners that want to upgrade, which is quickly enough done by replacing the head. The Double 3 is expected to launch in September with prices starting at $3,999. More information on the Double 3 telepresence robot can be found on Double Robotics‚Äô website. -- -- Help Status About Careers Press Blog Privacy Terms Text to speech Teams

Title: How switching off my phone, and locking it away, gave me my best day in 3 months.
Subtitle: Written by Gurpreet Bharya
Author: Gurpreet Bharya
Article: Sign up Sign in Sign up Sign in Gurpreet Bharya Follow -- 7 Listen Share I had always thought I had a suitably healthy relationship with my mobile. While others were app-happy and always knew the latest Instagram gossip, I was reading a book or watching something on my laptop. And when I lit up the screen to discover 208 unread messages in group conversations, it reassured me that I was usually the last one to reply. Of course I was ‚Äî I hardly used my phone. But it was always there. Curled up in bed and reading the next chapter of my novel and there it lay a black screen in the corner of my eye. An episode of Mad Men wouldn‚Äôt be complete without my mobile sidekick taking its place on the sofa. Messages would light up while I cooked, wrote poetry and in the middle of the night, and every time I would swipe access with urgent reluctance and read the gist of the conversation, before promising to reply later. Before I knew it, my phone had become a mental crutch and I was double-checking every subtle reflection of light my eyes mistook for a pop-up message. From once being able to easily read a novel for hours, in ignorance of the whereabouts of any technical device, my attention had been dramatically shortened to the width of the iPhone 6 screen I was anxiously lighting up after every 3 lines. It meant that I could not dedicate my complete concentration to any single task, because my ultimate focus was my phone. Without it, I was missing something ‚Äî what if someone wanted to contact me urgently, for advice or communicate some information that required my absolute immediate attention? Of course, it was an irrational thought, but as my phone focus grew bigger, my world was getting subtly smaller. I wasn‚Äôt enjoying or living in the things I was doing in the present, but constantly watching and waiting for something else to happen, in the future and through a device and this was making me feel anxious. Perhaps the moment when I knew things had to change was when my mobile lost charge at the supermarket. Despite being a mere 10 minutes from my home and within the safety of a large shop, with lots of customers and staff, I distinctly recall the stomach-sinking anxiety that took a hold of my nerves. Bizarrely, I felt alone, disconnected from my family and friends, almost as though I was my own island. My heart beat faster before a fresh breeze of freedom came through to heighten my senses and awareness of my surroundings. For the first time in a long time, I was seeing and hearing everything with its outline, rather than the hurried smudge that often comes with always looking down. Grocery shopping stops being a mundane task when you notice the quality and colours of fruit and veg or the rainbow-sheen of salmon on the counter. So, that weekend I switched off my phone. I knew it would not be enough to simply turn it upside down in a drawer for the reason that I would know it was still on and definitely potentially receiving messages. Switched off, however, and I could sit there all day and the screen would still be black. It was the kind of break-up that I needed. Instantly, I felt a peace of mind just knowing that I didn‚Äôt have to worry about any messages or calls. I had already told my friends that I wouldn‚Äôt be available for the day and knew that if there were any kind of seriously unlikely urgent reason they needed to contact me, they had my Mum‚Äôs number. And then I went outside, to stand in nature and experience all of its outlines. It was a beautiful day and I bought potted flowers and learned how to make hanging baskets. Sure, at times my mind drifted to my phone, but, overall, I spent the day being more mindful of the outside world, the people around me and myself. I slowed down to create something that lasts and will grow and change every day and just looked up to breathe a bit deeper. It‚Äôs easy to think that if you‚Äôre not on social media every day or the frst person to reply on WhatsApp, that you‚Äôre not negatively affected by your phone, but the likely reality is that you are. Phones are so commonplace and central to the way we run our lives today that it‚Äôs difficult to mentally switch off. In fact, according to The Telegraph, we now spend an entire day a week online and check our phones, on average, every 12 minutes. While there is no doubt that they are useful, like most things, it‚Äôs all about balance, and knowing that the strongest connections are created without it. -- -- 7 Wellness copywriter at G.B. Title: Your future self is your most important mentor
Subtitle: How to learn from tomorrow‚Äôs hard-won wisdom ‚Äî today
Author: Aytekin Tank
Article: Sign up Sign in Sign up Sign in Member-only story Aytekin Tank Follow The Startup -- 3 Share Peter Emshwiller was 18 years old when he interviewed his future self. Dressed in a tan suit with his age pinned on the lapel, Peter asked an invisible, future version of himself a series of questions about his life: Was Future Peter married? What had he accomplished in his career? And, most importantly, was he an ‚Äúexceedingly rich superstar?‚Äù Thirty-eight years later, at the age of 56, Future Peter finally recorded his answers for a film project he calls ‚ÄúLater That Same Life.‚Äù The result feels a bit like time travel ‚Äî and it holds some powerful insights. After some playful questioning, the interview turns serious when Future Peter, clearly wiser for his age and experience, responds to his younger self‚Äôs question about his family. ‚ÄúI don‚Äôt know how much I should tell you, but spend as much time as you can with him,‚Äù Future Peter says to his younger self. ‚ÄúJust spend more time with Dad.‚Äù -- -- 3 Get smarter at building your thing.
