Title: Taking that leap‚Ää‚Äî I can explain‚Ä¶
Subtitle: CoE Analytics
Author: John Galletta
Article: Sign up Sign in Sign up Sign in John Galletta Follow -- Listen Share ‚Ä¶or can I? It‚Äôs hard to comprehend what I just did and even harder to decide how I feel about it. But, this will be my attempt at doing just that. My name is John Galletta, and I‚Äôm a graduate of the Master of Science in Information Systems program at Drexel University. I recently completed an international rotational internship program at SAP and you may, perhaps, call me a risk-taker because I‚Äôve decided to take take a leap from a sure thing in an effort to advance my technical career. For those who are looking to challenge themselves, take a leap of faith, or achieve their own big hairy audacious goals (or BHAG‚Äôs), this is my story about my time as an SAP STAR Intern and the difficult decision I had to make to move on and pursue my next big move. Well, let‚Äôs get to the root of this quickly so I can try to explain how I felt as I went through the process of looking for jobs from within a major tech company, what it was like to be swarmed by recruiters on LinkedIn, and the factors I considered along each step of my journey. As a full-time master‚Äôs student at Drexel University in 2018, I qualified for the Student Training and Rotation (STAR) Program at SAP America Inc. For those who don‚Äôt know, SAP is a global enterprise software company with headquarters in Walldorf, Germany. The company specializes in Enterprise Resource Planning (ERP) software and is building upon an already impressive portfolio of integrated software solutions which serve the specific needs of various lines of business across 25 industries. As STAR Interns, my colleagues and I were given real-world responsibilities during our rotations through a custom procured selection of organizations within SAP. My first rotation was on the Analytics team in the Center of Excellence (CoE) located at the company‚Äôs North American Headquarters in Newtown Square, PA. During my time on this team, I was entrusted with the task of leading a team of three interns and one full-time developer in building a highly scalable platform for the creation, distribution, and tracking of training curricula for support engineers in North America all while learning about the company‚Äôs flagship analytical offerings: WebI, Business Warehouse, Business Objects, and SAP Analytics Cloud. Over the course of six months, my team and I went through design thinking, prototyping, entity relationship modeling, development, and deployment of the product using SAP UI5, SAP WebIDE, SAP Cloud Platform, and SAP HANA. The end product of this work, the SAP Training Dashboard, is currently being used to manage the onboarding and training of new hires in the company‚Äôs 6-month CoE Bootcamp program. My second rotation was a dual part-time role where I split my time between the SAP Leonardo Machine Learning Solution Management Team and the Enterprise Analytics Customer Success Team. During my time on the solution management team, I was given the opportunity to participate in a week-long design thinking workshop led by the global team lead and participated in discussions regarding the various topics within the team‚Äôs scope. At this event, I was asked by the global lead to develop an analytical dashboard that would display the team‚Äôs KPI metrics on the wall in her office at global headquarters in Walldorf, Germany using SAP Analytics Cloud. While on the Solution Management team I was also presented with the opportunity to develop a multi-lingual chatbot using SAP‚Äôs Conversational AI platform, under the mentorship of the North America team lead and one of the team‚Äôs machine learning architects. The product of this work was shared with account executives who demonstrated its capabilities to potential customers in the State and Local Government and Education (SLED) sector. My last task on the Solution Management team was to present the SAP Leonardo Machine Learning portfolio to a group of approximately 20 C-level executives during a co-innovation partner workshop. This presentation outlined the capabilities of the solutions in the portfolio and included video demonstrations and teasers about what SAP‚Äôs machine learning solutions would be capable of achieving in the future. During my part-time rotation in Enterprise Analytics, I was blessed to work with amazing data scientists while they created statistical models to predict customer churn for the products in SAP‚Äôs portfolio and generated forecasts for the company‚Äôs service bookings. During this time, I helped enhance the team‚Äôs model deployment process by coordinating with a third data scientist located in Paris to generate a logging script to trace errors during deployment of their predictive models into company‚Äôs productive SAP Business Warehouse environment. During my first rotation in the STAR Program, an opportunity came up to lead an exchange program between the students at SAP America and SAP Hungary. I saw this as a way to demonstrate my leadership abilities while expanding the reach of my network to an even larger geographic area. With the help of the Vocational Training (VT) Exchange Program lead in Hungary, I started hosting a series of exchange calls between the US and Hungary which lead to the very first snack exchange between SAP America and SAP Hungary. During these exchanges, my colleagues and I took the opportunity to learn about foreign cultures while sharing our own equally foreign cultures with those abroad. As students in the STAR Program, each of us was given the opportunity to qualify for a three-month rotation abroad to the destination of our choice (as long as there was a role at the destination‚Äôs SAP office which made business sense for us to pursue). The work I had done, my contributions to the STAR Program, and overall ethic I had displayed during my first two rotations had qualified me for a rotation abroad. Since SAP SE (the global parent company of SAP) is headquartered in Walldorf, Germany, it was a natural choice for me to pursue the open positions available there. After interviewing with many of the teams at headquarters, I decided to follow my passion for developing applications and pursue a role as a React UI Developer as part of a team whose manager reports directly to the Chief Operating Officer of SAP. Upon my arrival I was greeted by an executive assistant who showed me around the office and introduced me to our manager and the rest of the team. Under the mentorship of a User Experience Design Expert and a Senior UI Developer, I learned the ins and outs of developing web applications using React.js to further enhance my web development skill set and deliver a fully functioning asset library for the company‚Äôs ‚ÄúSAP Runs SAP‚Äù dynamic storytelling application. During the company‚Äôs annual SAPPHIRE NOW event in Orlando, Florida where our team‚Äôs application was being used to showcase SAP‚Äôs own use of SAP software ‚Äîand while all of the executives were away ‚Äî the team‚Äôs executive assistant took the opportunity to give me and my colleagues a tour of the company‚Äôs digital boardroom as well as building WDF49, the company‚Äôs newest and most innovative living workplace laboratory. This quickly became the most memorable part of my rotation in Walldorf. While abroad, I also had the opportunity to meet up with my manager and several colleagues for a weekend getaway in Oslo, Norway; enjoy the waters of Venice, Italy; visit the Mona Lisa, the Eiffel Tower and enjoy escargot in Paris, France; and spend time with family in Chisinau, Moldova. Needless to say, the entire rotation was a once in a lifetime experience. One thing worth mentioning about the culture of SAP is the closeness of its people. Guided by a unifying mission to ‚Äú help the world run better and improve people‚Äôs lives,‚Äù SAP‚Äôs culture is ethically aligned with what it means to be human. Part of this includes developing a strong sense of unity and oneness with those around you. To this end, the STAR Program provided us with excellent opportunities to share experiences together during team building trips to Skytop Lodge in the Pocono Mountains of Pennsylvania and even take part in a variety of other activities together outside of work. This past summer, my team and I enjoyed playing paintball and participating in an ‚ÄúAmazing Race‚Äù style competition on the grounds of the resort. For me, working at SAP was the best experience I‚Äôve ever had. I made friends with over 100 people during my 1 year and 3 months at the company, received some of the best mentorship in the world, had absolutely the best manager ever, and even had the opportunity to be a mentor to others all while traveling the world and advancing my career. The people I got to work with are surely the best in the industry and I will and already do miss going in to the office to see them on a daily basis. But, all good things come to an end and this is where it starts to get hard for me to explain things. When it came time for me to choose a full-time position at SAP, I knew I wanted to remain technical, and I had already built a very strong network on a global scale with some amazingly talented people and an incredibly vast knowledge of SAP‚Äôs portfolio. I received a very generous offer for someone coming straight out of an internship program, but frankly, I knew I needed to keep pushing myself. The role I was offered was not as technical as I had originally anticipated and I knew that I wanted to keep climbing to new heights and take my passion even further. This led me to look for junior to mid-level developer roles I knew I could fulfill outside of the company. After listing myself as open to recruiters on LinkedIn, I was quickly able to understand what someone with my skills can do in the current job market. This is because over the span of two months I had been contacted by over 50 recruiters! The recruiter who was the most proactive, provided me with a technical skills assessment which assessed my skill level as a React developer as well as my technical knowledge of pure vanilla javascript. This helped both her and I find exactly the right position for me at a level that was right for the skillset I had to offer. I received honest feedback from that recruiter after meeting over coffee at a local Starbucks, and knew that I needed to pursue what was available to me. It‚Äôs not unlike me to know exactly what I want to pursue and set my sights on executing a strategic plan to attain it. When I found the UI Developer Role available at Comcast, I knew it would be the perfect place for me to sharply hone my development skills in a fast paced and structured corporate environment which would provide opportunities for me to grow. It‚Äôs this aspect that drives me to show up ready for success every day and push myself towards excellence ‚Äî this is the reason I‚Äôm confident in having left my sure thing back at SAP. I know for sure that the true friendships I made at SAP will continue to endure and I am certain that the decisions I‚Äôve made will lead to great outcomes and many more true friendships in the future. For now, my sights are set on getting better at what I do and never forgetting to extend a helping hand to help those who are also striving to achieve their own goals, while always being willing to accept the advice I need when it‚Äôs given. That‚Äôs why, for my next steps, I plan to begin mentoring others as they pursue their own paths within the technology industry as part of my own side hustle ‚Äî the details of which I will be writing about very soon ‚Äî and I am very excited about it! If you‚Äôve made it all the way down here, I want to thank you for taking the time to read my first blog on Medium. I‚Äôm a truly passionate individual who takes the time to appreciate those around me, and since this may be the only chance I get as you‚Äôre passing by, I‚Äôd like to take the opportunity to appreciate you now. I wish you the best in what you‚Äôre pursuing, and if you‚Äôd like to, please feel free to respond below. I look forward to your feedback. -- -- Help Status About Careers Press Blog Privacy Terms Text to speech Teams

Title: buying my grandfather AirPods
Subtitle: Written by idk
Author: idk
Article: Sign up Sign in Sign up Sign in idk Follow -- Listen Share A few weeks ago, my grandfather asked me to buy him a pair of Apple AirPods‚Ä¶ He was tired of his headphone wires getting in his way while working out and became very interested when he saw people at his local YMCA walking around with wireless earbuds. The thought of my grandfather walking around in public, flexing his AirPods made me laugh. Nonetheless, I brought down my AirPods and helped him try them out. After his free trial, he took out his wallet, gave me $200, and told me to buy him a pair by the next week. Ever since I can remember, my grandparents have visited my parents‚Äô house every single Wednesday morning. As the years have gone by my feeling towards their presence that one day a week evolved from pure excitement as a child, to bitter irritation during my adolescence, and to deep regret for not spending more time with them throughout college. After realizing how much my grandparents had aged and how little I truly knew them, I made it one of my top goals this gap semester to devote more quality time to them. However, even with this awareness and extra free time, I am ashamed to admit that there were a few Wednesdays that I did not even wake up in time to see them stop by. Thankfully, this all changed with the help of AirPods. The first day my grandfather received his AirPods, I taught him how to use bluetooth to connect them to his Android phone (Yes, he is using AirPods to listen to an Android phone LOL). I also downloaded an Android app to allow him to check his AirPod battery life. The last feature I taught him that day was how to use his AirPods to listen to videos and music he could search on YouTube. A small part of me wanted to leave him at that. I wanted him to learn the rest on his own and be free of teaching him the seemingly most basic steps in using a smartphone. However, another larger part of me knew that assisting him and teaching him the basics of music streaming technology would be both an ambitious and rewarding journey. The next Wednesday, he returned with several concerns. He was having difficulty keeping his AirPods in and asked if anything could be done. He ended up trading his AirPods with my brother‚Äôs Beats wireless headphones (which he eventually ended up switching back). After hearing that he wanted music to play non-stop during his workouts, I decided to download Spotify (non-premium) for him. I downloaded playlists for his favorite Korean artists such as Ïù¥Î¨∏ÏÑ∏ and Ï°∞Ïö©ÌïÑ. A part of me felt bad for enjoying the benefits of being a Spotify Premium owner, while watching my grandfather deal with annoying advertisements and the limited ability in choosing to play specific songs... The following week, he came back and switched back the Beats for the AirPods because he liked the AirPod look better (my grandpa got CLOUT). My dad also agreed to subscribe to the Spotify Family Plan so the whole family could use it (At the time, my brother, dad, and I were all sharing my personal Spotify premium account LOL). With Spotify Family, I taught both of my grandparents how to utilize the app and presented them the benefits of being a premium owner. I showed them basic functions such as searching for artists, making simple playlists, and shuffling songs. Every Wednesday, my grandfather comes over with a new question or concern about his AirPods or limited music selection. Although his ÏûîÏÜåÎ¶¨ (nagging) gets on my nerves at times, I am learning constant patience and more importantly showing my love for my grandparents, which has been extremely difficult to do with just words due to the language barrier. Sitting down on our family room couch and giving my grandparents the most simple technology lessons in my broken Korean allows for conversation to segue into even deeper conversation about life before I was born, memories we have together, and how my grandparents are doing in their daily lives. A few years ago, my grandfather refused to get a smartphone because he thought he‚Äôd die before he‚Äôd learn how to use one. Now, he has somewhat mastered the use of AirPods. It is truly amazing how technology can open doors for people of all ages and stages in life. If you have a parent, grandparent, or even a younger relative, who is struggling to use technology, I highly recommend being open to helping them out. You never where it will take you. Ìï†Î®∏ÎãàÏôÄ Ìï†ÏïÑÎ≤ÑÏßÄ, ÏÇ¨ÎûëÌï¥Ïöî!!! ‚ù§ -- -- Help Status About Careers Press Blog Privacy Terms Text to speech Teams

Title: Designing a(n imaginary) school app on a smartwatch
Subtitle: Written by Celia O
Author: Celia O
Article: Sign up Sign in Sign up Sign in Celia O Follow -- Listen Share Smartwatches have come a long way since they started, expanding to allow for various functionalities from what we know on the phone into something way smaller and lighter. All around your wrist. And so, as part of a semester long module, I came up with the idea of creating an Apple Watch/smartwatch interface around what my group decided to tackle during the module ‚Äî an (imaginary) app interface intended for Nanyang Technological University (NTU) students to find seats around the various school libraries. Personally, I‚Äôve never had a go at designing smartwatch interfaces, so why not give it a shot now? When it came to deciding functionalities for the mobile application, we came up with ideas such as booking seats, personalisation of amenities and favouriting of libraries and also a seat forecast that takes into account both your preferred amenities and favourite libraries. To explain the seat forecast, I have to begin with the personalisation of amenities. This function meant that the student could choose around 3-4 amenities that they absolutely would require, for example a window seat, a charger for their laptop and phone, the distance from where they are or even to opt to use the library‚Äôs PC. They can also save libraries that they frequent. Once they have saved the information on the app, the app will filter out based on what is the best library that fits their amenities requirements, and from there, the number of fitted seats available will be reflected. For the seat forecast, it will use the number of fitted seats available over the total number of fitted seats to determine whether it will be a good or bad forecast. And if you‚Äôve saved more libraries, the ‚Äúalgorithm‚Äù gets more complex to find you the best seat for you in school. For this challenge, I decided to go with the Apple Watch size of 42mm from the Apple Watch Series 3. I decided to scale down the functionalities and only show the seat forecast, along with a filtering function of your personalised amenities and favourite libraries. In the event that the student does not have favourite libraries, it will show a list of libraries ranked based on the amenities they‚Äôve saved. Version 1 (on the left) was done during the brainstorm process, whereas version 2 (on the right) was a second design proposal just for this post. There‚Äôs definitely a huge leap in terms of what each screen shows between versions, simply because after some research, it is best not to clutter the screen with too many words. Instead, to try and use visuals to represent those information. This way, it‚Äôll be easier to navigate through the interface whilst on the go. After planning, I came up with the final design, likening closer to the 2nd plan and with that in mind, let me explain with different scenarios to understand what sort of interfaces were needed. This user has saved 2 libraries from the app: the Lee Wee Nam library and the ADM library. The user has also saved 3 amenities that they would like for it to be reflected on the watch: plugs, window seats and discussion spots. When you click into the ‚Äúapp‚Äù on the watch, the watch will display a good forecast first, and the user can swipe left to see the libraries they‚Äôve saved, ranking the best libraries to study at, at the top. A progress indicator is used so that there‚Äôs a quick indication of how many fitted seats there are, that fulfils the 3 amenities the user requires. Plus, it will indirectly provide a gauge for the user to guess the quantity of fitted seats there are without having to display a number. Still, the user can tap into the library to see exact seat numbers. From there, they can head to the library. In this scenario, the app will display a bad forecast and a button will appear to suggest to the user better spots around the school that satisfies the amenities requirements. In the event that they still want to go to their favourite libraries, they can swipe to the next page to see it. From our surveys during the module, there were students that said the ‚Äúsuggestion‚Äù might not be that helpful since they already like what they like, or already have plans to head to their saved library. Also that they might just head to their favourite library anyway and wait for an available seat. Which is why the option to view their initial saved choices is just a swipe away. If they tap into one of the libraries, they can actually reduce their amenities saved, to get a higher seat number. After all, all these 3 amenities are taken into account when finding seats, as the app assumes that the student wants/needs all 3 of them. In the event that the student doesn‚Äôt mind not having some of the amenities, they can adjust the filter by tapping the amenities buttons at the bottom and updating them. From there, an updated seat amount will be shown. In the event that the user doesn‚Äôt mind taking up the suggested libraries, the user can hit the ‚Äúrecommend me‚Äù button and suggestions will appear. Upon choosing one of the suggested libraries, the user has the option to get directions to that library, as it is likely that the library might be new to the user. The watch will vibrate to update the user to either walk, change direction or take public transport etc. The user can also manually update the map and the position with the button on the bottom left corner, and the map will be zoomed in or out correspondingly. I decided to keep this design and the functionalities simple because a smartwatch should be something you could quickly glance at without having to fiddle around too much. Which is why the amount of steps in each scenario is not a lot. Although it might mean that certain functionalities are not available, they can always turn to the mobile app to do more. This was definitely an interesting challenge and I do aim to do more (and maybe write more on this platform). Let me know what you think about this and if you enjoyed this, feel free to leave some claps! -- -- A front-end developer who loves to explore new tech, libraries and do some designing in my free time. Title: Student Lender SoFi Details Wealth Management, Crypto Trading Plans
Subtitle: Cheddar
Author: Tanaya Macheel
Article: Sign up Sign in Sign up Sign in Home About  Original reporting on social media, fintech, entertainment, cannabis, and more from the leading‚Ä¶  Tanaya Macheel Follow Cheddar -- Listen Share Online lender SoFi is rounding out its suite of financial services and wading deeper into wealth and asset management, with an online brokerage that is now widely available and a suite of exchange-traded funds set to debut this year. On Monday, the company filed with the Securities and Exchange Commission to launch four SoFi-branded, exchange-traded funds this year. Two of them, the SoFi 500 ETF (SFY) and SoFi Next 500 ETF (SFYX), will be fee-free until March 27, 2020. They carry a 0.19 percent management fee that their investment advisor has agreed to waive for the first year. SoFi is the latest fintech company to try to make a zero-fee splash in a market dominated by long-established legacy giants like Vanguard and BlackRock. But CEO Anthony Noto maintains that SoFi‚Äôs new push is not just a marketing scheme to lure high-earning potential customers. ‚ÄúThe offering we have today is meant to be the offering,‚Äù Noto told a group of reporters on Tuesday morning. ‚ÄúIt‚Äôs not introductory, and it‚Äôs built on a five-year plan.‚Äù The new offering will sit under the SoFi Invest umbrella, which was made widely available to the general public Tuesday and to which SoFi plans to add cryptocurrency trading this year through a partnership with Coinbase, Noto said. ‚ÄúInvest and Money will both uniquely bring in new members that we wouldn‚Äôt have brought in through the lending products,‚Äù said Noto. ‚ÄúWithin Invest it‚Äôs hard to know if it‚Äôs going to be stocks, robo, ETFs or cryptocurrency. We know our members and nonmembers that fit our target want those different elements.‚Äù SoFi Invest is a free consumer investing service that offers stocks, ETFs, and robo-advising accompanied by newsy and educational content. Noto took the wheel at SoFi exactly one year ago, when the company was still a student loan refinancing brand battling the sex scandal that led to then-CEO Mike Cagney‚Äôs dramatic exit. In the past year the company has expanded and shifted to a mobile-first strategy. It launched Invest , a beta version of its personal finance manager, and SoFi Money, a fee-free bank account with a 2.25 percent interest rate. It plans to roll out a credit card, joint accounts, savings vaults, and roundups this year. In addition to its current life insurance offering, SoFi plans to expand to apartment insurance, car insurance, and more under the SoFi Protect umbrella, Noto said.. But 2019 is about ‚Äúnot just what we build, but how it works,‚Äù Noto said, in front of a slide introducing ‚ÄúThe New SoFi.‚Äù Specifically, it‚Äôs not just about the product rollouts, but about the membership and social experiences the company offers, like social events and career coaching sessions though a partnership with Korn Ferry. Noto said SoFi has specific partnership strategy and ambitions on the horizon, but none involve mergers and acquisitions. He noted that the fintech industry is still in its ‚Äúformation phase‚Äù of the investment cycle. He also said while in the long term SoFi strives to become a public company, an IPO is not a 2019 priority. The company‚Äôs product expansion is on trend with fintech companies that made their mark in the great unbundling of financial services and are now rebuilding them, thanks in large part to the high cost of customer acquisition. ‚ÄúThis is a great example of brand extension and SoFi can onboard wealth management customers at significantly lower onboarding costs than other robos which must acquire customers from scratch,‚Äù said April Rudin, chief executive and founder of wealth marketing strategy firm The Rudin Group. ‚ÄúIt is smart business and expected that SoFi would extend its play into wealth management services for its millennials borrowers. This cohort clearly needs wealth management advice and more financial literacy education.‚Äù Noto said one reason there hasn‚Äôt been a ‚Äúbroad-based‚Äù company in financial services „Éºlike in retail or travel, for example „Éº is due to the amount of capital required to operate. Many companies have launched individual products and achieved great success with it but haven‚Äôt expanded, which usually leads to M&A deals. ‚ÄúWe have a strategy where the success of one product will help drive the success of the next product, both directly and indirectly,‚Äù he said. ‚ÄúWe are seeing the behavior from opening an account, funding an account, direct deposit and then spending ‚Äî that‚Äôs the path we want to see‚Ä¶ You can imagine us adding rewards programs overtime and economic opportunities with merchants.‚Äù -- -- Original reporting on social media, fintech, entertainment, cannabis, and more from the leading post-cable network. Reporter for Cheddar covering financial services and the future of money. Help Status About Careers Press Blog Privacy Terms Text to speech Teams

Title: You‚Äôve Been Hacked. Now What?
Subtitle: 5 Important Steps to Help Your Business Respond Quickly and Safely
Author: Daniel Rhodes
Article: Sign up Sign in Sign up Sign in Daniel Rhodes Follow Silent Breach -- Listen Share Unfortunately, successful cyberattacks are growing far too common. A 2018 study found that nearly 70% of SMBs have experienced a cyberattack in the past year, yet an astounding 47% of respondents said they ‚Äúhave no understanding‚Äù of how to protect themselves in the event of an attack. Due to the relative complexity of today‚Äôs digital infrastructure, most companies are moving towards Managed Security Services for digital protection and proactive security. In fact, Silent Breach estimates that partnering with a reputable cybersecurity firm is the single most effective step you can take to mitigate digital security risks and minimize security-related costs in the long run. Remember, protection is always cheaper and more effective before an attack takes place. However, if you believe that you‚Äôve been the victim of an attack, here are five critical steps you can take after the fact to immediately reduce your risk: The actions taken in the first few hours following a breach will continue have large ramifications throughout the remainder of the recovery, for better or for worse. It is therefore critical to consult with your prepared BCP before doing anything else. Most likely, your situation (or one sufficiently similar) has been forecasted and a series of processes and procedures have been developed to guide you along the way. While the average data breach costs close to $4 million, Ponemon‚Äôs latest Cost of a Data Breach Study estimates that having a Business Continuity Plan will save you $365,000 on average. On a per-file basis, the savings comes down to about $15 per compromised file. Although Business Continuity Plans should be specially tailored (in consultation with your cybersecurity partner) to your organizations needs and abilities, most effective BCPs will include the following 3 sections: Disaster Recovery: This will focus on recovering any IT resources and infrastructure that may have been compromised. Unlike natural disasters, cyberattacks are not constrained by geography, offering the attackers a distributed attack surface. DR for cyber breaches should prepare for targeted simultaneous outages. Business Impact Analysis: Not all breaches are created equal. A good BIA will account for interdependencies to ensure that resources are being deployed effectively and efficiently. Cyber Incident Response Plan: This will include a forensics unit composed of IT personnel (dedicated to tracking down and patching the breach), a regulatory unit of legal analysts (to identify and remediate compliance gaps), and a public relations team (to communicate with customers, the media and shareholders). If you do not yet have a Business Continuity Plan, use this Emergency Contact Form for access to Silent Breach‚Äôs Provisional Crisis Guideline for rapid triage and proceed immediately to Step 2. If you would like help developing your Business Continuity Plan, come and talk to us. Don‚Äôt wait until you‚Äôve been breached. Cyberattacks often operate via the snowball effect, where each breach will trigger an additional, larger attack which will in turn do the same. It is crucial, therefore, that all infected devices be disconnected from your network as soon as possible. This will not only prevent the spread of the attack, but may also assist forensics experts in tracking down the cause of the attack. The importance of this step cannot be overstated. If you haven‚Äôt done so yet, contact your security partner and share everything you know about the breach as well as the affected systems and devices. Most likely, the security firm will have a 24/7 Security Operations Center which will work with you in real-time to mitigate the breach. If you do not have a security partner or are unable to reach them, note down everything you know (while the details are fresh) and immediately contact a security service provider for further directions. At Silent Breach, our security and forensics experts specialize in Incident Detection & Response and are available around the clock to assist you. Tip: Read our post on How To Choose a Cybersecurity Firm Deleting what you believe to be infected files will only make it harder for the forensics team to trace the attack and, in some cases, can even trigger a follow-up attack. In order to ensure that the attack can be fully discovered, contained and eradicated, it is vital to preserve the ‚Äòscene of the crime‚Äô. Hackers can take advantage of your identity by pivoting to attacks against business colleagues or personal contacts. Posing as yourself, they will use social-hacking techniques to convince close contacts to divulge sensitive personal information. Furthermore, under GDPR, stakeholders must be notified within 72 hours of a breach. To prevent this, immediately contact family members, friends and business associates to inform them that your account has been compromised. You can use social media or an email blast to quickly spread the word. For further assistance or to talk with a security professional, you can contact Silent Breach from anywhere in the world, at any time of the day. About Silent Breach: Silent Breach is an award-winning provider of cyber security services. Our global team provides cutting-edge insights and expertise across the Data Center, Enterprise, SME, Retail, Government, Finance, Education, Automotive, Hospitality, Healthcare and IoT industries. -- -- Stay updated on the latest cybersecurity news and announcements Head of Growth @ Silent Breach. Title: Experimentation helps retailers optimize their supply chain ‚Äî here‚Äôs how
Subtitle: Testing high-risk experiments
Author: Thoughtworks
Article: Sign up Sign in Sign up Sign in Thoughtworks Follow ThoughtWorks Featured Insights -- Listen Share By Praful Todkar We have been collaborating with a large US-based fashion retailer to improve their supply chain efficiency. One of the key factors that help solve supply chain puzzles is making sure online orders are fulfilled from the most profitable location ‚Äî a warehouse or a store that maximizes the profit margin on the order. This is the responsibility of the Order Routing algorithm. To identify the most profitable fulfillment location, the Order Routing algorithm uses a variety of ‚Äòlevers‚Äô such as the shipping address, shipping service (example, Expedited vs Regular shipping), inventory, among others. The client‚Äôs Order Routing team wanted to improve their algorithm by leveraging demand forecast and further optimize for gross margin per online order. The principle here is that demand forecast pinpoints the most ‚Äòdisadvantaged‚Äô location ‚Äî a location where the product is likely to go on markdown (a 50% off sale) in the near future. Therefore, margin on the online order can be improved by fulfilling the product from such a disadvantaged location. Let‚Äôs dig into this a little with an example. It‚Äôs fall season and the retailer has received an online order for a pair of shorts. There are two stores that stock the product. One, based out of Chicago and other in San Diego. Our demand forecast tells us that the approaching winter in Chicago will ensure less demand for the product, which means the shorts will go on markdown. As opposed to this, in sunny San Diego the product will sell full price. The order should be fulfilled from Chicago, the disadvantaged location, to yield a better margin. The Order Routing algorithm is a ‚Äòsensitive‚Äô algorithm and small changes to it can have a big impact on the margin of fulfilled orders. One example could be; accounting for higher shipping costs of one location over another. This is why prototyping is a preferred path when evolving the algorithm. The project team‚Äôs new demand forecast approach went through the prototype stage as well but, with certain limitations. The prototype could not be built for the entire data set due to sheer volume which meant inaccurate results. There was also no real-time feedback from the changes planned for the production software, as the prototype was disconnected from the production systems. We needed to find a better solution! Our client partnered with ThoughtWorks not just for our software development expertise but also to inculcate the culture and capabilities of Lean Thinking (test-and-learn). And, given the algorithm‚Äôs sensitivity, a real time feedback loop for software changes was essential. While a solution was identified based on prototype results, it did not guarantee a lot of confidence. In response, the team built a test-and-learn platform that pitted multiple solutions against one another, and used business metrics to determine the best solution. While test-and-learn is a commonly used technique to test variations of user interfaces, this situation was unique because we were testing business logic. Moreover, it had to be carried out on an enterprise backend, low latency system within a complex business domain and a high risk environment. Getting this right was paramount and called for a well thought out architecture that would support the business need. Let‚Äôs get into a little more details of the kind of architecture we were working with. A test-and-learn platform conventionally has 3 components: The algorithm in production is called the ‚Äòactive‚Äô algorithm. The new solutions are implemented as experiment algorithms in ‚Äòpassive‚Äô mode ‚Äî running in isolation without affecting the active algorithm. This safety feature was instrumental in getting us the green light to build the platform. The active algorithm‚Äôs input parameters are passed on to the experiment algorithms, along with the necessary transient data. This helps with an ‚Äòapples-to-apples‚Äô comparison. The analytics framework compares the experiment algorithms‚Äô output with the active algorithm‚Äôs output using complex business calculations (gross margin lift). The winning experiment algorithm is promoted to production, making it active ‚Äî merging it with the active algorithm or running it alongside the active algorithm. The aforementioned business impact dashboard monitors the newly promoted experiment algorithms‚Äô impact, on the health metrics. These metrics are the Order Routing‚Äôs Key Performance Indicators (KPIs). Although the test-and-learn platform has been a great success, the project team did overcome their fair share of challenges to meet this success. Running the experiments in passive mode was the perfect way to avoid negative fallout from the experiments on the Order Routing algorithm. Business users try new improvements without worrying about consequences. Additionally, business could turn off a newly promoted experiment after reading the business impact dashboard, and immediately have orders routed through the earlier, safe version of the algorithm. Quick feedback is the lifeblood of experimentation, and the team built a low-fi implementation for the dependency; demand forecast. The team imported a small subset of real data into the application database and manually refreshed it at regular intervals. This low-fi implementation meant the team could launch the experiment in just a few weeks instead of a few months, and receive valuable feedback from production. The low-fi and hi-fi implementation shared a common interface which resulted in minimal change (and a lot less throw away work) when migrating to the hi-fi implementation. The real data used in the Low-Fi version was periodically refreshed from the external dependency. This was a temporary hassle but it helped uncover a lot of issues early on ‚Äî not only in the algorithm but also in the data from the dependency. For example, of different demand forecast variants, we requested the appropriate variant based on initial learnings. This helped us to influence the development of the external dependency as well. Conventionally, web based A/B test results can be analyzed relatively quickly. However, in our case, the algorithm‚Äôs effectiveness, measured in gross margin lift, could only be carried out after 6‚Äì12 weeks. In response to this longer loop, the project team came up with the ‚Äúfeedback confidence levels‚Äù concept. A quick but low confidence level was used to make small tweaks to the algorithm, while the highest confidence level (that took longer) was used to determine eligibility for promotion to production. The business impact dashboard‚Äôs KPIs needed to have a direct cause and effect relationship with the code being changed, while also staying aligned to the organization‚Äôs KPIs. For example, shipping costs is an organizational KPI. But this metric could be affected by multiple organizational initiatives that sometimes even run contrary to each other. To avoid system ‚Äònoise‚Äô, the project team picked a metric that was only affected by our system while giving us a directional read on the organizational KPI. One such metric was ‚Äòpercentage of shipments from stores versus warehouses‚Äô. The code in our system directly impacted that percentage. As a general rule of thumb, shipments from warehouses are cheaper than stores and hence if the percentage of shipments skewed largely in favor of stores after a certain experiment went live, it would increase shipping costs, thus negatively affecting the organization‚Äôs ‚Äòshipping cost‚Äô KPI. The metrics were identified by the same team developing the experiment which meant they would be prioritized as per the project‚Äôs needs. It was also encouraging to witness the team‚Äôs emotional investment in the success of the experiment since the metric was real time validation not only of the experiment but also the hard work put in. One of the unintended but pleasant consequences of having a business impact dashboard was relooking at existing business inefficiencies and identifying new opportunities. For example, store shipments would skew from normal to becoming excessively high during certain business hours. The test-and-learn platform created highly specialized algorithms for certain types of orders, like expedited orders, which have incidentally been a huge upgrade for the product. It has been a game-changing experience to solve business problems with creative solutioning and validating the right solution through rapid experimentation. In our particular scenario, during the test phase, we averaged a +2% in gross margin per single SKU transaction. This effectively meant that with the new test-and-learn platform, there had been a drastic reduction in cost of validating business hypotheses. And, the project team had gone on to enhance the Order Routing product, and consequently the architecture, to support experimentation and analytics as first-class concepts. Originally published at https://www.thoughtworks.com on June 25, 2019. -- -- Essays on Technology, Innovation, Product Strategy and Leadership. Readers favorites and editors choices from ThoughtWorks Insights. A community of passionate individuals whose purpose is to revolutionize software design, creation and delivery, while advocating for positive social change. Title: Top Cloud Computing Technology News:
Subtitle: Written by Nancy Lee
Author: Nancy Lee
Article: Sign up Sign in Sign up Sign in Nancy Lee Follow -- Listen Share 7 Keys To Unlock The Perfect Enterprise Cloud Computing Systems: The applications of the cloud square measure increasing on the far side the horizons; the sole constant within the cloud computing material is its key characteristics. By acquainting themselves to those key characteristics, CIOs will hack into the implementation of cloud computing with ease. AWS was the pioneer within the full application of cloud computing as an alternative to on-premises infrastructure in 2006. Today, the cloud computing technology covers IaaS to SaaS and every one the services enclosed in between, such as AI, containers, serverless systems, databases, IoT, dedicated networking, analytics, business apps, and lots of others. Each subdivision has its distinctive edges and challenges, that square measure supported core options that underpin all the subsets. These square measure the seven key characteristics of cloud computing the CIOs ought to understand before customizing, deploying, and building the cloud into the most recent application of the company: The majority of the public cloud platforms provide resources to the users at the click of a button or through an API call. These vendors possess massive amounts of compute and storage assets on standby for immediate use, distributed among data centers all over the world. This not only monitors efficiency but also presents somewhat radical changes among the CIOs and their teams who are accustomed to long waiting periods for completion. 2. Self-Service Provisioning: Self-service provisioning works resourcefully with on-demand computing, avoiding wait times during the delivery of new servers to a private data center. Developers are also given the freedom to choose the tools and resources necessary to be built right away‚Ä¶‚Ä¶‚Ä¶ Read More Cloud Computing Exceeding Expectations: Cloud computing, over a previous couple of years, has big to become the expression in any type of business. World Health Organization would have thought that dynamical the approach we tend to store knowledge would have such an enormous impact on the approach we tend to do business. Cloud computing provides exciting new opportunities for corporations to expand and grow on a world scale. By providing secure access to your knowledge anyplace, anytime, cloud computing has established itself from startups to well-established organizations. Title: Holiday Gift Guide: Bitcoin Edition
Subtitle: Published in Tantra Labs
Author: Tantra Labs
Article: Sign up Sign in Sign up Sign in Tantra Labs Follow Tantra Labs -- 1 Listen Share The holiday season is a time for gathering with friends and family, but most importantly, it‚Äôs a great time to shill Bitcoin TO your friends and family! At Tantra Labs we love the holidays. The day after Halloween someone in the office lit a gingerbread-scented candle, and we‚Äôve been counting down the days until our office holiday party ever since... Every day though, it seems like a new list of ‚Äúgreat‚Äù holiday gifts pops up on the web, and while I will definitely be writing to Santa to ask for the new noise-cancelling airpods‚Ä¶ we thought it would be fun to come up with a list of gifts for all the bitcoiners, newcoiners, and precoiners in your lives. After polling the team at Tantra, here‚Äôs what we came up with: No surprise here! But how do you gift bitcoin to friends and family who are new to bitcoin or, how do we put this lightly.. friends and family who aren‚Äôt the most tech savvy? Our favorite method is with GiveBitcoin. With GiveBitcoin you can gift BTC to friends and family without having to worry about them losing it. That‚Äôs because GiveBitcoin time locks the BTC for at least a year (you can choose a longer time frame), and they will send your recipients a curated curriculum of educational resources from experts like Saifedean Ammous & Yan Pritzker, so your friends and family can learn not only why Bitcoin is important, but also how to safely secure it on their own when the timelock is up. Check them out. We are BIG fans. P.S. You can gift yourself Bitcoin too! So this category isn‚Äôt really about the person receiving gifts‚Ä¶ its about you! If you‚Äôre going to be buying gifts anyway, you should definitely take advantage of these awesome platforms and stack some sats: FoldApp.com ‚Äì Fold is an amazing platform and iOS & Android app that allows you to buy gift cards for major retailers like Amazon, Starbucks, Best Buy, and REI. You can pay using a credit/debit card, but if you pay in BTC using the Lightning Network, you get a much higher Sats Back reward. For advanced Bitcoin users, you can use SparkSwap to instantly convert the boomer bucks in your bank account to Lightning BTC. Using Fold also helps protect your privacy by shielding your transactions from retailers. Hell yeahü§ò And lastly.. Fold will be rolling out the ‚ÄúSend as a Gift‚Äù feature very soon, right in time for the Holidays. That means you can purchase a gift card, stack some sats, and Fold will send the gift cards to whoever you like. P.S. Use my code ‚ÄúO96Fvmsv‚Äù when you sign up and we both get 20,000 sweet, sweet sats! Lolli.com ‚Äì Lolli is another amazing way to earn sats on purchases you‚Äôre already going to be making. With hundreds of online retailers to choose from, you‚Äôd be doing yourself a disservice if you don‚Äôt check Lolli for holiday gifts before you make your purchases. Want to know what their best deals are? Check out their Ultimate Holiday Sats Back Gift Guide. Coldcard Wallet - Hands down the best hardware wallet for Bitcoiners. It isn‚Äôt as easy to use as a Ledger or Trezor, but if you‚Äôre a real Bitcoiner, the Coldcard is a must. Frankly it really isn‚Äôt that difficult to use, and you‚Äôll REALLY feel like a cypherpunk when you set it up. Our friends at Tales from the Crypt have a great video guide as well in case you need some extra hand-hodling. Casa Node 2 - With a sleek new redesign, the Casa Node 2 (part of every paid Casa membership) gives you everything you need to get started with running your own Bitcoin + Lightning node and multi-sig. ‚ÄúEverything you need to use, secure, and support Bitcoin in one easy package.‚Äù And when they say easy, they mean it. Their UI/UX is unparalleled. The Nodl One & Nodl Dojo - Sorry Casa, but in our opinion the Nodl nodes are a wee bit sexier than the Casa. But with more power and more memory, they‚Äôre also more expensive... These nodes are definitely for more advanced Bitcoin users, but they‚Äôre well worth it. For a longer lasting node, go for the Nodl Dojo, which comes with dual SSDs in a RAID configuration for backups & storage. Also it‚Äôs red. That means it‚Äôs faster. myNode One+ - In between the ‚Äúnode-in-a-box‚Äù options above and the ‚Äúbuild-your-own-node‚Äù below, is this nifty option from myNode. It includes the myNode Premium Software, Rock64 device, an aluminum case, power supply, SD Card, and 1TB hard drive. Check it out folks. Raspberry Pi 4 - Have a Bitcoiner in your family who‚Äôs been looking to build their own node from scratch? The Raspberry Pi 4 is the way to go. It‚Äôs actually what powers the new Casa node, and you can use it for all sorts of fun coding projects. Hook them up with the Raspberry Pi 4 CanaKit and they‚Äôll have almost everything they need to get started. Note that you should probably buy your soon-to-be node operator an external hard drive as well so he or she can download the full Bitcoin blockchain. And in terms of how to set up the node, we recommend the Raspibolt guide from Stadicus. GoTenna Mesh - Off-grid bitcoin transactions? Yes please! GoTenna‚Äôs mesh devices are a really unique gift. You can use them to send bitcoin transactions from off-the-grid, but they‚Äôre also fantastic for emergency situations, hiking, music festivals, or any other situation where internet and cell-service are spotty or just plain lacking. Lightnite ‚Äî This game is going to be so cool! Yes it‚Äôs a Fortnite clone, but it promises to be so much more than that. Play in ‚ÄúBitcoin-mode‚Äù and steal sats from your friends! There‚Äôll also be limited edition in-game items that you can steal from the enemies you‚Äôve vanquished in glorious low-poly battle! The game isn‚Äôt out yet, but you can preorder it now and be one of the first to play. CoinmineOne - You may not make a lot of money using this, (or you might!) and in some places where the cost of electricity is high, it may not be profitable to run it at all, but that being said, the CoinmineOne IS pretty damn SEXY and it‚Äôs a great conversation starter. We have one mining in our office, and I‚Äôd be lying if I said it wasn‚Äôt fun to open up the Coinmine App and watch the satoshi balance get higher and higher. Check it out if you‚Äôve got some extra boomer bucks to burn. And make sure you‚Äôre mining for bitcoins not shitcoins... Fun fact, when you mine for ‚Äúbitcoin‚Äù with the CoinmineOne it‚Äôs mining for shitcoins and auto-converting them to bitcoin for you, but this is actually good for Bitcoin as it creates sell pressure for those shitcoins. BitPiggys - For young and old alike, who wouldn‚Äôt want a cute little piggy bank tied to an Opendime? Perfect as a functional desk ornament for the bitcoiners in your lives or as a tool to teach anyone about bitcoin and saving. Bitcoin Money: A Tale of Bitville - Written by Michael ‚ÄúThe Bitcoin Rabbi‚Äù Caras, this illustrated children‚Äôs book is truly a joy to read. And it‚Äôs not just for kids. Without getting too technical, this book explores what money is and how Bitcoin really is better money. Get a discount when you order a 10-pack or a 30-pack, and drop these in your neighbors‚Äô mailboxes with a note from Santa Claus (or Hanukkah Harry!). We won‚Äôt tell on you.. Cryptosteel Capsule - This is one of the cooler private key storage solutions to come out of late. I‚Äôm personally not a huge fan of the tiled options out there, and I really love the aesthetics of the capsule. Their website states: ‚ÄúOur solution combines the age-old idea of engraving ‚Äî in a DIY assembly format ‚Äî with material that is stainless, shockproof, acid-resistant and fireproof up to 1400C/2500F. It is compatible with most secret sharing and key generation algorithms, and keeps the enclosed data secure. Even in cases of aggressive acts such as theft, bribery, vandalism or violence your master secret can remain safe forever.‚Äù Cryptotag Thor - Definitely one of the more expensive options, especially if you go with the Thor model that includes a hammer. But like come on, that‚Äôs a pretty rad hammer, and if you carry it with you maybe it can help fend off those $5 wrench attacks‚Ä¶ Regardless of the high price tag, you definitely get what you pay for here. This solution scored all A‚Äôs in Jameson Lopp‚Äôs latest metal bitcoin seed stress test. Crypto Key Stack - I‚Äôm a big fan of this option as well. As I mentioned earlier, I‚Äôm really NOT a fan of tiled options. They‚Äôre just a bit clunky in my opinion. Now granted, this option requires you to have good handwriting, but I like the ability to stack multiple private keys. That may not be the best thing to do for opsec reasons, but everyone‚Äôs threat models are different. And good to note, this option also scored top marks on Jameson Lopp‚Äôs earlier stress test. The Internet of Money (Volumes 1, 2 AND 3) - Part of the Bitcoin literature canon, this series from Andreas Antonopoulos compiles the best of his many talks, and no Bitcoin bookshelf is complete without them. And Volume 3 comes out on December 15th, right in time for Christmas. Pre-order it on Amazon today. The Bitcoin Standard - What is money? Why is our current system so screwed up? And how does Bitcoin fit into all of this? The Bitcoin Standard by Saifedean Ammous is one of the most popular books on Bitcoin and Austrian Economics, and for very good reason. It‚Äôs a fantastic primer on the history of money and how the current financial system came about. If you haven‚Äôt read this book yet‚Ä¶ can you really call yourself a bitcoiner? And for those who already have a copy or two on their shelves, another great gift to consider is Saifedean‚Äôs The Bitcoin Standard Academy, a series of very affordable online courses on Bitcoin and Austrian economics. Inventing Bitcoin - Yan Pritzker really hit it out of the park with this book. It‚Äôs short, only 111 pages, and it explains the underlying technology of Bitcoin in a way that is accessible to just about everyone. You may have to read it once or twice if you‚Äôre completely new to Bitcoin, but it‚Äôll be enjoyable every time. The Little Bitcoin Book - Written by some of the top names in the Bitcoin and human rights spaces, including Alena Vranova, Jimmy Song, and Alex Gladstein (and others!), this pocket sized book takes a more human approach to understanding the importance and potential of Bitcoin. Definitely a good gift for those folks who are new to Bitcoin or less tech savvy than most. Bitcoin Billionaires - From Ben Mezrich, the author of Bringing down the House and The Accidental Billionaires: The Founding of Facebook, Bitcoin Billionaires is a fantastic read that gives you a unique glimpse into the early days of Bitcoin. Step into the shoes of Charlie Shrem and Cameron and Tyler Winkelvoss. Learn about the early days of Bitinstant and experience Mark Zuckerburg‚Äôs treachery from the Winkelvoss‚Äô point of view. To be perfectly honest, The Social Network gave me a bad impression of the twins, but after reading Billionaires, I gained a newfound respect for them and their role in Bitcoin history. Highly recommend this book for bitcoiners & precoiners alike. LuchoPoletti.com - When it comes to Bitcoin propaganda art, Lucho Poletti really knows what he‚Äôs doing. Inspired by street artists like Shepard Fairey, Lucho sells an amazing array of artwork and apparel designed to make you rethink the world around you and look to Bitcoin for hope. Opendimes - From the same folks who make the Coldcard Wallet, get yourself some Opendimes immediately! They look like little USB drives, but they say ‚ÄúBitcoin‚Äù on them. What are they? Basically they are a way to store bitcoin and make offline transactions. You can load up an Opendime with some bitcoin using the public key, but the private key won‚Äôt be revealed until you poke a needle through a small hole on the back, popping out part of the hardware. It‚Äôs basically a bearer instrument for bitcoin. And the best part is they‚Äôre cheap and fit perfectly into your stockings. Also they have curved edges so they also fit nicely into ‚Äúnature‚Äôs stocking.‚Äù Bitcoin and Friends - What do you mean you haven‚Äôt watched Bitcoin and Friends yet?! Go to YouTube and binge all the episodes immediately, and then check out their merch shop here. All sorts of fun stocking stuffers to proudly rep Bitcoin and Friends. Rock on little man! You‚Äôll find your dad one day! 21X (formerly Bitcoin Outlet) - From the folks over at Bull Bitcoin, 21X puts out some of the coolest, limited edition Bitcoiner apparel out there. But be warned, they only accept Bitcoin. Don‚Äôt trust me though, check out their site and verify for yourself just how badass their merch is. Tales from the Crypt - ‚ÄúSup freaks?‚Äù Tales from the Crypt is one of the best Bitcoin podcasts out there. If you or your friends and family are fans of TFTC, why not support the pod by purchasing some quality merch? Bkawww! LayerOneBTC - Definitely one of our favorite Bitcoin merch sites. They put out so many clever t-shirts, you‚Äôll have trouble not buying all of them. From their ‚ÄúRunning Bitcoin‚Äù T, to their ‚ÄúCraig Wright is a Fraud‚Äù T‚Ä¶ LayerOneBTC has got you covered. Excellion.com - According to Samson Mow, ‚ÄúA hat is the first step on the path to self-discovery.‚Äù The exploration of the philosophical underpinnings of that idea deserves its own Medium article. So we won‚Äôt go any deeper than that just now. Either way, you can‚Äôt go wrong with this TOXIC hat. It glows in the dark and is guaranteed to make at least 21% of Twitter hate you. But only because deep down inside they know you‚Äôre right. VonBitcoin.com ‚Äî Last, but certainly not least‚Ä¶ a shameless plug for my own e-commerce site! I sell tons of Bitcoin-only apparel and gifts, including t-shirts, art prints, Bitcoin & Lightning ‚Äúnot‚Äù pop-sockets, and if you‚Äôre looking for something very special, contact me here for one-of-a-kind Bitcoin artwork. Thank you all for reading and we hope you found this holiday guide fun and helpful. From myself and the rest of the Tantra team, we wish you a very happy hodlday season! And if you think there is a Bitcoin product we should add to this list, please leave a comment below! ‚Äî Brekkie von Bitcoin, Creative Director at Tantra Labs Stay tuned as we present more thought pieces and our ongoing research! For more about Tantra Labs, check out our introductory post here. For more from Brekkie von Bitcoin, follow him on Twitter @BVTBC. To learn about the Triumvirate of Liquidity, read this article from Nik Bhatia. For a list of beginner Bitcoin recommendations, check out this article. Title: Cryptocurrency Mining ‚Äî Channeling Your Inner Tolkien Dwarf
Subtitle: Cryptocurrency
Author: Thomas Mallick
Article: Sign up Sign in Sign up Sign in Member-only story Thomas Mallick Follow The Capital -- Share Bitcoin, Bytecoin, Ethereum, Litecoin, Monero, Vertcoin, Electroneum, Dogecoin and whatever other ___coin is released in the future all structure themselves around the concept of mining. Cryptocurrency mining does not involve swinging a pickaxe in a poorly-lit, claustrophobia-inducing mineshaft. It does not require years of tutelage under the expert dwarf miners of Erebor. Quite the opposite ‚Äî cryptocurrency mining can be conducted from the comfort and safety of your own home. Hell, you could make some deviled eggs, garnish them, take your dog, Lucy, for a walk around the block, and proceed to eat those deviled eggs all while you mine for Bitcoin. Every time a cryptocurrency transaction takes place, a miner is responsible for ensuring its authenticity and updating the blockchain with the transaction. To do this, miners compete with each other to solve really complicated math problems. Imagine if the worst‚Ä¶ -- -- Educating and empowering readers on all things crypto and blockchain. Title: Introducing Blockchain-Powered Shopping App
Subtitle: Written by Younghyun Yi
Author: Younghyun Yi
Article: Sign up Sign in Sign up Sign in Younghyun Yi Follow -- Listen Share It‚Äôs a new year, it‚Äôs a new day, and we‚Äôre feeling good! Today (that‚Äôs 1st Jan) marks the official launch of QuuBe, Asia‚Äôs first online marketplace built on the blockchain. Launch festivities will last through the whole month of January, so download the app today (iOS / Android) to stay in touch with the latest promotions. Read on for more details! But first, for those who aren‚Äôt familiar, what is blockchain? In short, ‚Äúit is a digital ledger technology that creates permanent and unchangeable records‚Äù. This new form of accounting uses advanced forms of information distribution and consensus mechanisms. In other words, that means that 1) it is virtually impossible to change or delete recorded transactions, and 2) multiple verifications are made to confirm that the transaction is valid and legit. Check out this video for a more detailed explanation on the basics of blockchain technology. With that out of the way, we get to what QuuBe is: an online marketplace built with blockchain as its core. What does that mean for users, and why should you check it out? Buyers and sellers on QuuBe will transact via the platform‚Äôs own token, the Q*coin. Built on the Ethereum blockchain standard, your Q*coins are stored in a digital wallet built into the QuuBe app, and can only be accessed by you. Literally. You‚Äôll see that our set up process recommends for you to back up your Q*coin wallet password, because if you lose that password, it will be pretty much impossible for our support colleagues to unlock the wallet for you. It‚Äôs that secure. The Q*coin is also pegged to the value of the US Dollar, which ensures that a stable value is maintained, and makes an easy point of reference. Right now, the conversion rate for 1 Q*coin is 1 USD, with plans to appreciate the token‚Äôs value by increasing the conversion rate, as more Q*coins go into circulation. As a buyer, you can purchase Q*coins with no extra conversion fees, although prevailing currency exchange rates will apply. For the month of January, you will also enjoy a 10% introductory discount with every 100 Q*coins purchased (ie. you only pay 90 USD)! As a seller on the QuuBe platform, you will be able to list your items and sell them for no platform or service costs at all. You will also get to convert your earned Q*coins back to currency for no additional fees. How are all of these cost removals possible? The amount of administrative manpower required on conventional e-commerce websites, including Qoo10, means that charging platform fees and sales commissions are unavoidable if the business intends to survive in the longer term. A blockchain-based platform, on the other hand, is able to utilise smart contracts to digitally manage many of these administrations. Think of a smart contract as a will or rule book that automatically governs and executes a certain set of transactions and processes. Putting this automation in place greatly reduces the administrative manpower required, and consequently, its associated costs. QuuBe is open and ready to welcome you today! Through the month of January 2019 (ie. 1‚Äì31 Jan), QuuBe will be running various events and non-stop promotions to welcome new users to the platform. As part of this event, the team will be giving away a whopping total of 100,000 Q*coins (that‚Äôs worth USD 100,000!). Don‚Äôt miss out on your chance to score insane deals with QuuBe‚Äôs various auction types, spin our roulette wheel to win daily, and spend big to win even bigger prizes for being our top spenders! All you need to know about QuuBe can be found at its official website, QuuBe.xyz. You‚Äôll find guides there to sign up for a new account, and/or conveniently link with your existing Qoo10 account! For the most optimal shopping experience, remember to download the QuuBe app on iOS or Android. On the website or in-app, you will also find instructions on how you can purchase Q*coins. Payment methods are supported at launch are credit/debit cards, PayLah!, eNets, bank transfer, AXS machines, and 7-Eleven branches. More convenient methods will be added in time, so if you have any suggestions, we‚Äôd love to hear from you! The QuuBe team has been and still is working hard to bring your favourite products to the platform. Expect to shop from all of Asia‚Äôs most competitively priced gaming consoles, digital electronics & mobile accessories, home & living appliances, beauty bestsellers, and more. Check out the QuuBe launch event page on Qoo10 for more details on the latest giveaways, contests and promotions, and see you on the new side of e-commerce! <Qoo10 SG Blog ‚Äî http://blog.qoo10.sg/introducing-quube/> -- -- Introducing Blockchain Shopping App ‚Äî QuuBe Help Status About Careers Press Blog Privacy Terms Text to speech Teams

Title: Are You in the Moment?
Subtitle: Written by TA Sullivan
Author: TA Sullivan
Article: Sign up Sign in Sign up Sign in TA Sullivan Follow -- Listen Share How distracted are you, or do you even recognize the distractions anymore? I‚Äôm not speaking of the little interruptions that occur when you lose focus on a task. I‚Äôm speaking of the mindless tasks you complete every day without even recognizing for a moment what it is you‚Äôre doing. You scurry down the street toward your job focused on your phone, your email, or on all the things you‚Äôre going to say or do during the day. You don‚Äôt see the other people sharing the sidewalk with you; you fail to notice whether the sun is out or not; and you definitely have no idea of where you are or where you‚Äôre going. It‚Äôs all instinct and habit. But what if you let go of all the distractions and simply focused on the moment. What if you looked at your surroundings and actually took notice of the day? How much more interesting your day might be if you actually participated in it rather than drifted along, going from distraction to distraction? While going for a walk the other day, I actually took that advice. I put myself into the moment and was amazed at all the things I had been missing up to then. There was a hint of pink just lining the edge of the horizon. A deer raised its head and gazed stoically at me before resuming its grazing of the neighbor‚Äôs garden. A squirrel chittered overhead, unseen and hidden in the canopy of one of the nearby trees, and one of the neighbor‚Äôs cats slunk under the car, its green eyes following me as I strolled past. I wondered how often these creatures had been out there watching me as I marched through the numerous mornings ignoring everything around me while texting, tweeting, or checking my email. When at work, I often find myself disengaged because I‚Äôm too busy doing everything on automatic instead of actually thinking about the tasks I need to accomplish and what they entail. So many evenings I would get home and think, ‚ÄúI need a new job, this one is just so boring.‚Äù It seemed that my days were mechanical ‚Äî go in do the tasks, go home. Never anything different; never a change. But you know what? Sometimes, you don‚Äôt need a new job, you just need a new attitude, a new perspective. You may do your job out of habit right now, but that doesn‚Äôt mean you need a new job. If you actually look at each task and treat it as something new and unique, instead of just the same as yesterday‚Äôs tasks, you‚Äôll find yourself not only engaged, but perhaps even enjoying the days and the job a lot more. In today‚Äôs world, it is so easy to become distracted. We have cell phones that do everything from letting you watch television shows and movies, read books, text, tweet, and‚Ä¶oh yeah, even make and receive phone calls. We have cars that let us send and receive phone calls, texts, and watch movies; we have watches that link us to social media; and we have computers that keep us linked in, hooked up, and completely distracted wherever and whenever we want. And if all that technology fails to keep us distracted, we can do an excellent job of distracting ourselves by worrying about the past or the future instead of focusing on the here and now. So, unplug, disconnect, and stop worrying about what was and what might be, and simply focus on the what and when of now. Notice the people around you, listen to the sounds around you, and involve yourself with the events happening right now. It‚Äôs amazing how energized you‚Äôll feel when you do. -- -- TA Sullivan was born in the back of a cab and has continued to be unconventional in all that she does. She makes a living as a technical and marketing writer Help Status About Careers Press Blog Privacy Terms Text to speech Teams

Title: Time to Democratize Digital Transformation
Subtitle: Published in Purdue Engineering Review
Author: Purdue College of Engineering
Article: Sign up Sign in Sign up Sign in Purdue College of Engineering Follow Purdue Engineering Review -- Listen Share Until the advent of the PC, computing power was the domain of large companies that could afford massive mainframe computers. A similar dynamic is at work today, where entrepreneurs and small and medium-size enterprises can‚Äôt tap the latest technology because of cost. Larger companies all around the world are remaking themselves in a digital transformation, and the technology that enables this should be made available to their junior partners as well. This is critical for today‚Äôs worldwide supply chains, which, along with globalization and e-commerce, have emerged as one of the most core and critical competencies in the modern world. A global supply chain now spans the planet, with suppliers that produce needed parts, components and subassemblies providing them to product manufacturers for assembly into their finished goods. These larger manufacturers have invested heavily in digital transformation ‚Äî like digital simulation, to prove things out beforehand by modeling a digital replica ‚Äî and enterprise-wide digital makeovers are sweeping across industry after industry globally. Yet many organizations in their supply chains lack the resources to become full partners in these digital ecosystems. I chose the word ‚Äúdemocracy‚Äù to suggest that all participants in an industrial supply chain should have ‚Äúequal‚Äù access to this important technology. This access would bring benefits not only to the supply chain member but also to the larger manufacturer, as the small firms would now have the tools to innovate performance and cost gains in their particular corners of the supply chain. Right now, the benefits to the haves greatly disadvantage the have-nots. Using tools like digital simulation, the haves are able to explore the possibilities of a wide variety of manufacturing materials and processes without having to develop the real manufacturing system. This means that more alternatives can be considered ‚Äî and more risk reduced ‚Äî before the decisions are made to invest in the physical assets necessary to execute an optimal manufacturing strategy. Small and medium-size businesses have been the have-nots, relying on the trial-and-error methods of the past ‚Äî because the requisite investments in new simulation platforms, and supporting personnel fluent in the digital enterprise, are substantial, and beyond their means. Purdue University is tackling this problem with a ‚Äúvirtual factory hub,‚Äù which will make advanced modeling and simulation tools available via a simple web browser and cloud services platform. This browser-based system with cloud computing will put the power of digital tools into the hands of engineers at smaller and medium-size companies ‚Äî no matter their location or computer assets ‚Äî so they can simulate different manufacturing strategies to predict how each will perform in actual use, in such industries as automotive, aerospace, and clean energy. Our Composites Virtual Factory Hub at the Institute for Advanced Composites Manufacturing Innovation (IACMI) is investigating browser- and cloud-based delivery of ‚Äúdigital twins‚Äù ‚Äî simulated, digital duplicates of manufacturing processes like additive manufacturing (3D printing), molding, and forming, which have been tailored for these high-tech combinatorial materials. Others are trying something similar in different sectors ‚Äî for example, nanoHUB.org hosts simulation tools for nanoscale technology research, education and collaboration. One of the biggest issues in business today is how to bring supply chain members into the larger digital enterprise, to close the loop on the complete digital transformation that is required for modernization and competitiveness. The democratization of innovative technologies like digital simulation will be a giant step forward toward achieving that aim. by R. Byron Pipes, John L. Bray Distinguished Professor of Engineering; Member of the National Academy of Engineering; Executive Director of the Composites Manufacturing Simulation Center, Purdue University -- -- Pioneering groundbreaking technology, unlocking revolutionary ideas and advancing humankind across the country, planet and universe. Explore how leading educators, thinkers and innovators at the Purdue University College of Engineering are shaping the future‚Ää‚Äî‚Ääand beyond. Title: EU Event Charts a Course on Digital Policy
Subtitle: Published in Issues Decoded
Author: Anna Tobur
Article: Sign up Sign in Sign up Sign in Anna Tobur Follow Issues Decoded -- Listen Share Digital Assembly emphasises individual and consumer concerns Written by: Laurent Chokouale Datou, Chairman, EU Public Affairs, Anna Tobur, Account Director, and Claudia Trivilino, Manager at Weber Shandwick Brussels Digital Assembly, one of the European Union‚Äôs largest tech policy events, recently took place in Bucharest, Romania. This year, the conference focused on the EU‚Äôs long-term strategic priorities in the digital space and uncovered likely drivers for policy agendas over the 2019‚Äì2024 term. Three points to keep in mind: Policy trends to watch: As with other large-scale phenomena, the EU will have an important role in guiding technology-related regulatory processes to ensure change is embraced effectively. Setting a more ethics and values-based approach to legislation, the EU will be able to distinguish itself from the rest of the world. If you would like any further information on this issue, please do not hesitate to get in contact with LAURENT CHOKOUAL√â DATOU Chairman, EU Public Affairs lchokouale@webershandwick.com Article edited by Jennifer Shang -- -- Weber Shandwick‚Äôs Public Affairs thought leadership platform, Issues Decoded, offers insight from a deep bench of Public Affairs strategists with issue-specific, political campaign and integrated media expertise from over 35 markets and every major capitol around the world.
