Title: This Hacked-Together Raspberry Pi Laptop Is the Essence of Cyberpunk
Subtitle: Written by Cameron Coward
Author: Cameron Coward
Article: Sign up Sign in Sign up Sign in Cameron Coward Follow -- 5 Listen Share When people talk about the ‚Äúcyberpunk‚Äù style these days, they‚Äôre usually saying something glows. Get a green mohawk, throw on a studded leather jacket, and make something light up, and boom ‚Äî cyberpunk! But the true spirit of cyberpunk, as it goes back to its literary origins, is in hacked tech. Real cyberpunk is a bunch of futuristic tech smashed together to do something new. Imgurian Keyofnight‚Äôs Cyberpunk Laptop fits the latter definition perfectly. Take a quick look at this laptop and you‚Äôll immediately see why. Every component, down to the individual keyboard key caps, looks mismatched and hacked-together. Circuit boards are exposed, and everything is mounted inside a vintage wood Mahjong case. Despite the purposefully-crude construction, it somehow manages to be both incredibly stylistic and utilitarian. It looks cobbled-together ‚Äî but with a purpose, and that‚Äôs the true essence of cyberpunk. Style aside, this is a pretty useful build. The heart of the laptop is a Raspberry Pi 3 Model B+, and the screen is an Adafruit 5" LCD connected by HDMI. It‚Äôs powered by a 12,000mAh LiPo battery through an Adafruit Powerboost 1000C. The unique keyboard is based on /u/pyrocrastinator‚Äôs Alpha PCB. Most importantly, it has a Pimoroni Phat Stack board for doing some actual hacking on the go. If you want a real cyberpunk laptop, this is the build to emulate. -- -- 5 Author, writer, maker, and a former mechanical designer. www.cameroncoward.com @cameron_coward Help Status About Careers Press Blog Privacy Terms Text to speech Teams

Title: What I learned at Blockchance 2019 in Hamburg
Subtitle: Top 10 Blockchain Courses for 2019 | Data Driven Investor
Author: Dennis Hillemann
Article: Sign up Sign in Sign up Sign in Dennis Hillemann Follow DataDrivenInvestor -- Listen Share Blockchain is not about money. It‚Äôs about change. I left the Blockchain convention in Hamburg (Blockchance, 17th-18th of August) both impressed and motivated. Impressed not only on the sheer number of attendees but because how much the technology has evolved. As a lawyer working in the Public Sector, it‚Äôs a challenge to keep track of what is possible and what is already done through blockchain. What might come naturally to ‚ÄûTechies‚Äú in this regard, I can learn and understand from listening to great speakers explaining the advancement in excellent overviews (and Blockchance 2019 sure had quite a few of them). www.datadriveninvestor.com However, it left me even more motivated. I‚Äôm interested in the way blockchain can change our society, our governmental organizations, maybe even the way we think and act on so many levels. The financial aspects of blockchain, especially making money with cryptocurrencies, are of little interest to me and my daily work. Therefore I‚Äôm always a little skeptical when attending such a conference, as it sometimes appears to me as if it is all about shaking the gold pot. Blockchance wasn‚Äôt. Think big and change the world Many speakers, among them the charismatic thought-leader Marc Buckley (UN SDG advocate), sent out a message to the audience. We can change the world with blockchain technology, and to do so, we all must change our minds. Marc Buckley underlined that technology could do so much more, and we use so little of ist potential so far. Astronauts travel to the moon using state-of-the-art technology but must claim their expenses filling out a paper formula after the trip. His story reminded me, even while I don‚Äôt do space-travel, very much of the places I‚Äôve worked: using state-of-the-art technology in some aspects and also counseling on it, but not going that final step to digitize my work and that of others entirely. What more could I have achieved for others and myself if I only changed my mind on things? If we find this phenomenon on a company level, where it‚Äôs all about reducing costs and being efficient, how much do we have of this on administration and governmental level? I know from my work in the Public Sector first hand: A lot, a whole lot. What would happen if we change our approach if we fully digitize procedures, files, supply chains, and everything else? So to speak: if we digitize the very way we think about the world? What if we embrace technology, do not see a threat in it, and go all the way? The Deloitte key speaker Nicolai Andersen made a good statement on people‚Äôs fear towards technology, here concerning AI technology. We discuss the fear of being run over by an AI-driven car with all our heart, but not the chances such cards offer. Just think of older people living in small villages, for who every trip tot he doctor is a hard challenge. What good could the AI-driven car do for them? It feels as if people prefer to be run over by a human than by a robot. So what can we do? Let us stop pondering all the threats technology can offer at first impression: Let us first think of all the possibilities, let us dream, let us think big, and then address all the possible miss-uses/dual-use cases and the inherent problems. However, let us first think of technology as a real problem solver for the world. I believe this is where Marc and other speakers were pointing us towards, and I like the direction. Recently I read this great article by Renee Yang: ‚ÄûBlockchain needs selfless people.‚Äú Many speakers proved that this is precisely the mindset they are living out, not only the before mentioned Marc Buckley but also speakers like Dr. Juie Maupin from IOTA or Albert Peci from Blockchance. I enjoyed this mindset: Let us embrace technology to make the world better for all beings. How does blockchain fit into this? About cooperation and transparency Quite a few speakers lined out that blockchain technology can‚Äôt solve all problems. Nearly everyone lined out: Blockchain technology isn‚Äôt good or bad, nor selfless, nor evil. Only people are and the way we want to use blockchain. We must use it fort he common good. Blockchain offers great possibilities, in its decentralized technology, in ist neutrality and its transparency. It can boost cooperation, between national and international organizations, between people and companies, because as the transactions within the collaboration become transparent and secure, trust arises. As someone who has written many cooperation contracts in the Public Sector, knowing how every party is worried about being taken advantage of, I can embrace this idea wholeheartedly. If cooperations can work better through blockchain technology, the world will become a better place naturally. Because wherever people work together and trust each other, there will be less hate and cheating. Moreover, cooperations in the Public Sector are necessary, to challenge climate change, to challenge hunger and poverty, to challenge migration risks and criminal behavior on a global scale. The omnipresent Facebook‚Äòs Libra Facebook‚Äôs Libra was a big subject as well. It did not come as a surprise when even I had published on that matter. I did, however, not experience the usual disdain towards Facebook that I usually encounter when talking about this subject. Some speakers and attendees underlined that Libra could also offer a strong possibility to the blockchain community, as it could lead to a mass-adoption of blockchain technology worldwide and address underbanked people. Those speakers of course also questioned if Libra is a cryptocurrency at all, or even if we can call it a blockchain solution, as it is neither decentralized nor neutral. Most speakers and people I talked to, however, agreed that the whitepaper on Libra was just a ‚Äûtry and error‚Äú-approach, meaning Facebook published it to see the reactions on that matter worldwide and then adjust to it once it comes to concrete adoption. We also discussed the question if others, such as Amazon, are not sitting back right now, letting Facebook do all the dirty work and then come up with their neat solutions once the path has been made clear by Zuckerberg & Co. I found this very differentiated discussion on Libra quite refreshing. The big company world Nonetheless, the big company world was visible too at Blockchance, at least from a German point of view. Moritz von Bonin from Deutsche Bahn (the national ‚Äûtrain company,‚Äú so to peak) gave a very thoughtful presentation on the possibilities of blockchain concerning the railway system, and it was good to hear that even this very conservative Germans company is looking into the technology. To no surprise came to me that the most prominent German car companies, Volkswagen, Daimler, and BMW, are very interested in the technology, as autonomous driving won‚Äôt ‚Äì from my point of view ‚Äì be possible without blockchain or another distributed ledger technology. What interested me as a lawyer though was the fact that the car companies addressed the following issue: The representatives of the companies did not argue the idea that a mutual blockchain solution would be the best option, as a ‚ÄûVolkswagen blockchain‚Äú parallel to a ‚ÄûDaimer blockchain‚Äú does not make sense at all, as it speaks against all what autonomous driving does need. However, and here‚Äôs the exciting part, anti-trust regulations in Germany and the European Union might even forbid that the companies talk at all about a standard mutual solution. For me, this is a typical example of how ‚ÄûLaws from the analog times‚Äú might prevent digital advancement that is in the common interest. We must change this in Germany and Europe. Asap. Be a visionist The Tron Europe representative Frank Schulze said something that stuck with me: When it comes to blockchain, be a visionist. I like this. Of course, I can‚Äôt claim that I am one, but we can all try to develop the mindset of one: Let us think big. Let us imagine a world in that blockchain technology plays a significant role to make things better for everyone. Don‚Äôt le tour fears or worries stop us from making the first step: Imagine how everything can be changed through blockchain, not to make money, but to make the world a better place. Would love for you to connect. Follow me on Medium, visit my website http://theblockchain.lawyer or connect on LinkedIn. -- -- empowerment through data, knowledge, and expertise. subscribe to DDIntel at https://ddintel.datadriveninvestor.com Lawyer and partner with a track record of successful litigation and a passion for innovation in the legal field Help Status About Careers Press Blog Privacy Terms Text to speech Teams

Title: Freedom, Equality, Technology
Subtitle: Written by Olivier
Author: Olivier
Article: Sign up Sign in Sign up Sign in Olivier Follow -- Listen Share Freedom and equality are often contradictory. Societies are defined in large part by which one they chose. The U.S. made the choice of freedom. The government keeps out of people‚Äôs lives, mostly. Taxes are also much lesser than in Europe. Which means more freedom. And more inequalities. Europe made the other choice. Taxes are high and the government is everywhere. Which means less freedom. But also a true safety net and more equality. The future, starting today, will force us to make the ultimate choice between freedom (i.e. ‚Äúprivacy‚Äù), and equality. Because data is the most valuable commodity. But data, especially the gold mine that‚Äôs our personal information, is owned by just a few companies. These companies generate tremendous profits and unprecedented economic efficiencies. Which makes them rich, but which also leaves the rest of the world with not so much to share. The fact that data ownership is so concentrated creates huge inequalities. Little privacy for big inequalities. The other choice would be that data belongs to no one. Every bit of information is public. Very little privacy. Very little freedom to act without everyone knowing about it. But also much equality. Would you rather everyone know about your sexual inadequacies and stop worrying about money? Or have just a few huge companies know about these inadequacies, because Alexa overheard what‚Äôs going on in your bedroom, but maybe not be able to make a living? That‚Äôs the choice that we have to make today. It might determine the kind of society we‚Äôll be living in tomorrow. -- -- Meditation Enthusiast / Wannabe Athlete / Psychedelic Adventurer / Work in Progress Help Status About Careers Press Blog Privacy Terms Text to speech Teams

Title: QURAS And Its Privacy Technology
Subtitle: Written by qurasofficial
Author: qurasofficial
Article: Sign up Sign in Sign up Sign in qurasofficial Follow -- Listen Share QURAS utilizes the two leading privacy technologies, ring signatures and zero-knowledge proofs, to give network users options in the way that confidentiality is handled within the transactions. Readers should refer to the Quras technical whitepaper for details on the mechanics of implementation. Transparent addresses work similarly to what is implemented on Bitcoin. The private key is generated randomly first out of the key pair, and the public key is then derived using Elliptic Curve Cryptography (ECC). QURAS uses a secp256r1 standard for its public key generation, which is enforced by organizations such as the NSA. Although Bitcoin uses the secp256k1 standard for its key pair generation, QURAS uses an alternative as an extra measure of security. Users can choose between two industry-leading private transaction methods, zk-SNARKs (zero-knowledge proofs) and ring signatures. The former is considered as a more robust method of privacy; however, will consume more system resources to produce the result. Thus, the second option of Ring Confidential Transactions is offered to give users an option of fast and light anonymous transactions. To accommodate for these transaction types, users can generate the appropriate keys to construct the transactions ‚Äî spend, receiving, viewing, anonymous and stealth keys. The QURAS blockchain includes a virtual machine layer, which users can use to deploy smart contracts written in C#, a widely adopted programming language.7 Developers can utilize two key functions within their contract code ‚Äî zero-knowledge proof and validation methods. These functions are general purpose and can be implemented in the contract code for a wide variety of use cases. As these privacy methods are merely functions, developers freely choose to use them in order to create transparent or secret contracts. Whenever a user calls (interacts) with a smart contract, QURAS GAS is consumed. There are two types of anonymous transactions ‚Äî complete anonymity and partial anonymity. Completely Anonymous Transaction means all transaction information will be hidden including sender‚Äôs address, recipient‚Äôs address, remitted amount, etc. A Partly Anonymous Transaction means a part of transaction information such as the sender‚Äôs address, recipient address or remittance amount is hidden. A Part Anonymous Transaction uses zk-SNARKs or the ring signature technology to realize the anonymous effect. For more details, please refer to the technical paper. -- -- Secret Contract Platform for Privacy 2.0 Help Status About Careers Press Blog Privacy Terms Text to speech Teams

Title: Growing Demand of Industrial Oil Segment in Bangladesh
Subtitle: Written by Zulker Naeen
Author: Zulker Naeen
Article: Sign up Sign in Sign up Sign in Zulker Naeen Follow -- Listen Share By Zulker Naeen Keeping pace with the automotive sector, the demand for industrial oil is eyeing exponential growth in Bangladesh. And the oil players have already established their footprints in this segment. Also, the growing industrial sector is on the way of setting up efficient machinery to be used in the factories. The demand from the industrial machinery and equipment application also accounts for a major market share and is driven by the end-user sectors such as power, manufacturing, logistics, automotive manufacturing, and others. The growth of the power sector has already highlighted the industrial oil in our country. With the prospective textile sector, the untapped industries which are yet to explore are steel manufacturing, cement, and the growing plastic. And in the near future, the manufacturing of automotive vehicles and motorcycles will create the opportunity for the marketer. To know the current status of it, we tried to find out the key barriers that are facing by the marketer. With extensive working experience in the industrial arena, Rajat Chakraborty, Assistant General Manager to Runner Lube and Energy Limited, said, ‚ÄúWe mostly face the short cummings on technical knowledge among the user end.‚Äù Most of the case, it has been observed that the operators of the production unit of the factories use OEM product until the warranty period of the machinery, which is recommended by the manufacturer. But after that, the operators have a tendency to change the brand to save a little amount of money. In this regard, Mr Rajat said, ‚ÄúUnfortunately, we found that to save a little amount of money for purchasing the oil, you are playing with the lifespan of your machine.‚Äù ‚ÄúImmediately, you aren‚Äôt facing any trouble. But in the long run, the lifespan of your highly expensive machinery is in threat,‚Äù he added. Currently, industrial oil segment holds the third-largest demand after mineral-based monograde segment and automotive-based multi-grade segment. With an estimated annual consumption of around 45,000 tonnes in 2018 that is projected to reach the 52,500 marks by 2019. This industrial sector accounts for around 30% of the total lubricant oil consumption. -- -- South Asia Fellow at Climate Tracker Help Status About Careers Press Blog Privacy Terms Text to speech Teams

Title: El Ecosistema del Blockchain
Subtitle: Written by Telos Feed ES
Author: Telos Feed ES
Article: Sign up Sign in Sign up Sign in Telos Feed ES Follow -- Share El blockchain no es solo un protocolo o un sistema de programaci√≥n, sino que es considerado como un ecosistema; como tal, est√° compuesto por una serie de elementos que interact√∫an entre s√≠ y con los usuarios permitiendo un funcionamiento √≥ptimo de la plataforma. Los elementos principales de este ecosistema son el registro compartido, la aplicaci√≥n de nodos, la m√°quina virtual y el algoritmo de consenso. A continuaci√≥n se describir√° cada uno y c√≥mo es la interacci√≥n entre ellos. El registro, o libro mayor, es un t√©rmino originario del mundo de la contabilidad definido como ‚Äúun documento que recoge de manera cronol√≥gica todas las operaciones contables de la empresa registradas en cada una de las cuentas‚Äù (Economipedia). En el ecosistema del blockchain este t√©rmino fue tomado para denominar as√≠ a su base de datos o registro; √©sta es compartida, replicada y sincronizada a trav√©s de los usuarios de una red descentralizada (en el caso de la red del blockchain). Dichos usuarios, o m√°s espec√≠ficamente nodos, se encuentran a cargo de grabar transacciones entre pares o P2P (datos din√°micos) y registros (datos est√°ticos) al mismo tiempo que mantienen toda la informaci√≥n disponible para los dem√°s usuarios. En Telos Blockchain estos nodos son conocidos como productores de bloque (BPs) o testigos. Un registro compartido tiene tambi√©n el beneficio de no requerir de intermediarios, lo cuales normalmente cobran honorarios y centralizan el sistema. Al mismo tiempo este registro hace eficiente el almacenamiento de datos al evitar el duplicado de la informaci√≥n y su distribuci√≥n errada a trav√©s de los usuarios; esto ahorra tiempo y dinero. Para poder garantizar la seguridad y auditabilidad de las transacciones almacenadas en el registro, cada transacci√≥n tiene una marca de tiempo y es marcada con una firma criptogr√°fica √∫nica. En Telos, cada BP y auditor tiene su firma propia registrada en un contrato inteligente, respectivamente en el ‚Äúregproducer‚Äù y el ‚Äúregarb‚Äù. De esta manera cada transacci√≥n validada y registrada lleva una firma de los nodos que la autorizaron. Este procedimiento permite la inmutabilidad del sistema, lo que es una de sus principales caracter√≠sticas, y es clave para mantener la seguridad del sistema para los usuarios. Esto es garantizado gracias al procedimiento de validaci√≥n y registro de transacciones: criptogr√°ficamente, cronol√≥gicamente y √∫nicamente luego de ser aprobado por los nodos, dependiendo del consenso de algoritmo del sistema. De esta manera se previenen los cambios al bloque luego que la transacci√≥n ha sido completamente validada y la siguiente est√© en proceso de validaci√≥n. Inclusive, si alguien intenta hacer alg√∫n cambio en un bloque, todo quedar√≠a registrado. En el blockchain, la principal caracter√≠stica de seguridad, y b√°sicamente lo que permite a este tipo de sistemas existir de forma descentralizada, son los algoritmos de consenso. Estos mecanismos a prueba de fallas se utilizan en el blockchain para unificar las decisiones de los nodos, o sus contribuciones, respecto a las transacciones, de esta manera valid√°ndolas o no. Es por esto que se les llama algoritmos o mecanismos de consenso; son utilizados para alcanzar un consenso entre los nodos para validar transacciones, producir bloques y asegurarse que el funcionamiento de la red sea continua y segura. Este funcionamiento es de gran importancia para mantener la seguridad del registro compartido y mantenerlo disponible para todos los usuarios, al mismo tiempo que se evitan los duplicados. Actualmente, existen tres principales mecanismos de consenso aplicados por las redes de blockchain: Proof of Work (PoW), Proof of Stake (PoS) y Delegated Proof of Stake (DPoS). Por ejemplo, Bitcoin, Ethereum y Litecoin usan PoW, NXT usa PoS y tanto EOS como Telos usan el mecanismo m√°s novedoso: DPoS. En el protocolo de consenso PoW la red est√° compuesta por nodos, o mineros en este caso, que se encargan de validar y registrar las transacciones en la cadena. Para lograrlo, estos deben tener grandes recursos computacionales para resolver c√°lculos complejos para producir el bloque, el minero que resuelva el √∫ltimo valor del hash es el que recibe la recompensa. Debido al creciente n√∫mero de mineros, la dificultad del algoritmo para resolver los hash es cada vez m√°s compleja, por lo que dichos mineros requieren recursos computacionales cada vez mayores para resolverlos. Esto √∫ltimo trae como consecuencia que minar sea cada vez m√°s costoso y haya m√°s consumo de energ√≠a. En el mecanismo PoS no existen mineros, sino BPs, quienes son seleccionados dependiendo del n√∫mero total de tokens que poseen; mientras m√°s tokens tengan mayor ser√° el n√∫mero de bloques sobre los cuales podr√°n trabajar. Este m√©todo nace como una alternativa al PoW, ofreciendo menores costos de operaci√≥n y menor consumo de energ√≠a. El registro es mantenido por estos usuarios seleccionados; sin embargo, este sistema gener√≥ lo que se conoce como ballenas; usuarios con grandes cantidades de tokens a comparaci√≥n del resto, son los seleccionados para validar bloques, lo que les da m√°s poder para decidir sobre el sistema. En respuesta a este inconveniente, se comienza a implementar el mecanismo DPoS. En √©l, los BPs son seleccionados por todos los token holders a trav√©s de un sistema de votaci√≥n. Por eso, los BPs tienen que demostrarle a la comunidad que son merecedores de su voto al desempe√±arse exitosamente en su rol de validadores de transacciones, producci√≥n de bloques y mantenimiento general del mainnet y los testnets. En el caso de Telos, el sistema de votaci√≥n tiene una ponderaci√≥n inversa; esto significa que el peso del voto de un usuario depende de la cantidad de votos que emita. Cada token holder tiene un n√∫mero m√°ximo de candidatos a BP por los que puede votar, si votan por esa cantidad total de candidatos su voto alcanza su valor total; si por otro lado emiten menos votos, el peso del mismo disminuye. Este sistema evita votos favorables y propicia un alto rendimiento de los BPs. A continuaci√≥n se muestra una comparaci√≥n de los diferentes algoritmos de consenso. La m√°quina virtual fue definida por primera vez en 1974 por dos cient√≠ficos computistas: Gerald J. Popek y Robert P. Goldberg. Ellos la definieron como ‚Äúun eficiente y aislado duplicado de una computadora real‚Äù. B√°sicamente se trata de un emulador de una computadora que puede correr software o hardware para ejecutar programas en un ambiente virtual. En blockchain, Ethereum fue la primera plataforma en adoptar la m√°quina virtual dentro de su ecosistema y la llamaron M√°quina Virtual de Ethereum (EVM por sus siglas en ingl√©s), la cual permite a los usuarios programar sus propias operaciones o transacciones. La idea era correr un protocolo a trav√©s de una red P2P para operar como el backend y as√≠ ejecutar acciones (como contratos inteligentes escritos en lenguajes de programaci√≥n) y potenciar las Dapps, mientras el computador f√≠sico es operado por los nodos. El EVM, por ejemplo, se encarga espec√≠ficamente de confirmar la validez de las firmas y los valores en una transacci√≥n, calcular los cargos por la transacci√≥n y ejecutar la transferencia requerida en dicha transacci√≥n. Con las m√°quinas virtuales los desarrolladores pueden correr sus Dapps sin requerir de instalaci√≥n o contrataci√≥n de servidores. Todo el RAM, las transacciones y el almacenamiento de los datos se realizan en el blockchain; este proceso es seguido en Telos Blockchain. √âste est√° construido con la m√°quina virtual de EOSIO conocida como WAVM, es la m√°quina virtual de WebAssmebly (WASM). Los contratos inteligentes son escritos en C++ y luego compilados y ejecutados con WASM, que es un formato binario capaz de ejecutar una variedad de lenguajes de programaci√≥n tales como Python, Ruby y Java. El WAVM se caracteriza por una m√°quina de pila (o stack machine) basada en un sistema de apilamiento last-in, first-out y un programa contador. Este sistema de apilamiento lo permite ser un objeto de c√≥digo compacto, con compiladores simples, interpretadores simples y control de flujo f√°cil. Por √∫ltimo, la aplicaci√≥n de nodo es el software a trav√©s del cual el usuario (nodo) se comunica con su computadora a la red del blockchain y al registro compartido. La m√°quina virtual y el consenso de algoritmo forman parte de la aplicaci√≥n de nodos mientras el registro compartido est√° almacenado en la misma. ‚ÄúEn un √°mbito un poco m√°s t√©cnico, el ecosistema del blockchain constituye una red superpuesta de servicios (SON por sus siglas en ingl√©s) y para ser un nodo en esta red tu computadora debe ser capaz de procesar mensajes espec√≠ficos de la aplicaci√≥n de nodos que afectan el estado compartido del SON‚Äù No est√° dem√°s entonces decir que la aplicaci√≥n de nodos es para el ecosistema del blockchain como la tierra lo es para nuestro ecosistema. -- -- Vimos el futuro y luce como una nuez. Help Status About Careers Press Blog Privacy Terms Text to speech Teams

Title: Where to start with UX design?
Subtitle: An introduction to how we design and build user-centered experiences
Author: Mart√≠n Pettinati
Article: Sign up Sign in Sign up Sign in Mart√≠n Pettinati Follow manas.tech -- Listen Share In this context of sharing economies, empowered users and the ‚ÄúInternet of ratings‚Äù (don‚Äôt google that, I just made the term up), we see a rise of experts, thought leaders and consultants talking about the ever-growing relevance of the User Experience. This article is meant to give you an introduction to UX design: an approach to what takes place during the process of designing experiences; ones that take into account what we want our users to feel like when interacting with our products and services. But not just any generic approach to UX design: this is Manas.tech‚Äôs own way to tackle it. Paraphrasing the Rifleman‚Äôs Creed, ‚Äúthere are many like it; but this one is ours‚Äù. If you‚Äôve been working in UX for a while, this article probably won‚Äôt bring you any kind of epiphany, but I find it‚Äôs always nice to share how one does things as a way to maybe expand someone else‚Äôs knowledge, give them a fresh point of view, or get feedback that allows us to improve. So here goes. User-centered design means working with your users all throughout the project. - Don Norman Often, when reading case studies, it‚Äôs common to find that they narrate the process of developing a tool or system like if things just magically fell into place. After reading those accounts, one is often left to wonder ‚Äúwell.. yeah, but how exactly did they do it?‚Äù. Usually, no answer is provided. This article strives to do just the opposite. There are two basic principles to good design, as described by Don Norman, in his book ‚ÄúThe Design of Everyday Things‚Äù: In short, good design is intuitive and interactive: users shouldn‚Äôt have to wonder what to do next, or where to find things, and every time they interact with a tool, they should have a way to know that their action was received, and that something happened because of it. Building a great User Experience (UX) requires understanding the users, their mindsets, what they are trying to accomplish (their jobs-to-be-done), and the environmental constraints they operate within. Good questions to always keep in mind are ‚Äúwhat is this for?‚Äù, ‚Äúwho is this for?‚Äù, and ‚Äúwhy did we put this here?‚Äù. The first question helps you focus on the purpose of what you‚Äôre building, what it will do for the user; the second question one helps you keep the user in mind, how their experience will be affected by your intervention; and the third one is a reminder of the decisions that were made every step along the way. This last question is also a way to ensure that whatever you are building stays as lean as possible, and that you don‚Äôt waste time or resources: if you ask ‚Äúwhy did we put this here?‚Äù and can‚Äôt come up with a good, satisfying answer, maybe you should re-evaluate whether it should go there. The emotions that users experience when they interact with the thing you‚Äôve built largely determine the way they think about it, and how they evaluate it. That is why it‚Äôs important to design and build the User Experience with intent. If you can manage to get that right, you can trust that your users will have a delightful experience, and thus they‚Äôll be delighted with your product. At Manas.tech, our approach to this is simple and straightforward: we start with a concrete user, who is affected by a concrete problem, and every effort we put into it is directed towards helping the user solve their problem or some aspect of their problem, with as little friction as possible for them. The first mission is getting to know the user. It‚Äôs already been said a bunch of times and you‚Äôve probably heard it before. But it‚Äôs never enough. Get. To. Know. Your. Users. There are two main ways to tackle this part: It may sound counterintuitive to hold an interview with stakeholders before interviewing actual users, but it is fundamental to understand the stakes of the project, and the change the team is trying to make in the world. Also, the stakeholders are the best source of information to get a grip on the project‚Äôs constraints: how much time, budget and support we can count on. This will produce a Findings Document, that will be of great use when we get to the user interviews. Interviews with users will ideally be performed on-site, ethnographically, and there we will put our findings to the test, and lay the groundwork for the next step: building Personas. In case you‚Äôve never heard the term, ‚ÄòPersonas‚Äô is a documentation tool. Though it may sound like one should attempt to depict users as accurately as possible, it is an exercise intended to understand and describe the needs, goals and motivations of a prototypic user. Once we have our Personas in place, we can begin to craft short stories about them trying to achieve their goals or get a job done, by using our tool in their context. These are what we call Scenarios, and they are useful to imagine how each Persona will interact with our tool in real life. Once we have researched our users in depth, built Personas and had them play out in Scenarios, we can make some educated guesses about the way our tool will be received and used. Still, no guess is as good as the real thing, so the best thing we can do is build a preliminary version of the tool and have some users play with it. Let‚Äôs see how this works in a real project. Brium is a tool we built for ourselves, and it has a very simple yet meaningful mission: it tracks the time that each member of your team spends on different activities, by asking them, via chat, what they are doing. A couple of words a day is all it needs to provide accurate timesheets. It all started out with a fairly simple problem: how can we improve the way we bill our clients for the work that we do? On one hand, we need to know how people are spending their time, since that information is what we use to bill our clients. The usual approach to billing for worked hours is making people fill out timesheets. But, as we know, everyone hates timesheets: most times they don‚Äôt get filled out in the moment, but at the end of the week or the month, and that leaves a lot of room for error; how are people supposed to remember what they did 4 days ago, or how long they were at it? So, improvement meant collecting this information faster, more accurately, and with less dependency on human action. Put in a few words, the problem goes like this: Let‚Äôs say you manage to get people to actually fill out timesheets, and by some miracle the data is complete and accurate. You still have one more hurdle to overcome: accounting still needs a way to keep track of billable, non-billable and billed hours. That‚Äôs a whole other headache! Our approach to this problem was to take it apart into two major components: These two components respond to the two kinds of users that operate in this system: employees who log in hours, and accounting/administrators who use that input to bill clients. So any good solution had to encompass the needs of both. We came up with this: A chatbot that can be easily integrated with messaging services like Slack, Telegram and XMPP chat clients. The mechanics are beautifully simple: Brium asks people, a few times a day, what they‚Äôre working on. They respond using a keyword. And that‚Äôs it. Administrators can then decide how activities should be reported, and how much or how little detail they need Brium to ask people to report. People can answer with messages like ‚Äòemail‚Äô, ‚Äòtraining‚Äô or ‚Äòacme-bizdev: call with customer‚Äô and Brium will understand and create an entry. Back to Don Norman‚Äôs principles, discoverability is addressed by making the system responsible for initiating the circuit, and by using a channel that users already use and are accustomed to: the bot talks to users via chat, and all they have to do is answer, like they do with any other chat. Along the same lines, feedback is provided with a message that simply and directly states ‚ÄúGot it‚Äù and, in case the user misspells the keyword or that a keyword isn‚Äôt recognized, Brium replies with a warning message that lets the user know that they need to check their answer or provide a new one. As far as the two components we divided the problem into, proactive action from users is no longer an issue, since Brium gets the ball rolling by asking people what they‚Äôre working on. This brings another benefit: since users are no longer reporting every few days, trying to recall what they were doing 4 days ago, we get the highest possible accuracy in your reports. And as far as the consolidation problem goes, administrators can see, at a glance, the status of the billing pipeline. Every entry has 3 stages in Brium: reported, allocated and billed. A simple interface allows administrators to quickly allocate entries to projects, and set them as billable or non-billable. Brium also has an interactive dashboard that displays the broad view of all entries per month. Simple, easy, efficient. No more cumbersome spreadsheets, a lot less room for human error and missing or corrupted files, and oh, so much time saved! That‚Äôs why we put a chatbot where a timesheet used to be. Years upon years of designing and developing custom software and complex information systems have earned us a very valuable body of lessons learned and knowledge about the workings of building experiences. One of those lessons learned is that the best way to test discoverability and feedback is giving the thing you‚Äôve built to real people and observing them while they use it to try and solve a concrete problem. The reason this works is that it puts together a winning combo: real people, in real settings, with real constraints, producing very real outcomes. The User Experience design goal, then, should be an intuitive and interactive user interface (UI), one that creates no doubt in the users‚Äô minds about how to operate, what to do next, and the results they should get from each action. UI and UX are often named as two sides of the same coin, and that is because a good interface makes for a good experience. We also learned that it‚Äôs not so important to get it right on the first try; it‚Äôs actually much more important to build the smallest, most discardable version of the tool, while maintaining all the functionalities we want to test. And then, of course, test it. Why? Because it allows us to learn fast. By understanding that whatever gets built, it won‚Äôt remain the same forever, it no longer makes sense to strive for perfection: the goal is to build something useful and delightful. And in the process, learning as much as we can, so the next cycle is always more efficient than the one before. -- -- We build unconventional software, and here we talk all about it Ideas need to be clear in order to be passed along, to find the others. Clarity enables reach. Reach enables change. This is what I offer. Help Status About Careers Press Blog Privacy Terms Text to speech Teams

Title: Machine Learning Classification Models
Subtitle: Great Learning
Author: Great Learning
Article: Sign up Sign in Sign up Sign in Home About  Great Learning is an outstanding platform for a career transformation which is collaborated with a‚Ä¶  Great Learning Follow Great Learning -- Listen Share In machine learning, we often use the classification models to get a predicted result of population data. Classification is one of the two sections of supervised learning, and it deals with data from different categories. The training data-set trains the model to predict the unknown labels of population data. There are multiple algorithms: Logistic regression, K-nearest neighbor, Decision tree, Naive Bayes etc. All these algorithms have their own style of execution and different techniques of prediction. To find the most suitable algorithm for a particular business problem, there are few model evaluation techniques. In this article different model evaluation techniques will be discussed. It probably got its name from the state of confusion it deals with. If you remember hypothesis testing, you may recall the two errors we defined as type-I and type-II. As depicted in Fig.1, type-I error occurs when null hypothesis is rejected, which should not be in actual. Type-II error occurs when the alternate hypothesis is true, but you are failing to reject null hypothesis. In figure 1 it is depicted clearly that the choice of confidence interval affects the probabilities of these errors to occur. But if you try to reduce either of these errors, it will result in the increase of the other one. So, what is confusion matrix? Confusion matrix is the image given above. It is a matrix representation of the results of any binary testing. For example let us take the case of predicting a disease. You have done some medical testing and with the help of the results of those tests, you are going to predict whether the person is having a disease. So, actually you are going to validate if the hypothesis of declaring a person as having disease is acceptable or not. Say, among 100 people you are predicting 20 people to have the disease. In actual only 15 people to have the disease and among those 15 people you have diagnosed 12 people correctly. So, if I put the result in a confusion matrix, it will look like the following ‚Äî So, if we compare fig.3 with fig.2 we will find ‚Äî Now if I ask what is the accuracy of the prediction model what I followed to get these results, the answer should be the ratio of the accurately predicted number and the total number of people which is (12+77)/100 = 0.89. If you study the confusion matrix thoroughly you will find the following things: Now, you may ask the question that why do we need to measure precision or recall to evaluate the model? The answer is it is highly recommended when a particular result is very sensitive. For example you are going to build a model for a bank to predict fraudulent transactions. It is not very common to have a fraudulent transaction. In 1000 transactions, there may be 1 transaction which is fraud. So, undoubtedly your model will predict a transaction as non-fraudulent very accurately. So, in this case the whole accuracy does not matter as it will be always very high irrespective of the accuracy of the prediction of the fraudulent transactions as that is of very low percentage in the whole population. But the prediction of a fraudulent transaction as non-fraudulent is not desirable. So, in this case the measurement of precision will take a vital role to evaluate the model. It will help to understand out of all the actual fraudulent transactions, how many are being predicted. If it is low, even if the overall accuracy if high, the model is not acceptable. Measuring the area under the ROC curve is also a very useful method for evaluating a model. ROC is the ratio of True Positive Rate (TPR) and False Positive Rate (FPR) (see fig.2). In our disease detection example, TPR is the measure of the ratio between the number of accurate predictions of people having the disease and the total number of people having the disease in actual. FPR is the ratio between the number of people who are predicted as not to have disease correctly and the total number of people who are not having the disease in actual. So, if we plot the curve, it comes like this ‚Äî The blue line denotes the change of TPR with different FPR for a model. More the ratio of the area under the curve and the total area (100 x 100 in this case) defines more the accuracy of the model. If it becomes 1, the model will be overfit and if it is equal below 0.5 (i.e when the curve is along the dotted diagonal line), the model will be too inaccurate to use. For classification models, there are many other evaluation methods like Gain and Lift charts, Gini coefficient etc. But the in-depth knowledge about the confusion matrix can help to evaluate any classification model very effectively. So, in this article I tried to demystify the confusions around the confusion matrix to help the readers. In the early 2000s, Songza implemented a manual music recommendation system for its listeners, where a team of music experts and curators would create playlists. But these recommendations were not objective, as they were dependent on the personal taste of the curators. It was an average experience for listeners, with a fair share of hits and misses, because it was impossible to make a playlist which catered to the varied tastes of a diverse set of people. The technology and the data did not exist back then to build a playlist that would be personalized to the taste of each individual listener. Along came Spotify a few years later, offering a highly personalized weekly playlist called Discover Weekly that quickly became one of their flagship offerings. Every Monday, millions of listeners receive a fresh playlist of new song recommendations, customized to their personal tastes based on their listening history and the songs they‚Äôve engaged with. Spotify uses a combination of different data aggregation and sorting methods to create their unique and powerful recommendation model that‚Äôs powered by machine learning. ‚ÄúOne of our flagship features is called Discover Weekly. Every Monday, we give you a list of 50 tracks that you haven‚Äôt heard before that we think you‚Äôre going to like. The ML engine that‚Äôs the main basis of it, and it‚Äôs advanced some since, had actually been around at Spotify a bit before Discover Weekly was there, just powering our Discover page‚Äù ‚Äî David Murgatroyd, Machine Learning Leader at Spotify. Spotify uses three forms of recommendation models to power Discover Weekly. 1. Collaborative Filtering Collaborative Filtering is a popular technique used by recommend-er systems to make automated predictions about the preferences of users, based on the preference of other similar users. On Spotify, the collaborative filtering algorithm compares multiple user-created playlists that have the songs that users have listened to. The algorithm then combs those playlists to look at other songs that appear in the playlists and recommends those songs. This framework executed by matrix math in Python libraries. The algorithm first creates a matrix of all the active users and songs. The Python library then runs a series of complex factorization formula on the matrix. The end result is two separate vectors, where X is the user vector representing the taste of an individual user. Vector Y represents the profile of a single song. To find out users with similar taste, collaborative filtering will compare a given user vector with each and every single user vectors to give a similar user vector as the output. The same procedure is applied to the song vectors. Spotify does not only rely on collaborative filtering. The second recommendation model used is NLP. 2. Natural Language Processing NLP is the ability of an algorithm to understand speech and text in real-time. Spotify‚Äôs NLP constantly trawls the web to find articles, blog posts, or any other text about music, to come up with a profile for each song. With all this scraped data, the NLP algorithm can classify songs based on the kind of language used to describe them and can match them with other songs that are discussed in the same vein. Artists and songs are assigned to classifying keywords based on the data, and each term has a certain weight assigned to them. Similar to collaborative filtering, a vector representation of the song is created, and that‚Äôs used to suggest similar songs. 3. Convolutional Neural Networks Convolutional Neural Networks are used to hone the recommendation system and to increase accuracy because less-popular songs might be neglected by the other models. The CNN model ensures that obscure and new songs are considered. The CNN model is most popularly used for facial recognition, and Spotify has configured the same model for audio files. Each song is converted into a raw audio file as a waveform. These wave forms are processed by the CNN and is assigned key parameters such as beats per minute, loudness, major/minor key and so on. Spotify then tries to match similar songs that have the same parameters as the songs their listeners like listening to. With these key machine learning models, Spotify is able to tailor a unique playlist of music that surprises its listeners every week with songs they would have never found otherwise. A key problem in many machine learning models is the lack of access to clean, structured data that can be processed. Spotify has been able to circumvent that problem due to their access to massive amounts of data that they collect from their users. They‚Äôve been able to shine as a great example of effective use of Machine Learning models to give their users an unrivaled personalized experience. Saikat Bhattacharya is a Senior Software engineer at Freshworks, and is pursuing the PGP-Machine Learning program from Great Learning. This article originally appeared on Towards Data Science and has been syndicated with permission from the author. Happy modelling! -- -- Great Learning is an outstanding platform for a career transformation which is collaborated with a few of the world‚Äôs best educational institutions. Great Learning is an ed-tech company for professional and higher education that offers comprehensive, industry-relevant programs. Title: The Optimization Side of a Liquiditex
Subtitle: Written by Iman muda
Author: Iman muda
Article: Sign up Sign in Sign up Sign in Iman muda Follow -- Listen Share Trading is a form of profit maximizing activity that is currently often carried out by most business people in the world. This activity becomes a profit land with productivity that guarantees in the future. Simply put, trading can be interpreted as a process of buying and selling currencies simultaneously between one country and another. Trading was chosen because this activity has so many advantages such as time and place that is flexible, fluctuations in prices that rise rapidly and can be personally authorized. Since the presence of Blockchain technology in the midst of the world‚Äôs technology industry, trading has increasingly caught the attention of the world‚Äôs public. This is because Blockchain is the cause for the birth of new currencies that have the potential for optimal profits in the trading world compared to fiat currencies in general. This currency is known as the crypto currency. Not only as a milestone for the birth of the crypto currency, Blockhchain is also a driving force for the birth of sophisticated platforms that contribute so much to the progress of all sectors of the world industry. One platform that was born using this technology is Liquiditex. Liquiditex is a platform designed to meet human needs in trading activities. As explained previously, this platform has used a new technology called Blockchain. This technology is a recent innovation that works with 2 highly reliable operational systems. These systems are called decentralized systems and encryption systems. Decentralization is a system that works by providing full access control for each user without being able to be acquired by other external parties, be it the government or a banking institution. While encryption is a system that provides multiple layers of data protection. Every user name, signature and even password will be protected in multi-protection by going through a gradual verification process. Seeing the reliability brought by this technology, it guarantees confidence in the performance of a platform that has used the technology. To become a trader at Liquiditex, users can start by registering themselves on this platform using an email account that is still active. For registrants who have successfully passed the process and have become a Liquiditex client, a digital wallet can be used as a tool to deposit their coins or tokens. Henceforth, they can carry out trading activities using the capabilities they have. On this platform, a trader can exchange their dollars with cryptocurrency like BTC, XRP, and ETH. In addition, users can also exchange their cryptocurrency like Bitcoin with Ethereum on this platform. These money can be traded only in a very short time. This is because this platform has been committed to creating a trading platform with optimal performance and using very sophisticated technology. Liquiditex has prepared 1,000,000 shells for clients who have registered on this platform. Each user who has successfully registered and successfully passed the complete ID verification process will be given 20 shells. In addition, each user who successfully invites a friend to join this platform and passes the ID verification process, each will be given 20 additional shells. Shell is a form of loyalty provided by the liquiditex platform for their favorite clients. The more number of shells collected, it will place a person at the highest rank and have the opportunity to get a large profit opportunity on an airdrop activity carried out by this platform. This offer is certainly a very interesting opportunity and should not be wasted. Liquiditex is a platform created with the principle of simplicity that will make it easy for their clients to trade on this platform. Each prospective user can learn about the rules contained in this platform through the manual that has been prepared. In this book, prospective users will be taught how to register and verify data on the Liquiditex platform. In addition, they will also be taught how to deposit tokens, withdraw or trade on this platform and they will also be notified of all other information related to this platform. To be able to access it the first time, a user can visit their official page at www.liquiditex.com. For more information please click the link below Website: https://liquiditex.com/ Telegram: https://t.me/liquiditex Twitter: https://twitter.com/liquiditex My information BTT: https://bitcointalk.org/index.php?action=profile;u=2538358;sa=summary -- -- Help Status About Careers Press Blog Privacy Terms Text to speech Teams

Title: How Blockchain Technology will impact your Business?
Subtitle: Written by ITExpertsIndya
Author: ITExpertsIndya
Article: Sign up Sign in Sign up Sign in ITExpertsIndya Follow -- Listen Share Blockchain is a distributed database that provides a method for conducting, tracking and validating digital transactions. Blockchain is open for anyone and can be securely used to make digital transactions that can involve money, information, intellectual property etc. Blockchain is an open ledger which records the transaction data in a decentralized manner and doesn‚Äôt allow the data to be altered.Blockchain ensures the integrity of the transaction and enhances trust between the parties who are making the transfer. Due to its secure nature of transferring valuable information digitally, blockchain has opened a myriad of possibilities for various businesses. In this article, we will cover some use cases of Blockchain, and your business could benefit from these blockchain trends.The blockchain trends that are likely to continue and impact the businesses are mentioned below: ‚Ä¢ Healthcare ‚Äî In the healthcare domain, several digital transaction and information sharing takes place between the patients, healthcare providers, and insurers. Blockchain can provide a secure medium to transfer information and authorize digital payments in a trustworthy manner.‚Ä¢ Media ‚Äî Blockchain prevents the theft of digital rights. For example, artists or production house can release the music in a blockchain-based music ecosystem and control its usage rights, terms of use and royalties.‚Ä¢ Pay-for-performance- This is one of the best features and going to impact several businesses. It leverages the Blockchain‚Äôs ‚Äúsmart contracts‚Äù features where the agreements get enforced on meeting the pre-described criterions. Since the transaction is decentralized and stored securely, there is no way that a party can deny its existence and compliance of criterions.‚Ä¢ Regulatory tax enforcement ‚Äî In a digital world where all the transactions are recorded in a decentralized manner in real time, it will be tough to hide a transaction from the regulatory ‚Ä¢ Internet of Things- Blockchain technology could help companies better utilize their high-value equipment/ assets by selling their idle time on digital marketplaces. It will essentially help in improving the Return on Investment of the company by optimally utilizing their resources.‚Ä¢ Legal industry- Legal as an industry involves a large amount of digital information in the form of agreements and contracts. Blockchain support ‚Äúsmart contracts‚Äù where the agreement gets automatically activated upon meeting the desired conditions. This functionality can have a tremendous impact on the legal industry.‚Ä¢ Trade Finance- Banks are at the forefront of implementing blockchain technology for trade finance operations. In blockchain, the official trade documents are dematerialized and transferred over the private blockchain to concerned parties including banks. The technology has the potential to make considerable savings in terms of money and time that are involved in traditional trade finance operations.ConclusionBlockchain trends are going to impact several businesses positively as we have discussed above. Blockchain will improve the efficiency of transactions by reducing the time and cost involved. Now it‚Äôs your turn to evaluate the impact of blockchain to your business. Stay ahead of the competition and educate all the stakeholders before taking the final call. -- -- ITExpertsIndya is one of the leading Web Development Company providing Web Development Solutions abd Custom Web Design Services. Title: News ‚Äî At The Edge ‚Äî 9/14
Subtitle: NASA visualization shows a rapid decline in Arctic Sea ice over the last 35 years. (2 min. video) ‚Äî
Author: Doc Huston
Article: Sign up Sign in Sign up Sign in Doc Huston Follow -- Listen Share While technological innovation is always a double-edge sword ‚Äî climate, artificial intelligence, 3-D printing & aging ‚Äî the existential risks may be outpacing the desirable potential. ~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~ In the 1st week of January 1988, over 1.2 million sq. miles were covered by sea ice 4 years of age or older, compared with just over 44,000 sq. miles in the same week in 2019. https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=oTaRhCrzkEk ‚Äú[Despite] a few individuals such as John Maynard Keynes, economists as a class were once held in almost universally low esteem by serious policymakers‚Ä¶[until] the decades after the second world war‚Ä¶[and] ended in a fog of financial crisis, economic conflict and resurgent nationalism‚Ä¶. [They] worked to turn legal attitudes to antitrust on their head, allowing decades of corporate concentration and increasing market power‚Ä¶[and] a wave of deregulation from the 1970s to the 1990s, and provided the intellectual case for tax cuts from the 1960s to the 1980s‚Ä¶. But overall growth never rose as‚Ä¶promised. Inequality widened. Workers and communities increasingly lost out to firms‚Ä¶[and] recessions stoked by monetarism did immense harm‚Ä¶. [Economists] were often‚Ä¶accomplices to a broader movement of conservatives determined to reverse the encroachment of the state‚Ä¶passionate about reducing tax and regulation‚Ä¶[and] the easy ascent of a few ideas that appealed to the wealthy and powerful‚Ä¶. [Also] ignored critics‚Ä¶within the profession‚Ä¶[warning] theories did not adequately capture society‚Äôs complexities‚Ä¶[but] too impressed with their own intelligence to consider the unintended consequences‚Ä¶[or] implications of the politics that allowed them to enact their ideas‚Ä¶. Often, their theories operated on the assumption that the self-interested actions of the rich would benefit everyone, even as those self-interested rich used the same economists to pursue their own agenda.‚Äù https://www.economist.com/books-and-arts/2019/08/31/when-economists-ruled-the-world ‚Äú[T]he allure of semi-automated war never faded‚Ä¶[but] is being supercharged by‚Ä¶artificial intelligence (AI)‚Ä¶[and] ‚Äòpoised to change the character of the future battlefield‚Äô‚Ä¶. The Pentagon‚Äôs budget for 2020 has‚Ä¶$1bn on AI and over four times as much on unmanned and autonomous capabilities that rely on it‚Ä¶.[China] wants to lead the world in AI by 2030‚Ä¶[and] Putin famously‚Ä¶[said] ‚Äòwhoever becomes the leader in this sphere will become the ruler of the world‚Äô‚Ä¶. [T]he paradox is that AI might at once penetrate and thicken the fog of war‚Ä¶[at] a speed and complexity that renders it essentially opaque to humans‚Ä¶. [Military] applications into three sorts. One is to allow machines to act without human supervision. Another is to process and interpret large volumes of data. A third is aiding, or even conducting, the command and control of war‚Ä¶. [Still] many modern AI systems combine rule-following with added randomness as a stepping stone to more complex planning. DARPA‚Äôs Real-time Adversarial Intelligence and Decision-making (RAID) software aims to predict the goals, movements and even the possible emotions of enemy forces five hours into the future‚Ä¶. ‚ÄôFor Chinese military strategists‚Ä¶AlphaGo‚Äôs victories was the fact that an AI could create tactics and stratagems superior to those of a human player in a game that can be compared to a war-game‚Äô‚Ä¶. [I]f algorithms that surpass human creativity also elude human understanding, they raise problems of law, ethics and trust‚Ä¶proportionality (between civilian harm and military advantage) and necessity‚Ä¶. ‚ÄôWhat do we do when AI is applied to military strategy and has calculated the probabilistic inferences of multiple interactions many moves beyond that which we can consider‚Ä¶and recommends a course of action that we don‚Äôt understand‚Äô‚Ä¶[yet] might result from the AI grasping a political chain of events that would not be immediately perceptible to commanders‚Ä¶. [A]n AI might support, if not take over, decision-making in real-world warfighting‚Äô by using a ‚Äòmassive near-real-time simulation‚Äô‚Ä¶.[Military] already purchasing a‚Ä¶cloud-based virtual replication of a complex operating environment ‚Äî known as a single synthetic environment‚Ä¶using open standards, so everything from secret intelligence to real-time weather data can be plugged in. ‚ÄòIt will revolutionize how command and control is done‚Ä¶[creating] a ‚Äòsingle synthetic command tool from the national security council down to the tactical commander‚Ä¶. It seems likely humans will be increasingly both out of the loop and off the team in decision-making‚Äô‚Ä¶.The result would not only be autonomous weapons, but an automated battlefield. At the outset of a war, interconnected AI systems would pick out targets‚Ä¶and choreograph rapid and precise strikes to destroy them in the most efficient order. The wider consequences of that remain unclear. The prospect of accurate and rapid strikes ‚Äòcould erode stability by increasing the perceived risk of surprise attack‚Äô‚Ä¶[or] AI might equally‚Ä¶parry such blows, by identifying the telltale signs of an impending strike‚Ä¶. [N]o power wants to risk falling behind‚Ä¶.[Since] ‚Äòdata is the fuel of AI‚Ä¶China may have a structural advantage over the rest of the world.‚Äô‚Äù https://www.economist.com/science-and-technology/2019/09/07/artificial-intelligence-is-changing-every-aspect-of-war medium.com ‚Äú[New] robot consisting of multiple units that can operate as a cluster, responding to‚Ä¶their environment without the need for any centralized control ‚Äî much like living cells‚Ä¶[and] capable of more sophisticated behavior‚Ä¶. The weakly linked mass is‚Ä¶[resilient] because it has no single point of failure and can keep working even if some individuals become disabled‚Ä¶[for] search and rescue operations‚Ä¶deliver drugs to hard-to-reach parts of the human body or boost research by modeling the cellular action involved in organ formation‚Ä¶. [I]n simulations with up to 100,000 units, even if 20 percent stopped functioning the cluster could still travel at about half of its top speed‚Ä¶[Researching] applications, including the ability to adapt to changes in tasks, the environment and the robot‚Äôs own state.‚Äô‚Äù https://www.scientificamerican.com/article/particle-robots-work-together-to-perform-tasks/ ‚ÄúModern technologies‚Ä¶mean one does not need to be‚Ä¶[smart] to create [weapons]‚Ä¶in their living room ‚Äî and firearms are just the beginning‚Ä¶[since] artificial intelligence and 3-D printing might‚Ä¶make it much easier‚Ä¶to covertly build nuclear, chemical and biological weapons‚Ä¶. [Already] U.S. National Nuclear Security Administration (NNSA)‚Ä¶[uses] these machines to manufacture models of nuclear weapons for testing‚Ä¶ Raytheon has a 3-D printer that can manufacture 80 percent of a missile, and Los Alamos National Laboratory is using these machines to produce high explosives‚Ä¶. [T]here are concerns that AI could allow unskilled humans to come up with the necessary blueprints, thanks to‚Ä¶generative design‚Ä¶process [where] a user can give a computer a design problem and set requirements for the final result. The AI suggests many possible solutions, and humans pare down the results‚Ä¶.NASA recently used the technique to create a prototype lander for space missions‚Ä¶ [3-D] manufacturing and AI creates three major risk areas‚Ä¶. ‚ÄôGiven the speed at which technology is advancing‚Äô‚Ä¶3-D printing could be part of the WMD supply chain within the next 10 years.‚Äô‚Äù https://www.scientificamerican.com/article/3-d-printers-could-help-spread-weapons-of-mass-destruction/ medium.com ‚Äú[A] company named Made In Space is building‚Ä¶first self-manufacturing satellite, due for launch in three years‚Ä¶[using] 3D printers and automated assembly‚Ä¶. 3D printers have already done several tours of duty on the International Space Station‚Ä¶[and] Made in Space‚Ä¶will manufacture two ten-meter-long wings of solar arrays‚Ä¶generating ‚Äòas much as five times more power than traditional solar panels on spacecraft‚Ä¶[using] recycled waste polymer on the ISS. They plan to manufacture optical fiber in space which would ‚Äògreatly outperform‚Äò standard fibers‚Ä¶and are interested in 3D printing metals‚Ä¶. 70% moondust can be mixed with 30% polymer‚Ä¶that can be heated into 3D feedstock for a remarkable one-thirtieth the energy cost‚Ä¶[with] ambitious long-term plan to construct spacecraft from asteroids.‚Äù https://techcrunch.com/2019/09/02/3d-printers-on-the-final-frontier-made-in-space-is-building-satellites-that-build-themselves/ ‚Äú[T]he production of the world‚Äôs first 3D-printed plant-based beefsteak in 2018‚Ä¶[now] meats like steak, chicken breasts and other fibrous textured meat replacements‚Ä¶[with] a new scaffolding technology that mimics the texture, appearance, nutritional and sensorial properties of fibrous meats‚Ä¶. While many clean meat and plant-based food companies have‚Ä¶meat replacements‚Ä¶with similar taste and textural qualities to the real thing, steaks and cuts of muscle meat have proven harder to replicate‚Ä¶. [Novameat] customized printer that enables companies to create the kinds of fibrous tissues needed to make a steak‚Ä¶‚Äôproviding the equipment, the machinery, under a licensing agreement‚Äô‚Ä¶[and] speeds up the time to create meat substitutes‚Ä¶. [The] company‚Äôs micro-extrusion technology enables companies to get a three-dimensional structure‚Ä¶[and] provides a flexible and tunable method of producing plant-based meat, with the utility to create different textures from a wide variety of ingredients, all within a single piece of meat‚Ä¶. [This] gives plant-based meat manufacturers a wider array of tools to mimic all types of meat and seafood.‚Äô‚Äù https://techcrunch.com/2019/09/05/novameat-has-a-platform-for-3d-printing-steaks-and-has-new-money-to-take-it-to-market/ ‚Äú[I]n five to 12 years‚Ä¶a pill that could‚Ä¶stave off the fragility, osteoarthritis, memory loss, macular degeneration and cancers that plague old age‚Ä¶. [T]he science of senolytics: an‚Ä¶area of anti-ageing medicine‚Ä¶more concerned with prolonging‚Ä¶‚Äòhealthspan‚Äô than [lifespan]‚Ä¶to age with less pain and illness‚Ä¶with a lot of benefits, both for governments and older patients‚Ä¶. [Ageing] is the biggest risk factor for most chronic diseases‚Ä¶[so senolytics] targets senescent‚Ä¶so-called ‚Äòzombie‚Äô cells linger and proliferate as we age, emitting substances that cause inflammation and turn other healthy cells senescent, ultimately leading to tissue damage throughout the body‚Ä¶. [2019] a small early human trial showed an improvement in the distance patients were able to walk‚Ä¶[and] injecting a senolytic drug into the knees of people with osteoarthritis showed promising, if mixed results‚Ä¶. [Theoretically] it should prove impossible to build up a resistance to the drugs, ‚Äòbecause senescent cells cannot proliferate‚Äô‚Ä¶[and] there is significant data to show ‚Äòthat‚Ä¶just treat them once a week or once a month‚Ä¶[will] have huge benefits‚Ä¶. [Also] obesity can cause senescent cells to develop prematurely‚Ä¶[so] clearing senescent cells improves insulin sensitivity‚Ä¶.[and] senescent cells ‚Äòplay a big role after cancer treatment‚Äô, developing as a result of chemotherapy and radiation therapy‚Ä¶[so] a detrimental side-effect‚Ä¶could be alleviated‚Äô‚Ä¶. [T]he ideal treatment age will differ from person to person, and‚Ä¶a blood or urine test that can assess the level of senescence present [soon]‚Ä¶. Intermittent fasting may have senescent effects‚Ä¶[and] linked to healthy ageing and longevity. Mouse trials have shown that they can live 30 to 50% longer than control animals‚Ä¶. [A] healthy diet, ‚Äòreducing the amount of animal protein‚Ä¶[to] once per week, maximum‚Ä¶[because] association between low protein intake and longevity is well established in humans‚Ä¶[so] protein should come from vegetables.‚Äô‚Äù https://www.theguardian.com/science/2019/sep/02/the-science-of-senolytics-how-a-new-pill-could-spell-the-end-of-ageing Find more of my ideas on Medium at, A Passion to Evolve. (and archived at bottom of the page.) Or click the Follow button below to add me to your feed. Prefer a weekly email newsletter ‚Äî free, no ads, no spam, & never sell the list ‚Äî email me dochuston1@gmail.com with ‚Äúadd me‚Äù in the subject line. May you live long and prosper!Doc Huston -- -- Consultant & Speaker on future nexus of technology-economics-politics, PhD Nested System Evolution, MA Alternative Futures, Patent Holder ‚Äî dochuston1@gmail.com Help Status About Careers Press Blog Privacy Terms Text to speech Teams

Title: WeWork Valuation: Phase I
Subtitle: What matters to customers?
Author: Panabee
Article: Sign up Sign in Sign up Sign in Panabee Follow -- Listen Share WeWork is a hybrid of AWS and Marriott. Because WeWork leverages technology and scale to lower costs, increase flexibility, and improve the office experience, companies across the world will outsource office creation and management to WeWork. Co-working is merely the springboard. WeWork is an overhyped-Regus with a frail capital structure, no scale benefits, no network effects, and dangerous liabilities. It will likely collapse during a recession. Although bias is unavoidable, many people unfortunately allow preconceived notions to compromise their WeWork judgments both positively and negatively. These two questions help expose bias. If someone offers an opinion yet cannot answer fundamental questions, the opinion most likely reflects bias and not insight. Beware informed, but biased, opinions. For illustration purposes, if research reveals there are 500mn knowledge workers and only 20% need to rent, this yields a market size of 100mn users. All questions should benchmark WeWork against direct competitors and the internal teams of large companies. Debating tech vs. non-tech is a distraction from what matters. What matters is fast growth and strong moats. Torrid growth is undeniable. In 2018, WeWork grew revenue over 100% compared to the previous year. For contrast, Marriott grew sales about 1% in 2018. The argument hinges on WeWork‚Äôs defensibility and pricing power. Choosing the appropriate multiple requires comparing WeWork‚Äôs growth and moats to alternative equity options. For instance, Salesforce has slower growth but arguably stronger moats while Marriott may have stronger moats but zero growth. What‚Äôs the right multiple? There‚Äôs no scientific answer, only estimates of where the market one day converges. Title: Key Considerations to Implement and Activate a Data Lake
Subtitle: Published in Engineered @ Publicis Sapient
Author: Publicis Sapient
Article: Sign up Sign in Sign up Sign in Publicis Sapient Follow Engineered @ Publicis Sapient -- Listen Share Khyatee Chhabra- Senior Director, Technology A successful data lake implementation is more than setting up a big data repository. The data lake needs to serve for access of data, understandability of data and trust in the data in order to generate excitement and stimulate demand and adoption. However, data lake implementations often fail to serve these objectives and end up into data swamps or muddied waters. What are some of the common mistakes and incorrect assumptions that lead to data lake failures? What are the key considerations for implementation and activation of a successful Data Lake? Setting up Data Lake is more than just the technology. It is about getting people, processes, organization and technology together to establish the right data foundation. 2. People: It is important to understand that not everyone in the organization is data-literate. What are the training and coaching needs of people for data definitions, tools and most importantly, the data-driven mindset? 3. Organization: It is important for the organization to align to the vision of establishing ‚Äúdata‚Äù as a ‚Äúbusiness asset‚Äù. Removing data silos, fostering a collaborative style, aligning on the data definitions within the organization are some of the imperatives to establish a data-driven culture. Integrating multiple business units by establishing a single and harmonized source of enterprise data is crucial to the success of data lake implementation. 4. Technology: There is no one size that fits all. Multiple tools and technologies need to coexist to meet the various needs around ingestion, processing, storage and access of data. If the organization is interested in open source, it is important to be active in the open source community, and to keep monitoring the changes, advancements and their value to the program. Let me know your thoughts. In my next blog, I will elaborate on the characteristics of a self-service data lake that acts as the foundation for a data-driven culture. -- -- We fuse startup thinking and agile methods to help established companies increase value, drive efficiencies and thrive in an evolving world A digital transformation partner helping established organizations get to their future, digitally-enabled state, in the way they work and serve their customers. Title: 9 Secret Weapons for Real Estate Sales Agents in 2019
Subtitle: Written by Mintbean
Author: Mintbean
Article: Sign up Sign in Sign up Sign in Mintbean Follow -- Listen Share As a real estate agent it can be challenging to stay on the cutting edge of the technological market. Below, we‚Äôve listed 9 great software tools that will help you better serve your clients, and keep your business running at peak efficiency. Zillow‚Äôs Premier Agent is a powerful software for real estate agents that harnesses Zillow‚Äôs massive monthly visitor base. It allows you to place your contact information on listings you claim in your MLS system to to help you generate leads. For an additional fee, you can place your advertisements on the listings of other agents, set advertising budgets, and choose which geographical areas your advertisements should appear in. AreaPulse is a software tool that allows you to compile market data, and send professional looking reports to your clients. The data gathered includes average pricing, the number of new homes in the area, and how many homes have been sold recently. Pricing for the platform is flexible, and is calculated on a user by user basis. Videolicious is an app designed to make editing professional video easier. Everything from adding watermarks to your video to cutting together smaller clips can be done in-app, making video production a breeze. Loom is a web extension and desktop app that can be used to record your screen and webcam footage, as well as audio from your microphone. All of this can be recorded and instantly shared from a single link, for free. The paid version of the app also allows you to store and edit footage, and create custom thumbnails. Bomb Bomb is a desktop app that lets you add personalized video to your emails, text messages, and social media posts. By adding some personal flair to your messages you can build trust faster and engage with more of your potential audience. Slack is a messaging app that facilitates instantaneous team communication. Themed Discussion channels, personal messages, and a robust file management system help to keep your team on-task, and lower communication overhead. Slack allows for improved communication, no matter what the size of your team. Everlance is a mobile app that allows for easy tracking of mileage, monitoring of travel expenses, and maximizing tax deductions for business travel. The software also lets you export your data to PDF or Excel reports to help you better track where your expenses are. The basic version is free, but for a low monthly fee, you gain access to a variety of custom options for teams. Waze is a crowdsourced traffic app that will help you cut down your travel time, and spend more time focusing on your clients. With information available on everything from traffic slowdowns to police activity, Waze makes it easy to get the most out of your travel. Grasshopper is a service that allows you to quickly and easily generate vanity phone numbers for your business. By creating a memorable number for clients to reach you at, you can unify your brand and improve client retention. -- -- Write Code. Get Noticed. Get Hired.
