Title: 7 Ways to Trigger your Child‚Äôs Interest in Technology
Subtitle: Written by BeSingular
Author: BeSingular
Article: Sign up Sign in Sign up Sign in BeSingular Follow -- Listen Share Your child since birth is surrounded by technology, right from his first pic to his first footsteps are recorded and shared through the latest technology. In fact, his scheduled check-ups and every other detail related to him are collected and secured with the help of technology. The ever changing technology has become a part of our lifestyle. These technology trends are such that having a working knowledge of robotics, programming, Artificial Intelligence, IOT is a must for all. STEM skills today have become a must for all children. If we give it a thought, it‚Äôs not difficult to engage your child in tech activities. These days a child‚Äôs first pal is mobile, he is keener to explore the realms of mobile technology than any other toy you might offer him. Similarly, as he grows older his grasp of technology is much more than we can fathom. Hence it‚Äôs easy to indulge him in technology. However, to make him serious for technology is a different ballgame altogether. STEM skills are in great demand today and they will remain so in the days to come. We have to ensure that the coming generation is fully equipped to deal with the hurricane of change awaiting them in the near future. Here are a few ways in which you can trigger your child‚Äôs love for tech: Indulge your child with STEM Toys: Gone are the days when parents bought dolls or cars for their child to play. These days market is flooded with STEM toys for all ages. They play a dual role by giving your child a new toy to play with and learn something new and worthwhile at the same time. Let him explore: Kids learn by exploring and we should let them discover the hidden gems of the latest technology. Become their student and try to learn from them. This gives them confidence in their abilities and also pushes them to learn more about the subject. Share awesome technology invention stories: There are so many wonderful stories to share with your child. Stories of successful technologies, stories of people who are behind that success. This inspires them to achieve something or form an affiliation towards one such role model. His curious mind would want to learn and understand the latest technology and its trends. Enrol your child in a Technology Course: This is the best way to ensure that your child does not lag behind his peers and is ready to face the future with gusto. These courses offer a basic understanding of robotics, programming, IOT, Artificial Intelligence etc. Talk about the power of Technology: Exponential technologies are the way forward and it‚Äôs always good to talk about the power of technology and its impact on our day-to-day life. Technology advancement also means that it can solve many of our real world problems. This helps a child understand the importance of technology and how he can help bring a positive change to the world around him. Join a Tech Summer Camp: Summers are the time to try something new and if that something new is learning how to code or construct a robot than nothing like it! These summer camps have a life-long impact on children and learning newest in technology will help him throughout life. Lay Emphasis on Computer Science Classes: When we were young computers was never given much weightage in school. In fact, it was considered a poor cousin of other important courses. But things have changed now and computers have taken over everything else. Hence you should emphasise on a computer science class and if possible enrol your child in extra classes for this subject. Technology is at the forefront of everything we do. It has taken over our lives and promises to keep delving into it in the times to come. Working knowledge of tech is important for all but for a child who has yet to step into adulthood learning basics of technology takes on a significant turn. His grip on the subject should be such that he can face the future with aplomb and confidence. About BeSingular: BeSingular is a learning platform to skill the next generation to create real and responsible impact working with the technology of the future. The innovative and well-researched curriculum imparts skill set based in exponential technologies which will benefit them in every aspect of their lives. The well-designed programs are age-appropriate and are made to engage the natural curiosity of a child. -- -- BeSingular is a learning platform that activates young minds to a future full of possibilities. Title: Innovations In Utility Industry- ALL About Utilities
Subtitle: Written by christopher henry
Author: christopher henry
Article: Sign up Sign in Sign up Sign in christopher henry Follow -- Listen Share Technologies are helping the utility industry to modernize its business model by driving a customer-centric approach. The possibilities and benefits of technology are endless and the advancing tech trends are imperative for the utilities like water, electricity, oil, and energy in a substantial way. The transformation that the new and existing technology brings has notable benefits for businesses. Utilities are tasked with balancing disruptive forces at an increasing rate with a deep commitment to customer satisfaction. With a customer-centric mindset, leveraging new technologies will help utility companies adapt and thrive ahead. Top Technologies Guiding the Utility Industry ‚Ä¢ Cloud Cloud-based software has enabled businesses of all sizes to take the benefit of speed, security, and scalability. It has also helped software organizations in deploying, refining, and updating offerings with features and enhancements in ways that were earlier not possible for software installed on office local machines. Many enterprise software suppliers are cloud-first, offering the best of the needed features. ‚Ä¢ The Internet of Things (IoT) Utilities have the responsibility to manage pipelines, powerlines, dams, among others, to make up the infrastructure. This enables them to generate and deliver power and water. Nowadays, users are increasingly comfortable with connected lights and other smart devices in their homes. With the help of apps and smart speakers, intelligent network connectivity is expected to get better and accurate steadily. Check This Out: Top Electric Utilities Companies ‚Ä¢ Artificial Intelligence Constant connectivity and increasingly more intelligent equipment add up to a lot more data being collected and in need of being processed. Every other business is in the data businesses virtually. Technology Guiding Utilities Utility Tech Innovations Leading Ways to a New World Full of Possibilities Unique tech innovations contribute to exploring new utility landscapes and meeting the rising demands of the modern customer. Artificial Intelligence (AI) and robotics contribute to regular developments in the utility industry, optimizing the delicate, demeaning, demanding, dangerous and, dull operational approaches. AI and robotics in the utility workplace ensure the increase in productivity while maintaining quality. Here are a few such intelligent innovations transformation the utilities. ‚Ä¢ Autonomous Vehicles The incorporation of autonomous vehicles helps streamline public transit. As it utilizes the remote sensors and automation, it can augment and replace current transit for safer and more efficient operations with the help of AIs. It can be initiated by taking more vehicles off the road and reduce emissions and traffic accidents. Taking measures like sharing autonomous shuttles offer a convenient, efficient, and cost-effective ways of transportation. It also reduces traffic congestion and missions and alleviates the need for additional transit station parking. It can provide more economical and reliable mobility services, increasing the access for senior citizens and accommodation for the disabled rider. ‚Ä¢ Empowering the Disabled Robotic technology is not only benefiting humans to perform and revolutionize their workplaces, but also empowering people with their disabilities through assistive innovations. Today there are lots of apps and gadgets to ease the difficulties people with the disability face daily. Meanwhile, organizations are developing joint strategies to improve utility services, with the common goals of extending their access for all the group of people, enhancing the efficiency of delivery, and reviewing tariffs. Tech Innovations Utilities and Blockchain: Simple Applications Promising Great Results! Improving utilities with the help of blockchain technology holds vast potential. Here is how blockchain enables better management and distribution. Few Electric Utilities Companies: CTC Global, G&W Electric, MultiTech The utility sector is always on the look-out for innovative solutions. With fluctuating demands and supplies, transforming sources of energy and a rising concern for environmental impacts, the industry faces numerous challenges. Blockchain technology has answers that can help make utilities better. Many companies in the utility sector are trying and testing blockchain while some have already implemented the technology. There are many advantages associated with a blockchain, and they can be successfully translated into potential utility offerings. ‚Ä¢ Simpler Energy Trading between Peers The concept of energy sharing is catching up with the general public. Every time consumers feed energy back into the grid, they can earn some money. The process of transactions associated with the transfer of energy is simplified if blockchain technology is applied. Even while sourcing locally produced renewable energy, the transaction with blockchain makes costs lesser. Blockchain-enabled smart contracts allow real-time monitoring of production and flow data. Hence, energy exchange becomes convenient and cost-effective with blockchains. ‚Ä¢ Balancing Supply and Demand As non-conventional and renewable sources of energy take over conventional power, there is a lot of disparity in demand and supply. To attain a balance between the demands from consumers and the possible supply, smart and flexible services are necessary. Blockchain can be deployed to help consumers adjust their demands according to the energy available through temporary interruptions and intelligent management of batteries. Utilities and Blockchain Together -- -- Help Status About Careers Press Blog Privacy Terms Text to speech Teams

Title: Agile technologies
Subtitle: Written by Andrew Gibson
Author: Andrew Gibson
Article: Sign up Sign in Sign up Sign in Andrew Gibson Follow -- Listen Share This is the first in a series of musings about how to best use technology to achieve discrete outcomes ‚Äî often business applications or services. he said to him, ‚ÄúThere is still one thing lacking. Sell all that you own and distribute the money to the poor‚Ä¶‚Äù ‚Ä¶when he heard this, he became sad; for he was very rich. Achieving agility with technology reminds me of this story. Often what is needed is to give up the tools we want to use and to rely on something more basic, more fundamental. And we are so, so rich in tools and frameworks these days ‚Äî the choice seems unending. I worked with a team recently who were using Serverless (the framework, not just the architecture). Their rationale was good, and the framework itself is an awesome piece of kit. The team I was working with wanted to use it to deploy an API and an application into a VPC integrating with external JSON and SOAP-based APIs. Deployment used a typical CI/CD pipeline. The Serverless framework leverages serverless technologies, like AWS Lambda or Azure Functions, to automagically deploy applications consisting of pay-per-execution functions into production. It builds on infrastructure-as-code concepts to ensure that you can repeatedly deploy your stack into production without manual configuration. I like it. It‚Äôs very handy. Single command deploy ‚Äî nice. The downside to this flexibility is‚Ä¶ well you have to run a single command to deploy it. The teams‚Äô solution, designed by a very senior technical resource in the organisation, was to spin up an EC2 instance (a sort of bastion), download the code, run the single command, deploy the serverless app, then teardown the EC2 instance again. Bizarre but true ‚Äî create an ephemeral virtual server to deploy a serverless application. This works well, is performant and cost effective. If I recall correctly, the creation of this EC2 instance was orchestrated using a terraform script, which, again, takes the heavy lifting out of creating the necessary resources. That in turn was kicked off using a bash script running in a Circle CI container. I‚Äôm glossing over some essential details here, like ensuring the correct IAM credentials exist and that provisioned resources are versioned in a way that can be tracked ‚Äî built into the Serverless framework paradigm. The thing is, just a few months earlier, I had worked with a different team on a similarly spec‚Äôd app deployed in a similar scenario which was missing almost all of these moving pieces. There was still a Circle CI container to kick off builds, but deployment was basically just: This seemed to work just fine ‚Äî no terraform, no Serverless framework, no bastion EC2 instance. It left me wondering if I was missing a trick. Was there some benefit to the extra hops that I was missing? Was it just over-engineering? When choosing the technology, this simpler solution was designed to avoid as many tools as possible in order to allow more junior engineers to wrap their heads around it. I also have a friend who publishes Twitch analytics and is very successful at what he does. He uses very basic technologies, very effectively, to produce a product which is beneficial to a large community of users at almost no cost, and with a very small investment of time. I am in awe of his ability to be useful to the world. I‚Äôve seen countless people (yup, me too) fail to produce working software despite having far more financial, technical and human resources at their disposal. Why is it so hard to be effective sometimes? When we have so many tools at our disposal, why is it sometimes so hard to do good work? What does it take to have truly agile technologies? What are the different types of agility we might be interested in achieving? Why do we employ ‚ÄúAgile‚Äù processes to achieve agility but neglect to ensure we are building agile solutions? This is part of a series of articles on agility and software which are linked below: -- -- Business and technology in the software engineering space Help Status About Careers Press Blog Privacy Terms Text to speech Teams

Title: A quick guide to investing
Subtitle: Written by Kristopher Saber
Author: Kristopher Saber
Article: Sign up Sign in Sign up Sign in Member-only story Kristopher Saber Follow -- Share Millennials are notorious for being hampered by debt in the form of student loans. Despite this, In the information age, finding data to support investing endeavors is something that the millennial generation has done. This has come in the forms of Exchange Traded Funds (ETFs) and Mutual Funds. In smartphone era, there is also a trend for Millennials to use mobile trading software, like Acorns or WiseBanyan, to make safe trades passively. The Millennial generation needs to find new ways to invest money when their net income is less compared to previous generations because of debt obligations. Other generations can also can invest digitally, this article isn‚Äôt restricted to just Millennials. if you can afford to put 20 dollars away a week, you can follow some of the suggestions laid out here. There are a variety of different ways to invest and grow your money. Investing can range from putting money into real estate, stock, gold, and other securities. A security is an investment that you can trade, ranging from bonds to real estate. There are many ways to invest, mainly we‚Äôll be talking about investing stock, bond and fund securities. This can be accessed and bought on multiple platforms‚Ä¶ -- -- Senior UX Researcher. My opinion is my own, and does not reflect the business that I'm employed to. Title: Interrogating the Future of Digital Democracies
Subtitle: Written by Dr. Lydia Kostopoulos
Author: Dr. Lydia Kostopoulos
Article: Sign up Sign in Sign up Sign in Dr. Lydia Kostopoulos Follow -- Listen Share [Originally published in the Observer Research Foundation ‚ÄòDigital Debates‚Äô CyFy Journal 2019 and at ORF] Democratic governance is one of the oldest forms of political governance, dating back to 507 B.C.E. in Ancient Greece. Most people believe that since then, democracy has only flourished. The reality is that ‚Äòancient democracy‚Äô collapsed; first into anarchy and then into dictatorship, heralding the medieval period, also known as the dark ages. When the United States of America declared itself a sovereign nation in 1776 (1776‚Äì1789) and ratified its new government, it was the first ‚Äòmodern democracy‚Äô. Near simultaneously on the other side of the Atlantic, the French revolution overthrew the monarchy to establish a republic with liberal democratic values. Both countries experienced violent political periods a few decades after becoming democracies and have grown into their form of governance over the centuries since their forming. Today, the United States and France are liberal democracies that continue to uphold democratic values, human rights and maintain their commitment to the political freedom of their citizens. This is not without struggle, because democracy is messy and it is a constant dialogue between citizens and their elected leaders. Citizens demand that their many voices be heard, that actions be taken in support of different interest groups, and that elected leaders be held accountable. Democracy is naturally messy because it is meant to represent an entire nation of people who think differently and want different policies from their leaders. Liberal democracies are the preferred choice of government for those who wish to elect their leaders and, no matter the outcome, experience a peaceful transition of power. It is the preferred choice for those who wish to be able to live free from prosecution because of the gender they love, the god they pray to (or don‚Äôt believe in), as well as for women to freely have access to civic liberties (and have a space to defend them) such as the pursuit of independence in all its forms (economic freedom, political participation, professional choice, reproductive rights and sexual consent). Over 2,500 years after the birth of democracy in Ancient Greece, and just a few hundred years after its resurgence at the end of the medieval times, we are transitioning into a ‚Äòdigital democracy‚Äô. We are toddlers in this new period, learning how to walk in the digital spaces of an intangible territorial sovereignty, where the digital borders are blurry but play a role on the democratic infrastructure inside physical borders. What does it mean if most of a nation‚Äôs time is spent in digital spaces? Their mind and attention is in these digital spaces, while their physical bodies are in the territorial sovereignty of a nation‚Äôs government. Digital spaces for work, love, shopping, hobbies, and religion can all be found online. Over the years, the platforms that facilitate these exchanges reached across borders to become the glue for social and professional networking, they have provided access to business markets for a new wave of digital ‚Äòmom and pop‚Äô shops, and have documented our lives in ways that generations of royalty have never experienced. These digital technologies, combined with the pervasiveness of corporate algorithms, have created a social and economic infrastructure that has increasingly taken power away from government as more citizens sign onto terms and conditions of the platforms they digitally inhabit. While this has taken away layers of bureaucracy in some aspects, it has brought more power to individuals to deliver their messages to broader audiences, sell their products to larger markets, learn new skills for free through many digital mediums, enjoy more forms of digital entertainment and connect with like-minded people across the world. However, as the spaces we inhabit (with our attention) have shifted from physical to digital, we have entered the sovereignty of those digital spaces, and their respective algorithms, which have increasingly become the mediators of our lives. They suggest who to date, what job to apply to, what home appliance to buy and which political candidate to vote for. In this sense, the algorithmic mediators of our lives have taken agency away from citizens, with several consequences, one being that the thoughts in our minds may not have necessarily come from there. It is unrealistic to argue that individuals should simply ‚Äòleave‚Äô these platforms. The costs of leaving are too high for those who rely on them for market viability and economic sustenance. Some say it is convenience, but these platforms are also a form of liberation (for revival of ‚Äòmom and pop shops‚Äô on Instagram and Etsy and Uber). They are also a form of entrapment when there aren‚Äôt other platform options. Opting out can have financial, professional and social consequences. In this space, unelected leadership and corporate policies are the de facto form of civil law online. How do liberal democracies around the world exercise their authority inside their physical territory, when the hearts and minds of their citizens residing in that same soil are living digital lives (for the most part of their day) under another leadership‚Äôs terms and rules. If liberal democracies are meant to be ‚Äúfor the people, by the people‚Äù, then the corporate jurisdictions in which we inhabit most of our digital lives are ‚Äúfor the corporation (and its shareholders), by the founders, mediated by a small group of engineers and defined by lawyers protecting corporate interests‚Äù. None of these people are democratically accountable to the citizens of any nation because they have never been elected in democratic elections. While citizens vote in government elections to determine who will govern them in the physical space, unelected leaders govern the digital spaces we spend time in, and they are playing an important role in the new fabric of our digital governance. Does democracy exist in the digital world if no one elected those who govern it? Does democracy exist in the digital world if no one elected those who control the main platforms of our digital lives, or write the algorithms that play a role in our fate? What does that mean for the role of those who are democratically elected in the physical spaces we inhabit? What does it mean to have an ‚Äúinformed‚Äù civic debate in these circumstances? When democratic representation in the physical world does not apply to the digital world, the laws as they stand are not fit for purpose. *** Dr. Lydia Kostopoulos (@Lkcyber) consults on the intersection of people, strategy, technology, education, and national security. Currently a Strategy and Innovation Advisor at the J5 at the U.S. Special Operations Command. She addressed the United Nations member states on the military effects panel at the Convention of Certain Weapons Group of Governmental Experts (GGE) meeting on Lethal Autonomous Weapons Systems (LAWS). She speaks and writes on disruptive technology convergence, innovation, tech ethics, and national security. In efforts to raise awareness on AI and ethics she makes reflectional art #ArtAboutAI, and made a game about emerging technology and ethics called Sapien2.0 . -- -- Strategy & Innovation | Emerging Tech | National Security | Story-telling Fashion | Art #ArtAboutAI ‚Üí www.Lkcyber.com Help Status About Careers Press Blog Privacy Terms Text to speech Teams

Title: Iranian Scientist Builds Quantum Microphone
Subtitle: Published in IFP News ( Iran Front Page )
Author: Maryam Khy
Article: Sign up Sign in Sign up Sign in Maryam Khy Follow IFP News ( Iran Front Page ) -- Listen Share An Iranian scientist has invented a quantum microphone that can track the smallest sound packets called phonons. Amir Safavi Nayini, an assistant professor at Stanford University along with a team of researchers at the university, has devised a quantum microphone that can detect the smallest sound or vibration packets called phonons or phonetic energy quantum. The achievement provides the background for more efficient quantum computers. Previously it was impossible to track phonons because traditional microphones were not sensitive enough to detect them. When a sound wave hits a membrane, the microphone detects it. But phonons are very small and cannot be tracked alone. Instead of relying on acoustic wave measurements, scientists have devised a device that measures the energy of phonons directly using very small resonators that act as a mirror for sound. For a brief review of Iran‚Äôs achievements in various fields of science and technology, check the book ‚ÄúScience and Technology in Iran: A Brief Review ‚Äî 2019‚Äù A resonator is a device or system that displays a resonance or resonance reaction. It can capture photons and detect the vibrations they emit. The device is described in an article in the ‚ÄúNature‚Äù journal. It is a step towards the invention of a new kind of quantum computer. The traceability of tiny particles enables devices to encrypt information using acoustic energy. This way, large amounts of information can be stored in small machines. A phonon quantum computer is much more compact and efficient than a quantum computer that uses photons or light particles because phonons can be manipulated more easily than photons. More information can also be stored in less space. ‚ÄúPhotons are now being used for encryption,‚Äù says Safavi. ‚ÄúWe want to use phonons that have more advantages. Our device is an important step in creating a mechanical quantum computer,‚Äù he noted. https://ifpnews.com/exclusive/iranian-scientist-builds-quantum-microphone/ -- -- Latest news and views from Iran, Middle East and the World Help Status About Careers Press Blog Privacy Terms Text to speech Teams

Title: Not all devices are meaningful, nor should they be.
Subtitle: Written by Vanessa Julia Carpenter
Author: Vanessa Julia Carpenter
Article: Sign up Sign in Sign up Sign in Vanessa Julia Carpenter Follow -- Listen Share After having done a whirlwind circuit in the beginning of June, visiting Jewellery of Tomorrow, Respond Festival and Folkem√∏det and presenting some design guidelines for Designing for Meaningfulness, a question kept arising, ‚ÄúDoes every device have to be meaningful?‚Äù ‚Äî Answer: No. The quick answer is no, and if I may be so bold as to say - no, of course not. The slightly longer answer is ‚Äî there are plenty of devices and systems which do a great job and do what is needed, and the area of devices which I am interested in is those which affect people on a personal level, consumer facing devices. Read on for the elaborated answer ‚Äî which, by the way, is very open to debate! Please feel free to contact me at hello@vanessacarpenter.com or in the comments on Medium. During a workshop at Respond Festival , some questions which I have heard before began to arise. Sometimes people have created services, which get you from point a to point b; or maybe they‚Äôve made a device such as a water sensor to detect when there is a leak in your home. There are many examples of useful, functional and even necessary devices which do not need to consider meaningfulness. Let‚Äôs take the example of the water sensor. FIBARO makes such a water sensor: https://www.fibaro.com/en/products/flood-sensor/ It has all the expected bells and whistles. It notifies you and sounds an alarm if there is water detected, it can control floor heating and can be coupled to a smart valve to turn off a valve if a leak is detected. If I think about the Mechanics of Meaningfulness, it does fit some of the characteristics ‚Äî namely, identity, being someone who has taken precautions to take care of their home; value over function, the function is to detect water, but the value is in the security of knowing your home will be okay when the valve is automatically shut off in case of a leak, or that you will receive a notification if there is a storm and water is flooding in. However, these are not necessarily personal aspects. It has some level of comforting, reassurance, but it is not helping you develop as a person, to deepen your relationships with others, or to build towards a life of fulfilment. This is what I mean when I am talking about Designing for Meaningfulness. It‚Äôs not to say that this is not a meaningful product ‚Äî again, the terminology of ‚Äòmeaning‚Äô, ‚Äòmeaningfulness‚Äô and a ‚Äòmeaningful life‚Äô is to say the least, complicated. And furthermore, a product can be quite meaningful, it can save you thousands of dollars if you can do something about water damage before it gets too far, or if you can have a valve automatically shut off when there is a problem. That‚Äôs meaningful. It saves time, money and definitely headaches. The kind of meaningful I am speaking about however, is on a much more personal level. Let‚Äôs take another example. I recently came across the Willow breast pump. https://shop.willowpump.com/ This is a wearable breast pump, which is discreet, wireless, and is described as ‚Äú The first all-in-one wearable breast pump. Mobile. Quiet. Spill-Proof. Trusted. Willow fits inside your bra, and into your schedule. ‚Äú. Now, to be clear, I do not have children. I haven‚Äôt experienced the pain, shame, suffering, and frustration that my friends have described when trying to pump breast milk whilst trying to keep up with the daily circus of having children, a home and a career ‚Äî or any combination thereof. To me, the Willow breast pump sounds like an amazing solution. And judging from their testimonials, it is working wonders ‚Äî or rather, allowing women to work wonders. Maybe it doesn‚Äôt directly help you develop as a person, or does it? If we are speaking about the Mechanic: Personal Development then doesn‚Äôt it address identity: career woman / mother? Or Meaningfulness in the Everyday ‚Äî being able to go about your day and not worry about finding a private place to pump breast milk, where you won‚Äôt be disturbed or disturb others? (Maybe not so much a problem here in Denmark where we have a year‚Äôs maternity leave, and many public spaces have breast feeding rooms, but definitely a problem in some other countries). It definitely speaks to Value over Function, the function is to extract and store milk, but the value is allowing a woman to do what she both needs and wants to do without the typical hassle associated with pumping milk. So does it help with personal development? I would argue yes, indirectly, it allows for a woman to be who she wants to be, to work if she wants to, or to participate in activities, or to be free of a complicated, loud machine. Does it help with relationships? Yes again, I‚Äôd say yes ‚Äî you can socialize, you can work, you can schedule your life as you would like to. So this is perhaps a great example of Designing for Meaningfulness ‚Äî an indirect example, the device itself is not necessarily pushing for you to work on self development or to develop relationships but it allows you to do those things. I encounter people making all kinds of devices: industry 4.0 monitoring solutions, smart home products, medical devices, children‚Äôs toys, the list goes on. Sometimes, Designing for Meaningfulness will be useful, as a thinking experiment, or as part of the design process itself. Other times, a company might just need a product which measures a parameter and delivers clear numbers. As a result of my research for presentations, I‚Äôve been looking more and more into sustainability. I cover some of this in my dissertation, the tendency to design for obsolescence and how many academics are working to combat this, and how some companies are also looking for more sustainable solutions. Recently, when I presented Designing for Meaningfulness, I had someone come up afterwards and say how important this work was (thank you!) for their domain. They work in construction and explained about how much waste there is in building sites. I won‚Äôt get into the details, but suffice to say, even though they are not designing for self or interpersonal development, they could still see how utilizing critical thinking, or considering the value over function, or designing for the long term would be beneficial to them. This is a very brief post ‚Äî but one which I hope answers the question, do all devices need to facilitate meaningfulness? Nope. Your car keys will open your car, all and any contextually derived meaning resulting from that experience is entirely up to you. But that doesn‚Äôt mean that we shouldn‚Äôt be focused on how we might Design for Meaningfulness in other areas, or at the very least, ask ourselves if it is something we might consider when ideating new products. Originally published at http://www.meaningfuldevices.com on September 12, 2019. -- -- Challenger of the status-quo and dedicated to playfulness and creativity, Vanessa is on a mission to enable meaningful experiences. www.vanessacarpenter.com Help Status About Careers Press Blog Privacy Terms Text to speech Teams

Title: Is GraphQL Editor a right tool for business users?
Subtitle: Written by Robert Matyszewski
Author: Robert Matyszewski
Article: Sign up Sign in Sign up Sign in Robert Matyszewski Follow -- Listen Share This article covers the basic introduction and advantages of GraphQL and GraphQL Editor for business users. Have you heard tech terms like frontend, backend or API? Well, those are essential components of every web application. The front end is what you see; the backend is the hidden engine that powers every action of your visual interface. API is a connector in between those two which allows them to communicate. It‚Äôs a set of clearly defined methods, definitions and routines how apps communicate with each other. GraphQL is a query language to describe an API So far REST API was the most popular standard of creating API‚Äôs. GraphQL was introduced in 2015 by Facebook as an alternative to REST. Back then It wasn‚Äôt just an experiment ‚Äî it was already in production inside facebook mobile apps since 2012. Just after public release, It became extremely popular, and around that time many companies were working on similar solutions. This technology started to gain attention since it can be used with many other languages and there‚Äôre many ready to go libraries to most popular styles. Right now according to Stackshare there‚Äôre nearly 2k companies using it. Early adopters included Coursera, Github, ProductHunt, Yelp or Twitter. GraphQL from its core name is something more than new API standard. Some users describe it as a tool for the specification of new solutions. Thanks to graph sourcing we can visualise existing database schema and show existing solutions on the screen. From the other side, you can prototype new business applications. With visualised graph possibilities are endless. Think about the potential advantages of giving access to internal systems for a business manager at company meeting or speeding up onboarding of new developers. Some companies have significant and complex systems; therefore it slows down digital transformation. Check below how Github‚Äôs schema in action. GraphQL is easy to learn. You have to learn 15‚Äì20 definitions to start understanding it. Not joking! Check below a list of the most important ones. Don‚Äôt get overwhelmed by too many definitions at the start. Start by checking object type ‚Äî in definition is a group of fields. Basic type definitions Graphql is strongly typed, which means that each definition must have a particular type. The Type System comes with the help, which provides several possibilities for defining elements of our API. Another exciting thing about strongly typed is the visual part. The most important feature of GraphQL for business users is that it‚Äôs language agnostic. It‚Äôs not created to work with a specific technology. It‚Äôs a query language with its own rules which for most popular programming languages. There‚Äôre many supportive libraries on the internet for C#/.NET, PHP. Javascript, Java, Python, Ruby and many more. Therefore learning a little bit of schema definition language, you‚Äôre able to communicate with all kind of developers. GraphQL is flexible and efficient. In traditional REST approach developers had to send many requests to show data on one screen. It‚Äôs not super efficient when it comes to mobile apps ‚Äî it slows them down and needs more internet data transfer. GraphQL allows a user to create only one endpoint and get exactly required data. Thanks to technology introduced by Facebook engineers communication between client and a server is better optimised. That‚Äôs the power of GraphQL ‚Äî flexibility. You don‚Äôt need to create endpoints for different screens. Various clients can use a once defined schema in a way that they need to. If you‚Äôre looking for best graphql tutorials check this article comparing top graphql tutorials for 2019 Originally published at blog.graphqleditor.com. -- -- Tech Business Developer. B2B Sales Hacker. Marketer. ADHD ‚Äî Sports Lover. Traveler. Help Status About Careers Press Blog Privacy Terms Text to speech Teams

Title: Monitoring Kubernetes
Subtitle: Dashboards
Author: Albert Navas
Article: Sign up Sign in Sign up Sign in Albert Navas Follow Zinklar Tech -- Listen Share Kubernetes is an orchestration tool for applications and is oriented to the microservices architecture using containers. When we have a lot of services, traffic between them and incoming connections‚Ä¶ we need to be sure that everything is optimised to prevent overloads and to detect potential problems. When we work with an autoscaling configuration we need to monitor these changes in order to make sure that we have enough resources, among other elements. There are a lot of monitoring tools on the market. In this article, we are going to approach Kubernetes, on Google Cloud Platform. Kubernetes on GCP shows some metrics on its dashboards, such as cluster nodes, deployments, pods, and services. For each of them, we can see the CPU, Memory and Disk Usage. This may be enough to start with, but when the infrastructure grows and you need more control over what is happening on your system, you need to implement other tools. Now I‚Äôm going to describe some useful tools for this purpose and how we can combine them to reach our goals. Prometheus is a monitoring platform that collects metrics from third-party systems. There are a lot of integrations. A complete list can be found here: https://prometheus.io/docs/instrumenting/exporters/ With Prometheus, we can create alerts for any metric or we can expose these metrics to other services on port 9090, as we will see later. StackDriver provides monitoring on the Kubernetes infrastructure. This service is from Google and is available to everybody on GCP. We can connect Kubernetes to StackDriver enabling the option ‚ÄúStackDriver Kubernetes Engine Monitoring‚Äù on our cluster. Now we‚Äôll see a lot of metrics that Google provides as default. StackDriver uses Prometheus to get the metrics from our cluster automatically. Now we can create dashboards with the exact parameters that we need and share them easily. It‚Äôs possible to create alerts from our dashboards and even create custom metrics from our logs. This last option is very useful as we can have direct metrics of our services‚Äô behaviour. Istio is a service mesh that allows us to connect, secure, control, and observe services within the Kubernetes infrastructure. It provides us with metrics from our services. Prometheus pulls the metrics from Istio and displays them. Then we can create alerts from these metrics on Prometheus or we can use another platform like Grafana to do this. Istio also provides is the possibility to encrypt communications between services, ingress and egress rules, a cluster gateway and much more. Grafana is an observability platform that pulls metrics from other services. To pull the metrics we need to add a data source. It can be for example, Prometheus, PostgreSQL, StackDriver, ElasticSearch‚Ä¶ Grafana allows us to create dashboards to display the metrics with beautiful graphics. We can use dashboards built by the community or official providers. Go to the Dashboards->Manage section and click the Import button. Here you can provide a JSON with the dashboard information or the ID of a dashboard from https://grafana.com/grafana/dashboards Then you‚Äôll have to provide additional information, such as name, folder, Prometheus data source, etc. depending on the dashboard. With Grafana we can create alerts for each of the metrics and send them to different channels. Channels include email, Slack, Telegram, PagerDuty, VictorOps, etc. To create an alert, go to the dashboard and click Edit on the graph you want to create the alert for. Then click on the bell icon on the left panel and click on the Create Alert button. Here you can specify the parameters of the alert you want to create. Then you can select the notifications parameters. This is a difficult part of the process. We have to try to identify the critical components of our system and think about how we can track them. We can start monitoring these attributes: We have to check if the cluster and workloads are up and running. This can be done through metrics or health endpoints on our apps. We need to monitor the cluster‚Äôs resources, which are usually CPU, memory and I/O traffic. We need to be sure that we have enough resources to run our applications without performance issues and that we have enough resources if the workloads need to scale. Istio can provide all of these performance metrics. Prometheus is the core of our monitoring, complemented with Grafana for Dashboards and Alerts. There are a lot of tools and services that can be used to set up your monitoring system. The approach explained here works for us but we recommend that you always try to adapt the tools to your needs, depending on how your system has been built. -- -- At Zinklar we eat, sleep and breathe Market Research. Our tech team wants to share their knowledge with you so read on! Software Engineer at Zinklar Help Status About Careers Press Blog Privacy Terms Text to speech Teams

Title: Organizing the biggest IT event in the most promising European country.
Subtitle: Prolog
Author: Anton Perkin
Article: Sign up Sign in Sign up Sign in Anton Perkin Follow FusionWorks -- Listen Share IT is always about communities. Such was my thinking in the far year of 2011 when I created the first Moldovan IT community on Facebook ‚Äî DeveloperMD. After a half-year of online activity we decided that we have to get together offline. Said and done: in September 2011 we had the first DeveloperMD Community Offline with approximately 40 participants. One week later me and my partner created a software development company ‚Äî FusionWorks ‚Äî this was inspired by the outcome of the first event. Already in November, now having FusionWorks as the main partner, we‚Äôve organized the 2nd edition. At some point, due to the growing size of the event, we realized that it should be done once a year and eventually we had 11 editions so far. In 2018 the big change took place ‚Äî event was extended to two days, the name was changed to Moldova Developer Conference and another, much bigger venue, was selected. This led to the increase of number of participants ‚Äî 350 ‚Äî which makes MDC the biggest IT conference for developers in the country. This year #MDC19 is planned for November 2‚Äì3 and we expect around 450 awesome people to attend. So let me tell you more about what is going to happen in 2019. Well, let‚Äôs count: Still not sure? Just watch this video from 2018. Like it? Then read more below :) Simple! Sometimes people ask: ‚ÄúWhy are you doing this?‚Äù. The answer simple ‚Äî we do it because we can. And because we love it! Having hundreds of bright eyes before you is the pleasure that can‚Äôt be denied. So we started in 2011 and are not going to stop. Ok, let‚Äôs now learn more about the host country ‚Äî Moldova ‚Äî this small IT valley. See you in the most promising IT country in Europe! Anton Perkin, CEO at FusionWorks -- -- FusionWorks is a software development company that focuses on full-cycle product development, outstaffing services and IT community building. The company was founded in 2011 by Genadii Ganebnyi and Anton Perkin. More at https://fusion.works I‚Äôm a passionate company and product manager, software engineer and community builder. Working in IT since 2004. CEO at FUSION Help Status About Careers Press Blog Privacy Terms Text to speech Teams

Title: Amazing Benefits of Xcard for Traders
Subtitle: Written by Wiliam paul
Author: Wiliam paul
Article: Sign up Sign in Sign up Sign in Wiliam paul Follow -- Listen Share Every money we use in childhood is all a gift from our mothers, fathers or other families so that we once thought of the childhood where our parents got their money they gave us after their parents were gone. As we get older, we finally know that all the assets owned by our parents come from the efforts they make so that we realize how important a business must be to gain profitability in life. Many types of businesses that can be done by someone to fill their financial coffers, one of which became the target of the acquisition of the general public is trading. This type of business is considered as a business that provides bright opportunities like the future and has an independent nature where a trader can regulate the ups and downs of the trading situation that they do without having to be bound by the rules of the leadership that are sometimes different from one‚Äôs will. In the world of Blockchain technology as it is today, trading activities have been carried out in modern ways. Unlike past forms of trade where everyone has to find the right location in various market lands to build their shops and must guard it from morning to night, now trading has been done through the digital world where everyone is free to choose the location of their stores even exist which makes their private room their land for sale and every item they sell will be posted on various e-commerce sites to further obtain orders from their customers. Along with the development of Blockchain technology, various crypto currencies such as BTC, ETH and DOGE were born which are widely used by people in making payment transactions for the trades they run so that traders today are highly demanded to have a platform that can store and transact all types of crypto currencies given the rampant use of cryptocurrency today. For this reason the XCard platform was created. XCard is a Blockchain technology for payment and transaction crypto currency that is useful in handling the management of trade transactions conducted by someone. Every user can send or receive money instantly wherever and whenever they want. And the good news, traders who use this platform can receive payments from all customers in crypto or fiat currencies so they don‚Äôt need to worry about the limited currency payments they will receive from the sales they have made. Every trader who has joined this platform will be given a wallet called XWallet in the form of a smartphone application that can be downloaded via Playstore for android users and Appstore for Iphone users. XWallet is an XCard multi-asset wallet which supports more than 150 types of fiat currencies from various countries in the world where traders can conduct financial transactions on their crypto and fiat currencies here. traders can also exchange their crypto currencies with fiat currency or vice versa on this wallet. With the presence of this wallet in the middle of the digital market share provides an installation service for digital traders around the world. In addition to the privileges provided by XCard for traders through the ‚ÄúAll In One‚Äù wallet, this platform also provides a credit card called the XCard Credit Card that can be used as a crypto or fiat currency transaction tool at various ATMs around the world. Users are provided with ease in the form of easy access to this card where users can use this card as a means of depositing money and payment instruments in any E-commerce and can also be used for cash withdrawals in cash withdrawals machines anywhere as we have mentioned before. The Xcard credit card that has the same principles as XWallet is a debit card that has used the VISA Logo. VISA is the name of a company providing financial authorization services that has operated in various countries in almost all continents in the world. Credit cards that have been certified by this company are considered an appropriate tool and to be used for various activities in the banking world because this company guarantees every security from various companies that have worked together as partners. Therefore, it is very appropriate for traders to choose XCard as their trust platform. Title: AI Biweekly: Optimistic Outlook for IoT & AI-Powered Smart Homes
Subtitle: An Optimistic Forecast for IoT
Author: Synced
Article: Sign up Sign in Sign up Sign in Synced Follow SyncedReview -- Listen Share Ivan Zhou ‚Äî Analyst, Global Industry With the new year underway a number of consulting firms and research institutes have released their forecasts for Internet of Things applications in 2019. According to the IDC, global IoT spending will increase by 15.4 percent in 2019, with US$100 billion going to manufacturing; while insurance, the federal government, and healthcare will see the fastest investment growth. The forecast provided by the consultancy Nerdery is similar: healthcare, manufacturing, automotive, and local city councils will see a broad range of rapid IoT applications. There is a clear trend to leverage IoT technology to connect devices and bring data online, then use artificial intelligence technology to do proactive mitigation, risk management, and efficiency improvement. It is a clear path, but based on past experiences, it is still very challenging in implementation, and will likely require one of the industry giants to finish building an end-to-end implementation platform and show clear monetary value. The remaining players will then follow and replicate the success. By this point the proliferation of IoT will become sustainable. January 4 ‚Äî Four Industries Will See More and Rapid Implementation of Internet of Things January 4 ‚Äî IoT Spending will Reach US$745 Billion Globally in 2019 Rirou Xiong ‚Äî Analyst, Global Industry Consumer electronics manufacturers such as Panasonic and Sharp are launching lines of dedicated Internet of Things Home Electronics products. The core ‚Äúsmart home‚Äù definition has changed from saving energy to improving lives, and Panasonic‚Äôs new ‚ÄúHome X‚Äù service creates consumer convenience by linking rice cookers, water heaters, roller shutters, consumer electronics, electronic locks and wireless connections etc. in residential installations. An artificial intelligence system can control the entire digital home through the cloud network. Panasonic is also working on next-generation Home X models enabled by cloud-based artificial intelligence, a trend which is expected to continue this year and into the future. Title: Apple, Amazon, and the Great Media Wars to Come
Subtitle: Can we trust our tech overlords to bundle the publishing industry?
Author: Mike Mallazzo
Article: Sign up Sign in Sign up Sign in Member-only story Mike Mallazzo Follow -- 4 Share For a company that looked like it had frankly given up on selling to the commoners, Apple‚Äôs keynote this week was a refreshingly egalitarian product launch. The company announced a low-interest credit card, a TV streaming service, and the long-awaited Apple News+. Even with the ludicrous 50 percent tax Apple levies on publishers, the potential ubiquity (read: 1 billion iPhones) of Apple News+ makes it about as close to a potential savior of journalism as the free market has the ability to create. No other company can offer the same scaled combination of distribution and bundled incentives to entice people to pay for news. No other company except the sleepless giant in Seattle. Before diving into that, let‚Äôs take a quick look at the publisher side of the Apple News+ equation. There‚Äôs a tendency to treat the business dynamics of publishers as a homogeneous plight, but the economics of the New York Times and the New Yorker are vastly different, to the point that a single model cannot well serve the interests of each. Furthermore, even as the industry transitions from advertising to subscriptions, media economics is largely a zero-sum game where a user subscribing to the Wall Street Journal often does so at‚Ä¶ -- -- 4 Drinking gin and writing about the future of media and commerce.
