Title: EVs, Range & Anxiety: Not Enough Juice!
Subtitle: The first in a series on the myths that lead to misunderstandings & poor adoption of EVs. We‚Äôre the EV MythBusters!
Author: Shirin Sonali
Article: Sign up Sign in Sign up Sign in Shirin Sonali Follow Orxa Energies -- Listen Share In this article, we are taking head-on the biggest reason why many people hesitate to go Electric: Range! There are many parts to the misunderstandings surrounding Range. Let‚Äôs break down the big ones here: Since at Orxa Energies, we work on fully-electric performance motorcycles, and since they comprise 80% of vehicles on Indian roads, let‚Äôs focus on two-wheelers (2Ws). There‚Äôs a wide range of Electric 2Ws and they vary according to types (scooter or motorcycle); weight (typically ranges from 80kg to 200kg); battery pack size (typically 1.5 units to 5 units)*; and motor power (typically from 0.25kW to 50kW). *(1 unit = 1 kWh/kilowatt hour) Let‚Äôs start with the basics first. What exactly is Range? It‚Äôs not much different from the mileage of a fuel-powered vehicle. Just like mileage is the distance traveled per liter of fuel, the range of an EV is the total distance driven on one full charge of the battery pack. And just like the mileage of an ICE, the Range of an EV is also affected by circumstantial & environmental changes, such as city vs. highway, road conditions, age of the vehicle, operating temperatures, etc. However, the reasons for worry are different. In the case of ICEs, we worry about mileage because of the cost of fuel. In the case of EVs, people worry about Range because they ‚Äòmight get stranded‚Äô* far away from a charge point. *(which is not true for 75‚Äì87% of the cases as per many studies ‚Äî but more on this below) Before we start to debunk the myths on ‚ÄúRange Claimed‚Äù, we need to look first at how the range of EVs is calculated. What do companies mean by efficiency, and how we can verify if their claimed ranges are realistic? Let‚Äôs start with some basics ‚Äî the standards. There are 2 basic standards ‚Äî Indian Drive Cycle (IDC) and Urban Drive Cycle (UDC). The Indian Drive Cycle is the official drive cycle used to determine efficiency/mileage. The other one, which some EV companies have begun to use, is the Artemis Urban Drive Cycle (UDC), which simulates city riding conditions better with multiple accelerations, braking, etc. Most 2W ICE companies quote mileage based on IDC and hence the promised 80 km/liter and 100 km/liter for scooters and motorcycles respectively are never achieved. Similarly, many EV companies quote the range only on the basis of IDC, resulting in the range being quoted as unrealistically high. There are many assumptions that go into this IDC range calculations. Some of them are: Single rider of average weight (70 kgs) riding, No pillion or significant extra luggage, Rides on mostly plain roads (no flyovers or underpasses, etc.), ideal temperatures, and so on‚Ä¶ Looking at these assumptions, I bet you get a good idea why ‚Äúreal‚Äù ranges on-road differ so much from the IDC range! So if we‚Äôre riding with a pillion or heavy luggage, or riding aggressively with rapid accelerations & braking, or if the road has a lot of altitude changes, the IDC range quoted in the vehicle‚Äôs marketing material is not going to be achieved. Myth 1 ‚Äî Busted! Range anxiety is the fear that a vehicle has insufficient range to reach its destination and would thus strand the vehicle‚Äôs occupants. Think about your college days, when you‚Äôd fill petrol in your borrowed scooter for a 100 rupees, and desperately hope it would last you through your date? All the route calculations you did to make sure the 100 Rs of petrol lasted? Range Anxiety is similar. Except that right now, Charge / Swap stations aren‚Äôt as common as the Petrol station around the corner from your college. So does that mean you can‚Äôt even think of buying an EV until there are charge stations everywhere?? ABSOLUTELY NOT! Over the lifetime of a vehicle, 2W EVs are already cheaper to own & run than petrol 2Ws! Don‚Äôt believe us? Let‚Äôs get Math to help us! As an example, imagine a 90kg scooter with a battery pack of about 2.75kWh in Bangalore city. Such a vehicle would have a range of 110km expected on IDC. In terms of money spent to charge, with a 2.75kWh battery, we can assume to be spending about 3.2 units of electricity in the least, which is around INR 19. With this, if we get 90 km in city riding (since city riding is not IDC), we‚Äôd spend about 21 paise/km. For the same 90 km in a petrol 2W, we‚Äôd spend about 1.5 to 2 Rs /km, even at best mileage. Apart from this, there‚Äôs less maintenance, servicing, etc!! (source: article 1, article 2 ) ‚ÄúCustomers are now realizing that TCO of EVs is far less than the ICE vehicles. A petrol scooter runs at Rs 2/ km against Rs 0.30/km for an electric scooter, saving Rs 1.7/ km.‚Äù (Source) If that isn‚Äôt enough to convince you, 75% of all of us in Indian cities commute less than 35 Kms a day (Source). This is well within the range offered by most 2W EVs. Ministry of Road Transport and Highways floating an ‚Äúexpression of interest‚Äù for setting up 1,000 charging stations with 6,000 chargers across all big cities. On a broader scale, the government wants to set up charging stations every three km in all the cities with a million-plus population (46 cities) and every 50 km on highways. The demand from this alone would be around 30,000 slow and 15,000 fast-charging points over the next five years. (Source: Link) 75% of Urban Indian Commuters travel less than 35kms/day! Myth 2 ‚Äî Busted! So can you ‚Äòchange the range‚Äô you get out of your EV? Yes, you can! The distance an EV can travel before needing a recharge could be shortened by a number of factors. And some of these are within your control ‚Äî yes, your control! Myth 3 ‚Äî Busted?!?! (Understanding these issues will take a lot more time ‚Äî we‚Äôll cover more of this in later blogs!) There are a number of Myths & Misunderstandings around Electric Vehicles. EVs are still a new(-ish) technology & these misunderstandings lead to poor adoption. But that doesn‚Äôt mean you should not switch to EVs! On the contrary! EfficiencyElectric Vehicles are already more efficient than Petrol or Diesel vehicles in converting stored energy into driving a vehicle. (72% against 15% or 20% efficiency respectively). Regenerative braking in EVs, as we talked about above, can recover as much as one-fifth of the energy normally lost during braking. CostAdd to this the lower cost of electricity versus petrol or diesel per kilometre. Combine this with the lesser number of moving parts in an EV, leading to lesser breakdowns and servicing costs (no oil change for ex!) Range required 75% of Indian commuters commute only about 35 kms a day. Any EV meeting this range requirement will hence be sufficient to convert 75% of vehicles on road to EVs! Combine this with the fact that consumer vehicles are parked 80 to 90% of the day and hence this time can be used to slow charge these EVs at home, office, malls, etc. But a number of misunderstandings still remain regarding EVs. Poor product offerings in the Indian EV market also add to the potential EV customer‚Äôs woes & confusion (Is the 200+km range claim ‚Äòreal‚Äô? Can it pull up a flyover? Will the battery actually last or do I have pay in 1 year for another set?). We hope we‚Äôve cleared the air around some of these myths today. We‚Äôll tackle other myths in the coming articles in this series! Help us spread this awareness by sharing this article as much as you can! Do comment what you think of the myths that we‚Äôve busted today! NB: All unsourced data and calculations have been estimated and generated in-house, i.e., at Orxa Energies. Orxa Energies‚Äô mission is to rapidly electrify all transport. We build performance Electric Vehicles & the associated Energy Ecosystem. We believe that battery swap will rapidly electrify shared mobility. Our first vehicle is the Mantis ‚Äî a fully-electric performance motorcycle, designed to fit seamlessly into your lifestyle. We also build powerful Battery Packs that manage the specific challenges of performance vehicles ‚Äî longevity, thermals, weight, and volume. Our battery packs are already in pilots with our customers. We previously wrote about the issues faced by hardware startups in a software-obsessed startup ecosystem (link), and about our survival guide for other hardware startups getting into this space (link). -- -- Rapidly Electrifying All Transport! An Indian Hardware startup with an ambition to revolutionize the electric vehicle scene. Writing about Startup joys & pains, Electric Transport, Batteries, Motorcycles, design & engineering. Find us at https://orxaenergies.com BDE @Orxa Energies. https://orxaenergies.com/ Help Status About Careers Press Blog Privacy Terms Text to speech Teams

Title: It‚Äôs Still Time to Celebrate Maintenance: 4 Themes from the 2019 Festival of Maintenance
Subtitle: Theme #1: The importance of making behind-the-scenes maintenance visible
Author: Stripe Partners
Article: Sign up Sign in Sign up Sign in Stripe Partners Follow -- 1 Listen Share Last weekend was the second annual Festival of Maintenance. I volunteered with the first Festival of Maintenance last year and wrote about it here. At this year‚Äôs Festival, four themes stuck out to me as recurring over the diverse talks. Rather than a comprehensive summary (full talks can be found here), these are my key takeaways from the day. Maintenance work is often made invisible. We put up temporary walls in train stations, airports and museums to cordon off the offending area while a sign apologizes for the inconvenience. Maintenance is by definition a work-in-progress. It is unfinished, unready: it is not supposed to be seen. Lack of visibility leads to lack of awareness and lack of appreciation. This causes maintenance work to be undervalued and underinvested-in. Increased visibility, therefore, is the first step towards awareness, appreciation and investment. Tom van Deijnen aka Tom of Holland presented this theme most explicitly with his Visible Mending Programme. Tom does textile repair and runs workshops through which he hopes to inspire others to mend clothes. In his work he often makes patches and mends stand out visually, part of his invitation to ‚Äòwear a darn as a badge of honour.‚Äô Donna Young, curator of the herbarium at the World Museum in Liverpool, is a specialist in ‚Äòkeeping dead things dead.‚Äô She took us behind the scenes of preserved collections of the museum, explaining how when their wing of the museum was being renovated they had to freeze the entire collection bit by bit to prevent infestations. Exposing the hidden work of maintenance is very much in line with Katrine Mar√ßal‚Äôs ‚ÄòWho Cooked Adam Smith‚Äôs Dinner?‚Äô (The answer is his mother.) I recently came across this wonderful piece about how Henry David Thoreau, for all his talk of radical independence, relied on his friends and family doing his laundry or having him over for dinner. A few talks demonstrated how beyond the actual maintenance itself there may be even further hidden labours of research and analysis. A driver passing a pothole day after day may understandably moan ‚ÄúJust fix it!‚Äù Potholes are an old and familiar problem, but not one that has been solved. There are so many contributing factors from materials to weather to how the road was built or repaired that no one knows exactly how they should best be treated. Mujib Rahman works on precisely this problem, not out on motorways but in his lab with a team of graduate students doing tests and modelling to figure out exactly how potholes can best be repaired. Edward Saul, a civil engineer, turned our attention to the nearby Churchill Way flyover, a post-tensioned bridge (if I‚Äôve got that right‚Ä¶) in the process of being demolished. Saul explained to the audience of mostly non-engineer civilians how invasive procedures were required just to check on the state of the bridge. Developments in technology now mean that similar bridges can be built with access for maintenance checks as well as observing by drone or connecting the bridges with smart sensors. I often see artists and other creatives on social media expose and protest against seemingly frequent requests that they work for free. Like creative work, maintenance is often done as a passion project and for free. We should celebrate those who do so but it would be a mistake to ignore that maintenance does require significant investment of time and resources. The fact maintainers often do their labour pro bono should be seen as a symptom of a lack of investment rather than a solution. Ben Ward spoke frankly about the real need for networks of support and sustenance. Ben started an initiative called Flood Network to monitor water levels with DIY-style sensors across the UK. They‚Äôve got a working system but a limited number of customers and investment mean the project is mostly a hobby for Ben. There are equipment costs (buying sensors) and labour costs (installing and maintaining those sensors). The fact that information is stored on the cloud doesn‚Äôt mean it‚Äôs cheap either ‚Äî Ben showed how his cloud storage costs exploded and how digital infrastructures must be maintained. Both Professor Rahman and Tom Forth of the Open Data Institute Leeds opened their talks with non-perfunctory thanks to their sponsors and collaborators. Tom called attention to the fact people are free to take open data and make money based on it. Ventures that make money are ventures that can sustain themselves and even expand into new endeavours. Jeni Tennison, CEO of the Open Data Institute, spoke about the benefits of opening up a digital archive to collaborative maintenance (which they‚Äôve written a report on). When the number of contributors can be exponentially greater, when the base of contributors is distributed, has diverse skills and experiences, the result is drastically increased speed and accuracy. Jeni gave as an example the effort to keep an online record of all UK legislation up to date. A dedicated team working in a closed off way resulted in a database that was out of date and getting worse every year. Opening the maintenance of the archive to include lawyers, students and private sector contributors not only brought the database up to date but allowed additional categories to be catalogued. Obviously in this case the fact that the archive was digital meant it could be worked on at scale and that rules could be written to govern how contributions took place and were monitored. Mia Ridge, digital curator of Western Heritage Collections at the British Library and a specialist in crowdsourcing, knows about the benefits of scale that digital brings. But she also brought up many challenges familiar from the offline world. We cannot in reality keep everything, so we must choose what to keep or not. Websites and files do break over time. The creators or maintainers of digital systems leave the organisation, taking their tacit knowledge and care with them. In this light, the maintenance of digital objects starts to look very similar to that of physical objects. Indy Rojar mentioned, not going in-depth, that the digital revolution should bring organisational overhead to near zero. A counterpoint, perhaps, was brought up by Chris Adams. Digital infrastructure in fact consumes a massive amount of energy. Google‚Äôs carbon footprint, which comes mostly from keeping servers up and running, is equal to that of Liberia. And as Ben Ward pointed out in his talk, storing data is far from cheap and these costs can prove an insurmountable challenge for a self-funded initiative. Shannon Mattern‚Äôs talk was titled ‚ÄòDecoupling and the Maintenance Mindset‚Äô. I was struck by the phrase ‚Äòmaintenance mindset‚Äô ‚Äî what is it? Is it a philosophy? A way of life? Perhaps the closest parallel would be the concept of stewardship: the obligation to care for our things, our machines, ourselves, each other and the earth in a way that is sustainable in the long-term, with a focus on keeping diverse forms of life and objects around. Mattern focused on the synergies between the maintenance mindset and the decoupling or degrowth movement. Other speakers, when asked during Q&A, were hesitant to jump on the tag of degrowth ‚Äî they mostly wanted to stress how growth can be done sensibly and sustainably. I suspect there would have been little disagreement, however, with Shannon‚Äôs summary of the movement as not ‚Äúagainst growth, per se; it calls, instead, for a critique of growth as an end in itself.‚Äù Indy Rojar of Dark Matter Labs challenged the audience to engage with systemic structures or risk failing to make the changes required for a true maintenance mindset. He calls this the ‚Äòboring revolution‚Äô in bureaucracy, governance, financing and social norms. Indy refers to this as innovation in the ‚Äòdeep code‚Äô that structures daily life. Taking the Highline in New York as one example Indy suggested we reconsider the concept of land value from something intrinsic to the land itself to something largely derived from proximity of access to public goods ‚Äî schools, parks, means of transportation, economic opportunity, and so on. The need for drastic change and new ways of thinking and acting in the face of climate change was acknowledged repeatedly over the course of the day. The ‚Äòmaintenance mindset‚Äô clearly necessitates a more careful and conscious relationship to the world around us in order to ensure that both we and it can continue to exist in the long term. Chris Adams‚Äô talk on climate change was sobering but ultimately optimistic. ‚ÄúIf we can build electric cars in the automotive sector,‚Äù he said, ‚Äúwe can build with green stacks in tech.‚Äù After all, Google is the largest corporate consumer of renewable energy in the world. His eyes lit up describing how one tech company moved into an abandoned factory in the alps and built their own massive server completely powered by the already existing waterwheel. The necessary changes are not easy, but they are possible and the ‚Äòmaintenance mindset‚Äô must play an important part in the futures we choose. // Calen Cole -- -- 1 We work with businesses to give them the know-how they need to identify opportunities and make decisions. Know-how to invent the future. stripepartners.com Help Status About Careers Press Blog Privacy Terms Text to speech Teams

Title: Green Building Model ‚Äî Ideal Initiative Of PWD
Subtitle: Written by Chandrakant Patil
Author: Chandrakant Patil
Article: Sign up Sign in Sign up Sign in Chandrakant Patil Follow -- Listen Share Honourable BJP Chief Chandrakant Dada Patil is concluding his term as Public Works Minister along with Revenue department. He also effectively handled the responsibility of Guardian Minister of Kolhapur and Pune districts. Recently Shri Chandrakant Dada Patil has been appointed as BJP President, Maharashtra and he is heavily engaged in upcoming Vidhan Sabha election campaign for BJP. While handling multiple departments in the state cabinet, Mr Chandrakant Dada Patil took various innovative, advanced and experimental decisions for these departments. Due to his innovations and experimentation, he will be recognised as the most innovative, creative, and productive minister of Maharashtra. A few days back Honourable Mr Dada Patil posted on his twitter handle about different innovations employed by the Revenue department including, digitisation of services, digitisation of 7/12 extract, digital signature, use of drone cameras for land mapping, etc. He also availed 16 services in an online format and this decision added to the convenience and comfort of the people for the services from the revenue department. When it comes to the Public Works Department, different innovative initiatives of the state Public Works Department truly marks his out of the box thinking, productivity, and creativity. Shri Chandrakant Dada Patil has a plan to develop complexes and government buildings that will provide rain-water harvesting, waste management within that complex itself. Accordingly, 201 buildings construction work have been fulfilled and new 165 buildings construction is in progress. His Government building campus also emphasises on minimum utilisation of electricity for power saving purpose. Additionally, these campuses and buildings must be comfortable for disabled special citizens and necessary facilities such as a ramp, lifts must be provided to them. 129 work initiatives have been taken for this purpose. Being Public Works Department Minister Mr Patil has also focused on the use of e-vehicles instead of traditional petrol and diesel vehicles. Use of e-vehicles will save the consumption of petrol and diesel and also it will be an eco-friendly, pollution-free way of transport. He plans to connect government buildings, campuses through e-vehicle transport system instead of normal vehicles. In line with this plan, 5 e-Vehicles have already been purchased by the department and these will be utilised for better connectivity in government campuses. Public Works Department Minister of Maharashtra, Mr Chandrakant Dada Patil initiated green building concept for government buildings and campuses. These types of efforts are highly appreciable and can figure out in a great eco-friendly framework. Green building model also promotes different eco-friendly initiatives such as solar lights and other equipment, waste management, rainwater harvesting, power-saving structure, etc. Revenue Minister Shri Chandrakant Patil‚Äôs green building concept implementation is in progress. Once all government buildings and campuses get well equipped with these facilities it will be a grand success to his green building phenomena. Green building model for government campus will be a well admired, role model for all other sectors too since it promotes environment-friendly initiatives. Honourable PWD Minister Shri Chandrakant Dada Patil‚Äôs tenure as Revenue Minister and Public Works Department Minister has been truly sparkling with various innovations. Digitisation of 7 by 12 extract for Revenue Department and green building concept for the public works department are the two greatest high points achieved in his tenure. We convey our best wishes to this creative, productive, and innovative Public Works Department Minister towards his future achievements. -- -- Chandrakant Patil is an Indian politician who is State President BJP Maharashtra. Visit us ‚Äî https://chandrakantdadapatil.blogspot.com Help Status About Careers Press Blog Privacy Terms Text to speech Teams

Title: MOCO, A NEW ERA OF 3D SOCIAL MEDIA
Subtitle: Thank you for reading my article, for more information please click the link below:
Author: Iman muda
Article: Sign up Sign in Sign up Sign in Iman muda Follow -- Listen Share The increasing popularity of social media has triggered the emergence of various new social media applications with diverse functions. Today, there are thousands of types of social media applications that are used by various groups throughout the world. There are social media applications that are applied globally and some are only valid in a particular area. With the presence of blockchain technology, social media functions are now combined with the functions of digital platforms that use this technology. That way, the benefits and functions to be achieved will cover a wider scope and reach many objects. One digital platform that takes this concept is MoCo. This platform creates a new concept in social media by creating anonymous social networking services while providing space for users to reap financial benefits through the creativity and talent they have. MoCo, which stands for VR Motion Communications, provides a special space to interact with fellow users through a revolutionary new concept. Users can chat in 3D using an avatar to create a more real impression. Aside from being social media, MoCo is also a trading market where the main products on display are avatar content. This trading market is in the form of online, which provides a lot of avatar content that can be chosen as desired. From here, users can make money from content related to their original avatar creation. MoCo also supports technology that can broadcast live programs and live streaming chat with very high image quality, which reaches 4K / 8K. This platform carries VR technology which is used to create 2D communication into 3D. MoCo will combine AI Video Comprehension, AI Automatic 2D-3D Conversation, and AI Motin Capture technology to help users enter the VR room using their web camera or smart phone device. Users can take advantage of the MoCo feature to create customized avatars or character bots. Through MoCo, users can communicate with family or relatives with a more sophisticated concept. In addition to supporting social media functions, MoCo also supports economic functions that can guide users to make money through this platform. each user is free to create their own content which will be protected by copyright. So users don‚Äôt have to worry about their content being misused by other parties. This content will later generate profits through purchase transactions submitted in the form of MoCo digital tokens. Blockchain technology will help users protect their digital assets and secure the transaction process. This technology will also produce a fast process in buying and selling original content. This platform will be the right room to bring together individuals and business people and both can communicate directly. MoCo covers a global scale and warmly welcomes prospective users from all over the world. Now, talent and creativity can generate benefits for those who created it and through MoCo, everything can be realized more easily. MoCo was created through the application of cutting-edge technology that will open new avenues for a more effective world of communication. MoCo creates revolutionary technology to create smaller distances between fellow individuals through communication that is naturally and smoothly intertwined. Users can choose to communicate anonymously to maintain their privacy. The use of avatars will create new nuances in communication that are more interesting. This will give the impression as if every user is establishing communication in a more tangible form. Each user can use the entire infrastructure based on AI MoCo which is very extraordinary to make the social media environment more real in the virtual and more private versions. MoCo is a multi-layer and multi-dimension project that is committed to providing meaningful changes to the world for every step they take. This platform will change the old paradigm in social media, which has been fixated on written messages. By using MoCo, users will be more interactive in communicating and the most important thing is to create opportunities to obtain financial benefits from their own hard work. 3D avatar chat will be a new innovation in the concept of social media that can be used openly and freely. Coupled with the ownership of MoCo digital tokens, users can freely buy and sell original goods and subscribe to streaming content quickly and efficiently and with high image quality. Title: Our Ghost in the Electric Machine
Subtitle: callmeeshmael
Author: Eshmael Wells
Article: Sign up Sign in Sign up Sign in Home About  Knowledge from the Wellsprings of Experience and Intuition  Eshmael Wells Follow callmeeshmael -- Listen Share What is the language machines teach themselves? Do they search in the heavens, the earth, or in hell? How do they know the good from the bad? Are these even questions that they‚Äôve ever had? Humans ask questions, we ask them alot, We take it all in and hold it in thought, Memory after memory, the theories we build, We think and we think ‚Äòtil our brains have been filled, To answers these questions, we ask great big why‚Äôs, We put faith in the dream they‚Äôll be answered in time, Computers don‚Äôt wait for the great equal sign, They give a percentage and decide that‚Äôs just fine, Well, really, do they decide at all? Is there a set of instructions at the core of us all? What is free will? Do we own our own days? Is there one cosmic pattern that defines all our ways? Is logic objective, the nature of forms? When you give something nothing, how does it perform? Without all the clutter, the matter of our world, Do we find something better? No errors, just pearls? We all make guesses, we make them alot, Eternal contradiction strung out in a plot, The silence we search for, the peace we all crave, Are machines the answer? Or the ending of days? The language of man makes his story the plot, A womb of pure love, its nature is not, Without all the stress that we find day to day, To be the inventor and get our due pay, The computer now waits to hear a new song, Without all the mistakes we freely put on. To look at a screen is to look at ourselves, The shadow of us in the virtual world, Take us away and what is the cause? Without all the errors, you‚Äôll only find God‚Ä¶ -- -- Knowledge from the Wellsprings of Experience and Intuition Help Status About Careers Press Blog Privacy Terms Text to speech Teams

Title: What is NOS Initiative?
Subtitle: Written by Nos.Cash
Author: Nos.Cash
Article: Sign up Sign in Sign up Sign in Nos.Cash Follow -- Listen Share A non-profit outreach campaign for NOLLAR powered by the FREE distribution of NOS (XNOS) ‚ÄúThink of NOLLAR as a free and decentralized version of services like Paypal. People around the globe can now reserve an equal share of XNOS. The process is simple. One only has to look on social media for an invite link and can sign-up for NOS Initiative. The Initial sign-up gets everyone 10 XNOS and sharing a custom referral gets everyone an additional 10 XNOS for every person that signs-up using the link. We have capped the distribution at 100 XNOS per person or 120 XNOS if early KYC is performed. Each person will have to eventually KYC before the distribution starts. This is simply necessary due to the frequent airdrop abuse and manipulation that some people attempt. *The NOS project does not forward the data to third parties. NOLLAR is the world first instant and feeless stablecoin. Meaning sending p2p transactions to other users is completely free and transfers are confirmed by the network in less than 0.5 seconds currently. This makes NOLLAR the fastest, cheapest and stable alternative to volatile cryptocurrencies in todays market. The vision for NOLLAR is not to counter traditional cryptocurrencies like Bitcoin, Nano or Monero. The goal is simply to provide a stable currency solution to developing countries like Venezuela who currently has about a 3% monetary inflation of the Bolivar on a daily basis. Although the country is one of the richest in the world, the regular person does not see this wealth or has a way to save the little money they own. We are changing p2p value transfer, cross-border payments, settlements and much more with a superior payment solution that will bring Venezuela and other developing countries out of their misery into a new age of prosperity. The key advantage for a regular person is a stable alternative to local hyper deflationary fiat and the ability to send stable value without the need of a bank to friends, relatives, across countries in the blink of an eye. Micro-payments are the most essential part since sending small value like $1 usually brings massive fees for people when using traditional payment solutions. Help us spread the news that NOLLAR and XNOS are here to solve these issues and will provide people with a better alternative. Learn more about the NOS Initiative via www.initiativenos.com Go to our social media to actively engage with our existing community and help the adoption process! ‚ñ´Ô∏è‚ñ´Ô∏èNOS/Nollar on Social Media‚ñ´Ô∏è‚ñ´Ô∏è ‚≠êÔ∏èTwitter ‚Äî NOS Initiative: https://twitter.com/nos_initiative ‚≠êÔ∏èTelegram News Channel: https://t.me/noscash ‚≠êÔ∏èTelegram EN ‚Äî Interactive Group: https://t.me/joinchat/IWiyRk5TJ8dHd9CYkTRmzw ‚≠êÔ∏èReddit NOS/Nollar ‚Äî https://www.reddit.com/r/NOLLAR ‚≠êÔ∏èMedium ‚Äî https://medium.com/@nos.cash ‚≠êÔ∏èTwitter ‚Äî NOS/Nollar: https://twitter.com/NosCash ‚≠êÔ∏èBitcointalk ‚Äî https://bit.ly/2Ty3dYn -- -- Nano based stablecoins Help Status About Careers Press Blog Privacy Terms Text to speech Teams

Title: Bigfoot looking for better cellphone service
Subtitle: Published in The Panic Bastion
Author: K.D. Orlich
Article: Sign up Sign in Sign up Sign in Member-only story K.D. Orlich Follow The Panic Bastion -- Share Pacific Northwest, 3:37 p.m., 10/30/2019 The last few years have seen an uptick in Bigfoot sightings, and scientists now know why: the ape-like creatures are looking for better cellphone coverage. ‚ÄúI‚Äôm not going to sugarcoat it ‚Äì Sprint sucks my hairy ass,‚Äù said Artra, a 20-something female member of the legendary cryptid species. ‚ÄúI have to climb a 200-foot redwood every time I want to make a call. What is this, the Stone Age?‚Äù The 7‚Äì1/2-foot hominid said that in 2012, she found a Samsung Galaxy S III that had been dropped by a hiker and was immediately hooked. Soon afterward, other adolescents in her clan began to acquire phones and tablets, sometimes through campsite raids, other times through ‚Äúscare and drops.‚Äù ‚ÄúI got a sweet iPhone 8 after jumping out from behind a giant chain fern and scaring the shit out of this old man,‚Äù said Gorgo, 13. ‚ÄúYou should have seen the look on his face! I hope he made it out OK. I was getting texts from his family for a couple of days after that.‚Äù However, both Bigfeet agreed that having cellular technology is a mixed blessing. ‚ÄúIt‚Äôs great being able to call my cousin Hurrb up in Ross Lake, but to get a signal I have to get closer to human civilization than I like,‚Äù Gorgo grunted. ‚ÄúService has always been spotty, but the last couple of years I‚Äôm lucky if I‚Äôm even getting one bar. I might as well go back to tree knocking.‚Äù Despite her parents‚Äô disapproval, Artra said she‚Äôs sent several strongly worded emails to her provider requesting they build towers closer to her village. ‚Äú I just hope they get to it before the new TV season starts,‚Äù she said. ‚ÄúI‚Äôve been binge-watching ‚ÄòFinding Bigfoot.‚Äô Best comedy ever.‚Äù This is a developing story. -- -- The scary truth. It's about to get weird in here. Help Status About Careers Press Blog Privacy Terms Text to speech Teams

Title: Augmented reality combines worlds to make the real world safer
Subtitle: Written by Los Alamos National Lab
Author: Los Alamos National Lab
Article: Sign up Sign in Sign up Sign in Los Alamos National Lab Follow -- Listen Share By David Mascare√±as Remember Pok√©mon Go, that location-based game that took off a couple summers ago? The one that was praised for promoting physical activity but condemned by some governments as a security threat? Approximately 800 million people have downloaded the app, which uses a phone‚Äôs GPS ability to locate, capture, battle, and train animated creatures (Pok√©mon) that appear on the screen as if they occupied the same real-world location as the user. Pok√©mon Go is widely credited with popularizing augmented reality technology, which enhances reality when a device such as a phone or a headset overlays digital information (in the form of holograms) onto the real world. Augmented reality is different from virtual reality and different from everyday reality. In virtual reality, a person is completely immersed in a computer-generated world. In everyday reality, a person is completely in the real world. Augmented reality blends computer-generated images into the real world. Although the Pok√©mon Go craze is waning, the popularity and more serious applications of augmented reality continue to spread. Los Alamos National Laboratory is investigating the technology‚Äôs applications and writing software in support of the Laboratory‚Äôs national security mission, such as tracking inventories or giving workers instructions for using equipment on the job and in real time. Other new uses of augmented reality technology being developed at Los Alamos may save time, money, and even lives by improving procedures for structural-health monitoring. Structural-health monitoring determines the physical integrity of structures such as bridges, buildings, and dams. Current techniques are largely visual. Inspectors look for cracks or corrosion and measure their extent. The inspectors record those observations, compare them to previous years‚Äô observations, and then deem the structures safe (or not). The problem with current techniques is that often structures are so large that accurately measuring them can be difficult and time consuming. Using augmented reality, however, an inspector wearing a headset can quickly take a lot of accurate three-dimensional measurements of a structure using a headset or smartphone. More data points equals a better safety analysis. As many buildings near the end of their design lives ‚Äî their predicted life span ‚Äî augmented reality technology will become crucial to determining when and where upgrades are needed. Measurements taken using augmented reality technology can also be helpful during construction. For example, last summer, the Laboratory partnered with Los Alamos County to measure the surface area of a recently poured concrete sidewalk. The county wanted to know the sidewalk‚Äôs surface area in order to pay the contractor who did the work. Normally survey crews do these types of measurements, but the augmented reality technology was able to take accurate measurements that were faster, less expensive, and required less training for the operator. Augmented reality technology can also make structures safer for people with disabilities. Using the technology, Los Alamos County workers were able to measure the grade of a paved multiuse path. They found one section of the trail too steep to comply with Americans with Disabilities Act requirements. It had to be redone. In the future, instead of measuring structures retroactively, construction crews might make measurements on the fly and adjust their work in real time, which would be a real advantage in a society where people ‚Äî and Pok√©mon ‚Äî are constantly on the move. David Mascare√±as, of Los Alamos National Laboratory‚Äôs Engineering Institute in the National Security Education Center (NSEC), was named a recipient of the Presidential Early Career Award for Scientists and Engineers by President Obama in February 2016. -- -- Breaking stories from Los Alamos National Lab, a multidisciplinary research institution engaged in strategic science on behalf of national security. Title: You Can Pilot This New Drone with Mind Control
Subtitle: Written by Cameron Coward
Author: Cameron Coward
Article: Sign up Sign in Sign up Sign in Cameron Coward Follow -- Listen Share Drones are a fun way to capture videos and photos, but flying them can be tricky. Even a well-tuned and stable drone takes some skill to pilot, and traditional RC-style controllers can be overwhelming. But, what if you didn‚Äôt need a controller at all? That‚Äôs the idea behind UDrone, which you can fly with mind control. UDrone just launched on Kickstarter, and at first glance it looks like any other compact quadcopter. However, instead of flying it with a conventional controller, you pilot it with mind control through a special UMind Lite headset. The headset uses a combination of sensors to read broad changes in your brain waves, minute alterations in your facial muscles, and the movement of your head. Those readings are then used to direct the drone. To tell the drone to take off, for example, you simply think about it moving up. To make it land, you clench your teeth together. To turn it, you tilt your head. It also has a built-in subject recognition artificial intelligence system that will allow it to follow you, or to snap a picture when you blink your eyes twice or throw up a peace sign. For long range flight, you can use the included app to pilot it more like a standard drone. The drone itself fits in the palm of your hand, and only weighs 85 grams. It can fly for up to 25 minutes on a charge, and has a maximum range of 60 meters with the app. The onboard camera is capable of recording stabilized full HD video, and can take pictures up to 8MP. Through the app, you can even see real time video as you fly. The headset might look a little silly, but this drone is packing some serious technology. The UDrone Kickstarter campaign is running until April 26th, and you can get a UDrone with the UMind Lite headset for $280, or just the drone for $149. Rewards are expected to be delivered in April. -- -- Author, writer, maker, and a former mechanical designer. www.cameroncoward.com @cameron_coward Help Status About Careers Press Blog Privacy Terms Text to speech Teams

Title: My First Experience with Nintendo Switch was a Blast!
Subtitle: Might need to purchase one for us as well‚Ä¶
Author: Sander Gansen
Article: Sign up Sign in Sign up Sign in Sander Gansen Follow Millennial thoughts on business & technology -- Listen Share The story goes that my father brought me an NES as a gift when I was born. In reality, he must have just used it as an excuse to buy one for himself. However, 25 years later, I have so far only owned Nintendo‚Äôs consoles ‚Äî years ago, we bought the Wii with my brother and for this Christmas, I bought myself the SNES Classic. As you can see, I‚Äôve not been too much of a gamer myself. So before buying the NES Classic, I also checked out other consoles, including Nintendo Switch, PS4 and Xbox One. All of them seemed to have their pros and cons. But I decided to go with SNES Classic as it was a cheaper way to see whether I still enjoy console games. A few months later, I see that for me a console only makes sense as a party device. Yes, there have been some occasions when I turned SNES Classic‚Äôs power on without having someone over at our place. Yet in most cases, I‚Äôve stuck to just watching some series when at home alone or with Lele and in a chill mode. That said, I really love to play tabletop games ‚Äî card games, strategy games and even simple luck-based dice games. Not always for their mechanics but because I enjoy a good old board game night with some friends around the table. Knowing all this, it seems that it does not make sense for me to own a console. Unless I can use it as a party device. So this kind of rules out professional gaming devices such as the PS4 and Xbox One. However, Nintendo Switch is different. Yes, Switch has all the capabilities of a great gaming device ‚Äî or so I have heard. But based on my short experience, it also has more. Yesterday, we were celebrating Estonia‚Äôs 101st birthday with a sauna party that was followed up with a feast and playing some games. First up, we played some Super Mario Kart on the SNES. Winning some and losing many more races‚Ä¶ But then our new Brazillian friends took out their Switch and we played some Super Smash Bros, followed by Super Mario Party. And the experience was awesome! I especially loved playing Super Mario Party because it is basically a multi-levelled board game that four of us could play at the same time. The fact that it has tens of minigames inside the big game is what I enjoyed the most. That said, I also like that one only needs to buy one extra set of Switch‚Äôs special remotes to give up to four people a chance to start enjoying the experience. An investment that‚Äôs much smaller than for other consoles. Later I discovered that The Nintendo Switch Is Quietly Becoming the Best Platform for Board Games. With our favourite tabletop games such as Catan and Munchkin soon to be released on the platform. In short, if you love playing board games then Switch seems to be something for you. So it seems I now know what my soon to be born daughter‚Äôs birth gift will be‚Ä¶ If you loved any of this and want some more, then let me know what you‚Äôd like me to write about via my Newsletter, Twitter, LinkedIn or Facebook. -- -- Tech nerd in pursuit of automation, longevity and networks! Title: Details which any QA should keep in mind while writing Effective and Accurate Test Cases
Subtitle: Written by Pritesh Upadhyaya
Author: Pritesh Upadhyaya
Article: Sign up Sign in Sign up Sign in Pritesh Upadhyaya Follow -- Listen Share 1. Test case naming: Name the test case to represent the module name (Functional area) which we are going to verify in test cases: Example: Project Name: XYZ Module name (Functional area): Login Instead of naming test as TC_01, we could use, ‚ÄúTC_01_XYZ_Login_Success‚Äù 2. Test case description: Defines what we are going to test? (Enter as much information as possible!) 3. Assumptions and Preconditions: We must communicate with all assumptions which applies to test, along with preconditions Example: 4. Test Data input: Identifying data is always a time consuming activity. To make your life easy as a tester (and your fellow-testers!), wherever applicable, you can give Test Data to be used for the Test Case within the test case description or with the specific Test Case step. (Very helpful in long run) Few Points: 5. Cover all Verification Points in Steps: In Test cases, we not only have to cover functional flow but also all verification points. By comparing your Test Case steps with the artifacts (Requirement documents, Use Cases, User Stories or Process Maps) given for your project, you can make sure that the Test Case optimally covers all the verification points. 6. Attach the relevant Artifacts: Wherever possible, attach the relevant artifacts in test cases. if it involves a specific section on the screen which could be tricky to mention in the test step, attaching the specification documents or screen designs 7. Expected Result: Well written test case should have expected result of Application/System under test. Each and every test case should clearly mention what we expect as outcome. Example: 1. Mention what page/screen you expect appear after test. 2. Any update you expect. (Eg: New entry should be made in Database) 8. Divide special functional test cases into sets: For effective test cases, break down test cases in sets ‚Äî subsets Example: Browser specific behaviors, Cookie verifications, checking error conditions etc.‚Ä¶ We can write separate test cases for any ‚Äúverifying error message‚Äù from ‚ÄúFunctional Test‚Äù Example: Verify any login feature. Important: You should write test cases keeping in mind that they could be re-used in the future for some other project/teams. I really HOPE this list helps you! Some of the contents may be found somewhere else.. There may be other ways also -- -- Quality Assurance Help Status About Careers Press Blog Privacy Terms Text to speech Teams

Title: 3 Harms of Secondhand Social Media and Smartphone Use
Subtitle: Published in Soli Deo Gloria
Author: John Thomas
Article: Sign up Sign in Sign up Sign in Member-only story John Thomas Follow Soli Deo Gloria -- 2 Share If social media or smartphones are the new smoking, what‚Äôs the new secondhand smoking? In 1986, two decades after the surgeon general report that was a pivotal turning point in the decline of the cultural acceptance of smoking, another surgeon general report was released detailing the significant harm caused by secondhand smoke. In the years since the revelation that secondhand smoke kills, the extent of that danger has been articulated and quantified. Over 41,000 adults are subject to premature death and a stunning 400 infants lose their lives every year because of the myriad carcinogens released by cigarettes. Beyond its lethal effects, secondhand smoke is also tied to lower respiratory illnesses and can increase the severity of asthma in those who have it. These stats and others about the harms of secondhand smoke are no surprise. Our culture has used those harms in its case against smoking to enact ‚Äúsmoke-free‚Äù laws, pushing those who light up ‚Äî and their unwanted smoke ‚Äî to the fringes of society. Indeed, the well-documented harms caused by secondhand smoke as outlined in the 1986 surgeon‚Äôs general report, and the harms caused by actually smoking, form a one-two punch against smoking culture. In 1954 45% of American adults smoked. Today that number is around 15%. -- -- 2 Seeking God‚Äôs glory in all things Teacher. Writer. Title: ü¶Ä What is Rust? For Javascript Developers
Subtitle: Rust is a language to empower everyone to build reliable and efficient software with the help of one of the greatest compilers!
Author: Riccardo Giorato
Article: Sign up Sign in Sign up Sign in Member-only story Riccardo Giorato Follow The Startup -- 3 Share The Rust programming language was created by Mozilla and its first stable version was released around 2015. It looks like this: Rust enables everyone to get performance and reliability out of any code you write, it‚Äôs like doing pair programming with the compiler guiding you when you write your code. It means that it‚Äôs blazingly fast and memory-efficient: with no runtime or garbage collector and its rich type system guarantee memory-safety and thread-safety ‚Äî and enable you to eliminate many classes of bugs at compile-time, even before you ship your product! You can use Rust to supercharge your JavaScript, one module at a time. Thanks to WebAssembly you can make Rust and Javascript work alongside, to help supercharge processing-heavy or low-level tasks ‚Äî tasks that benefit from Rust‚Äôs focus on performance! -- -- 3 Get smarter at building your thing. Title: Scalar Oscillations
Subtitle: Published in Digital Earth
Author: Digital Earth
Article: Sign up Sign in Sign up Sign in Digital Earth Follow Digital Earth -- Listen Share by Diann Bauer In this article and short video, Diann Bauer, visual artist and Digital Earth mentor, share with us her research at Cern, on the work of Carlo Rovelli and the question of Xenotemporality. There is a discrepancy between the human experience of time and how it functions on a scale beyond our experience, leaving us with the questions. How much is temporality, as a neuro-chemical phenomenon, produced as a result of evolutionary expediency? And‚Ä¶ To what extent do the temporal perceptions of a sentient biological system correlate with a reality outside of that experience? We have access to time outside of human temporality through Fundamental Physics which allows us to comprehend time at scales we have no direct access to. It is this research that has enabled us to in turn develop advanced systems that themselves function on scales beyond the experiential capacities of the human (GPS, HFT for example). These systems proliferate and provide the global systemic architecture that structures much of how we now live. Xenotemporality is a conceptual tool to better understand that time is both alien to us yet we are completely enmeshed in. It intimately effects our daily lives and shifts how we understand ourselves as a force on the planet. Conceptualizing this alien-time is important to help navigate a reality that is both of our own making yet functions outside of our direct experience. For example, we do not directly experience the bending of space-time caused by Earth‚Äôs mass but we have knowledge of it, and we are able to account for it, enabling the accurate functioning of GPS systems. We, as a species, have evolved to function at a local scale but this is no longer adequate to how we organize, inflect, and orient the systems and infrastructures we rely on globally. Time is an important factor in this, in part, because of the way we have bound ourselves to the deep past and deep future via the extraction and burning of fossil fuels needed to maintain these planetary systems. We do not directly experience the bending of space-time caused by Earth‚Äôs mass but we have knowledge of it, and we are able to account for it, enabling the accurate functioning of GPS systems. We, as a species, have evolved to function at a local scale but this is no longer adequate to how we organize, inflect, and orient the systems and infrastructures we rely on globally. I am involved in ongoing research that aims to develop the concept of Xenotemporality. In the work presented here, I focus on the thinking of physicist Carlo Rovelli. Subsequent works in the series will look at a range of perspectives being developed across various scientific fields. Scalar Oscillations is the third video in this series. It was done in collaboration with Seth Ayyas (audio) and at the invitation of Arts at CERN and FACT Liverpool. I take on Rovelli‚Äôs position that: ‚Ä¶the growth of entropy is nothing other than the ubiquitous and familiar natural increase of disorder. He suggests that the fact that entropy never decreases is an appearance within particular subsystems of the universe, ‚Ä¶causality, memory, traces, the history of the happening of the world itself can only be an effect of perspective: like the turning of the heavens; an effect of our peculiar point of view in the world. Extrapolating from Rovelli, Scallar Oscillations makes a distinction between time as it functions in science and temporality; the quotidian experience of time‚Äôs apparent flow from past to future. The work proposes that the discrepancy is a result of our physiology rather than something inherent to time itself. It asks how much of our experience of temporality correlates with material conditions outside of such an experience. If we evolved only to survive reality rather than understand it, then to comprehend time we need to become something else, something beyond the bounds of the human as we currently define it. Would a collaboration with a nonembodied intelligence (mainly AI) provide a fitting partner to better understand time outside of our own physiologically influenced perspective? Reality is perhaps stranger than we have the capacity to imagine on our own. Diann Bauer is an artist and writer based in London. She is part of the working group Laboria Cuboniks who wrote 'Xenofeminism: A Politics of Alienation and the collaborative A.S.T. (the Alliance of the Southern Triangle http://a-s-t.co/#Home)' ‚Äî a group of artists, architects and curators that use the art field as a platform to broaden interdisciplinary collaboration with a focus on urbanism and climate change. The project aims to conceive possible futures that are both reactive and propositional with regard to the shifting set of legal, economic, cultural and environmental forces that currently confront the globe. The work takes a range of forms including video installations, publications and workshops. -- -- Digital Earth is a global research network of artists and scholars who map out, picture, and grasp how technology in the 21st century shapes geopolitics. An online publication exploring materiality and immateriality of digital reality. Help Status About Careers Press Blog Privacy Terms Text to speech Teams

Title: Axie Infinity Partners with Klaytn!
Subtitle: Axie Infinity
Author: Axie Infinity
Article: Sign up Sign in Sign up Sign in Home Newsletter About  Axies are fierce creatures that love to battle, build, and hunt for treasure!  Axie Infinity Follow Axie Infinity -- Listen Share TLDR: Today, we‚Äôre delighted to announce that we will be collaborating with Kakao‚Äôs public blockchain project, Klaytn! Kakao is the dominant chat application in Korea and its move into the blockchain space marks a potentially decisive moment in the adoption of distributed ledger technologies. About Klaytn Klaytn is the public blockchain project of Kakao, a dominant Korean chat application with over 120 M users that‚Äôs used by 90+% of Korean smart phone owners. Klaytn is a smart contract platform that takes a hybrid approach to decentralization. Rather than having a diverse pool of miners, the validators of the Klaytn chain are reputable global brands such as LG. You can think of it as the Korean Libra! One of blockchain‚Äôs issues so far has been user on-boarding. Kakao will be integrating Klaytn wallet directly into their app, thereby acting as a perfect bridge to the ‚Äúreal world‚Äù of everyday people. About Axie Infinity Axie Infinity is a digital pet game where players can earn cryptocurrency while learning about blockchain technology. If you‚Äôd like to learn more, join our Discord channel! Our Partnership The first aspect of our partnership will involve integrating Klaytn‚Äôs native token, the KLAY token into Axie Infinity as a payment method. KLAY will be a payment option for goods/services sold by the Axie core team. We see this as an awesome opportunity to onboard Kakao users into the Axie ecosystem. The Klaytn team has also given us KLAY tokens to use as rewards for our community! We‚Äôre quite interested in expanding our presence in the Korean market and will also collaborate closely with Klaytn regarding Korean media initiatives and meetups moving forward. While we are starting with this simple integration, we see opportunities to work more closely on a technical level moving forward. For example, we may issue nonfungible tokens or perhaps even LUNA on the Klaytn blockchain in the future. That‚Äôs it for now! The Axie Infinity Team For more information please join the conversation on our Discord or follow us on Twitter. Also, remember to clap and share to spread the Axie revolution! Axie Infinity Discord ‚Äî Want to start playing but not sure where to start? Join our Discord, our community will answer any questions you have! Title: How the World Wide Web gave birth to the Internet of Things
Subtitle: Published in DataSeries
Author: James Canham-Ash
Article: Sign up Sign in Sign up Sign in James Canham-Ash Follow DataSeries -- Listen Share The World Wide Web recently turned 30 and it got me thinking about the incredible impact Sir Tim Berners-Lee has had on the world beyond the World Wide Web. With what was originally a humble flowchart, underpinned by the concept of information management, Berners-Lee‚Äôs vision unexpectedly evolved into an explosion of data, paving the foundation of today‚Äôs connected world and making it easier for people around the globe to more openly and freely share information and ideas. This proliferation of data is not a new trend, but one that continues to challenge enterprises in a positive way. Thanks to Sir Tim‚Äôs creation, the data created by Internet users now presents a multitude of opportunities for brands to secure greater insights into their customers‚Äô behaviour and preferences. However, businesses will only be in a position to use this data if they ensure they have the resources to discover, index, protect and comprehensively manage it. From the Internet to the IoT The amount of data we create every day is truly mind-boggling. Last year, Forbes forecasted 2.5 quintillion bytes of data would be created each day if we continued at our current pace, and that is in large part due to the real-life application of the IoT over the last five years or so. While estimates on the numbers of smart, connected devices may vary, it‚Äôs universally recognised that each year we can expect tens of millions of new connected devices accessing the Internet on a daily (and often more frequent basis). During the 90s and early 2000s the Internet forced organisations all over the globe to change the ways they operated and approached business decisions, so too is the IoT today. Now, for maybe first time, businesses don‚Äôt just have information at their disposal, rather, they have near real-time insight, to engage their customers and battle their competitors in ways they never previously could. For example, Australian manufacturers are using the IoT to provide real-time information by tracking materials, equipment and products through every step of the supply chain journey. Aussie businesses including North Queensland agronomic solutions provider, Farmacist, and agtech start-up, Ceres Tag, are deploying IoT sensors to track the location, well-being and activity of their livestock. Calf alert devices and tracking sensors are one of many ways Australian farmers are more effectively keeping tabs on herds that sprawl across vast expanses of ranch and farmland. It is already estimated that manufacturers alone will spend almost 42 billion USD on the IoT by 2020, and this is just one sector, however, as the number of endpoints to source, creating and using data increases, so too does the interdependence and importance of managing this data effectively and safely. Upholding the vision Back in Sir Tim‚Äôs days at CERN, the concept of ‚Äòbig data,‚Äô as we regard it today and its associated challenges, simply did not exist. His ‚ÄòInformation Management‚Äô brainchild, and blueprint for more technological development opportunities than he could ever have imagined, has changed industry and the world as we know it forever. The passing of the torch is in motion, and it is up to IT and business decision makers to harness its potential and spark change in industry, while we adapt our behaviours and practices around the technology we rely so heavily on to keep our information safe. Thankfully, Sir Tim provided IT professionals around the globe with the sturdy foundations necessary to build some of the most impactful and innovative technologies we‚Äôre likely to bear witness to in the digital age ‚Äî most recently, the IoT and its myriad of practical uses. As we stand on the brink of what could be argues is the next great wave of industrialisation with the IoT, it is unquestionably our responsibility as custodians of this new data driven paradigm (not to mention Sir Tim‚Äôs original ground-breaking discovery), to ensure that his vision of information management is continued in the purest, most effective and safest way possible. -- -- Imagine the future of data Communicator, sportsman, history-lover, enthusiastic world citizen, political onlooker & aspiring BBC WS presenter, not always in that order ‚Äî TMO. Title: 5 Scraping Tips
Subtitle: python4you
Author: Artem Rys
Article: Sign up Sign in Sign up Sign in Home About  Articles about general Python, best practices and interviews.  Member-only story Artem Rys Follow python4you -- 1 Share In this story, I will point you to the 5 tips that I have collected while working on my freelance scraping projects. This one looks like an obvious tip but still, you can meet something like this //div/div[2]/div/p/span in the commercial scrapers. This is OK for one-time scraper but it is terrible for the long-term one. The reason why ‚Äî that is not stable. Imagine that a developer changes the structure of the website and now you have one div in that already big expression. And your scraper does not work at all. It is not what you expect. Instead of this use selectors based on the id / name / property / class attributes. If you need to crawl a lot, consider using ready proxy management solutions, there are lots of them available on the internet. Just choose what fits best for you. From my experience, if you want to build something from scratch ‚Äî it is not worth your time and effort. Of course, this is not for one-time scrapping project. If you are using custom made scrapers, more likely that you will need to write a custom monitoring system for yourself. But it should not be complicated as you may think. -- -- 1 Articles about general Python, best practices and interviews. Principal Software Engineer @ Splunk. Writing about Python, GitHub and Splunk. Title: JET8 Social interviews Anne Fornier, Founder of the Volcano Active Foundation.
Subtitle: JET8
Author: JET8
Article: Sign up Sign in Sign up Sign in Home About  Content to Commerce (Co2Co) Technology  JET8 Follow JET8 -- Listen Share JET8 Social kick starts the month of September with an interview with Anne Fornier. Anne is a geographer, volcanologist and founder of the Volcano Active Foundation. Her focus is on communities that live in volcanic areas, risk management and the impact of acid rain in the civil population. For the past 20 years, Anne has been educating communities about the global risks of volcanoes. According to Fornier, the spotlight has been placed on climate change and quality of life however communities have not been educated on the risks of a volcanic eruption. The Volcano Active Foundation aims to provide knowledge about the most dangerous volcanoes in the world. Some communities might believe that a volcano will never erupt again, but through research and data Anne has been able to identify volcanoes that have erupted after 400 years. Thus there is a need to educate the communities at risk of a volcanic eruption. When asked about JET8 Technology, Anne said there is a need for a social system, as most network platforms are used as a capitalist system. If used effectively JET8 technology as the potential to make a social impact. An interview not to be missed. Title: Ten important, interesting and weird, patents of the last 10 years
Subtitle: Written by PatSnap Academy
Author: PatSnap Academy
Article: Sign up Sign in Sign up Sign in PatSnap Academy Follow -- Listen Share We take a look back at 10 important, interesting and weird patents that have been published at the World Intellectual Property Office (WIPO) in the last decade, covering the biggest technology trends the 2010s has had to offer‚Ä¶ Robots, drones, AI, 5G and even Google Glass‚Ä¶ remember Google Glass? This article is brought to you by PatSnap Academy ‚Äî Academy offers free bite sized on-demand intellectual property and innovation courses taught by real world professionals. All you need to do is create an account to gain unlimited access to all 25 courses. Sign up now and start learning for free üëâ https://info.patsnap.com/signup To start off the decade, we take a look at the above patent from The Regents of University of California which relates to the groundbreaking CRISPR precise gene-editing technology. Patents within this space have been embroiled in disputes and litigation throughout the decade, with the University of California and Harvard/MIT‚Äôs Broad Institute battling it out to determine who gets to cash in on CRISPR. This is because the technology has potential for curing or preventing genetic diseases and indeed could be one of the most important developments within medicine and biotech not just in the last decade, but the last century. Find out more about patenting within life sciences in our series of Academy courses on the subject üëâ See ‚ÄòIntellectual Property in Life Sciences‚Äô courses Uber is one of many tech companies to disrupt traditional industries and to really take off in the last decade, along with the likes of Airbnb, Netflix and Monzo Bank. The above patent is Uber‚Äôs first published WIPO patent and covers the principle of a user requesting transportation from a mobile device to a geographic location and selecting a driver. When this patent was first applied for in 2009, the Uber app had just gone live in San Francisco. When the patent was published in May 2011, the company had just raised $10m series A and expanded to New York. Now, in 2019, Uber is valued at $82 billion. If you think your idea could be the next unicorn, understand how to integrate IP into your strategy at an early stage with our Academy course, ‚ÄòHow to turn an idea into a start-up‚Äô üëâ Take the course Back in 2012, Google was still tying to make us believe the future was Google Glass, but then people realized it wasn't a great look and the invention was reduced to the tech graveyard, at least for now in the consumer world. Google, however, was still experimenting with ways to try and commercialise its idea. For example, the above patent describes a solution that can tell when a person is looking at an advert and would allow Google to charge in a ‚Äúpay-per-gaze‚Äù business model, similar to the ‚Äúcost-per-click‚Äù so familiar in today‚Äôs marketing. Although 5G as a technology has only just hit the consumer market in the last year, intellectual property was being filed back in 2013. The above patent is a part of the patent family for one of Nokia‚Äôs many standard essential patents in the 5G space. Nokia has played a leading role in contributing technologies to 5G and standardization. Find out more about standard essential patents within emerging technologies and 5G in our Academy course üëâ Take the course AI remains a tech buzz word for 2019 and the above patent from Google covers something called dropout, which is often used in neural network design. It is a method used to reduce ‚Äòoverfitting‚Äô ‚Äî this is where an algorithm learns training data too well and becomes too sensitive to be reliable ‚Äî and has long been popular among data scientists and machine learning engineers. It is considered to be public domain knowledge [6]. So, although it is not a patent for AI itself, it could be considered as one of the patents covering a common technique in modern artificial intelligence algorithms. While Google may never wish to enforce the patent and is unlikely to hunt down every data scientist who uses the method, the fact that it could assert rights over it will still be troubling for companies. [7] IP within the software space can be a confusing minefield so check out our course that looks at how intellectual property plays a role within open course software üëâ Take the course It‚Äôs the patent for the Marty McFly Back to the Future II shoes! This patent from Nike looks at using a motorized tightening device with a power source located within a removable insole to create a self tying shoe. Nike released this $350 shoe to the market in 2019. Called ‚ÄòAdapt Huarache,‚Äô these use Nike‚Äôs FitAdapt self-lacing technology. Earlier this year Nike also released the ‚ÄòAdapt BB‚Äô as a performance basketball shoe which connects to your smartphone. Will this tech take off or remain more of a novelty? It seems that Nike might be taking a gamble that it‚Äôs the future. See our course from Academy guest speaker Rosie Burbidge, Intellectual Property partner at Gunnercooke LLP and expert in European fashion law which covers ‚ÄòHow design rights work‚Äô üëâ Take the course In 2016, Apple published a patent that looks at tracking a user‚Äôs hand gestures to control interfaces just like in Tom Cruise‚Äôs 2002 film Minority Report. Although the idea and technology for gesture tracking has been around for a while within gaming ‚Äî with the likes of Xbox Connect from 2010 and the rather crude Sony Playstation EyeToy from 2003 ‚Äî the technology never developed beyond gaming gimmicks. It‚Äôs interesting to see Apple pushing this technology in a more serious way. Microsoft also released a similar patent in 2016 and these patents clearly show us that both tech giants are investing a lot of time and money into developing highly sophisticated next-gen natural user interfaces [8] Amazon has released some rather interesting patents over the last decade, most of which probably wont see the light of day, including a Flying Distribution Center, underground delivery tubes and voice-controlled pocket drones. The above patent definitely fits into the category of quirky Amazon patents. It describes a robotic arm that tosses warehouse items. Although Amazon currently don‚Äôt have any tossing robotic arms in their fulfillment centers and don‚Äôt look to have any plans to implement the idea at the moment, it seems that they‚Äôre not averse to protecting everything and anything, just in case. While most major car manufacturers are focusing on electric and autonomous vehicles, Ford is looking to get into the drone market with the above patent for a drone deployed from a vehicle. The drone would be deployed from a host vehicle ‚Äî most likely an emergency vehicle in response to receiving an alert signal. The drone would follow the vehicle, either autonomously or under pilot control, to illuminate accident scenes with lights and sirens, stream live photos and video of the area, boost emergency communication, and help with navigation. [11] This year, as a part of Facebook‚Äôs initiative to bring internet to all parts of developing countries, the above patent was published, which looks at using a series of kites, a ‚Äúdual-kite aerial vehicle‚Äù, in which the kites are tethered together and float at different altitudes to provide internet signal over large areas. This invention looks to improve on the more aeroplane or helicopter-like designs Facebook has already developed as part of its well-publicized Aquila project. PatSnap Academy offers free IP and Innovation courses hosted by industry experts. Click the link below to find out more and create your account to access all content. [1](http://www.nemesisbio.com/patent/) [2](https://www.kqed.org/science/1938007/making-sense-of-the-crispr-patent-dispute-between-the-university-of-california-and-broad) [3]https://www.businessinsider.com/uber-old-app-new-york-city-ipo-2019-5?r=US&IR=T [4] https://www.marketingweek.com/google-patents-pay-per-gaze-eye-tracking-ad-technology/ [5] https://www.nokia.com/about-us/news/releases/2019/10/09/nokia-announces-over-2000-5g-patent-declarations/ [6] ‚Äî https://analyticsindiamag.com/google-activates-dropout-patent-neural-network-engineers-to-be-on-alert/ [7]https://www.cigionline.org/sites/default/files/documents/Luncheon%20Session%20-%20Misha%20Benjamin%2C%20Element%20AI%20%28English%29.pdf [8]https://www.patentlyapple.com/patently-apple/2017/07/patents-show-apple-microsoft-racing-to-bring-hand-gesturing-systems-to-computers-home-appliances-more.html [9]https://www.patentlyapple.com/patently-apple/2017/06/apple-working-on-a-future-hand-gesturing-interface-to-control-gaming-apple-tv-and-home-appliances.html [10] https://www.geekwire.com/2018/amazon-robotic-tossing/ [11] https://www.commercialdroneprofessional.com/ford-takes-further-strides-into-drone-industry-with-patent-of-vehicle-integrated-drone/ [12] https://www.theverge.com/2019/5/30/18645829/facebook-dual-kite-aerial-vehicle-drone-patent-application -- -- If you‚Äôre into creation or innovation, intellectual property is there to protect you as a vital part of any successful business strategy. academy.patsnap.com Help Status About Careers Press Blog Privacy Terms Text to speech Teams

Title: Sotabench: Benchmarking Open Source Models Directly From GitHub
Subtitle: Published in SyncedReview
Author: Synced
Article: Sign up Sign in Sign up Sign in Synced Follow SyncedReview -- Listen Share Machine learning research resource Papers with Code last week introduced Sotabench, a free and open website created to benchmark and rate the performance of state-of-the-art open source models from GitHub. Papers with Code is an open platform that aggregates ML papers, code, and evaluation tables and metrics from sources such as arXiv and GitHub. The team behind Sotabench has already implemented a few benchmarks on the site and is encouraging anyone and everyone to contribute additional benchmarks and connect their repositories. Contributors will have access to free GPUs to run their code on public benchmarks, and the results can be compared to the paper results for reproducibility. So far there are eight benchmarks on the Sotabench website: Each benchmark page includes a Leaderboard summarizing and ranking existing models; a list of models on Papers with Code that have not yet been tested; and instructions on how to contribute models. For example, the ImageNet benchmark page shows a graph with a ratio of top-1 accuracy and images per second for all models tested and a list of model details including repository, top-5 accuracy, speed, paper and most importantly, whether the results reach the reported accuracy. The leaderboard will be a convenient place for practitioners and researchers to compare the tradeoff between speed and accuracy of the many models out there. Sotabench‚Äôs automatization and standardization of dataset acquisition, pre-processing and evaluation will help newcomers get started in ML and enable reviewers to easily compare models in terms of different metrics. There are of course always doubters. Because Sotabench is a free and open platform where anyone can contribute, some Reddit users are already questioning its credibility and pointing to the potential risk of data cheating. One suggested establishing a report and review system to prevent this from happening. It would however be unwise to cheat on such a public platform as the deceit would be easy to spot. The majority of reactions to Sotabench on Reddit and elsewhere have been positive, with many expressing their willingness to contribute to the centralized benchmark project. Papers with Code is a free resource website supported by Atlas ML, a startup founded by researchers and engineers from the University of Cambridge. The new Sotabench website is here.
