Title: 8 Essential Tools we Use While Running a Business Remotely
Subtitle: Written by Scale3C
Author: Scale3C
Article: Sign up Sign in Sign up Sign in Scale3C Follow -- Listen Share Thanks to the software available nowadays, working on and managing your business remotely is more plausible than it ever was before. To do that effectively though, you need to rely on software that works for you best and you can trust. With the number of tools available, however, it can be easy to get overwhelmed by the choices. In our previous article on running a fully remote business, we mentioned that communication is the key while working remotely. If you want to overcome some of the challenges of working remotely, the tools you use in your communications are just as important. To make sure that everyone is on the same page in regards to project management and deadlines, we will be discussing some of the tools we use in our daily operations. More specifically, we will be exploring the following categories and tools: Communications Slack WhatsApp GoogleHangouts Time Tracking and Security Toggl 1Password Proposals and Finances Qwilr Xero TransferWise In any business, remote or otherwise, having the proper communication channels setup first is essential. In both cases, people often struggle with communicating and updating each other properly. Which is why you should first establish consistent guidelines so that everyone knows how to contact each other and where. It‚Äôs also important to have separate communication channels as having only one is a sure way to get overwhelmed by the number of messages and end up with a lot of spam. First, define the different communication mediums you‚Äôll need, and for what purpose. For example, it‚Äôs generally good practice to have a different channel for project management recaps, instant communication, one for dealing with clients, and so on. So, here‚Äôs our take on the matter. Almost everyone uses Slack nowadays, and for a good reason, too. In a remote environment, a direct messaging tool is a must and for that, Slack is often the best tool. It has a lot of features that can simplify office communication, such as setting up different channels, file sharing (and storing), tons of 3rd party integrations (with Google Drive, Zapier, so on), and can even be used for task management practices. To make the best use of Slack, think about any other apps that you use regularly and see if you can integrate them with Slack. From fun GIFs to file-sharing and automated bots, Slack has a lot of other uses you might not know about. When it comes to using Slack, our approach is to set up different channels, each for every our client or a project. Other channels are mostly dedicated to each new project or task we‚Äôre working on and need to be able to share instant updates. WhatsApp is another instant communication platform and like Slack, it can be used for both group chats and direct messages. It‚Äôs quick and easy to set up, as it is simply tied to your own mobile device phone number ‚Äî making it a great option for personal communication. Though WhatsApp lacks some of the vital features Slack has, it‚Äôs still a powerful messaging app on its own. Depending on your business and requirements, you can also look into WhatsApp Business for additional paid features. If you‚Äôre going to be using WhatsApp in addition to other communication channels, it‚Äôs important to have a different use for it so that you know when to use which app. For example, while working remotely, there might be times when you need to get a hold of someone in case of an emergency. In such case, WhatsApp is ideal if you want to receive a reply straight away. Since the app is tied to your phone number, chances are, whoever you‚Äôre texting will receive it immediately. Similarly, WhatsApp also offers a variety of formats when messaging, which means you won‚Äôt be limited to text alone. While direct messaging can be used for most working environments (online team meetings, dealing with clients, so on), it simply can‚Äôt replace video calls. For online meetings, conference rooms, webinars and more, Google Hangouts is ideal. It‚Äôs easy to set up a meeting and invite other members. If you‚Äôre going to be dealing with a lot of clients in your business or need to be constantly catching up with other team members, it‚Äôs a good idea to have a stable video platform set up in place. With Google Hangouts, it‚Äôs convenient to get set up with all of the above and jump into a meeting straight away. As an added benefit of it being part of GSuite, the app can integrate into your other Google products, such as Google Calendar. Because most businesses use GSuite to begin with, they automatically get Google Hangouts for free. From all of the video calling software we‚Äôve tried, Google Hangouts ended up being more reliable, and easier for clients to join. Compared to Zoom, for example, Google Hangouts is free, can hold more people for a longer period of time, and doesn‚Äôt noticeably lag behind in terms of quality either. What gets measured gets managed. To be successful, you need to be keeping track of what works, what doesn‚Äôt, and have the data to back it up. This is even more the case when you‚Äôre working remotely and use a lot of tools in your business. In that case, one of the most important metrics you should be keeping track of is your time. Toggl is a powerful time tracking software that boosts productivity and shows you where and how you spend most of your time. If you want to get a sense of how long each project or task usually takes and how (or where) your team spends the majority of their time, you can do so with Toggl. The platform works where you do, no matter the device, even has the option of manual time entries, and by the end of it, Toggl provides a report of your work productivity based on the hours. It can be as detailed or simple as you need it to be. For small businesses and freelancers, it‚Äôs ideal as it comes with a powerful reporting system and plenty of team management features. Main benefits include better internal resource planning for businesses, accurate and transparent client billing, and making work time more focused, based on the specific project. Overall, the aim of the tool is to increase team productivity. Depending on your needs and the size of the team, you can either go with the basic features or the advanced plan. If you‚Äôre going to be using a lot of different tools, it‚Äôs a good idea to have one place dedicated to managing and organising everything. While working remotely, keeping track of passwords on sticky notes in the office won‚Äôt cut it anymore. So, to ensure everyone on the team has access to all the shared software without exposing the company to the risk of cyber threats, it‚Äôs worth investing in a password management software. 1Password is a simple all-in-one password management tool that does what it says. With it, you‚Äôll only ever need to keep track of one password, which will then give you access to your other saved passwords. As with most password management tools, security is key. This is why the information you store in 1Password is encrypted and can only be accessed from a device you‚Äôve already approved. Finally, if you‚Äôre going to be working with clients on a regular basis, it‚Äôs a good idea to have a ready system for the whole onboarding process, start to finish. The order might look something like this: First, you send a proposal detailing all of your services, the cost, and other important details in a high-quality proposal, you send them an invoice for the exact amount, and finally, have a ready-to-go money transfer account. These are the tools we use for the above process. Qwilr is an online tool for creating and sending professional proposals, sales, and marketing documents. The tool has a lot of different uses, from individuals to teams and organisations, allowing you to pitch your services with confidence through a proposal document that best represents you. The vision behind Qwilr is to make the future of documents online. This means no more PDF or Word proposals. Instead, with Qwilr, you can customise your proposal so that it best represents your brand. Their website has a number of award-winning templates to help you get started, which you can customise to fit your brand. You can add your logo within the proposal, edit and add interactive elements (e.g. customisable pricing table), and represent your visual identity through other means. Finally, it‚Äôs worth noting that with Qwilr, you can also track your proposals. Meaning, you‚Äôll get a notification when they first view it, how long they view it, and when they accept it. If they don‚Äôt accept it though, you‚Äôll know to refine your proposal and follow up accordingly. If you‚Äôre going to be doing business online, it‚Äôs essential to be keeping track of your invoice and overall finances. To manage your finances and invoices in an all-in-one accounting software, we recommend using Xero. The accounting software has a lot of uses, and allows you to run your business on the go from anywhere, anytime. While finances are often an intimidating field for many startups, using Xero to manage your situation is easy to learn and has all the time-saving tools needed to grow your business. Important features include being able to keep track of your cashflows and expenses in real-time, attaching other files to your invoices, paying bills, and finally, being able to generate an end of the month report to assess your overall situation. The tool is easy to set up, has an intuitive user interface to simplify your finances and is powerful enough if you need to manage your overall financial situation on the go. Finally, you might have already heard of TransferWise, as it‚Äôs another essential tool when it comes to sending and receiving money online. One of the best things about it is the fact that it comes with its own real exchange rate (also known as the mid-market rate) and doesn‚Äôt set ridiculously high fees like most banks do. If you‚Äôre going to be sending and receiving money to different countries, you need to make sure you‚Äôre not losing any on the currency exchange fees. Most banks charge more for this. TransferWise, meanwhile, stays 8x cheaper than the average bank. In addition to the transfer rates working in your favour, the online digital bank also tracks your money and sends an email with each stage of the transfer. Most online businesses and freelancers go with TransferWise to save costs, since as of right now, it‚Äôs one of the best and the cheapest ways to send money abroad. All in all, depending on the software you use, running a business remotely can be a convenient experience for everyone involved or a nightmare of a process. To save you time and money, you need to be making sure that the tools you‚Äôre using are working for you, not against you. Which is why you need to be using the tools that work perfectly for you. There are a lot of different fields in which using certain software can help alleviate some of the challenges that come with working online. The above is only a small list of the many tools we use consistently now. Finding the right set of tools that work for you best takes time and patience. The above list is what we stuck with and so far, has been extremely productive for our team. -- -- Helping companies improve their tech and product development Help Status About Careers Press Blog Privacy Terms Text to speech Teams

Title: Mon smartphone, Instagram, Roland Barthes & Kim Kardashian
Subtitle: Written by Isma√´l
Author: Isma√´l
Article: Sign up Sign in Sign up Sign in Isma√´l Follow -- Share ¬´ Le mythe ne nie pas les choses, sa fonction est au contraire d‚Äôen parler ; simplement il les purifie, les innocente, les fonde en nature et en √©ternit√©, il leur donne une clart√© qui n‚Äôest pas celle de l‚Äôexplication mais celle du constat (‚Ä¶) il abolit la complexit√© des actes humains, leur donne la simplicit√© des essences, il supprime toute dialectique, toute remont√©e au-del√† du visible imm√©diat, il organise un monde sans contradictions parce que sans profondeur, un monde √©tal√© dans l‚Äô√©vidence, il fonde une clart√© heureuse ; les choses ont l‚Äôair de se signifier toutes seules ¬ª. -Roland Barthes, Mythologies L‚Äôobjet g√Æt dans ma main. Ses rebords sont courb√©s, sa surface lisse et brillante refl√®te un noir absolu. Il me fait penser √† un de ces objets myst√©rieux dans un r√©cit d‚Äôaventures pour enfant, qu‚Äôun explorateur √† la na√Øvet√© malhonn√™te emporte avec lui, sans pr√™ter garde aux signes d‚Äôhostilit√© de l‚Äôobjet envers lui, √† la menace surnaturelle qui en √©mane. Cet objet dans ma main, ni magique ni maudit, n‚Äôen est pas moins fascinant et repoussant √† la fois. Ce n‚Äôest pas au monde ext√©rieur que l‚Äôobjet me relie, c‚Äôest au royaume de l‚Äôenfance. A ce qui en moi r√©clame obstin√©ment consolation, divertissement, amour et protection ; √† cette entit√© obtuse dont la soif avide de contact rassurant, de joie forte, ne saurait jamais √™tre tout √† fait satisfaite. L‚Äôenvie de redevenir un √™tre mou, qu‚Äôon amuse et nourrit, uniquement pourvu d‚Äôyeux pour avaler le monde et d‚Äôune bouche pour crier, se r√©alise gr√¢ce √† l‚Äôobjet. Je m‚Äôendors avec lui pr√®s de moi, le cherche de la main d√®s le r√©veil. Il contient un monde que je crois pouvoir ma√Ætriser et m‚Äôenchante uniquement pour cette raison. D‚Äôun geste amput√©, j‚Äôappuie sur des carr√©s multicolores et un torrent d‚Äôimages scintillantes se d√©verse sur moi. Mes yeux boivent, mon corps absorbe cette p√¢te doucereuse qui rend le monde moins laid, moins dur, qui a fig√© le r√©el et en a ass√©ch√© la substance. Une femme que je ne connais pas a publi√© une photo d‚Äôelle et de son compagnon en promenade. En l√©gende de l‚Äôimage, elle y a list√© tout ce qui y figure, de l‚Äôarbre au banc. Elle indique √©galement #love et #happiness. La m√©canique s‚Äôest plaqu√©e sur du vivant. C‚Äôest bien entendu inepte mais peut-on reprocher √† quiconque de rechercher les visages aimants d‚Äôautrui ? Le besoin de repr√©senter et de communiquer son exp√©rience afin qu‚Äôelle soit reconnue par d‚Äôautres, de l‚Äôinscrire dans une √©ternit√©, est aussi violent que l‚Äôinstinct de survie. La tristesse provient plut√¥t du fait que ces repr√©sentations soient con√ßues non pour leur sens profond, mais pour correspondre aux crit√®res d‚Äôune plateforme ; que le contenant l‚Äôemporte sur le contenu. Que la joie intime soit cadr√©e et liss√©e √† la fa√ßon d‚Äôune campagne publicitaire. La tristesse vient du fait d‚Äôavoir laiss√© une industrie s‚Äôapproprier le bonheur humain, √† tel point que le langage m√™me en est modifi√©. Les fa√ßons d‚Äôexprimer l‚Äôamour ou la joie sont alt√©r√©es pour correspondre √† un discours global qui ne tol√®re que superficiellement la singularit√©. Malgr√© son d√©luge de belles images et de messages positifs, le monde Instagram un monde immobile et mort, parce que clos. Ferm√© sur lui-m√™me, il est aussi rassurant qu‚Äôune cabane d‚Äôenfant. A l‚Äôabri de la temp√™te et de l‚Äôhostilit√© du monde ext√©rieur, ce monde est tout entier concentr√© sur son r√™ve petit-bourgeois de domesticit√©. On y c√©l√®bre tous les attributs du foyer : l‚Äôunion amoureuse entre deux √™tres, la famille, la nourriture, la d√©coration int√©rieure. C‚Äôest le r√®gne de l‚Äôinventaire, de l‚Äô√©tiquetage et du s√©quen√ßage. La magie √©clatante d‚ÄôInstagram, c‚Äôest son pouvoir de transformation du monde en une s√©rie de vignettes o√π s‚Äôexprime la satisfaction d‚Äôavoir domin√© le r√©el. La curiosit√© devient fixation st√©rile : on se projette soi dans l‚ÄôAilleurs plus qu‚Äôon ne cherche √† le comprendre. L‚Äôimaginaire s‚Äôexprime dans sa forme la plus superficielle : la collection d‚Äôimages. Les exp√©riences humaines y d√©contextualis√©es ; ce sont des absolus qui ne signifient rien, si ce n‚Äôest que l‚Äô√™tre humain, quel que soit son environnement, partage une m√™me essence et une m√™me vibration enfantine pour des √©motions primaires, coup√©es √† la racine. Cet √™tre humain universel n‚Äôest pris dans aucune structure sociale ; il est d√©politis√©. La logique Instagram ne comprend ne l‚Äôinteraction sociale qu‚Äôen termes de points, la vie en termes d‚Äôactions mises en sc√®ne. L‚Äô√©panouissement sera productif ou ne sera pas. Kim Kardashian, la femme au 124 millions d‚Äôabonn√©s, est l‚Äôune des incarnations les plus efficaces de la mythologie Instagram. Elle est le triomphe √©clatant du bonheur bourgeois, de la cellule familiale, de la domesticit√© et de la propri√©t√©. Son corps rel√®ve de l‚Äôextraordinaire, du merveilleux. Qu‚Äôelle semble poss√©der un contr√¥le absolu sur celui-ci pr√©sente un charme puissant. Alors que le sentiment de ne plus rien ma√Ætriser dans nos existences se fait plus violent et plus d√©sesp√©r√©, ma√Ætriser son corps pr√©sente un dernier rempart contre le chaos, la fuite, l‚Äôincessant changement de nature des √©l√©ments. Parfois, des comptes market√©s jusqu‚Äô√† l‚Äôagonie imitent le naturel et nous nous r√©jouissons de cette proximit√© avec des √™tres sup√©rieurs. Jouir de l‚Äôombre des rois et des reines, c‚Äôest leur reconna√Ætre un statut surnaturel. Parmi le commun des mortels, il arrive qu‚Äôune distanciation veuille s‚Äôop√©rer et qu‚Äôune l√©gende ironique ou ambigu√´ accompagne une photo convenue. Le jeu est de d√©clarer son intention, comme de suspendre le geste et de rester fig√© dans un acte interm√©diaire, ni tout √† fait candide ni totalement artificiel. ‚ÄúNous souffrons par les r√™ves et gu√©rissons par les r√™ves‚Äù √©crit Gaston Bachelard dans son essai L‚Äôeau et les r√™ves : Essai sur l‚Äôimagination de la mati√®re. Le pouce glissant d‚Äôune image √† une autre, pris dans un syst√®me sans issue, une galerie aux miroirs o√π bl√™missent d‚Äôanciens fantasmes de beaut√© et de richesse, je souffre et gu√©ris ind√©finiment. Have Smartphones destroyed a generation?, Jean M.Twenge, The Atlantic septembre 2017Et le mot de l‚Äôan√©e 2018 est‚Ä¶ ‚Äúnomophobie‚Äù, Thomas Messias, Slate, janvier 2019 -- -- Ally In Progress. Title: 16 Years Old and Living My Dream üöÄ
Subtitle: Personal Thoughts on AI
Author: Shagun Maheshwari
Article: Sign up Sign in Sign up Sign in Shagun Maheshwari Follow -- Listen Share Imagine you are a 16 year old who has the mission of wanting to positively impact at least a billion people in the world through technology. Now imagine you had an opportunity to intern at a company that was doing exactly that! I‚Äôm pretty sure I‚Äôd classify that person as the luckiest 16 year old in the üåé. The crazy thing is, that‚Äôs my reality right now and I do feel like the luckiest 16 year old in the world. This amazing company is called XPRIZE which is probably one of the most revolutionary companies you have ever come across. This is because XPRIZE sets hugely ambitious but audacious goals to improve the world. The mission is to create incentive competitions that target a pressing problem we see in our world today. These competitions are focused around topics such as increasing water abundance, recycling CO2 from the atmosphere into valuable products, and increasing adult literacy, etc. But the thing that really makes me the luckiest 16 year old in the world, is the fact that I get to work on the IBM Watson AI XPRIZE! This was literally a dream come true as over the past year I have developed a huge passion for artificial intelligence and the impact this technology can have in improving our world today. My deep interest in this technology led me to research into understanding the theory of complex deep learning concepts as well as self-learn how to build numerous different AI models. I found a particular interest with applying machine learning to genomics data which led me to build a model called a variational auto encoder that can identify which genes lead to cancerous tumours. The $5M IBM Watson AI XPRIZE What excites me the most about this XPRIZE is that it‚Äôs not creating an incentive competition to target just one problem, but actually numerous problems ranging over the topics of health diagnosis, health treatment, mental health, environment, education, humanizing AI, and improving the developing world. For example, ORBEM is a team a part of the AI XPRIZE that is leveraging image classification AI technology + MRI tech to differentiate between male and female chicken eggs. This is a huge problem they are tackling as previously no one could identify the gender of an egg before it was hatched. Not knowing the gender beforehand actually resulted in 7 billion baby male chicks being killed every year + billion of eggs going wasted that could have been used to feed the population. Another team called Element Inc, is using image classification to give digital identity to children in poverty. Around 1.1 billion people in the world don‚Äôt have any digital identity because of their economic situation. Element is making this scalable by enabling a smart phone camera to capture a child‚Äôs biometrics data in order to give them an identity. As you can see, both teams are using a subsection of AI called image classification, but they are leveraging that technology to solve 2 completely diverse problems. These are just 2 out of the 34 teams using the power of AI to tackle some of the world‚Äôs most known and unknown problems! One of the main reasons I‚Äôm so passionate about AI is because I see it as a tool with enormous amount of potential to leverage in solving the challenges we face in our world. The current status of AI is pretty much a tool that is being used to a) Optimize & Personalize our life b) Model complex problems and reach the output with more efficiency + accuracy I see development in AI as building new tools and filling our toolbox to help solve problems that were tedious to solve before with our bare hands. However, majority of people think of AI and instead of seeing it as a toolbox, they see it as this‚Ä¶ The reality is, we have not yet reached the stage of Artificial Super Intelligence which is AI that is 10x smarter and more powerful than us. Our current status quo is Artificial Narrow Intelligence. ANI is AI that extremely good at one particular task but cannot translate that intelligence to do another task. Examples are: Google‚Äôs AI system was able to beat the world‚Äôs best Go champion, in a match held in 2017. A computer vision algorithm was created to use pattern recognition to identify breast cancer in the slide images of a patients tissues. This AI model had an 89% accuracy in detecting breast cancer while the average accuracy of a trained pathologist was 73%. But an AI system has not yet been created that can output and perform on many diverse tasks like our human brain can. TL;DR Artificial Narrow Intelligence can be 10x more efficient/accurate that humans, when trained to do a particular task but the current status of the technology is not able to generalize and do multiple tasks like the human brain can. For these reasons, I truly believe investing in the current state of AI is extremely important for humankind. However this is not to say that ANI does not have the power to be used for malicious intent. With the huge amounts of data being aggregated about us through the technology we are using, privacy becomes a huge concern when companies like Dessa are able to create voice cloning technology that is accurate to the extent they can generate audio of your voice saying anything they want it to. Or when this technology is used in the wrong hands to create a DeepNude app that uses neural networks to remove clothing from the images of women, making them look realistically nude. AI has the potential to do harm but it also has the potential to do a lot of good. Incentive competitions such as the IBM Watson AI XPRIZE challenge and the Google AI Impact Challenge are structures to catalyze innovations with a positive impact using this AI technology. üöÄ -- -- 16 year old machine learning developer interested in philosophy, programming and gaining new experiences. Title: Keep YourHome Safe With Expert Garage Door Repair
Subtitle: Written by Overhead Door of Lexington
Author: Overhead Door of Lexington
Article: Sign up Sign in Sign up Sign in Overhead Door of Lexington Follow -- Listen Share A garage is more than simply a place to keep your car secure and to store some equipment and other materials. In most homes, the garage is one more essential access point into the home, and consequently must stay safe at all the time. This is why issues with the garage door should not be open until later on the day. Also, if the is issue actually bad, it must be taken care of with a garage door repair professional. When the garage doors pull or break, some persons just make short-term maintenance like boarding in the damaged areas. They will believe that so long as their doors look normal, simply no robber might ever think about screening their garages. However, this is how they are wrong as many robbers consider garages as good locations to break into. A vulnerable door or unsafe handles can turn your garage right into a haven for burglars. How Could You Secure Garage Doors? Issues with the doors to your garage do not simply pop up all of a sudden; usually, they will have indicators that show you something is wrong. In case your doors close suddenly, or make loud sounds, then something is up. It well worth your time to go over the doors from time to time to ensure all the parts is in best shape. If contaminants or rustic handles cause the sounds, then a small maintenance care is within the right order. Nevertheless, if the origin of the sound is a secret to you, expert repair solutions should be the best choice. It is preferable to fix any complications as they happen, otherwise you will end up getting a huge hassle in your hands that will be expensive to restore. Partner up with a garage doors repair service that has extensive experience and is professional. If you could, get one with twenty-four hour services. Your doors can encounter issues anytime and if you are in for many problems if you all of a sudden have a garage door that will not close or open. While emergency repair solutions are more costly, it is more costly to pay in return for your safety and security. When you are calling your repair company, it might imply that your door parts reach the end of their life span. Rather than burying yourself in regular restoration bills, think about a complete change of your garage doors. It is an expense worth making, since there is nothing essential than your satisfaction. With everything in top form, you will not have to be concerned about the doors breaking in the most bothersome of times. To find company that provide garage door repair 24/7, all you want is to search for companies through the web. It pays to ask about 24 hour solutions or complete garage overhauls so that you can keep not simply your garage, however your whole house safe. Expert companies have expertise at installing all required anti-burglar tools and therefore make your home and garage completely ‚Äòtheft proof‚Äô. Once you hire an expert, there is no need to worry about the protection of your house when you are away for a couple of days. The advanced tools and technology allow you to prevent any sort of outsider access or invasion. Do not wait any longer? It is about time you start paying as much attention to your garage and its door as you do to the other parts of the home. Title: Why all my Vuex stores have just one action and mutation and why yours should too
Subtitle: How we are using Vuex
Author: Jennifer Bland
Article: Sign up Sign in Sign up Sign in Member-only story Jennifer Bland Follow Vue.js Developers -- 17 Share As the size of your Vue application grows, the number of actions and mutations in your Vuex store grows too. Let me show you how to reduce this to something more manageable. Vuex is a state management pattern + library for Vue.js applications. It serves as a centralized store for all the components in an application, with rules ensuring that the state can only be mutated in a predictable fashion. We are using Vuex to share state between all the applications in our Factory Core Framework application. Since the framework is a bundle of applications, we currently have nine Vuex stores. Each store has its own state, actions, and mutations. We are using actions in the store to do API calls to the backend. Once the data is returned we use mutations to store it in state. This allows any component to access that data. As you can imagine, our stores can have a very large number of actions to handle these API calls. Here is an example of all the actions in one of our Vuex stores. -- -- 17 Helping web professionals up their skill and knowledge of Vue.js Software Engineer. Google Developers Expert. Title: GDG Ibadan 2019 Plans; 2018 in Review!

Article: Sign up Sign in Sign up Sign in Oyetola Taiwo Follow GDG Ibadan‚Äôs Blog -- Listen Share The year 2018 was amazing as we had several events targeted at improving developers‚Äô skills within the community. In all of these events, we had many developers learn from various facilitators within and outside the community and their contributions have made the community grow significantly well. It will not be good to end our 2018 story without mentioning that two Engineers from the community (in the persons of Goke Obasa and Yemi Olaoye) who Doubled as our top Organizers relocated to Germany in pursuit of their career as Software Engineers. The introduction of the Google Hangouts LIVE event Ask Me Anything with Devs formed part of our avenues to reachout the more to everyone, encouraging them to grow and invest in themselves to be better at what they do especially in terms of acquiring technical skills and being able to solve problems with technology. We are happy to announce that there were many positive reports from members of the community. Many have learnt from all the sessions and are currently putting lessons learnt to use. We will like to thank our Speakers on these sessions for their time and for their willingness to give back, We thank Abiola Ibrahim, Emmanuel Obidiegwu Zaga, Omoloro Oyegoke, Yemi Olaoye, Goke Obasa and Funsho Popoola. You are all appreciated. In 2019, we are looking at a GDG Ibadan with topnotch Developers. We want to see Developers within the community doing awesome stuffs and making significant progress. Do you have an idea you want to let us know about? Please reachout to Dapo and Oyetola Taiwo , We want to welcome as many ideas as you might have to better the community. We would also want to see as many people to get involved. Reach out to the above mentioned persons in that regard as well. We would be having our Meet Ups targeted to deliberately ensure we all learn and dates will be announced at a later time. Sometimes around March we would have an Hackathon which we believe people can learn from and benefit from. Ensure you follow us @gdgibadan on twitter and Meet Up to keep up with our events. We would be migrating from whatsapp to telegram so we can accommodate more people to benefit from the community. Here is the link to join http://bit.ly/gdgIbadanTelegram. Let us make sure to join immediately as there won‚Äôt be a need to maintain two groups meant for same purpose. Let‚Äôs expand by moving to telegram! Finally, Happy new year to every one. Let‚Äôs have an awesome 2019. -- -- Official Google Developers Group Ibadan‚Äôs Blog Researcher, I believe in constant personal growth Help Status About Careers Press Blog Privacy Terms Text to speech Teams

Title: How to move past the MVP stage and keep your business moving
Subtitle: Launchpeer
Author: Launchpeer
Article: Sign up Sign in Sign up Sign in Home About  Startup and entrepreneurship tips from the team at Launchpeer  Launchpeer Follow Launchpeer -- Listen Share Like this episode? A rating and a review on iTunes would go a long way! Today‚Äôs question comes from Lucien. I have a prototype built for a B2C app but I‚Äôm trying to decide what my focus should be in the MVP phase. How should I think about the next stages of my business development? Every founder has this problem when they are ready to launch, especially in the B2C space. How do you think about revenue, features, and monetization models? In the MVP stage, you should launch without charging. The reason you should take this approach is because it‚Äôs critical to acquire users so you can start to figure out how they are using their app. It‚Äôs hard to determine which features to charge for if you don‚Äôt know what is valuable to your users. And everything should be driven by your customers in a startup. This isn‚Äôt a long-term thing, but you need to start getting some feedback. If you already built the features you think could be premium, then why did you build them? Odds are, if you already built features that could be premium features then you probably waited too long to launch. When your free features are done, you should launch. Sprinkle in some places where you would put the paid features to see if people are trying to access them. This will help you understand which ones are actually valuable and that people will pay for because you have actual data. To do this effectively, you have to make sure you are tracking data. Too often people just throw money at various parts of their marketing and development and they don‚Äôt track the appropriate data to ensure that they can take their next steps with confidence. The simpler you can make all of these processes in the beginning, the better. ‚ÄúAll of your decisions as a startup should be based on your customers and what they are telling you is valuable and important to them.‚Äù Got questions about startups and/or startup culture? We‚Äôve got answers. Head over to LaunchChat.io and record your own question to have it featured on the show. Join our free Facebook Group for founders working to build, launch, & scale together with the help of our startup experts at Launchpeer! Get more details and join the club at Launchpeer.club. Our team is writing a book and it‚Äôs nearly ready to ship. We profiled 40 of the biggest startups of the 21st Century and documenting how they scaled their businesses. If you want to claim your free book, visit LaunchRecipes.com. Title: Improving online experiences through accessibility
Subtitle: Understanding disabilities
Author: Favoured
Article: Sign up Sign in Sign up Sign in Favoured Follow favoured. -- Listen Share Many of take for granted the ease of use when it comes to browsing the web. For many of us, we don‚Äôt have to make amendments to the way we find information and navigate websites, but for the 1billion+ people worldwide living with some form of disability, access to information isn‚Äôt always so straight forward. Accessibility awareness has risen in recent years and as a result, more and more brands operating online have made changes to their site to make the browsing experience more accessible to everyone. However, there‚Äôs still loads of room for improvements. With more than 59million distinct accessibility errors, detected by Google through research, across 1million home pages, this amounts to approximately 60 errors per page. It‚Äôs important to remember that a disability, which will affect your ability to use the internet to its full effect, does not end begin and end with vision, hearing, movement or cognitive impairments. User needs are far more complex, and it would be naive to limit the usability to only cater to these disabilities. The diversity of the user base is so extensive now that accessibility optimisation needs to understand every limitation which is currently affecting people around the world. Designing for accessibility needs to grow and evolve, which ultimately results in better user experience for everyone. One of the common issues with websites is low contrast, which for people with visual impairments, can cause an accessibility issue. Ensuring your site has sufficient colour contrast, will make viewing easier, especially for mobile users whilst on the go. You should ensure that your site layout is clear and concise. It might look nice to make menu items small in size, however, for people with visual impairments this can quickly drive them away from your site or make it completely unusable. Enhancing the appearance of your copy, by increasing the size of the font on your site, as well as ensuring that colours can be seen easily by those with visual impairments including the likes of colour blindness, is important for overall accessibility. Presuming that everyone has the same level of reading abilities is both unfair and can result in confusion. It‚Äôs important to be simplistic with language when creating the key elements of your site, including who you are and how to contact you. Plain language over specialised terminology may seem counterproductive if you work in an industry which relies heavily on this, but it‚Äôs important to simplify it to ensure that everyone can understand what it is that you do, regardless of reading level or level of understanding of the English language. Furthermore, headers and shorter paragraphs can help users determine content hierarchy on a page, for improved ease of use. This also has significant SEO benefits, by making it clear to a search engine what the key topics of the page are. Dexterity can be a barrier to utilising the web to its full potential. Particularly where data entry is concerned, it‚Äôs vital to reduce the overall effort of inputting information on the users part. Alongside the ability to import auto-fill information, sites should consider including the likes of a number pad or expanded options to choose from, where possible. The benefits of this type of streamlining capability are felt across all users, in fact, it can make people more likely to complete their purchase when their information is more easily inputted. Alongside this, as voice recognition becomes more advanced, inputting via speech will be more commonly rolled out across all websites, so ensure that your site is optimised and ready for this functionality. When considering how you will design and create your site, you should be aware of load speed. Of course, slow load speeds can affect your search capabilities but they also impair the user experience. Accessing your websites data should be at the core of your user experience process. So, it might mean that you can‚Äôt display loads of high res images or video on your home page, but you can find ways around, either through changing the design or compressing assets. With mobile more prevalent than desktop in most areas of the world, it‚Äôs important to ensure you have optimised and built your site with load speed in mind, ensuring accessibility to everyone. Ensuring your site is compatible with assistive technology, such as screen readers, hearing aids and magnification applications, allows full user capabilities to those with disabilities attempting to access your site. You should consider increasing the tappable areas of buttons to make them more easily reached and interactable and design inline with thumb reach research, considering different designs of mobile phone. Additionally, keyboard shortcut navigation should be fully implemented to ensure that those who cannot use a mouse are able to receive a good experience on your site, regardless. You can use sites such as web.dev which will run a basic accessibility audit, score your site and offer insights into best practices and recommendations for improvement. Alternatively, get in touch with us today for a free website audit where we will identify any areas of your website which could be jeopardising usability and accessibility. Originally published at Favoured.. -- -- We‚Äôre a performance-driven digital marketing, content agency. It‚Äôs our mission to help companies grow. Favoured are a full service digital marketing agency specialising in strategy, content and design. Help Status About Careers Press Blog Privacy Terms Text to speech Teams

Title: Verge Development Update #27
Subtitle: Features
Author: Swen van Zanten
Article: Sign up Sign in Sign up Sign in Swen van Zanten Follow vergecurrency -- Listen Share Two weeks ago, we skipped one iteration of the development updates after a whole year of consistency üôå. Let's see where we go from here! The latest update to the Verge Currency iOS wallet, v1.2.0! You can download it today from the App Store! This release brings the following features and bugfixes: The 1.2.0 update also made the wallet iOS 13 compatible. However, it was not built using the iOS 13 SDK. This means we miss out on some nice default iOS 13 UI changes. In the next big update, we‚Äôll be focusing on supporting the full iOS 13 SDK and add the additional features that the SDK supports. We recovered all the v4 core requirements, from the old blockchain to the new blockchain. I will try to cover all the changes that were made in order to give you a good overview of our fellow miners experience. At this point, I wanted to say thank you to all the people who were really helpful in finding, identifying and also resolving bugs with lightning speed. This couldn‚Äôt have been done without: In order to archive that we sat together and solved issue by issue that had to be addressed in order to build a fluent mining process. But those changes were mostly contrary to what the bitcoin base has given us. Thus, we decided to note those places down and decide for follow up tasks that would be nice to be implemented, such as: (mostly hardfork topics) Besides those controversy topics there have also been some fixes within: Features that also have been implemented: For this update I‚Äôm going to be like our upcoming wallet, lightweight (public sadly laughing in the background). I‚Äôve been implementing the VWS Service URL change feature in the wallet settings as you can see here: Exactly like in the iOS wallet, in the Android wallet you‚Äôll be able to use our public Verge Wallet Service (VWS) but you can also set up your own node (instructions here : video). Besides, I‚Äôve pretty much wrapped up the PIN feature. I‚Äôve implemented it only in the paper key for now, but the structure has mostly been defined and I‚Äôm a couple lines away from adding it to upcoming features (like sending money). Of course, the PIN number can be reset anytime from the settings. Otherwise, I‚Äôve been working on minor UX fixes, such as renaming titles or once a setting has been changed (like the fiat currency) and getting back to the settings page instead of making that a manual action. You‚Äôll hear from us in two weeks! -- -- ISO 20022.Circa 2014. A secure and user-friendly digital currency ($XVG), Built for everyday transactions. An ERC20 (XVGETH) token to assist the complete Ecosystem. Title: Por qual motivo est√° surgindo tantas Start-ups no Brasil?
Subtitle: Written by Andrew Caldas
Author: Andrew Caldas
Article: Sign up Sign in Sign up Sign in Andrew Caldas Follow -- Share Em primeira circunst√¢ncia, irei explicar o meu ponto de vista, dentro das minhas observa√ß√µes referentes a livros e jornais que tratam a respeito do assunto prescrito, e motiva√ß√µes importantes que andei notando dentro de algumas promissoras empresas brasileiras. Segundo, a Associa√ß√£o Brasileira de Startups (Abstartups), o Brasil conta com mais de 10 mil startups, e a maioria delas est√£o sediadas no Sudeste, principalmente, na grande S√£o Paulo. Muitos estados brasileiros est√£o tendo um crescimento acelerado de novas empresas tecnol√≥gicas, normalmente estas empresas se localizam dentro de escrit√≥rios corporativos, nos centros das grandes cidades. Acredito que, o grande motivo da cria√ß√£o dessas novas startups, giram em torno da grande demanda de tecnologias nas novas e velhas empresas, que obviamente, querem automatizar e melhorar os seus processos. As grandes e velhas institui√ß√µes que sempre cuidavam dessa demanda, devido ao seu tamanho e reputa√ß√£o, √© normal possu√≠rem um alto pre√ßo pelos seus servi√ßos, mas as novas startups trouxeram o mesmo servi√ßo com um pre√ßo mais atraente, chamando a aten√ß√£o dessa demanda. Para os neg√≥cios, isso √© √≥timo, j√° que traz concorr√™ncia e melhores servi√ßos. Nos √∫ltimos anos, o n√∫mero de pessoas empreendendo foi significativo, o crescimento econ√¥mico do Brasil foi um dos respons√°veis pelo surgimento de novos empresas, isso j√° √© notado por investidores estrangeiro, que est√£o empolgados com esses novos empreendimentos. Antes desse acr√©scimo, geralmente o empreendedorismo acontecia quando algum individuo era demitido, e ent√£o abria o pr√≥prio neg√≥cio. Essa efervesc√™ncia toda rendeu ao Brasil uma boa posi√ß√£o no relat√≥rio Startup Ecosystem de 2012 e S√£o Paulo aparece na lista de melhores lugares para empreender no mundo. ‚ÄúUma boa reputa√ß√£o vale mais do que dinheiro.‚Äù Publilius Syrus, escritor romano de m√°ximas. De fato, isso √© algo positivo para a economia brasileira, j√° que novos neg√≥cios significam um mercado de maior concorr√™ncia e novos empregos. Al√©m disso, o Brasil fica cada vez mais √† frente em dire√ß√£o as maiores economias mundiais, mas antes de tudo, necessitamos de um maior conhecimento econ√¥mico. Mesmo que o termo parece se tratar de uma pequena empresa, criar uma Startup n√£o √© para qualquer um, os riscos de abrir uma empresa de tecnologia vinda de uma ideia nunca usada, requer uma dose de coragem e risco, √© bem diferente de criar um pequeno ponto de venda em uma rua movimentada, h√° pontos de vendas em todo canto, j√° foram aceitos, os modelos est√£o l√°, passo a passo. Ap√≥s a minha leitura do livro ‚ÄúA mente do empreendedor‚Äù de Kevin D.Johnson, fiquei animado em criar o meu pr√≥pria neg√≥cio, e n√£o se trata de ir em algo grande j√° de cara. Empreender significa em primeira caso, tentar, por exemplo, como voc√™ saber√° que sua ideia cativara clientes sem ao menos jogar na boca do povo e ver o que acontece. Caso apare√ßa ordens de compra ou interesse na sua ideia, ent√£o voc√™ est√° no caminho certo. Fa√ßa isso antes de criar um Business Plan e todo o processo de cria√ß√£o, imagine o quanto seria desanimador se ap√≥s a cria√ß√£o, o seu projeto n√£o gerasse nenhuma venda. ‚ÄúO sucesso √© consequ√™ncia de tomar a iniciativa e fazer o acompanhamento posterior. Anthony Robbins, escritor e palestrando profissional. Futuramente escreverei mais a respeito da cria√ß√£o de uma Startup, do inicio ao fim. Caso haja interesse, sigam o meu perfil no Medium. Atenciosamente, Andrew Caldas. -- -- Help Status About Careers Press Blog Privacy Terms Text to speech Teams

Title: ‚ÄúAt the end of the day, creating a fantastic work culture really boils down to one thing: trust‚Äù with Kevin Lee of INPHANTRY
Subtitle: Authority Magazine
Author: Jason Malki
Article: Sign up Sign in Sign up Sign in Home Newsletter About  In-depth Interviews with Authorities in Business, Pop Culture, Wellness, Social Impact, and Tech‚Ä¶  Jason Malki Follow Authority Magazine -- Listen Share I came up with five ideas; however, each point follows a consistent theme. At the end of the day, it really boils down to one thing: trust. Trust your team to do their job. Trust them to make decisions, to ask for help when they need it, or voice their opinions. Everyone wants to feel valued. Nobody wants to be micromanaged. For us, this trust manifests in a number of ways. We don‚Äôt put limits on vacation time and sick days and we trust that our employees will responsibly manage their workloads, communicate with the team, and schedule time accordingly. Trust in your team‚Äôs ability to the point that when it comes to structure, you can essentially run flat. This is a bold move, and it‚Äôs not for everyone, but we‚Äôre fortunate that it works for us. We don‚Äôt operate within an org chart of executives, managers, and supervisors. We have only leaders, and on any given project, anyone can step into a leadership role depending on their expertise or desire. This allows for huge growth opportunities for employees to explore and steer their career down the path of their choosing. As a part of my series about about how leaders can create a ‚Äúfantastic work culture‚Äù, I had the pleasure of interviewing Kevin Lee. Kevin is the Co-Founder and Creative Director of digital experience agency INPHANTRY, where he has created breakthrough campaigns and experiences for History Channel, Captain Morgan, HSBC, PUMA, and Delta. Leading a team of designers, strategists, and technologists at his Boston-based agency, Kevin is passionate about creating immersive digital experiences that resonate with people and bring relevance to brands. Thank you so much for doing this with us Kevin! Can you tell us a story about what brought you to this specific career path? I‚Äôve always been a self-starter and tinkerer. When I was young, I probably spent more time learning how to make things online than I did in the classroom. My interest in design and technology led me to art school, but after landing an internship at what was one of the few digital agencies at the time, I quickly realized (yet again) that I was going to learn a lot more in the real world. So, halfway through my freshman year, I dropped out and jumped headfirst into the agency world and never looked back. The path that led me to where I am today was no less interesting. I was part of a team that was commissioned by a Europe-based online poker company to create a memorable experience for a Las Vegas event. Twitter was relatively new and touchscreen devices were nearly unheard of at the time, and we had to figure out how to build an experience that was not only engaging for players at the event, but also easily shareable with their friends and families back home in Europe. We ended up building a touchscreen, Twitter-enabled photo booth from the ground up. Keep in mind, this was before social photo booths were even a thing. That early experience is what led us to create INPHANTRY. We saw the excitement of attendees interacting with something digital in the physical space and instantly knew we were on to something. The ‚Äúhacker‚Äù mentality required to innovate on the fly came naturally to us, but we understood that there was something bigger than just technology going on. It was about helping brands connect with consumers by giving them an experience they‚Äôd never forget. Can you share the most interesting story that happened to you since you began leading your company? I think the most interesting thing for me, personally, has been just growing up with the company we started and watching all of us evolve. In the beginning, we were a group of kids figuring it out. Whether it was creating an experience at Lollapalooza that led to us being onstage with LL Cool J, to taking a break from an activation in Vegas to go on a joyride and get lost for hours in the desert, it just felt like one big crazy adventure. Now, some of us ‚Äúkids‚Äù have kids of our own. We‚Äôve grown into specialists at what we do. We‚Äôve added new members to the team from all kinds of backgrounds ‚Äî some of whom are as young as we were when we started. But what‚Äôs interesting to me is that it still feels like we‚Äôre on the same crazy adventure. The team has gone through changes, but we‚Äôre still in it together, having fun, and the bond is as strong as it ever was. Are you working on any exciting projects now? How do you think that will help people? Yes, while we can‚Äôt reveal any specifics yet, we are currently creating experiences for major brands in sportswear, automotive, and even construction and real estate development. Each project is different in terms of strategy, execution, and reach; however, the central theme here is we are being tasked with developing experiences that fulfill our clients‚Äô needs by merging storytelling with technology. In terms of how our projects can help people, first and foremost, we have a responsibility to deliver work that addresses our clients‚Äô respective challenges, but because we focus on user experience, what we do is only successful if it ultimately benefits the audience we‚Äôre trying to reach. Whether it‚Äôs creating a touchscreen experience that enables homeowners to design and envision their dream home in real-time, or building an augmented reality app that lets you show off your personal style, we find that it‚Äôs less about advertising products and more about understanding people‚Äôs needs and helping them achieve whatever it is they want to do. Ok, let‚Äôs jump to the main part of our interview. According to this study cited in Forbes, more than half of the US workforce is unhappy. Why do you think that number is so high? I think a lot of it has to do with having a sense of purpose and being invested in what you‚Äôre doing. It‚Äôs no secret that many workplaces value structure, hierarchy, and process over communication and personal interaction. While this model may work for some, the way we work today is changing. I can only speak for my industry, but when your job is literally to be creative every day, that kind of structure and bureaucracy can lead to burnout and frustration over time. When we feel free to experiment and take risks without fear of failure, however, we look forward to going to work and trying something new with our teammates. It‚Äôs the main reason why we‚Äôve remained small and why we work the way we do at INPHANTRY. Based on your experience or research, how do you think an unhappy workforce will impact a) company productivity b) company profitability c) and employee health and wellbeing? When an employee is unhappy with their current situation, they lose interest and motivation. Daily tasks become chores, and interactions with other co-workers become short, blunt, and aggressive. Their focus is inward as opposed to taking a collaborative approach, and it only takes one unhappy person to change the tone of the entire team. It‚Äôs bad for business and worse for your emotional health. Can you share 5 things that managers and executives should be doing to improve their company work culture? Can you give a personal story or example for each? I came up with five; however, each point follows a consistent theme. At the end of the day, it really boils down to one thing: trust. Trust your team to do their job. Trust them to make decisions, to ask for help when they need it, or voice their opinions. Everyone wants to feel valued. Nobody wants to be micromanaged. For us, this trust manifests in a number of ways. We don‚Äôt put limits on vacation time and sick days and we trust that our employees will responsibly manage their workloads, communicate with the team, and schedule time accordingly. Trust in your team‚Äôs ability to the point that when it comes to structure, you can essentially run flat. This is a bold move, and it‚Äôs not for everyone, but we‚Äôre fortunate that it works for us. We don‚Äôt operate within an org chart of executives, managers, and supervisors. We have only leaders, and on any given project, anyone can step into a leadership role depending on their expertise or desire. This allows for huge growth opportunities for employees to explore and steer their career down the path of their choosing. When you trust your people and take the ‚Äúboss / employee‚Äù relationship out of the equation, everyone talks to one another as peers, and there‚Äôs a much closer connection throughout the team. It‚Äôs one of the reasons we named our company ‚ÄúINPHANTRY.‚Äù It‚Äôs very nice to suggest ideas, but it seems like we have to ‚Äúchange the culture regarding work culture‚Äù. What can we do as a society to make a broader change in the US workforce‚Äôs work culture? I touched upon this in my previous response, but I do think that less hierarchy goes a long way in building trust and accountability amongst the team. Ego is a big factor in many work cultures. We all want to feel important, appreciated, and respected, whether it‚Äôs at work or in our personal lives. When we‚Äôre not put in a position to be impactful, the ego suffers and it can become a problem. In a work culture, fewer levels between management and the team means that everyone has a clear role, a voice, and is adding value. You don‚Äôt need to be higher up the chain to make an impact. How would you describe your leadership or management style? Can you give us a few examples? My management style is a reflection of who I am as a person. I do not talk to my coworkers any differently than I would a family member or friend. I am honest, transparent, and straight to the point. If and when my coworkers make mistakes, I give them the space to learn from them. I also try to advise on how to accomplish something differently. More importantly, I believe that emotions should be expressed, not suppressed. If I‚Äôm happy or frustrated about something, I let others know ‚Äî and vice versa. None of us are able to achieve success without some help along the way. Is there a particular person who you are grateful towards who helped get you to where you are? Can you share a story about that? I‚Äôd say my parents. They taught me what it means to be a decent human being. We grew up with very little, and I think that played a huge role in who I am today. It puts into perspective what we have now, and it makes you appreciate all of the little things. My parents are retired now but they still want to help out and contribute as much as they can. This is just the type of people they are, and whom I always aspire to be. They may not be very familiar with technology, or what I do on a daily basis, but they always want to support me in whatever way possible. Despite my best efforts to convince them otherwise, they won‚Äôt allow me to hire any cleaning or janitorial services. Instead, they come in themselves every Sunday to ready the office for the week and make sure the team has everything they need ‚Äî including a well-stocked pantry of snacks and goodies. If we need to build anything, benches, piping, tables or desks, they are here in an instant to help. This willingness to work hard and go the extra mile has shaped me ‚Äî not only as a person, but also as a business leader. How have you used your success to bring goodness to the world? We try to contribute to charities and give back as much as we can. Every holiday season, we reach out to several local shelters and work with the staff to gather wish lists from the families there. We then go out as a team to spend the day shopping (no online shopping allowed) and bring back a huge haul of toys, clothes, and other necessities so that moms living in shelters can still give their children the holiday they‚Äôd hoped for. This is something we‚Äôre extremely proud of, and we never look to receive any recognition for it. Spending the day out as friends, and bringing some joy to children who really need it, is pretty rewarding as it is. Can you please give us your favorite ‚ÄúLife Lesson Quote‚Äù? Can you share how that was relevant to you in your life? ‚ÄúWork Hard, Stay Humble.‚Äù Having been raised by immigrant parents who sacrificed everything to give us a life here in the States, this quote defines who I am and where I‚Äôve come from. Being rich or successful is not something I can control, but working hard and staying grounded is. You are a person of great influence. If you could inspire a movement that would bring the most amount of good to the most amount of people, what would that be? You never know what your idea can trigger. :-) Ok, so this might be counterintuitive, seeing as I work in technology and marketing, but I‚Äôd love to inspire people to put down their phones and step away from social media more often. Obviously, all of this has changed the way we communicate and in some ways has brought us all closer together, but there‚Äôs no shortage of debate about the pitfalls of being forever connected to our devices. Anxiety and dopamine spikes aside, I would just like for us as a society to be reminded of the reasons for why we do the things we do. It‚Äôs not about the recognition, the likes, and the shares. It‚Äôs about who we are and what drives us. This has been a belief of mine for a very long time now; it‚Äôs one of the main reasons why we like to remain anonymous when we shop for the holidays. It‚Äôs why we request that the kids receive the gifts from their mothers and not from us. I saw a story in the news years ago about a man who would go into discount dollar stores and shelters, and hand out $100 bills to people in need. He requested that his face be blurred for the story and that he remain anonymous because he was fortunate to be in his position and simply wanted to help out and give back. That story always stuck with me. I still don‚Äôt know who he was, but he inspired me and I‚Äôll always be grateful for that example. Sometimes it‚Äôs ok to do something simply for the sake of doing it. Put down your phones, interact with people, appreciate the beauty the world has to offer. These days, it‚Äôs more important than ever. Thank you for these fantastic insights. We wish you continued success! -- -- In-depth Interviews with Authorities in Business, Pop Culture, Wellness, Social Impact, and Tech. We use interviews to draw out stories that are both empowering and actionable. Jason Malki is the Founder & CEO of SuperWarm AI + StrtupBoost, a 30K+ member startup ecosystem + agency that helps across fundraising, marketing, and design. Title: Vietnam based SotaTek partners with XinFin Network
Subtitle: Vietnam based leading technology firm Sota Tek have joined XinFin Network, an open source enterprise-friendly hybrid blockchain platform
Author: XDC Network
Article: Sign up Sign in Sign up Sign in XDC Network Follow XDC Network -- Listen Share As a part of this partnership, Sotatek will deploy XinFin Network public network masternodes in the testnet that has been released on 30th January 2019. URL: http://xinfin.network/#stats XinFin Public Network is an EVM compliant public network with KYC Enforced masternodes with randomized Delegated Proof of Stake consensus that achieves decentralization with high throughput. The Hybrid architecture ensures privacy sensitive data and transaction information is operated in the private network while a limited set of data and transactions can be relayed on the XinFin Public Network. URL: https://github.com/XinFinOrg Sotatek will work for enhancement and improvement of XinFin Public Network, XDC Protocol and deployment of Relay bridges between privacy channels and blockchain platforms like Hyperledger, Corda and XinFin Public Network. URL: https://docs.xinfin.org Sotatek will also provide support and customization for deployment of Standardised Distributed Applications deployed on XinFin Network Testnet. The standardized applications range from Invoice Factoring, Global Trade and Finance, instant remittances, E-wallets, Liquidity relayers, University Certificate Issuance, Asset Digitization, and global Air Charter. URL: https://xinfin.org/xdc-utility.php Sota Tek is a software development company established in 2015, based in Hanoi, Vietnam. Sota Tek stands for ‚ÄúState of the art Technology‚Äù, it shows the desire to conquer new peaks of technology. A young, responsible, and professional team with 100+ engineers who build full-stack solutions in multiple platforms with highly scalable back-ends and rich media front-ends. So far Sota Tek has developed many innovative solutions for clients around the globe in various industries such as entertainment, medical, financial services and so on. Sota Tek has an objective is to provide services at a cost-effective price as well as scalability benefit to customer around the globe. Website: https://sotatek.com/ LinkedIn: https://www.linkedin.com/company/sota-tek-.-jsc/ Facebook: https://www.facebook.com/sotatek/ XinFin is an open source Hybrid Blockchain protocol initiated out of Singapore. XinFin Network[XDCE] is a utility network that lets enterprises deploy real-world applications on Hybrid Blockchain Protocol in a conducive, compliant and regulation-friendly environment for diverse use cases in trade, finance, remittance, supply chain, healthcare, and other industrial areas to improve business efficiency. The XDC Dev Environment encourages developers to build DAPPs using smart contracts. The XinFin community derives its success from the ecosystem comprising of developers, network utility and long-term backers. Slack: https://launchpass.com/xinfin-public Telegram: https://t.me/xinfintalk Twitter: https://twitter.com/XinFin_Official Linkedin: https://linkedin.com/company/xinfin/ Subscribe to the XinFin Community Newsletter by clicking here. You will receive XinFin‚Äôs newsletter direct to your inbox every month. Title: The Importance of Good Software Architecture for Your Business
Subtitle: Written by Dmytro Dvurechenskyi from openGeeksLab
Author: Dmytro Dvurechenskyi from openGeeksLab
Article: Sign up Sign in Sign up Sign in Dmytro Dvurechenskyi from openGeeksLab Follow -- Listen Share You, as a business owner, are interested in a high standard realization of your final product, and software architecture, in turn, is a mechanism for achieving this goal. It is a mechanism for building a quality product that performs specific tasks and meets specific requirements. In this article, openGeeksLab has outlined why good software architecture is a must for your business. The tasks that a software product will perform affect architecture, but they are not crucial in defining it. Architecture will complete the task that needs to be performed. Questions arise concerning the requirements. Software architecture is selected depending on specific requirements and tasks. Separately worth noting the fact that if you assign a separate set of tasks, a development company can take for itself the most straightforward architectural product solutions. Therefore, businesses often have problems after a product launch. During testing, everything was fine. As soon as a project is released, in real conditions, when a load increases, critical situations arise, a software product ceases to cope with these problems since architecture is not able to comply with the requirements. There may be various software requirements for a product. Let‚Äôs take a look at the simplest types of requirements: Architecture is built based on requirements and functionality. Good architecture is one that meets these tasks and requirements and can complete them. Among other benefits, in addition to full compliance with the requirements, applying an architectural approach to the development itself provides certain advantages to your product: There is a concept of classical software architecture design patterns (classical architectural solutions). The most common are MVC, MVM, Viper, Flux, various service-oriented architecture (SOA) options, common query responsibility segregation (CQRS), and many others. On average, such solutions can meet approximately 80% of requirements. 20% are the most problematic, and the majority of time on architecture building is spent on them. These 20% are unique to your software product. As a result, the first proposal from developers for applied architecture will be available almost immediately. Accordingly, after a simple Internet search, you can find out the main advantages and disadvantages of the proposed architecture and discuss them with developers for further work. Classic is important not only for developers but also for a business owner. If developers can not give an answer, then it is worth considering whether to cooperate with them. It is important to understand that in different sources the same architecture can be described in different ways. For example, for SOA architectures, the most authoritative are Martin Fowler‚Äôs works. You are going to develop an application. Let‚Äôs say that your project requirements are: It is an example of a set of requirements without specifying the project functionality. When mentioning such tasks, an experienced architect would almost immediately refer to one of SOA software varieties, Martin Fowler‚Äôs microservice architecture using CQRS to reduce user response time. The main principle of development would be SOLID. You can google these items. When choosing some architects, it is reasonable to select among those who provide you with architecture that is built to last and who can ensure your system quality and longevity. We at openGeeksLab know everything about innovative architectural solutions and making fundamental structural choices to achieve your business goals. Drop us a line, and we‚Äôll be delighted to assist you in meeting your challenges. If you have any further questions, please don‚Äôt hesitate to contact us. Title: The Automation Charade
Subtitle: The rise of the robots has been greatly exaggerated. Whose interests does that serve?
Author: Logic Magazine
Article: Sign up Sign in Sign up Sign in Member-only story Logic Magazine Follow Logic Magazine -- Share By Astra Taylor Somewhere, right now, a manager is intoning to a broke, exhausted underling that someone is willing to do the same job for less ‚Äî or, that some thing is willing to do it for free. Since the dawn of market society, owners and bosses have revelled in telling workers they were replaceable. Robots lend this centuries-old dynamic a troubling new twist: employers threaten employees with the specter of machine competition, shirking responsibility for their avaricious disposition through opportunistic appeals to tech determinism. A ‚Äújobless future‚Äù is inevitable, we are told, an irresistible outgrowth of innovation, the livelihood-devouring price of progress. (Sadly, the jobless future for the masses doesn‚Äôt resemble the jobless present of the 1 percent who live off dividends, interest, and rent, lifting nary a finger as their bank balances grow.) Though automation is presented as a neutral process, the straightforward consequence of technological progress, one needn‚Äôt look that closely to see that this is hardly the case. Automation is both a reality and an ideology, and thus also a weapon wielded against poor and working people who have the audacity to demand better treatment‚Ä¶ -- -- Logic Magazine is a print magazine that seeks to deepen our discourse around technology. Title: Goodbye, art? Will the next ‚Äúvoice of a generation‚Äù be a robot?
Subtitle: Grimes: "I think live music is going to be obsolete soon" - NME Music News, Reviews, Videos‚Ä¶
Author: Brian Larson
Article: Sign up Sign in Sign up Sign in Brian Larson Follow -- Listen Share Is art, in all its various human-led expressions, about to go extinct? Will art as we know it be supplanted by artificial intelligence (AI)? Will the next ‚Äúvoice of a generation‚Äù be a robot? **GASP** Some in the music community have recently started to debate this topic and I think it‚Äôs application can easily be viewed through the lens of the future of work. For example, many skeptics believe that ‚Äúthe bots‚Äù will supplant all forms of work in the future. This dystopian view is simply not true and, frankly, it‚Äôs unhealthy. Humans have learned from past industrial revolutions that advances in technology greatly improve the quality of human life while also contributing to more productive jobs (albeit some jobs do face elimination). What we see in the 4th Industrial Revolution is no different. The advent of ‚Äúsuperjobs‚Äù or humans working hand-in-hand with artificial intelligence and automation promise similar advances.[1] Grimes, a Canadian musician known for experimental but pop-laden music, is an outspoken futurist who has a rather dystopian view of the future of music and art in general. In a recent interview Grimes elaborated, ‚ÄúI ultimately probably believe in an AI dictatorship. I mean, I don‚Äôt think humanity is going to survive anyway. We‚Äôre f*c*ed. I think AI is the natural evolution.‚Äù Grimes furthered, ‚ÄúOnce there‚Äôs actually AGI (Artificial General Intelligence), they‚Äôre gonna be so much better at making art than us.‚Äù[2] www.nme.com Grimes‚Äô fear-infused future of art and, in particular, the music industry, are likely never to be realized. For starters, for hundreds of years, humans have been adapting to changes in technology and using such advances to better communicate their artistic visions (artists today like Billie Eilish and Taylor Swift have been known to lay down rough versions on tracks on their iPhones and, in Billie‚Äôs case, even fully record a song from the palm of their hand). Are the songs that are produced through such technological advances any different than those produced in a full-fledge music studio in LA or Abbey Road Studios? Probably not. Sure, mixing and mastering still need to be done in a studio, but the actual process of capturing one‚Äôs art in digital form has rapidly changed over the past 2 decades alone. Garageband is never likely to replace a talented producer just like autotune hasn‚Äôt replaced the need for incredible singers (leave Cher out of this argument- she‚Äôs untouchable with or without autotune). Holly Herndon, a Germany-based composer, has the right take on the future of music. Holly recently tweeted, ‚ÄúThe idea of technology and automation should allow us to be more human and more expressive together, not replace us all together.‚Äù Holly has proposed that ‚Äúinterdependent music‚Äù may be the solution to our AI-imbedded future. In a nutshell, Holly‚Äôs solution emphasizes using AI and other technological advances to facilitate ‚Äúhuman coordination‚Äù in music industry and to make sure that all parties in the ecosystem (writers, producers, singers, etc.) receive their fair share of the pie. This ecosystem of accountability and tracing of individual contribution (maybe there‚Äôs a place for blockchain in this process?!) to the finished product may sound idealistic but at least it offers a more salient solution than fearing the arrival of the overlord bots. Maggie Rogers, a Brooklyn-based and recently Grammy-nominated artist, known for infusing nature (yes, the sounds of leaves rustling, frogs croaking, and crickets chirping) into her infectiously-clever songs, has learned to embrace the change of technology while remaining true to her roots. Rogers noted in a recent GQ interview, ‚ÄúThe music industry is so cool because it‚Äôs constantly changing. Nobody has any idea what the f*ck they‚Äôre doing. A good idea can change the world. The music industry, and specifically the Internet and the way music is made now, democratizes that process. Someone in their bedroom could have a hit single because the Internet votes on it. The barrier to entry isn‚Äôt intense. You just need GarageBand.‚Äù[3] Can we all adopt Rogers stance on technology and nature‚Ä¶ and life in general? If you haven‚Äôt heard of Maggie Rogers or the below song (my personal favorite, ‚ÄúDog Years‚Äù) then please do yourself a favor and press play- the human connection is alive and well in every melody Rogers writes and produces (bot friendly, of course)! [1] https://www2.deloitte.com/us/en/insights/focus/human-capital-trends/2019/impact-of-ai-turning-jobs-into-superjobs.html [2] https://crackmagazine.net/article/long-reads/grimes-is-ready-to-play-the-villain/ [3] https://www.gq.com/story/maggie-rogers-makes-weird-music-for-normal-ish-people -- -- Brian is a graduate of The Fletcher School at Tufts University & lives and works in New York City .
