Title: Has BERT Been Cheating? Researchers Say it Exploits ‚ÄòSpurious Statistical Cues‚Äô
Subtitle: Published in SyncedReview
Author: Synced
Article: Sign up Sign in Sign up Sign in Synced Follow SyncedReview -- Listen Share Since Google Research introduced its Bidirectional Transformer (BERT) in 2018 the model has gained unprecedented popularity among researchers. BERT has set new records on 11 natural language processing (NLP) tasks, and more than half of the top 10 models on the GLUE (General Language Understanding Evaluation) Benchmark are built on top of BERT architecture. Now, a group of researchers from the National Cheng Kung University Tainan in Taiwan are challenging BERT‚Äôs efficacy. Their paper Probing Neural Network Comprehension of Natural Language Arguments proposes that BERT‚Äôs impressive performance might be attributed to ‚Äúexploitation of spurious statistical cues in the dataset‚Äù and that without them, BERT may be no better than random models. The paper has been accepted by the Association for Computational Linguistics (ACL). The researchers introduced a new adversarial dataset that cut BERT‚Äôs accuracy from 77 percent to 53 percent, and suggest this dataset could be adopted as a standard for future performance evaluations. The NLP community has built benchmark tests such as SQuAD and AllenAI as well as evaluation metrics like GLUE to test the performance of models. In 2018, a group of German researchers introduced The Argument Reasoning Comprehension Task (ARCT), designed to evaluate the inferencing ability of a language model. Given a premise/reason and a claim, the model has to infer to a warrant (why the claim follows from the premise) from two options. For example, given the claim ‚ÄúGoogle is not a harmful monopoly‚Äù and the premise ‚ÄúPeople can choose not to use Google,‚Äù the model should choose the correct warrant, which is ‚ÄúOther search engines don‚Äôt redirect to Google‚Äù and not the alternative, ‚ÄúAll other search engines redirect to Google.‚Äù Although the ARCT task raised the threshold for language models, BERT still scored 77 percent accuracy on it, only three points below the average (untrained) human baseline. That motivated the Cheng Kung University researchers to investigate why BERT works so well on ARCT. To their surprise, they discovered that the BERT model bases its predictions on spurious cues ‚Äî for example it tends to choose the warrant that includes the word ‚Äúnot.‚Äù Across the dataset, even a random model can achieve 61 percent accuracy if it simply keeps choosing the warrant that contains the word ‚Äúnot.‚Äù Spurious correlation was proposed in 1997, and denotes a mathematical relationship in which two or more events or variables are associated but not causally related. In this case, the word ‚Äúnot‚Äù is a type of spurious statistical cue that leads the model to choose the right answer but essentially has no causal relationship with the answer. Moreover, bigrams that occurred with ‚Äúnot,‚Äù such as ‚Äúwill not‚Äù and ‚Äúcannot,‚Äù were also found to be highly predictive. Researchers conducted additional experiments to test their conjecture. Previously, BERT had been trained on warrant-reason-claim pairs, but now researchers trained BERT on only the warrant data. It scored 71 percent accuracy, only six points below its peak performance. Researchers then created an adversarial dataset with the claims negated and the labels inverted so that the distribution of statistical cues was mirrored across warrant options, effectively eliminating the signals. This dropped BERT‚Äôs accuracy to 53 percent. The ACL paper is not the first attempt to rethink the efficacy of large-scale neural networks in NLP tasks. In fact, since neural networks were first applied to NLP, many language experts and linguisticians have been skeptical on whether deep learning models which can efficiently map latent representation from data are actually able to understand the semantics of languages. Earlier this year researchers from Johns Hopkins University and Brown University published a paper with similar conclusions: ‚Äúa machine learning system can score well on a given test set by relying on heuristics that are effective for frequent example types but break down in more challenging cases.‚Äù Some researchers have begun to question whether the machine learning community places too much emphasis on standard benchmark tests. Anna Rogers, a post-doctoral associate in the Text Machine Lab of Computer Science Department, University of Massachusetts Lowell, wrote in her blog that ‚ÄúIf the reader‚Äôs main takeaway is going to be the leaderboard, that increases the perception that the publication-worthiness is only achieved by beating the SOTA.‚Äù Rogers suggests the machine learning community should come up with new evaluation methods that reward those who innovate on new architectures, rather than having teams compete against each other by simply enlarging their models or throwing more data and compute into their existing research. The authors stress their paper is not intended to disparage the value of BERT, which they regard as a strong machine learning system that can improve if the problematic spurious statistical cues are neutralized. ‚ÄúAnalysis of easy to classify data points showed reliance on a lower proportion of the strongest cue word than the BoV and BiLSTM ‚Äî i.e. BERT has learned when to ignore the presence of ‚Äònot‚Äô and focus on different cues. This indicates an ability to exploit much more subtle joint distributional information.‚Äù Google AI Researcher David Ha echoed this view, ‚ÄúI think the features learned using a model like BERT are still very useful for many applications, and it is good that such papers remind us of their limitations. Makes us take a step back from squeezing out small gains, and take a look at the bigger picture of what we are doing.‚Äù The paper Probing Neural Network Comprehension of Natural Language Arguments is on arXiv. Journalist: Tony Peng | Editor: Michael Sarazen 2018 Fortune Global 500 Public Company AI Adaptivity Report is out!Purchase a Kindle-formatted report on Amazon. Title: How to Successfully Implement New Workplace Technologies
Subtitle: Written by Emily Lundberg
Author: Emily Lundberg
Article: Sign up Sign in Sign up Sign in Emily Lundberg Follow -- Listen Share According to an MIT study, 78% of executives believe upgrading their systems is critical for their organization‚Äôs ability to maintain a competitive advantage. Yet, 63% also said their organizations are slow to adopt new technology. Part of the reason they hesitate is that, though new technology is capable of producing huge gains, many companies don‚Äôt realize the full benefits due to poor implementation. One of the main reasons why companies fail is a lack of planning. You can‚Äôt just expect employees to take on the challenge of integrating a new tool into their workflow; you have to first provide proper training and messaging. Luckily, doing so is much easier than you think. Here are five strategies to help you successfully implement new technology in your workplace: Let‚Äôs dive in. Adopting new software has a significant impact on how your employees work thus, you should consider their opinions. While the question of whether or not to purchase a new software may be non-negotiable, give your employees a say in what specific solution you are buying. Once you‚Äôve narrowed down to your top two to three choices, email your team explaining why you‚Äôre interested in those options and invite anyone to research the tools and share their thoughts. Most employees will ignore your email but, the ones who care will make a case for why they prefer one tool over the others. Their feedback can be instrumental in helping you choose the right tool for your team. Plus, surveys find that employees who are involved in decision-making processes are more motivated, satisfied and engaged in their jobs. Giving them a say in the outcome transforms technology adoption from a disturbance that you force upon them to a collaborative effort to make the company more successful. If you‚Äôre struggling to narrow a list of tools that meet your business needs, check out our tools database. It‚Äôs a list of the most popular tools that our clients who range from soloprenuers to Fortune 500 companies use. How you describe new technology plays an influential role in employee attitudes toward it. You may have many metrics-driven reasons for the purchase; however, those alone are not enough to motivate your employees. We make decisions with the same part of our brain that controls emotions so, to convince your employees to embrace a new tool, you need to excite them by explaining how it solves their pain points. For example, if you‚Äôre adopting a more advanced CRM and one of your sales team‚Äôs top challenges is predicting which prospects and campaigns are most likely to drive sales, then explain how the new CRM has analytics tools that will help them determine where to focus their efforts. If you‚Äôre implementing software across multiple functional teams, change your message to reflect the specific benefits for each group. Read More: How to Capitalize on the 4 Types of Employee Motivation Humans naturally resist change, however, the extent that we do so varies. The Diffusion of Innovation curve explains that people‚Äôs willingness to adopt innovative technology falls onto a bell curve that‚Äôs divided into five groups of people: The percentage of your employees that fall into each of these groups may vary from the normal curve since your organization might attract people who are more or less open to change. However, you almost certainly have employees in all categories. Understanding the different perspectives on innovation helps you plan a smoother implementation. Here are the five perspectives on new technology: Innovators: These employees are always asking for new technology and proposing new ways to complete work. Give them access to the software first so they can learn how to use it and be able to teach other employees about it. Early Adopters: Early adopters curiosity is piqued when they see the innovators using something new. They are the employees who show interest in your new systems but aren‚Äôt as eager or change-driving as innovators. If you have time, create a 1‚Äì2 week long focus group from these individuals. Their questions, challenges, and positive feedback can be used to improve how you release the new system to the entire team. Early Majority: You‚Äôll reach the early and late majority when you roll out the new technology to everyone involved. People in the early majority will quickly jump on board and work collaboratively to develop best practices. Late Majority: People in this category will resist the implementation until they see proof that it works. They‚Äôll likely have a lot of questions and some complaints early on. However, once they start realizing performance improvements, they‚Äôll embrace the change. Laggards: These individuals will resist adopting new technology until you start punishing them for not using it. If possible, wait to force them to use it until you‚Äôve worked through most of the errors because they tend to be vocal complainers when they run into issues. Designing your implementation plan to cater to each of these groups will reduce the number of conflicts and resistance you face. Most Saas and other technology companies assign you an account manager. Take advantage of them; they are experts in the technology and can speed up your adoption process by helping you overcome the learning curve. Here are some questions you should ask your account manager: Ask as many questions as you need to feel 100% confident using the tool. If teaching your employees how to use new software is daunting, chances are you don‚Äôt have to do it yourself. Many Saas and other technology providers like Salesforce, Hubspot, Microsoft, etc. have free training programs that walk people through how to use every aspect of the software. Identify which sections are most useful to each of your employee groups and have your employees complete them. Though the training materials are great at explaining how to use the system, their assessments, if any, often aren‚Äôt strong enough to prove employee understanding. To ensure your team is learning the necessary skills, sync with them mid training to check their progress. After they complete it, give them an assignment that tests their ability to use it. For example, you might ask them to input data and run a few reports, use the analytics to generate actionable insights, or create a workflow to automate a process. About the Author: Emily leads Prialto‚Äôs marketing team with a special passion for helping people realize success. Her work and collaborations have appeared in Entrepreneur, Inc. and the Observer among others. Originally published at https://blog.prialto.com. -- -- I lead the marketing team at Prialto and am passionate about helping people realize success. Title: How Public Policy can thrive in a Data world
Subtitle: Published in Phoensight
Author: Audrey Lobo-Pulo
Article: Sign up Sign in Sign up Sign in Audrey Lobo-Pulo Follow Phoensight -- Listen Share With the emergence of new technologies, comes an opportunity to re-think public policy design. What I find really interesting is that we can do this by better utilising technology and using our ‚Äúhuman‚Äù attributes to greater advantage ‚Äî and I‚Äôm continually fascinated by how these not only complement, but enhance each other. Technology is rapidly disrupting our traditional policy approaches. And like people in most industries, policymakers are looking at new ways to adapt, with the two main factors in navigating this changing landscape being: Policymakers will soon integrate the two seamlessly, as new technologies become more familiar to us. What we‚Äôve seen is that the nature of these new technologies ‚Äî particularly the democratisation of technology ‚Äî also fundamentally changes how we choose to operate and interact with each other in society. And this is where the real paradigm shift happens! The Internet and Open Source technologies have created a world where it‚Äôs possible to share information (and code!) in an unprecedented way, that maximises accessibility to citizens while allowing for openness. High computational and processing power, along with sophisticated user interfaces and virtual reality, has the potential to offer citizens an opportunity to interact with their society like never before. Citizens may one day use new technologies to better understand their social and policy environments, and make more informed choices ‚Äî particularly if they have better insights into the impacts of policy decisions. If citizens could navigate their policy environment using technology the way I navigate through the city with my GPS, we‚Äôd have a better sense of the options available to us. Citizens may not need to know about the complexities of public policy design to understand how they‚Äôd be affected ‚Äî just as I may not know how my GPS works, but can still navigate to my destination! Technology ‚Äî and this iterative (and even real-time) feedback ‚Äî may add significantly to our tacit understanding of how our societal and economic systems work. Now, imagine a society where the public and stakeholders can co-design public policy with government, feel more empowered and share the responsibility of the decision making. The challenge here lies in knowing how to reach an intended outcome. The reason this has been so difficult is that it‚Äôs hard to know which policies will achieve their objectives, let alone the extent of their impact. And this is where the policy modelling story begins‚Ä¶ Policy modelling isn‚Äôt easy. In fact, most policy analysts know it can be something of a fine art. Judgments about assumptions, models etc. are all part of the craft, and it‚Äôs become more complicated and specialised. But the importance of quantifying policy impacts cannot be understated. Numbers and costings form part of the political armory in public debate and ‚Äî in the spirit of an open government ‚Äî should be up for public scrutiny. With this mind, perhaps the first step in a truly ‚ÄòOpen Government‚Äô is for governments to begin sharing their modelling‚Ä¶ ‚ÄòGovernment Open Source Models‚Äô refer to policy models released by governments that are freely available to use, distribute and modify by the public. The community would have the opportunity to improve the quality, reliability, and accuracy of policy modelling. And Government could use the incredible connectivity provided by the internet to tap into the multidisciplinary (and niche) knowledge of their citizens in the creation of these models. The result? New data-driven apps that are more developed, diverse, accessible and easier to understand. These would ultimately benefit the public through increased transparency, and add a new dimension (or rigour!) to public debate. So how can policymakers harness the full power of this potential? In an age where the debate on whether and to what extent machines can replace humans continues, there are two things I will always have sovereignty over ‚Äî my ability to experience and my urge to create. Our ability to experience and our desire to create is what makes us human. Facebook, YouTube, Instagram and Twitter are a testament to our innate ability to be content creators, and our willingness to actively participate in our communities. Without an active member base, these companies would not be flourishing today ‚Äî and policymakers can learn from this! ‚ÄòGovernment as a platform‚Äô is also provided the same opportunity with their citizens. With technology it is possible to co-ordinate thousands of people in a collaborate effort on a single project! Wikipedia with 72,000 active contributors working on more than 48,000,000 articles in 302 languages demonstrated that community engagement at scale was doable. So how would policymakers use technology to collaborate with their citizens at scale in an ‚Äòopen policy design‚Äô process? Github is one of the most successful modelling (and software development) platforms to provide governments around the world a mechanism to co-ordinate with an unlimited number of contributors on a specific project ‚Äî and that is powerful! The possibility of governments working on specific policy projects with an unlimited number of citizens and stakeholders by collaborating at scale is yet to be fully realised. ‚ÄòScalable stakeholder engagement‚Äô is a way to transform government modelling by opening up new possibilities for open policy design. The potential is unimaginable! And we haven‚Äôt even got to ‚Äòbig data‚Äô yet‚Ä¶ In 1945, the French singer, Edith Piaf wrote ‚ÄòLa vie en Rose‚Äô, a popular French song about looking at life through rose coloured glasses. Now if you were to look at the world using a data lens ‚Äî what would you see? Transportation data, transactional data, banking data, weather data, social media data, photos, employment data‚Ä¶ and the list continues. Policymakers could not possibly imagine all the data sources we have today. Our data ecosystem is rapidly growing and diversifying ‚Äî but what does this mean for informing policy and social issues? How can governments uncover new insights and create a better society with such extraordinary data sources? Before we embark on a journey into the future, let‚Äôs reflect on how far we‚Äôve come with government data and data collection. One of the earliest recorded data collections ‚Äî the well-known biblical census ‚Äî required people to return to their own towns to register themselves. So Governments collected data on their citizens even back then! But a lot has changed since that time ‚Äî governments began to get more sophisticated, and organised their efforts into various ‚Äòportfolios‚Äô. And our data collection today is marked by these legacies ‚Äî data is usually collected by agency portfolio. Data collection has become ‚Äòsiloed‚Äô ‚Äî and this sort of partitioning of the data began fragmenting our data ecosystem. Today we realise that many of the policy and social issues we face require a ‚Äòsystems approach‚Äô. For example, education data is often correlated with employment data and it is unsurprising that the employment prospects for an individual usually depends on their education. We recognise that social policy issues like health cannot be considered in isolation without reference to income etc. or accessibility to healthier food options. The same applies to the data we collect within each agency portfolio ‚Äî to fully understand the nature of the policy issues, we need a systems approach to the data too. This has lead us swiftly towards ‚Äòdata integration‚Äô solutions of all sorts. A kind of ‚Äòputting humpty back together again‚Äô ‚Äî with all the complexities and challenges that come with it such as data privacy, ethics, regulations and legislation requirements. But the picture is even more complicated!!! Government no longer holds a monopoly on the data on its citizens - and I‚Äôd argue that Google, Facebook and many other private organisations hold the lion share of these data assets. And the citizen-data fragmentation we are faced with is much bigger than we‚Äôd ever imagined 20 years ago. What policy makers thought was their data universe has now expanded‚Ä¶ and is continuing to expand prolifically! Policymakers today have to work with not just government agency silos, but a public-private collective of information that could be utilised to create a better world. Yet, the richness and diversity of this data is also a policy analyst‚Äôs treasure trove! We now have such a diversity of information ‚Äî more than we‚Äôve ever known before! The challenge here is that it‚Äôs hard enough to know what data is being collected by whom, let alone how to gain access to it and bring it all together! But before we put this in the ‚Äòtoo hard basket‚Äô, let‚Äôs think outside the traditional ‚Äòdata boxes‚Äô. Although we seem to be dealing with a data linkage problem between disparate data sources ‚Äî we can turn the problem around‚Ä¶ And tackle this by examining ‚Äî not just the silos that fragment our data, but the silos that define our roles when we look at data. And this is *huge*. What we are talking about is the ‚Äòblurring out‚Äô of our organisational silos! Let me explain with a brief segue‚Ä¶ This is a picture of the famous ‚ÄòSky and Water‚Äô wood print by the Dutch artist M. C. Escher in 1938. The central theme behind this picture is the equal proportion of birds and fish. According to Escher, ‚ÄúIn the horizontal center strip there are birds and fish equivalent to each other‚Äù. And it‚Äôs been claimed that this print has been used in the study of physics, geology, chemistry and psychology for the study of visual perception. Today we can use it for data and public policy! And we can look at this in two ways ‚Äì 1. Same data, different purpose. Data in and of itself can be used in many ways to answer many different questions. Private data collected in organisations is mainly used to provide new business insights and better customer/client services. But this same data, viewed from a different perspective, could also provide new policy insights that may be useful in designing and delivering better policy interventions. Data that looks like ‚Äòbirds‚Äô to private organisations may appear as ‚Äòfish‚Äô to policy makers. 2. Same people, different roles. Who are we? ‚Äî birds or fish? There‚Äôs a new trend in the workforce today -there‚Äôs evidence to suggest that employees are increasingly focused on contributing to a greater social purpose. Businesses are beginning to accept greater social responsibility ‚Äî and this is useful not just for social causes, but for organisations too. Allowing employees a greater sense of purpose in their work, allows for better employee and community engagement. This is already happening in some organisations today. Employees with access to privately held datasets are volunteering in their organisations to analyse their data so that they can contribute to the greater social good. Imagine a world where once we had Google‚Äôs 20 per cent time for innovation, we now have 10 per cent time where employees can actively contribute to their society through data! The result? A richer data ecosystem where individuals and entities co-create and share our social responsibility for the benefit of society. And by collectively putting the pieces of this puzzle together, we can start building better models of our social and policy landscapes. We can identify data gaps where collaboration and sharing between governments, private organisations and Not For Profits can really make a difference. We can create a new perspective of our society which, without sharing, would not be possible. And we are begnning to blur our traditional roles. But how do we begin to share data in a world that‚Äôs constrained (and understandably so) by concerns relating to data privacy and ethics? What‚Äôs at the heart of the issue ‚Äî is our ability and propensity to share. I am reminded of a quote I once read from ‚ÄòThe Inevitable‚Äô by Kevin Kelly ‚Äî and he says, ‚ÄúIf today‚Äôs social media has taught us anything‚Ä¶ it is that the human impulse to share overwhelms the human impulse for privacy.‚Äù And this reflection may point us towards a possible solution to our sharing problem. In a world where the limitations of our human cognitive abilities are augmented by technology, we have the opportunity to address the limitations of technology by augmenting it with what humans are good at! And we‚Äôre good at sharing stories ‚Äî data stories. We meet with people, we exchange views, we collaborate and we debate. We can also engage in a ‚Äòdata dialogue‚Äô, about social and policy issues we feel passionately about ‚Äî not just qualitatively, but in a quantitative way supported by data. Here‚Äôs a recent example: In October 2017, the Australian Treasury and LinkedIn embarked on a pilot project looking at the Australian labour markets. What began as a general question that interested both parties, turned into something much deeper ‚Äî a discussion that ventured into quantitative insights. But the challenge was entering into an open data-dialogue‚Äî a conversation where parties respected the rights and commitments to their citizens and members. In our current data environment issues such as data privacy and ethics are increasingly important, and rightly so, but we have yet to fully explore the human-side of what‚Äôs possible with data insights. In this pilot study tech entrepreneurship across 7 countries were examined: Australia, Germany, India, Israel, Singapore, the UK and the USA. And the most amazing part? Almost no data was exchanged between the parties. Each agreed to share the aggregate distribution of the demographic profiles, and this information was cross verified by comparing to census and national statistics data. Here was a situation that‚Äôs similar to a card game ‚Äî where parties have ‚Äòcards‚Äô that they cannot share, but where they can exchange insights that are mutually beneficial. And that‚Äôs exactly how some interesting and meaningful insights into tech entrepreneurship came to light. Let me tell you what was discovered ‚Äî although we are aware of the gender gap in tech entrepreneurship, it was surprising to learn how pronounced it was. The best case scenario occurred in Singapore, where for every 10 tech entrepreneurs only 2 were women. The results were eye-opening and brought many policy questions to the surface. And this was only the beginning ‚Äî the questions that followed, such as how this gap is distributed by education or age demonstrate that there is so much more to be gained in such public-private partnerships. Humans were able to get further into these social issues and so much more quickly, in this example, than more traditional data-driven collaborations. This work was presented at the 2018 Strata Data conference in London ‚Äî and the overwhelming feedback came from government agencies. They knew these data sources existed, and that they‚Äôd be useful - but assumed that data sharing would not be possible given the existing regulations, and so had never reached out. Here was a new source of information that was leveraged by ‚Äòhumanness‚Äô. So if you‚Äôre passionate about a particular social or policy issue, I urge you to venture further and engage in a data dialogue. You never know how these insights might impact the world we live in. And one day, we may be able to create new frameworks for these discussions, in helping us achieve the best outcomes for society. For public policy to achieve its true potential, we need to engage public participation at all levels and across all silos in society using our technological resources so that both may be enhanced in delivering a better world! Phoensight is an international consultancy dedicated to supporting the interrelationships between people, public policy and technology, and is accredited by the International Bateson Institute to conduct Warm Data Labs. -- -- Phoensight is an international consultancy dedicated to supporting the relationships between people and technology, and is accredited by the International Bateson Institute to host and conduct warm data labs. We are passionate about tech, public policy and open source. Founder of Phoensight, Public Interest Technologist, Tech Reg, Open Gov & Public Policy geek. Title: Facebook and Libra: Will Company-Specific Coins be the new ICOs?
Subtitle: This article will not be about Libra as such, but rather, about the precedence it sets: for the first time, a company is issuing its own cryptocurrency.
Author: Francesco
Article: Sign up Sign in Sign up Sign in Member-only story Francesco Follow Coinmonks -- Share How Facebook‚Äôs cryptocurrency sets a precedent in the blockchain sector. I am pretty sure you have all heard the news that Facebook is gonna have its own cryptocurrency by 2020 (or never, considering possible regulatory hurdles, but that is another story ). I mean, I really wanted to write an article about it, expressing my thoughts on it. But then I opened my laptop and the web was FLOOOOODED with so many of them that I did not even know where to start reading. Plus, it seems to me each one tackles things from a particular perspective and getting the whole picture is pretty hard. In 2017 and 2018 we saw the emergence and eventual collapse of the ICO bubble. An insane amount of companies rode the hype waves of the blockchain craze and tried to raise capital for the most‚Ä¶ -- -- Coinmonks is a non-profit Crypto Educational Publication. Title: Are you ready for the cyber future?
Subtitle: Published in Here‚Äôs to the future!
Author: STRP ‚Äî blog
Article: Sign up Sign in Sign up Sign in STRP ‚Äî blog Follow Here‚Äôs to the future! -- Listen Share by Angelina Times when cyborgs could only be seen in sci-fi movies seem to have passed; some of them are already walking among us. Blurring the line between human and machine, it‚Äôs not unusual for people to replace their missing limbs with prosthetic implants. However, a bunch of outrageous technology devotees took it a step further by practicing extreme body modifications: ones that could remind you of an episode of Black Mirror, only less aesthetic. These self-made cyborgs call themselves ‚Äúbiohackers‚Äù or ‚Äúgrinders‚Äù and what they do is augmenting their bodies with technology either at home or in piercing shops. But are people ready for their bodies to be taken over by technologies? After taking a look at the photos from Grinders by Hannes Wiedemann, visitors seemed to be slightly shocked. ‚ÄúI don‚Äôt understand why someone would do this,‚Äù shares one of the visitors who‚Äôs having hard times comprehending the idea of putting a foreign object into her skin. ‚ÄúBut yeah, I believe in the future we all will have some kind of chips implanted.‚Äù I notice a man taking photos of the off-putting procedures and come over to hear his thoughts. ‚ÄúThey are the first cyborgs! It‚Äôs really cool!‚Äù, he tells me. ‚ÄúThere was a club in Rotterdam where regulars could choose to have an implant to identify themselves. You could just scan your arm and go in. This is the future,‚Äù he continues, ‚ÄúI would do it myself one day when it‚Äôs performed professionally and in a sterile environment.‚Äù The community of grinders is rapidly growing. Website Biohack.me is a place to connect with other biohackers across the globe. ‚ÄúTo promote talk in the self-biohacker community‚Äù reads their mission. Annually, the community gathers in Tehachapi California to facilitate multidisciplinary collaboration and work as they operate ‚Äúin a space where any single approach simply isn‚Äôt enough‚Äù. During the festival the visitors participate in lectures, classes and tutorials where they discuss their findings and topics such as Utopia vs. Dystopia, Space Migration, and the role of art in futurism. It‚Äôs only a matter of time until each of us can forget about smartphones and have each of its functions installed into our bodies. Are you ready for the cyber future? -- -- STRP looks to the future with an open and critical view. We have had enough of the dark and tough flirt with dystopia and ask ourselves out loud: how in heaven‚Äôs name can we come through this conservative and fear-driven period together? STRP explores scenarios for a positive future in 2019 and 2020. Help Status About Careers Press Blog Privacy Terms Text to speech Teams

Title: Blockchain in the Future
Subtitle: Written by Piyush Grover
Author: Piyush Grover
Article: Sign up Sign in Sign up Sign in Piyush Grover Follow -- Listen Share ‚ÄúMost people overestimate what they can do in one year and underestimate what they can do in ten years.‚Äù ‚Äï Bill Gates As humans, we have always created tools as an extension of our existing abilities. We have automobiles because we can move, unlike trees. We have tools to look at the micro-organisms, to the stars because we have intrinsic ability to see. We first extended our physical abilities, then we built intelligent machines extending the power of our brains. If we define a way to experience tech advancements on the ‚Äúwhoa‚Äù scale, we would find that the last 40‚Äì50 years will give the same reading as 150 years before that. What that means is, if somebody from the 1830s time-travels to 1970s, he or she will be as surprised as someone time-traveling from the 1970s to today. On the same scale, the next 15‚Äì20 years will suffice to give the same ‚Äúwhoa‚Äù reading. So, to visualize the next 15 years, let‚Äôs grasp what happened in the last 50 years. 70‚Äì80s was all about building software and the winners were those who built it first. Microsoft, Adobe, etc took the lead. The 90s were all about building businesses online. Whoever could iterate rapidly and build products/businesses online, caught VCs‚Äô attention. Amazon, Google, eBay are such examples. Then, came the age of facebook & twitter and the winners were those who brought people together & built massive online communities faster than ever, we called it web 2.0. Then, Uber happened and since then, the theme has been to scale operations across geographies as quickly as possible. The boom is all about rapid industry shifts in a short period. There are overlapping between the phases but a couple of critical innovations grab all the attention and compel people to think along those lines. Extrapolating this, in the coming decade or two, we will see the next growth. And the winners will be those who will do/build ______ faster than ever. To fill this blank, let‚Äôs go back & understand the evolution which led to these shifts. 70‚Äì80s was all about building software but PCs coming to households led the software revolution. Companies building PCs made to the top too but the point to understand is, PC was a platform that provided access of the masses, to reach out to. Not just that, it changed the whole gaming industry. Businesses were going online in the 90s because the internet was the phenomenon. It led to setting up massive internet infrastructure. Not just setting up the broadband lines, but even the continents were brought together through sea-lines (SLOC). It provided internet access to a wider audience, which resulted in the formation of massive online communities. The Uber age was supported by the massive growth in smartphone adoption, around the world. If we extrapolate this, blockchain & other decentralized tech is another supporting infrastructure, a macro phenomenon. Nevertheless, it is & it will change the way businesses are currently being run although we are yet to see a mass level effect of this on the public at large, as no micro-level disruption has happened yet. So, what is it that we are not looking at! We have heard a lot about blockchain, decentralization, trustlessness, permissionlessness, which will require a separate post in itself for the explanation. But coming back to the point, what would it be, that blockchain would disrupt fundamentally, affecting the day-to-day life of individuals? What would the blockchain future be like? To get to the answer, we need to re-look history. If I ask when, according to you, the idea of internet incepted and when the first infrastructure was set up for the same. You probably would guess around the 40‚Äì50s the idea of the internet would have been conceived and 70‚Äì80s would have seen the manifestation of the idea into a product.But, that‚Äôs not true. Internet is just the transmission of information (data), an upgraded version of telecom. The idea is quite old. There are thousands of references for telecommunication, telepathy, teleportation, etc for ages. The first public infrastructure in that direction started with the telegraph which got replaced by electric telephone in the late 19th century. In the beginning, there was one telephone exchange that used to connect two parties on a call within a city then it progressed to multiple tele-exchanges connecting people across the cities and then continents. Initially, humans bridged these calls, then it got automated and then the hub & spoke model replaced by point-to-point communication. So, something which started as voice communication for humans completely shifted to today‚Äòs world of data communicating devices. Almost all the gadgets at the moment are transferring information way more to other devices than humans are transferring information to other humans. So, Bitcoin which was founded to enable trustless payments and other blockchain technologies that started with the aim to eliminate trusting 3rd parties is just setting the base to build protocols for establishing trust among the transacting devices. To understand the need for inter-device transactions, first, understand what trust is. Trust is a heuristic decision rule, allowing the human to deal with complexities that would require unrealistic effort in rational reasoning. In simple words, we trust because we don‚Äôt want to spend time, money and effort in understanding the complexities of something that we don‚Äôt know about (but want to get the job done). The Bitcoin revolution started with the developers‚Äô community. Developers understand the complexity of software. So instead of relying on a closed entity, working for its benefits, developers started relying on a community-driven, open and transparent payment system. But most of them still keep their crypto-assets in hardware wallets. So, entities are trusted for providing security, robustness and data privacy in the manufacturing of such wallets. If the intrinsic hardware complexities are well understood by the masses and the users start manufacturing these wallets at home, let‚Äôs say with 3D printers, they will no longer have to trust on such entities‚Äô claims. The idea of trust will shift. Now, to build a gadget, one will have to trust the silicon chip provider for providing robust quality chips. At the moment, it might look what could go wrong with the chip itself but we don‚Äôt know how fast quantum computing would progress, and invents atom level malware. So what I am trying to say is, the idea of trust is ever-changing for humans. However, the intrinsic notion of trust is non-existent in devices and, adhering to the pre-defined protocol rules is the way to establish trust for inter-device communication. At the moment, end-user devices communicate to trusted servers on certain protocols, similar to hub & spoke model of communication. These protocols offer secure and reliable communication but they lack capabilities to support inter-device transactions. The number of bits being generated by humans & devices is increasing exponentially day-by-day and the data has become the fuel of the 21st century. We have cheaper computation power and enormous data, We aren‚Äôt far away from the time when sophisticated, intelligent decision-making tools will start finding their way to everyone‚Äôs home. So coming back to where we started ‚Äî What is it which will bring disruption in the coming decade or two? You might have guessed it by now. The winners will be those who will make computers/devices learn skills, faster than ever. Designing an AI system is not much an achievement today but making system learn, is. A human-child learns things at some pace and to pass-on, the same learning to another requires similar if not the same, efforts & time. But a computer can pass its learning to its peers, in a split of a second. And the blockchain will provide the ideal platform to perform this. Think of it for a moment, that your computer or your device has some skills which it has learned over a period, on some proprietary dataset. In exchange for crypto-currency, your computer would pass this learning to some other computer or device without sharing the raw data. The blockchain will bring the transactional capability in the inter-device communication, for the devices to learn from each other. There will be open & transparent networks to authorize & validate such inter-device transactions to take place, which would need no manual intervention and no pre-established trust. To achieve this, the transactional nature in communication will enforce server-client networking to the peer-to-peer topology. It will be governed by consensus algorithms rather be governed by some 3rd party entity trust. The whole digital-learning economy will be formed around the transactions among the computer, gadgets, IoT devices & machines. The blockchain in the future is all about establishing the trust where it‚Äôs missing, in a trustless way. It appears to be an excerpt from a Sci-fi movie where machines are exchanging and learning skills automatically from one another and it might be little sooner to happen in the next decade but trust me :), two-decades is not a short time. -- -- Technology, Psychology & Spirituality and in no particular order. Knowledge democrat. Cofounder ‚Äî Maasika.in, Researching innovations, IIT Kharagpur ‚Äô09 Help Status About Careers Press Blog Privacy Terms Text to speech Teams

Title: No Title
Subtitle: Written by P.W. Staples
Author: P.W. Staples
Article: Sign up Sign in Sign up Sign in Casey Botticello P.W. Staples Follow -- 1 Listen Share Hi Casey, I‚Äôm hoping you can provide more information around some inconsistencies in your claims regarding stock photo payment. In this article, you claim that you were able to make over $60,000 in income from several hundred photos uploaded over 1 or 2 days. In a separate post located here: https://medium.com/p/f8406abd410d/responses/show You displayed the same screenshot and claimed to make over $60,000 in income from several thousand photos uploaded over 4‚Äì5 months. Also, per the data in your screenshot, it looks like you made an average of $3.82 per download, which seems quite high based on the payout numbers. Can you elaborate more on the payment structure? I found the rest of your article to be quite informative, but I don‚Äôt want to waste time pursuing something based on this information if it‚Äôs either misstated or outdated. Can you please clarify? Best, PW -- -- 1 An active agent of choice confronting a landscape of infinite potential and wasting most of it. Help Status About Careers Press Blog Privacy Terms Text to speech Teams

Title: Queer in Tech ‚Äî A safe space to hack!
Subtitle: Written by MJ
Author: MJ
Article: Sign up Sign in Sign up Sign in MJ Follow -- Listen Share Safe. Humbled. Proud. Those are a couple of sentiments shared by those that attended an LGBTQIA+ Hackathon last month. Pride is often marked by corporate rainbow-washing and endurance partying, but this event felt different. Using Tech for Good was the main purpose¬†for¬†us: build stuff to help the LGBTQIA+ community. In Tech, we have our own little super power‚Ää‚Äî‚Ääwith just a couple of hours of innovation, near shippable products can be built. Products that can sometimes change lives. On this day, the room was judgement free and full of superheroes. There were a complete mix of frontend, backend and UI developers, alongside Project Managers, Scrum Masters and graduates. After getting to know each other and hearing from the incredible grassroot queer charities, we put our powers to the test. Check out what we started! Personally, aside from seeing the community and charities benefit from all the goodness, the highlight of the event for me was feeling completely safe. Safe to create away from judgement, stereotypes or questions‚Ä¶it is so clear that we need more days like the #TechItForward with Pride Hackathon. Here‚Äôs to the next one! ‚ÄúRegardless of the early morning travel disruptions which reduced the number of people able to come, the hackathon was a blast. A particular highlight was the panel session in the morning which could have probably gone for the whole day. It was very endearing, humbling, and revelatory to hear the struggles all of these successful people have gone through to get to where there are. The conversation felt very honest which is not something that happens often with events like that. In general, the best thing about the hackathon was probably the atmosphere ‚Äî it was very refreshing to be in a room of people who felt comfortable being who they are and are there to just help some charities using technology, not to win a competition. In that regard, the event was unique. Not only were the participants comfortable, but the charities were also amazed and humbled to see so many people caring about their problems and doing their best to solve them. The work that these charities do is really admirable and I believe everyone felt very positive to contribute even a little bit to solve some their problems and make their lives a bit easier (especially Sean from AKT)‚Äù ‚ÄúIt‚Äôs my second Hackathon and I really enjoyed being part of it as it‚Äôs interesting, rewarding and educational. To begin with, we had a panel discussion, each personal story of the panelists was inspiring. My favourites were Meri Williams and Stephen Foreshew-Cain. My loosely formed team on the day supported charity http://lgbtiqoutside.org/, we helped fixing some frontend issues on the website. At the end, the charities were happy with the work that had been delivered within such a short timeframe ‚Äî they don‚Äôt usually have an army of professional IT experts. Their charities gained visibility throughout the event and some of the developers built a lasting relationship with them continued support. Although I wasn‚Äôt the main contributor as being a backend Java developer, there were a few lessons learned from my own experience and hopefully I can be better for the next one!‚Äù ‚ÄúI feel incredibly proud to have been part of the Hackathon here at Expedia with the Women Driven Development, which brought those from LGBTQI+ communities and allies together to hack solutions to their problems! It was a brilliant day from start to finish. The day started with an inspirational and thought-provoking panel of speakers: Stephen Foreshew-Cain (COO at Thoughtworks), Allie Fleder (Founder at Sherpa), Meri Williams (CTO at Monzo) and Chloe Davies (Head of Partnerships at myGwork). Our guests then spent the day (fueled with barista coffee and plenty of delicious food!) hacking to solve solutions to real life problems faced by charities ‚Äî all of which was captured by a professional photographer! The contagious positivity and excitement at the hackathon is articulated perfectly in the pictures from the day.‚Äù Thanks to Expedia Group and Women Driven Development for organising and hosting! Check out and support the incredible charities below: Albert Kennedy Trust ‚Äî Safe homes for LGBT+ young peopleThe Outside Project ‚Äî LGBT+ Homeless, Crisis and Community Shelter LBTQ Women ‚Äî Promoting and leveraging queer women globally -- -- Tech Manager, blue sky thinker and smothering mother to two beautiful cats! @MindyMachina Help Status About Careers Press Blog Privacy Terms Text to speech Teams

Title: Cashew Joins the Barclays Accelerator, Powered by Techstars
Subtitle: Written by Cashew Fintech
Author: Cashew Fintech
Article: Sign up Sign in Sign up Sign in Cashew Fintech Follow -- Listen Share Cashew has recently become the first Belarusian start-up ever to enter the Barclays Accelerator, powered by Techstars in Tel Aviv. For those of you who don‚Äôt know who we are, Cashew is a B2B2C blockchain based SaaS platform that allows bank customers to purchase goods and services both offline and online. These cashless payments occur with a user‚Äôs mobile phone through the implementation of the service in the existing MobileBank applications. This allows banks connected to the Cashew service to quickly start using innovative technologies and provide their customers with new convenient financial services attached to their personalized checking account. With the help of QR code, facial recognition technology, and blockchain technology users can feel safe transferring funds to any merchant, bypassing two intermediaries: international payment systems and payment processors. This reduces the costs of merchants that to pay commissions to payment systems, thus increasing business efficiency. And thanks to blockchain technology, both businesses and users can feel safe and secure, creating strong trust in the platform. We are actively negotiating with large banks to implement Cashew service MobileBank Apps in Belarus. In fact, an agreement with one large Belarusian bank will be signed in the near future. We are also open to partnerships with all Belarusian banks that want to use Cashew. But most recently we have joined the Barclays Accelerator, powered by Techstars for the next 13 weeks in order to improve our strategy, help bring our product to market, and to attract investors. Together with top-managers of Barclays, Techstars, founders and leaders of large technology companies, and 9 other start-ups, we will take part in mentoring sessions and trainings to prepare for the accelerator‚Äôs ‚ÄúDemo Day‚Äù. ‚ÄúDemo Day‚Äù is the final stage of the program where Cashew will get up and present at an event which 200 investors are expected to attend. We are proud to be working in an accelerator with both an international bank like Barclays and Techstars which is one of the top accelerator programs in the world. This will surely be one experience not to miss. https://cashew.me/ -- -- Cashew it‚Äôs not just new payment solution. It‚Äôs the next generation of digital payments! Title: Start with strong principles
Subtitle: Create shared context for hiring and growing
Author: Craig Atallah Frost
Article: Sign up Sign in Sign up Sign in Craig Atallah Frost Follow Workshop -- Listen Share Somewhat recently, I started managing a newly formed team tasked with creating and maintaining visual communication at Pusher. We‚Äôre a ragtag team of great people with skills in various disciplines, including Design, Engineering, Product, Illustration, Copywriting, and Project Management. Many functions and teams don‚Äôt create a set of shared principles until they‚Äôre larger or more mature. Whilst this is perfectly fine, we wanted to lead with principles; to establish early on which behaviours we considered vital to our success as a team, and to our potential impact on our company and customers. Principles are important not just for the people you have on your team, but for helping to figure out who you want to join next. It‚Äôs for this reason that we‚Äôre sharing them publicly; if these are some of the principles you live by, we‚Äôd love to talk to you about joining us‚Äîwe‚Äôre hiring for design and engineering. These principles inform the work we create. When our actions come into conflict with them, we should question the work or admit that they‚Äôre wrong. We exist to solve business and customer problems. Question anything that seems in conflict with serving Pusher or our customers, and where it‚Äôs valuable, employ first principles thinking to get at the root of the problem we‚Äôre looking to solve. Ask how things will change if we‚Äôre successful. Behaviours Fast growing businesses feel like different places every 6 months. We operate in a climate of ambiguity and need to take initiative in order to succeed. Inertia is the enemy of progress; we should always pick up the ball and keep running. Nothing is someone else‚Äôs problem. Behaviours What you ship is what matters. Our work isn‚Äôt the design deliverable, the illustration asset, or the code we write ‚Äî we execute to ship things of value to Pusher and our customers. We‚Äôre here to improve things, and should own the work we ship to make sure it has a positive impact. Behaviours -- -- News, opinions, and musings from the Workshop, the in-house creative agency at Pusher. Design Manager, London UK Help Status About Careers Press Blog Privacy Terms Text to speech Teams

Title: My Future Car ‚Äî 2025
Subtitle: Written by Hae Deshaies
Author: Hae Deshaies
Article: Sign up Sign in Sign up Sign in Hae Deshaies Follow -- Listen Share The automobile is, now in a stage of reinvention. It perfectly suits the phrase ‚ÄòReinventing the wheel‚Äô which can be modified and put as ‚ÄòReinventing the tire‚Äô. Futuristic cars are envisioned to float on water, fly in the air and to extrapolate more, hover in space. Back in time, even though the advent of a brand new car created eye-catching headlines, some of the common facts such as the irreducible requirements of engine, transmission, suspension, and fuel tank, and all the mechanical linkages involved (pedal to throttle, driveshaft to wheels), dictated continued defining the look and overall functioning of a car respectively. Finally, car manufacturers realized the two conspicuous spectrums of technologies that drew a line between them and the traditional car design: driving-by-wire, and power from fuel cells. Automakers have already started to make early inroads in them and a revolutionized design will, shortly be in the public spotlight With automakers making a paradigm shift to power electronics, you will see the entire mechanical mechanism being at the helm of an intricate power circuitry. The transmission, the drive shaft and the interior encroachments will be a forgotten past. Perhaps most important, the internal combustion engine is likely to be superseded by a compact fuel cell which will transmit signals to the tires. You will find no catalytic converter anymore because these fuel cells will only emit vapor and water. Car designs in 2025 are envisioned to have its interiors without an engine compartment, fixed instrument panel, floor pedals, or even a standard steering wheel. You may see a car that will have a flat floor to work with, making it possible and tangible to create interiors that double as living and working spaces. With the present mindset, these innovations may seem to be a pie in the sky but in hindsight, they are going be the center piece for car maintenance. You may have a model that may be lighter than the combined weight of all its tires. These lighter models will obviously be made robust and durable. Sceptics have voiced their palpable concern that the fact that the concept of light models, materializing into total success, may be a remotest possibility because if they were to be run by fuel cells, the combined size of these fuel cells in the contraption will make it bulkier. Scientists, however, are feeling bullish to accomplish this unprecedented and unimaginable feat with the some extra flavour of technological craftsmanship. These light model cars are likely to alter the entire landscape of the automobile industry. Apocryphal designs are constantly being reworked to make them fully customized. Reinventing the automobile has indeed gathered unimpeded steam. This is also going to be true and decisively applicable to the tires. For e.g. in 2025, your car may have all season tires that will have varied sensors embedded inside their grooves. You may see an end to the seemingly endless problem of tire check-ups and replacements by retrieving every minuscule data from these embedded, delicate, and unnoticeable yet high-tech and profusely tech-savvy sensors. This approach will definitely prove intriguing as it will give the drivers a hassle free respite in steering the wheel manually all the time, especially during long, tardy drives. This high-definition technology will be made a mandate to all the cars because at the end, it will be highly eco-friendly. The implicated fixes and repairs can soon be a cakewalk and inexpensive. Now as a driver, you may not find it difficult to procure spare parts. You are going to have an easy access to garages and office depot. Some of the astounding, fanciful adjustments such as moving the passenger seat in any direction or turning a car into a mobile office, even a mobile bedroom etc‚Ä¶ are some of the unthinkable notions which are now very much within the realms of possibility. The elite group of automakers are encouraging the firms not only to play with interior configurations, but to fundamentally alter the architecture of the automobile, creating vehicles that are not only innovative but functional, shrugging off most of the manoeuvres done manually. The crux of the matter is to have the interiors potentially versatile so that they can accommodate major adjustments to make it gregarious. With an impeccable, immaculate in-built interior, the driving will be as smooth as a feather. As of date, a brand new concept of driving by wire technology is being worked upon under the aegis of the prominent automakers. What would this mean to a driver? He/she would enjoy the luxury of enabling the steering wheel to become an aircraft-type control yoke or a joystick. As silly as it may sound, but your future car may not have a steering attached to a conventional steering column and could, potentially, be docked in several places about the car. You can pull it down from the ceiling when required or hide it as a measure of security when your car is parked. When traveling alone, the driver may no longer be in a driver‚Äôs seat but can sit in the centre of the vehicle, as an increased safety measure in case of a collision; side- or rear-view cameras would provide a full range of vision. You may find a crash-absorbing, well-oiled structure replacing an engine compartment for making the cars safer during a collision course or freak accidents which will result in saving the passengers from a catastrophic fatality. After reading this, I am confident that we are all tempted to have a car that will strike a perfect balance between nonchalant driving and safety. -- -- I am an RF Engineer by profession, I do design and development on 5G network at Nokia, prior I have done various jobs in marketing, maintenance and education. Title: Trade VITE Tokens on Bittrex + Year In Review :]
Subtitle: New Exchange Listing | 15 January 2019
Author: LKK153
Article: Sign up Sign in Sign up Sign in LKK153 Follow Vite -- Listen Share Bittrex International is a leading cryptocurrency exchange based in the United States. As of January 15th at 9:30 AM PST, VITE is confirmed for listing on this trading platform. Bittrex is renowned for its daily trading volume, reputation for security and focus on regulatory compliance. In mid-2018, Vite Labs closed funding through institutional capital without conducting a public crowd sale (ICO). Within six months, we built a team of 40 people in Beijing, Sunnyvale and San Francisco. We never outsourced talent and conducted no cosmetic marketing; our team insisted on doing the right thing and, this attitude of honesty and humility is paying off. 2018 was marked by speculative projects and investments, culminating in the recent bear market which we know as Crypto Winter. Bear markets are good for solid companies with sound technologies; we treat market volatility, including downturns in the overall blockchain industry, as positive moments in which mediocrity and hype are decimated. We have a decentralized ecosystem of blockchain solutions: a web wallet, iOS and Android wallets, decentralized exchange (DEX), online store powered by VITE, payment infrastructure without time lags nor fees, point of sale (POS) solution for merchants, smart contracts, one-click token issuance and a platform for decentralized applications (dApp). Our Test Net officially launched in November of 2018 and we expect our Main Net significantly ahead of schedule. Overall, our product team expedited the technical roadmap by an entire year. As a Directed Acyclic Graph (DAG) and Delegated Proof of Stake (DPOS) based blockchain, we had to address known security issues of DAG. Consequently, we invented the Snapshot Chain which is an overall ledger of all chains at the Local Consensus level (smart contracts and individual accounts) that maintains Global Consensus regardless of vulnerabilities within each smart contract and account. We focus on public sector and academic demographics because they control policy and education. It is commonly known that blockchain is applicable to enterprise use cases, particularly payment solutions, but we believe in serving a larger cause for mass adoption. By educating and assisting governments, specifically for blockchain adoption and investment, we hope to accelerate mass adoption on a socially meaningful level. By training and resourcing academics, particularly students and professors, we hope to create newly minted developers and curricula for blockchain mass adoption. Our partnership with the City of Syracuse Innovation Office, through Startup-In-Residence, is a manifestation of our belief in proving social use cases. We are exploring the utility of blockchain in creating a peer to peer micro loan platform to connect low income renters with people willing to provide short term loans without interest, for security deposits and other emergency housing funds. We are among 40 companies selected from 700 to work with 22 governments. Official: https://www.vite.org/ Vite ForumÔºöhttps://forum.vite.net Telegram: TwitterÔºöhttps://twitter.com/vitelabs DiscordÔºöhttps://discordapp.com/invite/CsVY76q RedditÔºöhttps://www.reddit.com/r/vitelabs/ -- -- Vite is a lightning-fast blockchain where transactions incur zero fees. It is the world‚Äôs first DAG-based smart contract platform. Vite‚Äôs flagship DApp is ViteX, a truly trustless DEX deployed on the Vite chain.
