Title: EdTech and the Mania over AI and 5G
Subtitle: Written by Mathew Black
Author: Mathew Black
Article: Sign up Sign in Sign up Sign in Mathew Black Follow -- Listen Share Has ISTE lost its way or is it being faithful to its true mission? ‚ÄúOnly a fool would blithely welcome any technology without having given serious thought not only to what the technology will do but what it will undo‚Ä¶‚Äù ‚Äî Neil Postman, 1997 As an educator, the International Society for Technology in Education (ISTE) has always troubled me. In fact, I‚Äôve always thought that ISTE does the whole notion of EdTech a disservice. Its recommended standards, like all standards I suppose, seem oblivious to the nuances and individuality inherent in the teaching ‚Äî learning process by suggesting a mechanical implementation that leaves little room for a student‚Äôs process of personal discovery or application of critical thinking. They also come off as shallow, as if following trends rather than truly being at the vanguard of something meaningful. With 68% of its revenue coming from its annual expo, it‚Äôs hard to see ISTE as anything but a sales venue with its widely cited standards and education initiatives as advertisements. This would explain, for instance, why its CEO, Richard Culatta, sounds like a salesperson. More than a specific brand or product though, Mr. Culatta sells the idea of technology as a social tool for capitalism. This past August, during his keynote for ISTE‚Äôs annual conference and expo, Mr. Culatta was in fine form as the head of sales. Glossing over how the datafication of our lives impacts every aspect of our individuality and society, he resorted to clich√®s (‚ÄúWe are standing on the edge of a major transformation‚Ä¶‚Äù), cheap scare tactics (‚Äú‚Ä¶our students won‚Äôt have the skills they need‚Ä¶) and shaming (‚ÄúWe asked teachers to explain AI, 80% of them couldn‚Äôt.) to sell the crowd on the virtues and inevitableness of 5G networks and Artificial Intelligence (AI). Hearing and watching his ebullience over these technologies reminded me of Neil Postman‚Äôs lecture to the College of DuPage titled The Surrender of Culture to Technology, given in 1997. Back then, there was considerable excitement and energy surrounding the drive to ‚Äúwire‚Äù schools for the Internet and make sure that computers were available in every classroom. Considerable resources were spent and Mr. Postman addresses them with brilliant irony in his lecture. In the years since 1997, the benefits to learning by embedding digital technologies in the classroom remains debatable at best and in fact most independent evidence suggests that the presence of Information and Communication Technologies (ICTs) in the classroom has a negative impact on student learning. Richard Culatta knows this but is perhaps swayed by his role in other companies that are heavily invested in Edtech initiatives to employ even the bare minimum critical thinking skills that should be on display at any event purportedly about education. Had Neil Postman heard him raving about the virtues of 5G networks and Artificial Intelligence, he would have surely encouraged Mr. Culatta to use the following questions to critically assess these new technologies. What is the problem for which these technologies are the solution and whose problem is it (that these technologies solve)? With 5G networks, Mr. Culatta says, we can ‚Äúdownload the entire eighth season of Game of Thrones in 30 seconds.‚Äù By that metric, 5G networks are apparently very fast. So there must be a problem in American schools regarding Internet speeds that is directly impacting student learning, right? The Brookings Institute recently asked itself a very similar question (albeit for entirely different reasons). ‚ÄúAre slow Internet speeds holding back American Schools?‚Äù According to its findings, only ‚Äú15% of school districts fall below the 250 KBPS threshold recommended by SEDTA needed for online learning.‚Äù In other words, a small percentage of schools in America lack enough connectivity to have all their students engage with online learning platforms simultaneously. Hardly a crisis. But the best part of the Institute‚Äôs report comes buried at the very end in an almost comical contradiction. ‚ÄúGiven the evidence that internet connections in the home and school are weakly related to student outcomes, it‚Äôs unlikely that slow internet speeds are preventing improvements in the classroom. However, there is a baseline level of internet access that schools need to function for administrative needs [‚Ä¶] and the FCC should continue this successful policy [of meeting broadband targets] rather than changing course and risking recent gains in school Internet speeds.‚Äù Students don‚Äôt need 5G netoworks and ISTE‚Äôs CEO knows this. ‚ÄúThe interesting thing about 5G networks that most people don‚Äôt realize,‚Äô‚Äô he shares, ‚Äúis that they‚Äôre not really being built for us, they‚Äôre being built for them (machines).‚Äù What he is referring to is the Internet of Things (IoT), the network that allows machines to talk to machines. ‚ÄúGartner says‚Äù, Mr. Culatta goes on, ‚Äúthat by 2020 there will be more than 20 billion smart devices on the planet [‚Ä¶] about three times the number of people in the entire world.‚Äù So 5G networks solve a connectivity problem‚Ä¶ for machines. ‚ÄúBut superfast connectivity is only part of the equation,‚Äô‚Äô Mr Cualtta explains. ‚ÄúWith these new applications comes an enormous amount of decisions that will need to be made way more than we have the capacity to make as humans [‚Ä¶] That brings me to the second technology that will change our world in the next couple of years and that‚Äôs Artificial Intelligence.‚Äù So AI solves the problem of data processing in a world of machines talking to machines, and 5G networks solve the problem of how those machines can share vast amounts of data between each other. In Richard Culatta‚Äôs own words, then, 5G networks and Artificial Intelligence don‚Äôt solve any problem that students, teachers or schools have, at least not in any way related to teaching and learning. Why then the 15 minute pitch to a crowd full of educators? He references a conversation with General Motors in which they express their concern over not having the labor force they will need to expand production in a future in which there are more machines talking to machines than people talking to people. To address this future short fall in workers with General Motors‚Äô required skill set, GM and ISTE partnered to help prepare teachers to help prepare students to be the kind of employees companies like GM will need. Very clearly and very tellingly he did not use his keynote in any way to address topics related to making learning meaningful to students but instead used it to make a pitch that was useful to corporations and in so doing revealed that for ISTE, technology in education, or maybe even education itself, isn‚Äôt about learning, it‚Äôs about training, and those are two very different things. Let us rephrase Neil Postman‚Äôs original questions, adapting them to the specific technologies promoted by Mr. Culatta. What is the problem for which 5G networks and AI are the solution? 5G networks allow machines to talk to machines and AI allows machines to process that communication. Whose problem is it that these technologies solve? It is a problem for corporations who wish to expand their markets by embedding 5G networks and AI in their products. And this leads us to Mr. Postman‚Äôs third question. What new problems might be created because we have solved the problem? We could refer to already existing issues of bias in algorithms, or to the kinds of exploitation of labor that can result from having algorithms perform managerial functions but perhaps the issue that should concern us most is Luciano Floridi‚Äôs concept of enveloping. In essence, enveloping is the process through which a particular environment is adapted for the sake of a technology‚Äôs performance. ‚ÄúWe envelop environments around simple robots to fit and exploit their limited capacities and still deliver the desired output. A dishwasher accomplishes its task because its environment ‚Äî an openable, waterproof box ‚Äî is structured (‚Äúenveloped‚Äù) around its simple capacities. Enveloping used to be either a stand-alone phenomenon [‚Ä¶] or implemented within the walls of industrial buildings, carefully tailored around their artificial inhabitants. Nowadays, enveloping the environment into an AI-friendly infosphere has started to pervade all aspects of reality and is happening daily everywhere, in the house, in the office, and in the street.‚Äù If we solve the problem of how machines can communicate with each other in increasingly complex ways, what new problems might be created because we have solved that problem? To paraphrase Luciano Floridi, these technologies risk constraining our physical and conceptual spaces, forcing us to adapt our bodies and our minds to the technologies because that is the best, or sometimes the only, way for these technologies to work. We therefore risk limiting humanity‚Äôs natural capacities for the sake of generating profits for technology companies. Well, at least it‚Äôs nothing we should worry about, which would explain why Richard Culatta didn‚Äôt feel the need to model any sort of critical thinking to a room full of educators. Fortunately for him and the Edtech industry at large, many educators and education policy makers are apparently not critical thinkers themselves. No wonder ISTE removed that strand from their standards in 2016. ‚ÄúThroughout the country we‚Äôre preparing to spend billions of dollars to wire schools in order to accommodate a computer technology and for reasons that are by no means clear. There certainly does not exist any compelling evidence that personal computers, or any other manifestation of computer technology, can do for children what good, well paid, unburdened teachers can do. Where then is the outcry from teachers? They are losers in this deal [‚Ä¶] American students already have an oversupply of sources of information. There are in America 17,000 newspapers, 12,000 periodicals [‚Ä¶] 500 million TV sets, well over 600 million radios (not including those in automobiles), there are 10,000 libraries and 40,000 new book titles published every year. Do American students now require an additional hundred million dollar investment to ensure that they become well informed citizens? [M]any teachers are thrilled by the thought of a hundred million dollar investment in computer terminals [and not in them]. Bill Gates loves this form of stupidity.‚Äù ‚Äî Neil Postman, 1997 -- -- Musician, teacher, artist and human. Help Status About Careers Press Blog Privacy Terms Text to speech Teams

Title: IBM‚Äôs ‚Äòe-tongue‚Äô can quickly identify liquids
Subtitle: Written by Phil Siarri
Author: Phil Siarri
Article: Sign up Sign in Sign up Sign in Member-only story Phil Siarri Follow -- 3 Share IBM has announced Hypertaste, an ‚Äúe-tongue‚Äù that can quickly identify the flavors in liquids. The tech giant describes its solution as an ‚ÄúAI-powered electronic tongue‚Äù which can be used to fingerprint liquids that are not so suitable for ingestion, but may need to be identified more rapidly than is possible using traditional labs (think remote water quality checks and counterfeit alcohol testing). Even though it is possible to analyze liquids by shipping them to a lab, such process can be long and expensive. IBM Hypertaste could become an alternative to this approach, enabling people to see the composition of a liquid in just one minute via a smartphone. The e-tongue uses a concept called combinatorial sensing, which involves individual sensors simultaneously responding to various chemicals in a liquid. The result is a ‚Äúfingerprint‚Äù of the liquid. The device was conceived with off-the-shelf electronics and works with a mobile app to transfer data to the cloud. Once the data is on the server, a machine learning‚Ä¶ -- -- 3 Founder of Nuadox | Tech & Innovation Commentator | Digital Strategist | MTL | More about me> linktr.ee/philsiarri Help Status About Careers Press Blog Privacy Terms Text to speech Teams

Title: Attractive Planchain Features for the Development of IP Monetization
Subtitle: Written by Avery Via
Author: Avery Via
Article: Sign up Sign in Sign up Sign in Avery Via Follow -- Listen Share There are thousands of studies from world scientists and various works of art from artists who have gained much recognition in the eyes of the world. However, this recognition is not very useful for its creators if it is not recognized legally that can prove ownership rights. This is so that the work is not easy to be recognized and commercialized by irresponsible parties. Copyrighted works have another name in their scientific language, intellectual property. Where this wealth does not only require physical protection, but also protection in terms of legality. Therefore Planchain is here to provide legality and monetization services by integrating Blockchain technology. Currently the work is not only in the form of goods or hardware, but now there are also works in the form of software, such as applications, computerized programs, trademarks, etc. Where all kinds of forms of intellectual property also require protection, both copyright and patent rights. This is certainly done as a form of appreciation for the hard work of its creator and also the work he has created. Currently there are a number of inventors or creators who have qualified knowledge to create a work. But not a few of those who do not understand how the concept of intellectual property protection itself. Therefore, with all its simplicity, Planchain invites us to understand how the system and procedures to protect intellectual property. The main step that must be done is to register an IP (Intelectual Property) on the official website of Planchain. Keep in mind that patents or copyrights do not matter who created them. But who first registered it. Therefore if you have a work that has a use value and high selling value, be careful when making publications and register immediately to get a certificate of ownership as Planchain will later provide. Speaking of proof of ownership, in fact you yourself have used it very often for the needs of daily economic activities. This certificate of ownership is, of course, the payment instrument or currency that you have been empowering all this time. If you pay attention to a banknote, there will be a number of stamps and signatures from certain financial authorities. These symbols do not directly explain that you are the owner. However, the instrument of payment is owned by a sovereign country and has the right to use it for the country‚Äôs economic needs. This also shows the financial identity of the country. The above phenomenon is the same as the IP you have. Where he also needed a certificate of ownership that proved effective in explaining his identity to the public. Seeing this, of course Planchain also has a proof of ownership printing tool with Vechainthor Blockchain technology and is accompanied by the addition of NFT for monetization services. As an IP protection service platform, of course Planchain also doesn‚Äôt work alone. This is because he has a professional business network which can certainly be a partner for IP owners or in being an intermediary if the IP owner wants to officially register his work at a government office. As with other cryptocurrency platforms, Planchain has PLAN tokens that can be used to access various services. At this time you can use the token if you register this certified IP on the Thorm. Where Thorm is like social media that promotes IP to be seen by investors who want to develop it. Therefore, as a creator you are also required to display the best portfolio that can attract attention from investors. Where later all transactions will be handled by the Vechaintor Blockchain and PLAN utility tokens. Currently Planchain not only provides proof of ownership and monetization of IP services. However, if you are interested in auctioning the IP work. So Planchain will also provide all kinds of facilities and infrastructures needed for this auction process. There are many reasons why an author decides to auction off his work, for example the auction results from the copyrighted work are used for social activities. One thing you need to know is that the auction process does not only end in the payment transaction. This is because the auction shows that ownership of the IP has changed hands and their royalties. Therefore we can say that the IP auction on Planchain has a continuous investment value. #PLAN_TGE_CONTENT Planchain information Website: https://planchain.io/ One pager: https://planchain.io/wp-content/uploads/2019/08/onepager-28-08-2019.pdf Telegram: https://t.me/Planchain MY BTT URL: https://bitcointalk.org/index.php?action=profile;u=2579599;sa=summary -- -- Moving in the shadow of time Help Status About Careers Press Blog Privacy Terms Text to speech Teams

Title: JARVIS: Not a Marvel reference anymore!
Subtitle: Written by Gautam Rege
Author: Gautam Rege
Article: Sign up Sign in Sign up Sign in Gautam Rege Follow -- Listen Share A few years ago, if someone saw you talking to your phone or computer, it would probably be a little bit awkward. Now, not so much. In fact, not at all. Siri, Alexa, Cortana and the Google assistant have become household names today. We live in a digitally evolving world, and this evolution is primarily fuelled by disruptions in technology. Conversational commerce backed by artificial intelligence and machine learning mechanisms have become so common today, that it‚Äôs hard to imagine our day to day lives without them. The numbers speak for themselves. A Juniper research states that the voice assistant market is all set to cross $8 billion by 2023. Along with smartphones, the smart TV category has also added to this growth, as more and more consumers want entertainment at their fingertips, whenever and wherever they go. And if you thought the millennials were the ones driving this trend, you‚Äôd be wrong. The maximum adoption is seen in the 55‚Äì70 age group, as they find it more convenient to converse, rather than use text commands. We Indians especially love talking. Our country has a 72% adoption rate when it comes to voice assistants! Why use them in the first place? The usage of voice assistants varies by context, but most commonly, they are used to perform general searches. Due credit to be given to the backend machine learning systems for this, that can understand different styles of speaking, vernaculars and tonalities. It‚Äôs easier to ask ‚ÄòWhat‚Äôs the weather like today‚Äô than search for your city and state from among a list of thousands. Playlists can be made, alarms can be set and recipes can be looked up instantly, in the blink of an eye. A little over fifty years ago, we would struggle to fit supercomputers into one room, and now we don‚Äôt even need to touch the technology anymore! I find that incredible, and the evolution has almost been invisible. Voice assistants are much better at anticipating consumer needs than text based systems, and anticipating their responses as well. I foresee them having a potential of way beyond addressing immediate, functional needs. Brands who can factor in the emotional aspect will be the ones who optimize the usage of these assistants, and trust me, it‚Äôll help them grow by leaps and bounds! How can they make people‚Äôs lives even more simpler? The two industries that are the most stressful to work for, are hands down healthcare and e-commerce. Both require great anticipation skills, and deal directly with sensitive consumer data. When it comes to healthcare, voice assistants can provide patients with round-the-clock care on demand and a cheaper alternative to in-office visits. Personalised healthcare is catching up fast, and is supposed to be the next big thing by 2030. Data entry and segregation which is an otherwise manual, cumbersome process can also be automated with the help of these assistants. Hospitals can then optimize admin spends, and allocate more budgets for R&D. The data they collect also has a potential to treat diseases from previous diagnoses and patterns, which means more staff time with patients, leading to better care. When we think of e-commerce, online shopping has existed for almost two decades now. Old news. What‚Äôs new is the possibility of intuitive shopping experiences, where most online retailers can make deft use of voice ordering as an opportunity. Voice assistants are an excellent way to track consumer behaviour, almost in real time. Data mined with assistance from predictive analytics can also contribute to building brand recall. Right now, all this is just in the stages of infancy, so imagine what happens when this escalates! Is the risk worth it? Consumers more or less like their personal assistants, but frustrations and worries exist. All good things come at a price, and in this case, that cost is your own data. The risk of sensitive data falling into the hands of the wrong people and organisations is surely a looming threat. This is the reason that consumers in the healthcare and ecommerce domain are not making much use of voice assistants. Especially when this data includes things like medical records, bank statements and credit card information, organisations need to be very careful in the way they analyse and use this data. One breach is all it takes to wash away years of trust. And today, one consumer is enough to bring the whole business down, thanks to the power of social media. But here‚Äôs the thing. In my opinion, the smarter we are about this technology and the more we use AI and ML to refine assistant-consumer interactions, the further it will take us. Consumers are very aware of the risks entailed, but convenience overpowers everything. JARVIS is going to become a reality pretty soon. Just you wait! -Gautam Rege is the Co-Founder and Director of Josh Software -- -- Rubyist, Gopher, Entrepreneur, Author, Co-founder & Director at http://www.joshsoftware.com. Author of 'Ruby and MongoDB Web Development' and 'Learning Mongoid' Help Status About Careers Press Blog Privacy Terms Text to speech Teams

Title: NEO Global Development Invests And Partners With Liquefy To Develop A Security Token Ecosystem
Subtitle: Written by Sparsh Singhal
Author: Sparsh Singhal
Article: Sign up Sign in Sign up Sign in Sparsh Singhal Follow -- Listen Share Liquefy announced today that NEO Global Development (NGD) will invest in and partner with Liquefy, to develop an NEO based security token ecosystem and allow asset owners to issue security tokens based on NEO. NEO is a leading protocol that utilizes blockchain technology and digital identities to tokenize assets and automate the management of tokenize assets using smart contracts. The recent update to NEO 3.0 allows it to scale and build a fully-integrated tokenized economy. ‚ÄúIt is important to develop a security token standard while the industry is still in its infancy. What separates NEO apart from other public blockchain protocols is the integration of NeoID, which allows KYC, AML and accreditation status to be stored on-chain while maintaining privacy. This allows issuers to monitor and maintain records of all transactions in the secondary market to remain compliant in multiple jurisdictions,‚Äù Adrian Lai, CEO of Liquefy. ‚ÄúWe are excited to welcome NGD as an investor and a partner to develop a security token ecosystem together and bring innovation to the financial market.‚Äù The Liquefy Platform will support NEO which will allow NEO stakeholders to gain access to the security token universe. The current process of transferring private securities is fragmented, cumbersome and expensive since KYC information of investors are siloed across multiple intermediaries and compliance is a manual process. Liquefy is solving a critical pain point in the market by providing an end to end solution from issuance, managing compliance across multiple jurisdictions to investor management services. The investment and partnership with Liquefy have cemented NEO‚Äôs commitment to develop the security token industry. Earlier this year, NEO had formed the Digital Asset Alliance (DAA) to explore, develop and share insights about the security tokens sector with a consortium of industry leaders such as Republic, Globacap, DLx and Liquefy. About Liquefy Liquefy is an end-to-end technology solution that provides a seamless experience for asset owners to create security tokens. The core offerings include tokenization technology, digital register of members and corporate action management tools. Liquefy has also developed a comprehensive compliance protocol for over 50 jurisdictions. For more information, visit https://www.liquefy.com/ About Neo NEO is an open source public blockchain project driven by community. It utilizes blockchain technology and digital identities to digitize assets and automate the management of digital assets using smart contracts. Using a distributed network, it aims to create a ‚ÄúSmart Economy‚Äù. Title: Pengenalan Terhadap Ray Tracing
Subtitle: Published in HMIF ITB Tech
Author: Shandy Gunawan
Article: Sign up Sign in Sign up Sign in Shandy Gunawan Follow HMIF ITB Tech -- Share oleh: Shandy ~ Teknik Informatika ITB 13516097 Peluncuran kartu grafis dengan kode RTX oleh Nvidia beberapa waktu lalu mengenalkan istilah baru kepada publik, yakni ray tracing. Akan tetapi, istilah ini masih belum banyak dimengerti sehingga publik mengira bahwa ray tracing adalah fitur Nvidia terbaru. Ray tracing sesungguhnya adalah sebuah teknik pembangunan gambar dari model (rendering) yang mampu menampilkan efek cahaya yang sangat realistis dan sudah banyak digunakan di industri film. Pada tulisan ini, kita akan menelusuri lebih jauh mengenai ray tracing, termasuk aplikasinya dalam bidang komputer grafis. Sejak tahun 1990, pemodelan 3D konvensional menggunakan proses yang bernama rasterization. Proses ini menggunakan kumpulan segitiga dan poligon untuk membuat model objek tiga dimensi. Kemudian, model tersebut dikonversi lagi menjadi pixels dan dilanjutkan dengan berbagai post-processing sebelum menjadi gambar akhir yang akan ditampilkan ke layar. Mengutip dari web resmi Nvidia, ray tracing mampu mensimulasikan perilaku fisik cahaya. Ray tracing mampu mengkalkulasikan warna dari pixels dengan menelusuri jalur yang ditempuh cahaya seolah-olah tampilan layar yang ditonton berasal dari mata penonton sendiri. Berbagai perilaku dari cahaya seperti refleksi, refraksi, dan bayangan menentukan warna akhir dari setiap pixel di layar. Hal terpenting yang kita butuhkan untuk menciptakan sebuah gambar adalah sebuah permukaan dua dimensi. Kemudian, kita dapat meng-visualisasikan permukaan tersebut sebagai dasar sebuah piramida horizontal dengan puncak (vantage point) piramida tersebut terletak di tengah mata kita dan tingginya sejajar dengan arah pandang (line of sight) kita. Dasar piramida tersebut kemudian kita sebut sebagai image plane atau canvas. Ilustrasi berdasarkan visualisasi tersebut antara lain sebagai berikut. Image plane ini berfungsi sebagai permukaan dua dimensi yang akan kita gunakan untuk memproyeksikan berbagai tampilan tiga dimensi. Sebagai contoh, jika kita ingin menggambar sebuah kubus tiga dimensi pada sebuah image plane maka kita perlu menggambarkan garis-garis yang saling menghubungkan titik-titik sudut kubus yang terlihat oleh mata. Pada gambar berikut, titik-titik sudut tersebut diberi nama c0, c1, c2, dan c3. Setelah itu, kita menarik garis dari masing-masing sudut tersebut ke vantage point yang merupakan mata kita. Perpotongan garis-garis tersebut dengan image plane juga membentuk titik-titik sudut yang akan merepresentasikan kubus tiga dimensi tersebut pada image plane. Titik-titik sudut tersebut kemudian disebut c0‚Äô, c1‚Äô, c2, dan c3‚Äô. Persegi hasil proyeksi tersebut yang akan ditampilkan pada layar dua dimensi. Metode diatas dinamakan sebagai perspective projection yang berfungsi untuk menerjemahkan objek-objek tiga dimensi yang kita lihat sehari-hari menjadi dua dimensi. Setelah kita mampu menggambar outline dari objek tiga dimensi pada sebuah permukaan dua dimensi, kita mampu menambahkan warna pada gambar tersebut. Seperti yang kita ketahui, kecerahan dan warna adalah hasil dari interaksi cahaya dengan material objek. Cahaya terbentuk dari photon mampu diserap, direfleksikan, atau ditransmisikan oleh objek-objek yang berinteraksi dengan photon tersebut. Besar persentase photon yang diserap, direfleksikan, dan ditransmisikan oleh berbagai material objek menentukan bagaimana objek tersebut terlihat oleh mata. Sebagai contoh, cahaya putih terbentuk dari photon RGB (Red, Green, Blue). Jika sebuah objek berwarna merah maka material objek tersebut menyerap photon Green dan photon Blue tetapi merefleksikan photon Red yang akan ditangkap oleh mata dan menerjemahkannya menjadi warna merah. Perlu diingat bahwa contoh diatas hanyalah simplifikasi, photon tidak sesungguhnya bersifat RGB. Selain itu, tingkat kecerahan dari suatu objek yang berasal dari jumlah photon yang dipantulkan juga memberikan dimensi lain bagi mata untuk merepresentasikan objek tersebut, seperti shading. Melihat pentingnya cahaya bagi penampilan objek, ray tracing dapat dikatakan juga mempunyai peran penting dalam menentukan penampilan gambar ke layar monitor kita. Ray tracing dinamakan demikian karena metode tersebut mensimulasikan jalur dari sinar cahaya (light rays) berasal dari sumber cahaya menuju mata manusia. Tujuan yang ingin diraih dari ray tracing yakni menentukan warna dari light rays tersebut, terutama jika light rays mengalami banyak pantulan dari berbagai objek. Penjelasan diatas akan jauh lebih mudah dipahami melalui gambar berikut. Seperti yang telah kita pelajari di sub-bab sebelumnya, kita melihat objek tiga dimensi dalam dua dimensi melalui image plane, dan warna objek diperoleh dari warna yang direfleksikan oleh material objek tersebut. Pada gambar diatas, terdapat suatu sumber cahaya, misal sebuah bohlam lampu, yang memancarkan cahaya ke segala arah. Jika kita melakukan tracing pada cahaya tersebut dari bohlam lampu maka kita akan dihadapi dengan beberapa pertanyaan: Pada ilustrasi diatas, garis panah utuh adalah sinar yang mempunyai jalur menuju ke mata, baik langsung maupun melalui pantulan, sedangkan garis panah terputus-putus adalah sinar-sinar yang tidak menuju ke mata. Tugas kita yakni mampu memilih sinar yang mempunyai jalur seperti garis panah utuh karena melakukan tracing pada sinar yang tidak menuju mata hanya akan menguras resources. Pertanyaan-pertanyaan di paragraf sebelumnya membuat tracing sinar-sinar yang terjamin menuju ke mata sangatlah sulit. Akan tetapi, jika kita melihat permasalahan tersebut secara terbalik (backwards), solusi dari permasalahan tersebut sangatlah mudah. Solusi tersebut yakni kita melakukan tracing sinar-sinar tersebut bukan dari bohlam, tetapi dari mata. Sebagai contoh, kita memilih sebuah titik pada image plane yang ingin kita ketahui warnanya. Warna dari titik tersebut berasal dari light ray yang menembus titik itu. Kita mampu melakukan tracing mulai dari mata, lalu menembus titik tersebut, dan seterusnya hingga mencapai sumber cahaya sehingga kita dapat mengetahui warna dari titik tersebut berdasarkan material objek-objek yang menumbuk tracing kita. Metode ini disebut sebagai backward tracing yang dapat diilustrasikan sebagai berikut. Algoritma Ray Tracing mengambil sebuah gambar yang terbuat dari pixels. Untuk setiap pixel-nya, kita menembakkan sebuah sinar utama (primary ray) menuju image plane yang berasal dari mata. Kemudian, kita melakukan tracing pada sinar utama tersebut untuk menentukan arahnya dan objek-objek yang tertumbuk oleh sinar tersebut. Pada kasus tertentu dimana sinar utama menumbuk lebih dari satu objek, kita memilih objek tertumbuk yang paling dekat ke mata dan menembakkan sebuah sinar bayangan (shadow ray) dari titik tumbukkan pada objek tersebut menuju sumber cahaya seperti gambar dibawah ini. Jika sinar bayangan tidak menumbuk objek lain saat menuju sumber cahaya maka titik tumbukkan tersebut terkena sinar langsung. Sedangkan, jika sinar bayangan menumbuk benda lain, maka titik tumbukkan tersebut dibayangin oleh objek yang ditumbuk oleh sinar bayangan. Jika kita mengulangi proses ini untuk setiap pixel, kita akan mendapatkan sebuah representasi dua dimensi dari sebuah pemandangan tiga dimensi. Berikut adalah implementasi algoritma ray tracing dalam bentuk pseudocode. Sesungguhnya materi-materi yang telah dibahas diatas hanyalah tip of the iceberg dari ray tracing yang sesungguhnya. Kita mampu mengkalkulasikan refleksi, refraksi, dan sifat-sifat cahaya lain untuk menghasilkan gambar yang semakin indah dan akurat dengan fenomena cahaya yang sesungguhnya. Oleh karena itu, penulis menganjurkan untuk membuka referensi-referensi yang digunakan oleh penulis untuk memperdalam wawasan pembaca mengenai ray tracing. Hayward, Andrew. (2018, March 21). What is ray tracing? Everything you need to know about the next big graphical leap. Retrieved from https://www.techradar.com/news/ray-tracing NVIDIA. NVIDIA RTX Ray Tracing. Retrieved from https://developer.nvidia.com/rtx/raytracing Rademacher Paul. Ray Tracing: Graphics for the Masses. Retrieved from https://www.cs.unc.edu/~rademach/xroads-RT/RTarticle.html Scratchapixel. Introduction to Ray Tracing: a Simple Method for Creating 3D Images. Retrieved from https://www.scratchapixel.com/lessons/3d-basic-rendering/introduction-to-ray-tracing/how-does-it-work -- -- HMIF ITB Tech Blog Help Status About Careers Press Blog Privacy Terms Text to speech Teams

Title: No Title
Subtitle: Written by Alan Lewis
Author: Alan Lewis
Article: Sign up Sign in Sign up Sign in Alan Lewis Follow -- Listen Share Why we created Match Me‚Ää‚Äî‚Ääthe social dating app. My Grandmother, Paula, moved into an assisted care living home in 2001. Soon after, she met a woman who became her ‚Äúpal‚Äù, her BFF, there. They began having tea and cookies in one another‚Äôs rooms in the afternoon. As Grandmothers will do, they began comparing stories about their families. ‚ÄúWait, you have a single grandson?!‚Äù Paula‚Äôs friend, Molly, said. ‚ÄúI have a single granddaughter.‚Äù ‚ÄúWell, is there something we can do about this?‚Äù the two thought. Not long after that, I got a call from my Grandmother one evening. telling me that there is a woman in her building, whom she likes very much, and that woman has a pretty granddaughter (she had seen her picture), whom I should take out for a nice dinner. Oh, and, I should call my Grandmother more often. I was working long hours, as a corporate lawyer in San Francisco, in my thirties and not dating anyone at the time, but wanted to. So, I called this girl. As it turns out, she was on a date at the time I called, but called me back and we laughed out loud that our grandmothers clearly liked one another, were clearly up to something, and maybe we should just ‚Äúhumor them.‚Äù We had a really nice dinner at a local French bistro, she gave me a really nice kiss goodnight, we had another date, and . . . about a year later, we were getting engaged. What can I say?! It just took. In 2003, we got married and now have 3 beautiful kids together. We‚Äôve since each gone our separate ways, but we have been asked, frequently, by good friends, if we could do for them what our grandmothers did for us. Naturally, we always answered that call to action with generosity and enjoyed helping friends of ours find their next great love, or, much more often and likely, just their next great date. What our Grandmothers were doing was what the Jewish tradition calls ‚ÄúShidduch‚Äù‚Ää‚Äî‚Ääcreating connection between two people who deserve to be connected. It‚Äôs considered a ‚Äúmitzvah‚Äù‚Ää‚Äî‚Ääa good deed. So many other cultures share this beautiful tradition, it‚Äôs really nearly universal, but when I became single again, I was amazed that there wasn‚Äôt an easy way to ask my social network to help in this way. I know plenty of people who would, if I simply asked them. And I know I would, if you just asked me. That‚Äôs how and why Match Me was born! Because algorithms don‚Äôt create connection between people nearly as well as people do. In the sphere of creating and sustaining human connection, we believe that Emotional Intelligence is often more helpful than Artificial Intelligence. Please check us out: https://matchme.love/ -- -- Help Status About Careers Press Blog Privacy Terms Text to speech Teams

Title: EaaS: Everything-as-a-Service
Subtitle: The Startup
Author: Ryan S.
Article: Sign up Sign in Sign up Sign in Home Newsletter About  Get smarter at building your thing. Follow to join The Startup‚Äôs +8 million monthly readers & +772K‚Ä¶  Member-only story Ryan S. Follow The Startup -- Share The year is now 2019, and we are fast approaching two whole decades in the 21st-century world. Changes have occurred at enormous scale since the early 2000s, across nearly every industry, sector, and vertical. Technology and its use in both business and everyday life has skyrocketed. Web 2.0 has come and gone, and we‚Äôre in the heart of digital transformation maturity. Everything is digital, and everything is a service. But what does this all really mean? And what is a service? In the tech space, words like service, digital, platform, ‚Äúbig‚Äù data, analytics, and robotics get thrown around quite often. They have become buzzwords ‚Äî overused, sometimes wrongfully applied, and downright bastardized. Each one of the aforementioned terms could have a guide of its own, but today we‚Äôre going to focus on services. In general, the word is a mess. Merriam-Webster has 11 different definitions for the word alone, and that is only for the noun format. Tack on adjectives and verbs, and you have a plethora of meanings for service. Without setting the proper context, you can see how easy it could be to misconstrue the meaning. And in a typical business, where many domains converge (think design, technology, marketing, sales, finance‚Ä¶ -- -- Get smarter at building your thing. Title: Applying Next Generation Technology for Social Good
Subtitle: Published in Givv Blog
Author: Givv.io
Article: Sign up Sign in Sign up Sign in Givv.io Follow Givv Blog -- Listen Share Applying next-generation technology, such as artificial intelligence and blockchain, for social good is a rising concept to accelerate the improvements in the state of the world. The companies applying technologies can be both for-profit, such as Givv, and not-for-profit but they have a common aim to improve the effectiveness of non-profit organisations and ultimately better the global human experience. Next Gen Technology for Good Over the last decade, the discussion on non-profit technology (#nptech) and next-generation technology for good has been primarily around social media, mobile technology, and online fundraising. As technology and connectivity enter the next phase, non-profits could benefit from better understanding some of the concepts that will shape the world in the decade to come. Technological advancements have changed how we improve standards of living and fundraise for causes, but new tools can provide global scalability and even change how we volunteer our time. There a several projects currently in existence that use technologies such as AI, blockchain, internet of things, cloud computing and even distributed computing to improve our current methods of improvement. How to Improve Non-Profit Funding Through Technology Non-profits like any other organization are looking to capture as many eyes as possible and bring in as much money as possible. So adapting to current technology is a no brainer, such as using social media platforms to bring awareness and accepting online donations or crowdfunding to raise capital. While this has shown significant improvement, 63% of people admit they don‚Äôt give to charity because they do not have the financial resources or they volunteer in lieu of donations. As we allow technology to improve every aspect of our lives, why not facilitate the process of giving to your fellow man. Not to discourage someone from giving up their time, as that is the most valuable thing a person could spare, but some of us just don‚Äôt have enough of it free to make a significant impact. Allow Givv to save you time and money by simply donating your computing capacity, instead of your time, and putting away those hard-earned dollars in your savings. Givv Innovates in Creating a For-Profit Technology for Good Givv is a distributed computing project that lets anyone with an internet connected device donate their idle computing power, which can generate up to $10 a month, and direct it to non-profits. Other distributed computing projects like Folding@home, the largest distributed computing project today, conduct disease research that simulates protein folding. Or Seti@home, the second largest, an internet-based public volunteer computing project searching for signs of extraterrestrial intelligence. These projects use the idle resource of personal computers owned by volunteers from all over the world, they have 8 and 5 million active processing units, respectively. Givv is much larger in scope, aiming to be a method of recurrent funding for any and all non-profits, mobilizing a larger category of people to close an enormous funding gap that would allow everyone to improve their standard of living. Givv is a for-profit technology company that facilitates funding for non-profits around the world. Givv uses blockchain, AI and cloud computing to aggregate idle computing power and sells it to companies in the market for computing capacity. Givv then directs all revenues to non-profits advancing the UN‚Äôs Sustainable Development Goals. Givv is building the largest cloud computing network in the world and in doing so will become the greatest source of recurrent funding for non-profits. Truly a for-profit technology, aimed at bettering the process for non-profits and ultimately bettering the world. Learn more about Givv today and join the movement! -- -- Power the solutions to the world‚Äôs biggest problems. Join the movement! Power solutions to the world‚Äôs biggest problems! Title: Cold Pressed Juicers ‚Äî What are they and should you go for them
Subtitle: Written by Akshit Anjana Seth
Author: Akshit Anjana Seth
Article: Sign up Sign in Sign up Sign in Akshit Anjana Seth Follow -- Listen Share Summer is coming (pun intended) and with the kind of heat we have to face, it is not a surprise that the demand for juices is going through the roof! Consuming freshly made juices at home is the best way to absorb all those nutrients and vitamins packed in the fruits. But which juicer to choose? Which technology? Centrifugal or Cold Pressed? Wait, what? There are two different types of juicers? You heard (read) that right! With the constant advancements in technology, it is not surprising to see that even the juicing technology has got a boost. So, before we begin to decide which is the juicer you should go for, how about a little background on both of them? Centrifugal Juicers These juicers are the ones you are aware about. Chances are that you even have them at your house. These are the juicers that use blades, rotating at high speeds, to cut the fruits against a mesh to produce the juices. While doing so, the juice and the pulp are separated. That‚Äôs centrifugal for you. Cold Pressed Juicers The way these juicers work are that they crush the already cut fruits and vegetables (yes, vegetables!) and press them at intense pressure levels to derive the juices out of them. So, which is the better technology? Cold Pressed Juicers have distinct advantages over their centrifugal counterparts. In Centrifugal Juicing, due to the mechanical nature of the blades moving at high speeds, heat is produced. Coupled with this heat, the juicers also incorporate air in their process causing oxidation. This oxidation leads to the destruction of important nutrients that are present in the fruits. Cold Pressed Juicers however do not employ such processes and thus the juices derived from them are much more nutritious. The problem with centrifugal juices is that you need to consume the juices right at the moment it is made. However, as Cold Pressed Juices retain most of the enzymes (as their parent fruit), they degrade very slowly giving them a shelf life of about 3 days! I had mentioned that the Cold Pressed Juicers even process vegetables. Is it really a big deal? Ask those who are into nut milks and green juices! Cold Pressed Juices can process vegetables like spinach and dry fruits like almonds to give you that super nutritious drink you have been paying brazen amounts for! Cold Pressed Juicers also produce more quantity of juices from the same fruit than a normal conventional centrifugal juicer. And if that‚Äôs not enough, they also create way lesser noise! In the days of noise pollution, you do not need one more appliance to lend a hand to the cacophony. This is not to say that Cold Pressed Juicers are for everyone. They are expensive and they take relatively a lot of time to make juices compared to the centrifugal juicers. However, if health and nutrition is your primary concern, Cold Pressed Juicers are the way to go. Disclaimer ‚Äî I used to intern at a Cold Pressed Juicer company called Kuvings. That is how I know a few things about Cold Pressed Juicing. In no way am I connected to them. Thanks. -- -- Just a normal (hopefully) guy trying to understand why we do what we do. And in the process, just maybe, change the world for the better. https://bit.ly/2VU3BAC Help Status About Careers Press Blog Privacy Terms Text to speech Teams

Title: Diversifying Tech
Subtitle: Does tech just need to get more diverse or should we also rethink what tech is to make it more inclusive of diversity?
Author: Steve Heitkamp
Article: Sign up Sign in Sign up Sign in Steve Heitkamp Follow -- Listen Share Not long ago tech companies tried to attract talent by out geeking each other, parading nerdy young guys as the world‚Äôs new superheroes. Over the past 10 years, however, diversity and inclusion have come to be valued by even the least diverse tech companies. In the past 5 years companies have started publishing data on how effective they are at actually becoming more diverse and inclusive. Despite these significant changes, efforts have plateaued, at least as evidenced by company diversity data. Some blame pipelines (not enough diversity in STEM) and others say it is about retaining diverse talent. Most everyone agrees that increasing diversity and inclusion at tech companies is a complex and multifaceted challenge. Yet, in a space where failure is a right of passage and iteration and pivoting are norms, few people are questioning the roles that exist at tech companies. It is assumed that tech companies are mostly Engineering + Sales (or Tech + Business). But as consumers and legislators start to ask how companies are leveraging user data and the frailties of systems built only to optimize clicks and ad sales are exposed, it might be time to think more broadly about the roles a tech company needs to have. Maybe it is time for tech companies to start hiring for data ethicists, human empowerment specialists, and even product and data compliance officers. Some companies are already doing this: Lever has Trust & User Operations Associates, Indiegogo has Customer Success Managers, and Clover Health has Data Stewards. These companies also happen to be some of the most diverse and inclusive within tech. This role diversification will require new hiring pipelines, broadening the hiring pool, and bring in new ways of thinking about technology. Combined this could help to create positive feedback loops that improve diversity and inclusion in tech while also helping tech companies better prepare for evolving expectations from regulators and customers alike. This won‚Äôt ‚Äòsolve for‚Äô diversity and inclusion in tech and is not an alternative to efforts to increase diversity specifically within technical roles, but it may help to break down the challenge differently while also helping to build tech companies that are more thoughtful about the diverse communities they want to serve. While not all tech companies value diversity equally, today most of them at least support the idea that diversity within tech is desirable. In the UK, for example, many companies take the legal requirement to publish and report specific figures about their gender pay gap as an opportunity to emphasize their commitment to all things diversity. A cynic might ask how many of these companies submitted reports prior to the requirement. I think we can all guess the answer: not (m)any. Setting cynicism aside, however, the increase in public affirmations that diversity and inclusion are valuable is a step in the right direction, even if it only a very small step on a very long path. As Megan Rose Dickey wrote in a recent TechCrunch article on The Future of Diversity and Inclusion in Tech, just over 10 years ago questioning the Silicon Valley old boys club was seen as risky. Today it is welcome. More recently, when I attended the Grace Hopper Celebration in 2015 the idea of publishing diversity reports and basic data was seen as pretty cutting edge for tech companies. Google, for example, first began publishing a Diversity Annual Report in 2014. And GoDaddy, which had previously made a name for itself through a series of truly nauseating ads, was getting a lot of press for its efforts to transform itself from one of the most toxic and least diverse and inclusive tech companies around to one of the most diverse and inclusive companies. Of course, diversity reports were great for companies because they could control the narrative, focusing their publications on all the things they were doing to develop a more diverse organization, and only releasing the data that they wanted to for the story they hoped to tell. The UK Gender Pay Gap reporting requirements mean that companies lose some ability to control the narrative. Having to publish metrics on diversity helps everyone to better understand where companies are and how they are progressing (or regressing) in their attempts to increase diversity and inclusion. If all the diversity and inclusion programs highlighted in company diversity reports are not improving the data, then they are clearly not the (only) solution. Looking at the data companies have been compelled to release rather than just what they wanted to release ‚Äî specifically 2017 to 2018 UK gender pay gap data ‚Äî reveals that year over year there was little progress in closing the gender pay gap across organizations (all industries), and that any progress is incremental at best. In an article in HR Magazine on the UK gender pay gap data, Rachel Sharp wrote, ‚ÄúNearly four-fifths (78%) of companies had a pay gap in favour of men, an exact repeat of the 2017 figure reported last year. At almost half (45%) of organisations the gender pay gap actually widened further in favour of men.‚Äù Within tech, many companies say this is less about pay discrimination than it is about uneven representation ‚Äî the people in the roles that pay the most, such as Engineering and Senior Management, lack diversity. So, if the gap is more a reflection of representation than pay discrepancies for the same work, the question then is, ‚ÄúHow can we increase representation?‚Äù Atlassian, one of the more active and vocal tech companies in support of diversity and inclusion, recently published a commissioned Report on the State of Diversity and Inclusion in U.S. Tech that found, ‚ÄúDespite massive amounts of attention and discussion about diversity and inclusion, the tech industry is still not making progress. The question is, why?‚Äù As highlighted in the report, and in other writings, there are many reasons why the diversity and inclusion numbers are plateauing for most companies. Some of the challenges in improving diversity and inclusion stem from more systemic undervaluing of the realities of people who fall outside of what Caroline Criado Perez describes, in her excellent book, Invisible Women: Exposing Data Bias In A World Designed For Men, as the ‚Äúdefault male‚Äù. These realities include bias in urban transportation planning, failure to recognize and appreciate unpaid work, norms around appropriate works hours, the myth of meritocracy in the face of (un)conscious bias, and on. Others are more specific to tech where the default is not just male, but also tends to be young, technical, geeky, and contrarian. Some companies, however, have gone beyond valuing diversity and inclusion, viewing it as a nice thing to have, to treating it as a strategic imperative. Companies like Lever, Indiegogo, and Clover Health built diversity and inclusion into their company DNA and are leading the charge within tech companies. While these companies and ones like them are doing a lot of things right, in looking at their websites I couldn‚Äôt help but notice both how they are presenting themselves and the roles they are hiring for. They are not just looking for diverse candidates, they are creating diverse roles. These roles are distinct from most tech companies and anchored off of inclusivity, collaboration, and empathy. As of writing Indiegogo, for example, has a Trust & User Operations Associate opening and they are looking for people described as, ‚Äúpassionate about helping people and problem solving. You are empathetic yet efficient, articulate, patient, and creative‚Äù. They are a tech company seeking people who are passionate about helping people, empathetic, and patient. Further, looking at their career page they describe themselves as ‚ÄúEmpowerment, Inc.‚Äù On their career page Clover Health practically shouts, ‚ÄúClover is hiring people who care.‚Äù They reiterate this in specific job postings and most begin with some version of, ‚ÄúWe value diversity ‚Äî in backgrounds and in experiences. Healthcare is a universal concern, and we need people with different backgrounds and experiences to help us build the future.‚Äù As noted in their Diversity & Inclusion at Clover Health: 2018 Update: ‚ÄúMany companies talk about the business benefits of diversity: different perspectives coming together to create better products and results for their customers. Here at Clover, this can literally be a matter of life and death. Healthcare touches everyone, so we need employees with different work experiences, backgrounds, and points of view to effectively solve the complex problems faced in Medicare.‚Äù These ideals are present even in areas of the company, such as IT, where one might expect diversity to be slightly less critical to the business. As an example, Clover‚Äôs IT group is (as of writing) is hiring for a Data Steward, which is a role focused on collaboration between business and IT and where facilitation and customer service are highlighted as reasons why someone might love the job. Perhaps more interestingly, the ‚Äúget in touch if‚Äù skills begin with a focus on health and managed care before shifting to the more ‚Äòtechnical‚Äô aspects of the job, such as ‚Äústrong knowledge and experience with relational and dimensional databases‚Äù. In addition to being ‚Äúproduct focused‚Äù and willing to ‚Äúembrace difficult problems‚Äù, which are both fairly standard ideas within tech companies, Lever notes, ‚ÄúWe care about cross-functional empathy (XFE!). We think the best companies are built when different teams have a shared understanding of each others goals and values.‚Äù The roles they are hiring for include Customer Success Managers and a Manager of Customer Success, both part of the Customer Advocacy team described as at, ‚Äúthe intersection between our products and our customers ‚Äî we‚Äôre the advocates that help inform product decisions based on customer feedback‚Äù. Looking at the roles within most tech companies, however, and in job listings more broadly, little of this role diversity is present. A recent report from Glassdoor on the roles within tech inadvertently highlights the general lack of diversity in tech roles: When we think of employees at tech companies, what usually comes to mind are software engineers and data scientists ‚Äî people with technical skills such as coding and machine learning. But, tech companies aren‚Äôt solely hiring for tech roles. They are hiring non-tech workers as well. In today‚Äôs job market, you no longer have to be a tech worker to work in tech. While this may sound promising, the non-technical Job Titles reveal that this is less an evolution in tech than a simple reflection that tech companies are not just tech, but also companies. As such, they have Sales, Marketing, and Operations personnel as well. Moreover, the listing of tech roles reaffirms that the focus for most companies is on the tech, not how the tech empowers (or not) humans. While this does make sense ‚Äî we are talking about tech companies ‚Äî as Lever, Indiegogo, and others have shown, tech companies are doing more than building and selling products. They transforming how humans interact with the world and with each other. The roles required to ensure that this transformation enhances human experience extend well beyond engineering, sales, and marketing. So, perhaps it is time for tech companies more generally to reconsider the roles that exist within their organizations. Role diversification is one of the clearest indicators that a company more than values diversity and inclusion, but actually sees it as a strategic priority. It is also a clear indication that a company is doing more than just selling products to users, but actually empowering humans in diverse and inclusive ways. This change would probably be good for increasing diversity and inclusion at tech companies. It would also probably be good for us humans more broadly. -- -- Empowering humans to better use data and avoid being used by it. Hence Co-Founder. Angel investor. Palantir Alum. Dad. . Title: 3 Terminal Commands to Increase Your Productivity
Subtitle: Aliases, pbcopy, reverse search, and a few bonuses
Author: Pankaj Gupta
Article: Sign up Sign in Sign up Sign in Pankaj Gupta Follow Better Programming -- 12 Listen Share Here are a few important shortcuts that help me be more productive throughout the day at work: Alias can be one of the most powerful tools in our hands, it provides us with the power to write our own shortcuts. Let‚Äôs see with an example what I mean. Whenever I type dev and hit enter it‚Äôll run this command. This becomes very useful when navigating to different folders. We can run almost all the commands in the alias. Here is the list of some of my most-used commands: So, using these aliases, I save a lot of time during the day, to up a directory I type, instead of cd‚Ä¶ I think the rest of them are self-explanatory. We can also use arguments with $1, $2, etc. for more extendability, like in this example: Now, all I have to type is gc ‚ÄúCommit message‚Äù and it‚Äôll commit my changes with the provided message. All you have to do is find your most-used commands and try to make them shorter using an alias to make yourself more productive. Now that we know what the aliases can do, let us see how we can set them. There are two ways in which we can achieve this, the first is temporary and can be set by running the command: This will work until the session is closed. The other way is to set these aliases permanently. For that, we need to set it up in our shell, I use Zsh, so I‚Äôll be updating my ~/.zshrc file. If you are using Bash, use the ~/.bashrc file. Add the commands to the file and your file should look like this: After making changes to this file, you need to run the command: Then, all your aliases will be available for your use. This command is available on Mac and if you want to use it on Linux distributions, you can follow this guide. pbcopy is copy on steroids. You can use this command to copy the contents of a file to the clipboard. Let me give you an example. Suppose you have to copy your SSH identity to the clipboard, you can do it with this command: You can save your other passwords in different files and make use of this while logging in. Suppose you are using and accessing a remote server, and you have to provide the password, instead of opening the file, you can just pbcopy it to your clipboard and without all the hassle of opening and closing files, you‚Äôll have the passwords. It becomes more useful when it is piped with other commands like grep. It‚Äôll copy the grepped results to the clipboard. Let‚Äôs see with an example: I use this command when I am debugging the log files, and I provide a keyword to be searched for, like a timestamp, and all the lines are copied onto my clipboard. I can paste it in a file to see the required logs instead of the whole file. It can be even more useful if you use the tee command as a pipe to grep, it‚Äôll write the results to a file. It has the following syntax: Reverse search is one of the coolest things available on the Unix system. Suppose you forget the full command and you only remember some parts, what you can do is you can go to the reverse search and type the words that you remember. Let‚Äôs see it with an example. I have to restart my server running in the staging environment, I only remember the staging keyword and forgot the rest of the command. So, I type ctrl + rto go into reverse-search mode and type: It‚Äôll remember the commands previously entered and finds the right match that you are looking for. It prints the current month on the terminal. It has many different options available, which can be checked using man cal. You can encrypt a file using vim, just type :X. It‚Äôll ask you to set a password which will look like this: When you access this file again, it‚Äôll ask you for the password. If you want to learn more about vim, here is a great article: medium.com If you want to learn more about terminal shortcuts, here is a great link: medium.com We can use these commands to make our day more productive and stay on top of things. -- -- 12 Advice for programmers.
