Title: Era uma vez, um ano depois
Subtitle: Written by Serena Fernandes
Author: Serena Fernandes
Article: Sign up Sign in Sign up Sign in Serena Fernandes Follow -- Share Est√° completando um ano que estou morando em Athlone e trabalhando na Neueda, decidi compartilhar aqui um pouquinho do que foi esse um ano. Tudo que voc√™ vai ler aqui √© somente a minha percep√ß√£o, n√£o quer dizer que seja uma verdade absoluta. A inten√ß√£o desse post √© s√≥ compartilhar uma experi√™ncia pessoal, taokei Caso voc√™ tenha vontade de saber como tudo aconteceu, eu escrevi contando como foi o processo seletivo e a mudan√ßa. √â dif√≠cil saber por onde come√ßar e o que contar mas vou compartilhar o que mais me impactou. Isso √© uma coisa que muda at√© quando voc√™ vai de um estado pra outro no Brasil, todo mundo sabe que as culturas s√£o diferentes, mas o que √© diferente? Idioma: o ingl√™s aqui √© uma coisa muito particular, o sotaque √© bem carregado e dependendo de quem est√° falando com voc√™ (se for jovem, velho, de Dublin ou de Donegal‚Ä¶), n√£o importa o qu√£o bom seu ingl√™s √©, voc√™ vai ter dificuldade de compreender. Existe o Gaelic (ou Irish) mas ningu√©m sabe. √â ensinado o b√°sico nas escolas para as pessoas quando ainda crian√ßa mas tudo que alguns se lembram s√£o frases que as vezes nem sentido fazem, tipo ‚Äúeu gosto de janelas‚Äù. Muitas vezes nem eles mesmos se entendem e a quantidade de g√≠rias que as pessoas falam √© impressionante! Mas voc√™ se acostuma e logo est√° perguntando ‚Äúwhat is the craic?‚Äù e querendo saber ‚Äúwhat the storie is?‚Äù. Vou deixar no fim desse post alguns links pra que voc√™ tire suas pr√≥prias conclus√µes sobre esse t√≥pico. Clima: eu costumo dizer que aqui tem 9 meses de inverno, um m√™s e meio de pr√© inverno e um m√™s e meio de p√≥s inverno. Chove na maioria dos dias, mas √© uma chuva muito estranha, ela n√£o te molha! (se √© que isso faz algum sentido). Voc√™ sai na rua, est√° muito frio porque √© √∫mido e venta, ent√£o a sensa√ß√£o t√©rmica √© bem mais baixa. Da mesma forma que o idioma, voc√™ tamb√©m se acostuma e logo, quando algu√©m disser que est√° muito frio, voc√™ vai dizer ‚Äúpelo menos n√£o est√° chovendo‚Äù. Comida: ‚ÄúSerena qual √© a comida t√≠pica da√≠?‚Äù ‚Äî Batata! Tem batata no caf√© da manh√£, no almo√ßo, no jantar, no bolo de anivers√°rio, no snack da tarde, no suco, na coca, no arroz! Brincadeira (#sqn). Falando s√©rio, assim como muitos pa√≠ses europeus batata √© um dos ingredientes mais usados, at√© porque a batata foi um alimento revolucion√°rio que salvou muitos pa√≠ses europeus da fome. Acompanhando as batatas vem o famoso Irish Breakfast! Pensa num almo√ßo completo, pensou? √â isso! Feij√£o, salsicha, ovos, bacon, p√£o de forma, cogumelos, tomate e (guess what?) batata. Esse √© conhecido como o melhor rem√©dio para ressaca. A maioria das comidas aqui tem um molho (gravy ‚Äî molho de knorr, sei l√°) ent√£o √© sempre uma comida seca coberta com molho. Ainda no t√≥pico comida, aqui depois de sair da balada (com um teor alco√≥lico que explodiria qualquer baf√¥metro) as pessoas est√£o mortas de fome e v√£o direto da balada pro ‚Äúcheaper‚Äù mais pr√≥ximo. O ‚Äúcheaper‚Äù ou ‚Äútake out‚Äù √© uma lanchonete que tem uma variedade inimagin√°vel de comidas por um pre√ßo MUITO baixo. Pizzas, hamb√∫rgueres, lasanha, macarr√£o, kebabs, batata‚Ä¶Acho que j√° deu de comidas n√©, no post do Eurodicas tem mais sobre, caso voc√™ ainda tenha interesse. O povo: o irland√™s √© uma criatura que deveria ser estudada. S√£o extremamente amig√°veis, sol√≠citos e AMAM falar. Voc√™ vai estar andando na rua e as pessoas v√£o te cumprimentar, voc√™ pode ir pra um pub sozinho(a) e vai sem d√∫vida ser abordado por um senhorzinho, ou uma senhorinha perguntando de onde voc√™ √© e contar que o sobrinho-neto da irm√£ do cunhado √© casado com um(a) brasileiro(a) e perguntar se voc√™ n√£o conhece. Muita gente vai perguntar se voc√™ √© do Rio ou de S√£o Paulo, porque n√£o h√° possibilidade de voc√™ ser de alguma outra parte da floresta que rodeia esses dois estados (sim eu ouvi que al√©m de S√£o Paulo e Rio s√≥ tem floresta). O Irland√™s reclama.de.absolutamente.tudo! Eu achava que o brasileiro reclamava, mas o irland√™s venceu. Reclama do clima frio, do clima quente, do clima seco, da chuva, de tudo! Mas existe algo que eles nunca v√£o fazer √© dizer que n√£o gostaram de algo diretamente. O cara vai no barbeiro, corta o cabelo, o corte fica uma porcaria, ele odeia! O barbeiro pergunta: ‚Äúis that ok?‚Äù O irland√™s vai responder ‚Äúyeah, it‚Äôs grand!‚Äù. Se voc√™ oferecer algo pra um irland√™s e ele dizer ‚Äúgrand‚Äù ele detestou! E adivinha!? Ele vai reclamar depois pra algu√©m. Mas em geral √© um povo muito am√°vel e foi o que fez minha mudan√ßa ser mais leve, me senti muito acolhida aqui. O ambiente de trabalho aqui √© bem diferente do que vemos no Brasil, em geral. As pessoas realmente tem vida fora do trabalho e valorizam isso. Voc√™ raramente vai ver algu√©m deixando de ficar com os filhos porque tem aquela tarefa que n√£o foi terminada na sexta as 5 da tarde. A pessoa vai pra casa, aproveita o fim de semana, volta na segunda-feira e retoma o que estava fazendo, nada de hora extra (a menos que seja extremamente necess√°rio e urgente). Dentro do meu time temos pessoas de 5 pa√≠ses diferentes, ent√£o d√° pra imaginar que incr√≠vel √© trabalhar com tanta diversidade cultural a sua volta. Voc√™ vai aprender sobre coisas inusitadas de cada cultura e se impressionar com as diferen√ßas. Mercado de trabalho: sempre me perguntam como √© o mercado de trabalho aqui, eu honestamente acho que √© bem aquecido (falando sobre o mercado de tecnologia), sempre recebo in√∫meros contatos de recrutadores com vagas e acredito que se voc√™ for bem ativo com suas redes (LinkedIn, Github, etc) voc√™ consegue uma oportunidade por aqui. Athlone √© uma cidade fofa, bem no cora√ß√£o da Irlanda. √â bem pequena, aconchegante, todo mundo se conhece (mais ou menos). Tem poucas empresas de tecnologia ent√£o as oportunidades s√£o muito menores que em Dublin por exemplo. √â muito bem servida de supermercados, cinema, shoppings e √© claro pubs! O Sean's bar, o pub mais antigo da Irlanda √© aqui e atrai v√°rios e v√°rios turistas pra cidade. Athlone tamb√©m √© um destino muito visado para comemora√ß√£o de despedidas de solteiras(os), todos os finais de semana voc√™ v√™ grupos e mais grupos de amigas vindo para os bares e baladas juntas pra se acabar de beber. Pra finalizar, abertamente falando sobre sentimentos, eu nunca imaginei que eu fosse t√£o ligada ao Brasil (emocionalmente). Eu sinto falta da comida, de falar portugu√™s, de ver minha fam√≠lia e meus amigos, ao mesmo tempo que sinto que aqui √© minha casa. Experimentei alguns altos e baixos, de ir dormir algumas vezes chorando e a √∫nica coisa que me consolava era pensar no qu√£o privilegiada eu sou de ter a oportunidade de estar aqui, com um excelente emprego. Minha qualidade de vida melhorou consideravelmente, meu n√≠vel de estresse √© praticamente nulo. Ir numa lojinha e comprar p√£o de queijo, tomar um guaran√°. Comprar pa√ßoca e fazer todo mundo do trabalho comer (e adorar). S√£o pequenos prazeres que morando longe voc√™ aprende a valorizar. Volto em breve com posts mais informativos que esse, s√≥ achei que seria legal compartilhar um pouquinho. Beijocas! Os links prometidos: Tente entender esse senhor contando sobre suas ovelhas desaparecidas. Aqui algumas g√≠rias pra voc√™ se enturmar -- -- Help Status About Careers Press Blog Privacy Terms Text to speech Teams

Title: COTI Opens Full Node Registration and Reveals Staking Model
Subtitle: Nodes in the COTI network
Author: COTI
Article: Sign up Sign in Sign up Sign in COTI Follow COTI -- Listen Share Bullet summary: COTI provides a decentralized solution that is designed to enable secure and trustworthy payments. This solution relies on the distribution of Trustchain responsibility to several types of nodes that are run by network users. Nodes are needed to verify transactions and to ensure that the COTI network remains safeguarded against potential fraud and cyber manipulation, such as double spending attempts, penny spend attacks, sybil attacks and more. There are four types of nodes in the COTI network, including Full Nodes, DSP Nodes, Trust Score Nodes, and History Nodes. The most common node type is a Full Node. We expect the number of Full Nodes to be in the hundreds, or potentially thousands at network maturity, while a reasonable number of DSP Nodes will be in the dozens and a lesser amount for Trust Score Nodes. In the current development stage, Full Nodes are the only available nodes that can be run by network users. DSP Nodes and Trust Score Nodes will also be operated by users as the network matures. Full Nodes are the main client-facing servers of the system. Each transaction sent from a wallet is received by a Full Node and propagated to the entire system. Full Nodes perform Trustchain Consensus by receiving new transactions from wallets, validating them, doing Proof of Trust and attaching them to the DAG. Full Nodes also execute COTI smart contracts in a decentralized manner. On the COTI network, Full Nodes can define their own price list for users and compete for them. Consequently, COTI Full Nodes are responsible for collecting fees on all protocol usage and transferring the network fee to the network pool. Watch this short video to find out more. ‚úì Simple, inexpensive and easy to run Full Nodes‚úì All node operators can earn profits from running nodes‚úì Node operator Trust Scores increase in line with the amount of work performed for the COTI network‚úì Merchants can run nodes and set their fees to zero to attract more customers When running nodes, operators provide the network with useful resources, including CPU, memory, storage and network bandwidth. These resources are not cost-free, which is why node operators are compensated and have the opportunity to earn a reasonable ROI. Full Node operators receive fees collected from transactions. The more transactions that a Full Node processes, the more it earns. COTI‚Äôs staking model is built to be competitive to decentralized finance (DeFi) income models and provides a means to generate a steady income from the process of transaction approval on the COTI network. The economic model of COTI nodes is designed to be fair, efficient and flexible and is based on finely tuned fee distribution mechanisms and staking requirements. As real world transactions are usually denoted in fiat currencies and node operator fees are a percentage of these transactions, a natural hedge for the COTI coin price is created. This is a major advantage over other staking models and currencies. All nodes are required to deposit (stake) COTI native coins to participate in the network, although the requirements are different for various node types. DSP Nodes and Trust Score Nodes, which are more substantial components of the network foundation, require higher staking than Full Nodes. In the COTI network, transactions are created according to several patterns defined by the transaction type. The most common types are payment for goods or services, remittance payments and singular transfers. In the first two cases, a transaction originator creates a payment request, and the transaction is created according to it. The transaction originator must input the Full Node address in the payment request in order to pre-select the node (a Full Node is selected by users for singular transfers). COTI provides an automated tool for Full Node selection, enabling a merchant, or any other transaction originator, to choose nodes according to the specified criteria. Merchants also have the ability to run Full Nodes themselves Full Node operators set fees autonomously, which makes setting competitive fee structures important. If a user knows a Full Node with a better price list, it can be re-selected when sending transactions. Important note: server throughput is limited, so large merchants can work with a pool of Full Nodes which are chosen at random at the time of transaction. As a rule, Full Node fees are collected in the same token as the main payment. Full Nodes are free to define which tokens they process and accept for fees and those they do not. Full Nodes can swap tokens they have received in various ways: For standard payment tokens, the network fee is calculated from the transaction flow and debited from the merchant‚Äôs virtual account in the network fee pool. The merchant is required to deposit the estimated amount of COTI native coins into the pool, or alternatively to cover the deficit at the end of the day. For singular transfers, all fees are payable in COTI native coins. All information presented below describes the basic model of Full Node staking. Future models will cover DSP and Trust Score Node models, as well as their delegated staking models. As described, Full Node operators gain fees by approving merchant transactions. Merchants select the nodes they wish to work with according to the node‚Äôs trust score, which is determined by its level of service quality and fees. Node operators can set fees as they see fit, with the understanding that other node operators may set lower and more competitive fees. The following model assumes 0.05% as a fee, although a node operator can set higher or lower fees. The COTI network processes merchant transactions in an ever growing volume every month, which increases the potential for nodes to turn a profit. In August 2019, the COTI network processed transactions equating to 225M COTI (an equivalent of about $5M USD). Assuming a 0.05% processing fee set by a Full Node, the potential income from transaction processing in August 2019 would have been 112.5K COTI. As COTI‚Äôs staking model is aimed to compete with DeFi models, we are aiming for the network to offer approximately 30% in annualized returns on staking. This means that in August 2019, Full Node monthly staking would have been 4.5M COTI for all nodes combined. Profits may increase as more merchants join the network and monthly turnover grows. Higher profits can also be registered by setting higher processing fees for a better quality of service (e.g., better uptime). New node operators joining the network will foster increased competition, which will lower returns, although we expect this dynamic to balance itself out under free market conditions. To encourage node operators while ensuring a healthy network environment and staking allocations, we are offering two incentive programs for running Full Nodes: As of October 2019, when the first Full Nodes will be operated in a decentralized nature, the staking requirements will be as follows: *Staking requirements may change over time** COTI ambassadors may run up to three Advanced Full Nodes In COTI, node staking amounts must be sent to the node‚Äôs special address which is maintained by DSP Node consensus at the network‚Äôs maturity stage. As a temporary solution for the network‚Äôs infancy stage, stakes are deposited to a node‚Äôs special address belonging to the COTI financial server, which is responsible for disputes, processing network fees, rolling reserves and more. The operation flow for this address is pre-defined, so staked capital cannot be seized from the node under any circumstances. Full Nodes have the opportunity to earn fees from merchants, as well as P2P transactions. Use our calculator below to estimate your potential earnings as a node operator in the COTI network. Profits are relative to your level of service and fees you‚Äôve set. The following tables illustrate various scenarios for network transaction volume, number of nodes, fees and staking requirements. Trusted users with high Trust Scores can become node operators after submitting satisfactory KYC documentation. At COTI, we‚Äôve made running nodes as easy as possible ‚Äî all you need is a Virtual Private Server (VPS) that meets the minimum requirements outlined below. You can read our technical guide on running a COTI Full Node here. The requirements for running a Full Node are as follows: ‚úì 16GB of memory ‚úì 4 vCPU cores‚úì Bandwidth (up to 3.5 Gbps)‚úì Broadband Internet connection‚úì 24/7 availability‚úì Operating system: Ubuntu/Linux/Windows The estimated costs for running such a VPS on Digital Ocean or Vultr is approximately $40-$80 per month. Users can operate the following nodes in the COTI network in the near future: Double Spend Prevention (DSP) NodesA set of highly trusted distributed servers responsible for DSP consensus, account balance control and general protocol and data integrity. Each transaction must be approved and signed by the majority of the DSP nodes, and users cannot directly connect to DSP Nodes. To run a DSP Node, a user is required to stake a substantial amount of COTI. This amount can be deposited solely by the DSP Node operator, or by a group of network participants delegating their deposits to the node operator. Trust Score Nodes Trust Score nodes are dedicated servers responsible for calculating and storing participant Trust Scores and KYC statuses. To run a Trust Score Node, a user is required to stake a substantial amount of COTI. Running a COTI Full Node enables operators to collect fees from each transaction. To be eligible to run a Full Node, operators must stake 100,000 COTI for each node and set the fee they wish to charge per transaction. An operator may also choose to stake 250,000 COTI to run an Advanced Node and guarantee a 25% annualized return. COTI has been built to be a free marketplace and operators may compete based on their service level and fee structure. In August 2019, node operators processed more than $5M in transactions in the COTI network. We expect turnover to continue increasing monthly and encourage users to run full nodes on the COTI network. We invite you to register to become a COTI Full Node operator today. For more information, you can view our technical guide and calculate your potential earnings using our Earnings Calculator. For all questions, feel free to get in touch with us in our Telegram group. Website: https://coti.io Github: https://github.com/coti-io Technical whitepaper: https://coti.io/files/COTI-technical-whitepaper.pdf -- -- COTI is the fastest and lightest confidentiality layer on Ethereum. Powered by the breakthrough cryptographic protocol Garbled Circuits and secured by Ethereum, COTI introduces the most advanced and compliant solution for data protection on the public blockchain. Title: ‚ÄúWhatever your big idea is, there is always a way to test it out cheaply‚Äù with Thomas Querton of atlasGO
Subtitle: Published in SuperWarm
Author: Jason Malki
Article: Sign up Sign in Sign up Sign in Jason Malki Follow SuperWarm -- Listen Share How can you test your idea cheap? I usually don‚Äôt like to give advice but I like to ask this question to people with ‚Äúideas‚Äù. We often want to have a beautiful product out in the market, have an app on the Appstore, or open a brick and mortar store. Whatever your big idea is, there is always a way to test it out cheaply. For example, before developing atlasGO I created a Facebook page and told all my friends that if they would post their #sweatyselfies on the page I would donate $0.10 to a non-profit. This was our first community which brought us press and a first investor. I had the pleasure to interview Thomas Querton, founder of atlasGO Thank you so much for joining us! What‚Äôs your startup origin story? How did you break into the space? Starting a company at 18, meeting Pr. Muhammad Yunus & running the 20Km of Brussels were some of the ingredients to kick atlasGO off. I started my first company during my studies in Brussels. With 2 friends we were bored in class and wanted to practice what we were learning in our economic books. We started a textile company that we never really had the ambitions to scale after our studies were over. Losing my entrepreneurial virginity at a young age was helpful to demystify the experience of starting a company. It is when I heard Pr. Muhammad Yunus talk in Brussels that I understood that I wanted to bring together my entrepreneurial ambitions with impactful goals. I had always been involved within my community by traveling with disabled youth or raising funds for underprivileged students but never thought that I could make it a career. Pr. Muhammad Yunus made me understand that not only could I make it my life‚Äôs work but that thousands of social entrepreneurs were also doing it! I was on. All I needed was a big idea. A couple of Months later my girlfriend at the time challenged me to run the 20Km of Brussels. I had never run a race before but I wanted to prove to her that I could do it. I hated the running but loved the community. I felt part of my own community for the first time in my life. The hugs, the cheers, the camaraderie. Everyone was raising funds for a cause they cared about and everything was beautiful. I was definitely high on people. When I was cooling off I wondered if we could create a platform for people to be part of such a community every day. A global community of sweaty change-makers! That was the first spark of atlasGO. What has been your toughest challenge as a startup founder and how did you overcome it? The toughest challenge was to be alone. You can‚Äôt do anything by yourself. I flew to San Francisco in 2015 with Steve Jobs‚Äô biography under my arm. I was as ambitious as I was naive. I didn‚Äôt know much about anything. I still don‚Äôt. But at least now I have a team! Meeting Magali and Olivier during my studies in San Francisco was the most important part of transforming the spark into an impactful fire. What has been your most notable accomplishment for your startup to date? Was there a particular thing that you attribute that success to? Resilience. Everybody has good ideas. Very few people follow through with them. Our proudest accomplishment is the community that we built. Together we have raised more than $450k for non-profits around the world by creating partnerships with some of the largest companies in the world. I am also very proud of the talent that has joined our team to make our vision a reality. With their hard work and creative ideas, we now offer products that help non-profits raise funding and engage their community as well as products that help companies engage their workforce around the causes they support. What are your words of wisdom for a founder who is about to launch their startup? How can you test your idea cheap? I usually don‚Äôt like to give advice but I like to ask this question to people with ‚Äúideas‚Äù. We often want to have a beautiful product out in the market, have an app on the Appstore, or open a brick and mortar store. Whatever your big idea is, there is always a way to test it out cheaply. For example, before developing atlasGO I created a Facebook page and told all my friends that if they would post their #sweatyselfies on the page I would donate $0.10 to a non-profit. This was our first community which brought us press and a first investor. How can our readers connect with you? Follow the journey on Instagram: @thomquert / @atlas_go Connect for business on Linkedin: @thomasquerton / @atlasGO Check out our new website: www.atlasgo.org -- -- The SuperWarm publication highlights leaders in the tech including founders, investors, and other executives. Jason Malki is the Founder & CEO of SuperWarm AI + StrtupBoost, a 30K+ member startup ecosystem + agency that helps across fundraising, marketing, and design. Title: Facing the Future, Connecting the Past: Kyriaki Goni‚Äôs Time-Bending Networks
Subtitle: Written by ARTWORKS Fellows
Author: ARTWORKS Fellows
Article: Sign up Sign in Sign up Sign in ARTWORKS Fellows Follow -- Listen Share Interview by Alexander Strecker Picture yourself standing alone on the highest point of an island. In every direction you look, the land runs underneath your gaze. It may be bare in places, there may be trees, roads, buildings, terracing, walls, farms, hotels, beaches ‚Äî but, at some point, everything falls away and ends at the sea. If the island is small enough, you will be able to see its limits in every direction you turn. Your separation is unavoidable: the word ‚Äúinsular‚Äù derives from insula, the Latin word for island. Still, if you are lucky, other forms are visible in the distance. No need to despair then: close by, you have neighbours, new people to meet, other lands to explore. As solitary as you might feel standing on these heights, there is the comfort that your island is part of something bigger: an archipelago. There is no way to understand Kyriaki Goni‚Äôs work without the concept of the archipelago. More than a cluster of islands, it is a community ‚Äî a carefully balanced collection of individualities that each retain their sense of separation and independence. A confederation of singularities. The clear inspiration for Kyriaki, in this regard, are Greece‚Äôs approximately 6,000 islands. Indeed, for the seafaring ancient Greeks, the water separating their islands was neither empty space nor a barrier, but an interconnected web of swift roads and fertile feeding grounds. There is no way to understand Kyriaki Goni‚Äôs work without the concept of the archipelago. More than a cluster of islands, it is a community ‚Äî a carefully balanced collection of individualities that each retain their sense of separation and independence. A confederation of singularities. Kyriaki tells me she spent every summer (‚Äúbeginning at age 0‚Äù) traveling across the Aegean archipelago. As a multi-disciplinary artist who focuses on the relationship between humanity and technology, for Kyriaki, the idea of the archipelago has a contemporary analog: the network. While popular techno-discourse pushes us to feel ever-more connected (to make more and more ‚Äúfriends‚Äù), Kyriaki‚Äôs vision of a network aims to retain the individual within the larger group. Even her most up-to-date work flows back and forth through time: an InterPlanetary File System (IPFS) overlaid with the ancient geological structures of the Aegean islands; a 19th-century astronomer converses with a machine learning algorithm. As a multi-disciplinary artist who focuses on the relationship between humanity and technology, for Kyriaki, the idea of the archipelago has a contemporary analog: the network. But before ranging too far afield, let‚Äôs begin with the single point at the center of this particular assemblage: Kyriaki herself. Born in Athens, Kyriaki was educated at the city‚Äôs German school (to the extent that she calls German a ‚Äúsecond mother tongue‚Äù). Trained first in anthropology, in Greece and then the Netherlands, she eventually returned to settle in Greece. Kyriaki, though influenced by her research-based training, is definitively an artist. She tells me, ‚ÄúThe starting point of my works are very emotional. It‚Äôs not a research curiosity that drives me but an ‚Äòemotional trigger.‚Äô My topics are ones that I‚Äôm moved by as a person, as a human being, living right now; not as a ‚Äòresearcher.‚Äô For example, my recent works have focused on observing technology and how it‚Äôs connected to society. I want to understand how these processes affect me, and then how they are shaping the way we all live, perceive, and express our emotions.‚Äù ‚ÄúThe starting point of my works are very emotional. It‚Äôs not a research curiosity that drives me but an ‚Äòemotional trigger.‚Äô My topics are ones that I‚Äôm moved by as a person, as a human being, living right now; not as a ‚Äòresearcher.‚Äô ‚Äú But, I ask her, with the growing popularity of research-based artistic practice, she must draw on her anthropological studies to some degree? She resists: ‚ÄúMy creative process is never strictly linear. Throughout my preparation, I feel myself falling into a black hole: I become overinformed, I‚Äôm in chaos. Eventually, this becomes a period of digestion; eventually, something starts to take shape. It‚Äôs not a predictable process, but neither is it driven by luck. Inevitably, my feelings, my observations, and yes, my research, start to form structures which organize my thinking. Still, I am uneasy when people present their artistic process as overly ‚Äòresearch-oriented.‚Äô Methodologies and rigor are fine but we shouldn‚Äôt, as artists, lose our freedom. Creativity and openness are the most important traits we have.‚Äù To drive home her point, she draws one more contrast: ‚ÄúI feel certain that the artistic process cannot be quantified. Yes, there are specific times of day when I‚Äôm ‚Äòworking‚Äô ‚Äî that is, consciously thinking and gathering material. But I don‚Äôt have an 8-hour schedule; it never stops. Ideas and solutions pop up throughout the day (and the night!), especially when I‚Äôm not in the studio. I believe you must put your brain, your body, and your soul into the artistic process ‚Äî you must expose yourself fully to the questions you‚Äôre having. There is never truly a pause; a part of my mind is always dedicated to these questions.‚Äù ‚ÄúI feel certain that the artistic process cannot be quantified. Yes, there are specific times of day when I‚Äôm ‚Äòworking‚Äô ‚Äî that is, consciously thinking and gathering material. But I don‚Äôt have an 8-hour schedule; it never stops. Ideas and solutions pop up throughout the day (and the night!), especially when I‚Äôm not in the studio. I believe you must put your brain, your body, and your soul into the artistic process ‚Äî you must expose yourself fully to the questions you‚Äôre having. There is never truly a pause; a part of my mind is always dedicated to these questions.‚Äù Going beyond Kyriaki‚Äôs internal processes, we discuss how these complex tangles of emotions and research find concrete expression. Take a recent project, Networks of Trust, motivated by an opposition to how world‚Äôs largest corporations (Facebook, Google, et. al) are profiting from our memories and feelings. To explore this vast subject, Kyriaki produced a multi-faceted work, consisting of a media installation, drawings, an audio manifesto, and a trove of digital material that can only be accessed when viewers are in proximity with one of three nodes that make up her alternative ‚Äúnetwork of trust.‚Äù Thus, like a pilgrim from days gone by, Kyriaki asks us to travel to one of the trio of nodes (on Tilos; in her studio in Athens; and a nomadic one which pops up wherever the project is exhibited) to experience the work. Through her demand, the universal ease and convenience promised by today‚Äôs start-up culture is confronted with an old-fashioned idea of locality, the topos. Such a sense of place is essential for Kyriaki, since from this groundedness, she can emphasize the idea of collectivity. She says, ‚ÄúIt‚Äôs important for me to cultivate a collective narration at the bridge between ancient oral traditions and contemporary internet culture. For example, in another project, Aegean Datahavens, I imagine places where our data could be stored and protected, not exploited. These havens would be powered by the sun and cooled by the Mediterranean water. They would be owned through a cooperation of the islands that housed them. They would mirror the way in which memory has always been preserved amongst islanders, as a shared effort.‚Äù Across her works, elegant syntheses of disparate artistic materials help her imagine futuristic possibilities built on past relationships ‚Äî a return to old ways, but with a difference. Indeed, Networks of Trust, Aegean Datahavens, or any of her projects really, are telling of the way that Kyriaki asks us to question our relationship to technology. She is no Luddite, she does not want to smash the machines. She expertly utilizes P2P and IPFS technologies. But she also wants us to be reminded of other ways of thinking, remembering, relating, and looking. She reveals how the newest, must-have technologies insist on making us forget that we ever lived otherwise. But she is never didactic, nor patronizing. Rather, Kyriaki‚Äôs works reveal themselves gradually; they demand time and listening. She admits, ‚ÄúThey are highly complicated. I can‚Äôt escape this. They ask for your sustained attention and engagement.‚Äù Two things that in our contemporary media environment are often in short supply ‚Äî which is exactly why such slow work is invaluable today. The subtlety of Kyriaki‚Äôs message may be difficult to grasp for overtaxed adults, but she is gratified with her work with children. In a series of workshops, with titles like, ‚ÄúDo Robots Dream, Mom? Are Robots Afraid, Dad?‚Äù, Kyriaki commits time and energy to working through these same topics with the next generation. She is consistently amazed by their flexibility and creativity. For example, a group of children asked to invent their own ‚ÄúAegean Datahavens‚Äù came up with refreshingly original solutions. Meanwhile, in another workshop focused on our relationship to technology, an unaccompanied Syrian refugee child living in Athens spoke about the importance of Messenger for keeping in touch with his distant family. Moments like these help broaden Kyriaki‚Äôs perspective. Our contemporary society has countless tech evangelists and a small but vocal chorus of critics. Rarer, though, are those who ask us to be more thoughtful with our machines while connecting their functions to ancient practices of connection and communication. Kyriaki has another motivation for running her workshops: countering the feeling that people on the periphery have of always being behind. Especially when her work began to focus on technology, she became worried herself about not having access to the latest advances and developments. Even as someone with the fortune of access to a good education, experiences abroad, and the ability to travel, she regretted her remoteness. She didn‚Äôt want young people in Greece to have the same fear. Lately, though, she has begun to see her surroundings in a more positive light. After all, it is the particularities of Greece that have informed her belief in other, older kinds of networks. And anyways, she adds, ‚ÄúPeople on the periphery are closer to each other.‚Äù She then goes on, ‚ÄúBeing on the periphery has its problems but it can also be fruitful. You have the space to take a different approach. I feel like I have an off space quality, one that allows me to draw on local and personal experiences to have a more balanced perspective. These days, I don‚Äôt feel like I‚Äôm chasing after the latest thing. Instead, by being in the periphery, I feel a desire to support other people who are with me on the edge.‚Äù ‚ÄúBeing on the periphery has its problems but it can also be fruitful. You have the space to take a different approach. I feel like I have an off space quality, one that allows me to draw on local and personal experiences to have a more balanced perspective. These days, I don‚Äôt feel like I‚Äôm chasing after the latest thing. Instead, by being in the periphery, I feel a desire to support other people who are with me on the edge.‚Äù As we conclude our conversation, we turn once more towards the future. While the periphery has often been defined from the outside as that which is behind, away from the center and its cutting-edge developments, Kyriaki points out that the edge also lies at the frontier and the avant-garde. She says, ‚ÄúWhile preparing my presentation for Transmediale on Networks of Trust, I came across something from a writer about the concept of the periphery. He said that we, on the international periphery, have the destiny to be the first to meet the future. For example, the peripheries have already been the first areas to face the effects of climate change. This is frightening but also inspiring. Who knows what will come out of the periphery next?‚Äù Visual Artist Kyriaki Goni is a 2018 SNF ARTWORKS Fellow. ARTWORKS is a nonprofit organization exclusively supported by its founding donor, the Stavros Niarchos Foundation. Our aim is to create a fertile and nurturing environment for Greek artists through funding and public engagement opportunities. You can always learn more about our Fellows at www.art-works.gr http://kyriakigoni.com/ Alexander Strecker is pursuing a PhD in Art, Art History and Visual Studies at Duke University. His research explores how artistic practices register the contradictions inherent in ideas of crisis, periphery, and technology, with a focus on how these tensions are felt acutely in contemporary Greece while also resonating worldwide. -- -- Essays, texts and interviews about contemporary Greek artists and the Stavros Niarchos Foundation Artist Fellowship Program. www.art-works.gr Help Status About Careers Press Blog Privacy Terms Text to speech Teams

Title: Easy and Effective Tech Solutions for Life and Work
Subtitle: Written by Nina Vaca
Author: Nina Vaca
Article: Sign up Sign in Sign up Sign in Nina Vaca Follow -- Listen Share Pinnacle Group is in the midst of a period of incredible growth and global expansion, which brings a whole host of challenges and opportunities. Having teams that are spread out across the world can make communication, collaboration, and productivity an issue, so that‚Äôs why we have found great value in apps and software that make our lives easier. One of the toughest things we deal with is which apps to choose and which new technology will be beneficial to our company. We have to be intentional about leveraging technology to make the most of our days and weeks. Crystal Washington, a futurist, technology strategist, and author, recently spoke at the Comerica Women‚Äôs Business Symposium in Dallas and gave some incredible insight about how we should view technology. Here are three questions that she asks herself when it comes to any task in life are: Does it have to be done? Can I delegate this? And, is there an app for this? She proposed using outsourcing applications like Fiverr, Upwork, TaskRabbit and more to make your personal and business life more efficient. I think this same idea applies to the use of any tool at your company as well. There are so many tools available for every part of your business, you can get bogged down just trying to decide which ones to use. At Pinnacle we ask ourselves a few questions before implementing anything: Do we need this? Will the time it takes to implement and learn this be rewarded with better efficiency or better user experience? Will we have strong adoption from all the users and stakeholders? Washington stressed at the end of her talk the importance of keeping the human touch and I want to make that same disclaimer here. Many of the tools I‚Äôll discuss below are communication and automation tools, but still nothing replaces the value of face-to-face interaction. Don‚Äôt use text messages or other ways of communication when actually speaking to someone is better. I‚Äôm a firm believer in the importance of the in-person meeting and the handwritten note. Use technology to make your life more efficient so you can actually have more time to have these human interactions. So, here are some apps and other tech that Pinnacle teams use to be as efficient and effective as possible. I‚Äôve broken them down into some categories: Productivity, Habits, Fitness, Communication, and Entertainment (because it‚Äôs always good to have a little fun). Email is still king when it comes to business communication. We use Outlook at Pinnacle and many of our associates make great use of the shared calendar features, especially our executives. As a rapidly expanding company, you never know if our executives will be in Argentina, Chile, Mexico, or somewhere else altogether. Getting a meeting set up can be difficult, but it‚Äôs made so much easier when everyone has visibility into calendars via Outlook. And when we need host meetings with remote attendees, we use Zoom to connect. Many of our teams have use Monday to get on the same page with projects. While it doesn‚Äôt take the place of Smartsheets for our most complex projects, it‚Äôs easy to pick up and use and has some powerful features that allow excellent customization and integrations with other apps. Monday gives each team member visibility into all the different projects they are involved in. It‚Äôs also a great place to store documents related to projects with their action items and related commentary in one place. Similar to Monday, but more effective for personal tasks with excellent Outlook integration that syncs with its mobile app, Todoist is a productivity hound‚Äôs dream. It allows you to keep all of your tasks in one place and many use it for both personal and business activities, so nothing is missed in a busy day (and it also integrates with Monday.com). There is nothing more satisfying than checking off a task on a to-do list! Communication is extremely important on every team, but especially when your teams are spread out across the country and the world. Using an instant messaging service cuts down on the clunky and inefficient use of email. Sending quick messages back and forth allows constant communication and keeps everyone on the same page. It‚Äôs almost impossible to be successful without communication. Our associates make great use of the Teams app on the phone to be able to communicate no matter where they are. This is a personal favorite of mine. Many people in the United States aren‚Äôt as familiar with WhatsApp, but people around the world can‚Äôt live without it. It‚Äôs another instant messaging/texting app, but it works all over the world and has some great functionality with voice messaging and media sharing. So often our phones are the reason we aren‚Äôt productive but using apps like Productive can help change that. Instead of using your phone to mindlessly scroll through social media, you can use your phone to remind you to go for a run, meditate, walk your dog, or practice other forms of self-improvement and self-care. I‚Äôve written about the importance of taking care of yourself in the past, and it‚Äôs so necessary to treat yourself well. Using Productive can be a step in that direction as it encourages positive habits and gives you that motivation to keep your daily streaks alive. Streaks is very similar to Productive in that it is geared around helping you form good habits and get a daily streak going for each habit. So, if you‚Äôre trying to break a bad habit like smoking, or start a new one like running, using an app like Streaks can steer you in the right directions. Plus, these apps add that gamification element that spurs you on to do good things for yourself and others. Running is so much easier when you have a community. I highly recommend finding a running buddy, but figuring out scheduling with someone else can be tough. So that‚Äôs where run tracking apps with community connections are so useful. You will be more encouraged to get out and exercise when you have that push from others that you are connected to. Use your natural competitiveness and desire not to let others down motivate you to get more in shape today! There are so many fitness apps out there, so this is far from an exhaustive list of fitness trackers. So many people who love using MyFitnessPal because of its food information. So much of losing and maintaining weight is what you put into your body. Using MyFitnessPal you can search the food you eat and learn the calorie count, nutrition information, and serving size. Knowledge is power, especially when it comes to food. When you know what you are putting in your body you can make more informed decisions with your food choices. I use my Garmin Forerunner 920XT watch every time I work out. It‚Äôs my favorite piece of technology! It goes well beyond the typical heartrate, workout time, length of a run or bike ride tracking and offers VO2 max estimates, running dynamics like ground contact time, and a whole host of other stats and information that help me be a better triathlete. It‚Äôs waterproof and even tracks my swimming distance, pace, stroke count, and more. I benefit so much from this watch. Any serious triathlete should look into getting a Garmin Watch. Long plane, train, and car rides can be used as opportunities for self-development and growth or to unwind and get some much-needed relaxation. Sometimes it‚Äôs good to put some headphones in and relax with a great book (especially if you get motion sickness from reading in moving vehicles!). Audible is a great way to learn about the latest leadership trends, catch up on great recommendations from your friends, or just immerse yourself in something you‚Äôre fascinated by. With Audible you can listen in your car during your commute as well. Start by listening to the books that I suggested in these two Medium posts! Most of us love binging shows when we get the chance, but the time can be hard to find. This is a great app to use on planes ‚Äî especially long international flights. You can download shows on Netflix so you can watch them offline, which means that you don‚Äôt have to pay for the WiFi on the plane to enjoy your favorite shows and movies. I don‚Äôt suggest spending all of your free time watching Netflix, but it can be nice to just turn off from time-to-time and relax! So tell me, what are your favorite productivity apps? Which apps do you use for fitness, and what are your favorite apps to use when you just want to relax? To stay up-to-date on all the advice, news, and updates from me and Pinnacle Group, make sure to follow me on Medium, like my Facebook page, and join the conversation on Twitter and Instagram @NinaVaca. -- -- Chairman & CEO of Pinnacle Group, civic leader, triathlete, global speaker, Presidential Ambassador for Global Entrepreneurship. Learn more: NinaVaca.com Help Status About Careers Press Blog Privacy Terms Text to speech Teams

Title: 5G SEPs & a nice cup of T
Subtitle: We talk Standard Essential Patents and the most essential of all essentials: a perfectly brewed cuppa.
Author: Andrew Samm
Article: Sign up Sign in Sign up Sign in Andrew Samm Follow -- Listen Share 7th September 2019 This week, we are in Brussels at the Solvay Brussels School of Economics and Management (ULB) for the Standard Essential Patents Strategy Conference. For the uninitiated, a standard-essential patent is one that covers an invention that must be used to comply with a technical standard. A technical standard is an agreed specification of a given technology that ensures products, components and services supplied by different companies will be mutually compatible. Basically, it‚Äôs why your Samsung TV can talk to your LG Blu-ray player, and both can talk to your Bose surround sound system (other consumer electronics brands are available). Without collaboration over these technical standards, each manufacturer would have proprietary solutions and that mass of cables in your cupboard would be even bigger. One of the busiest standards-setting bodies is the European Telecommunications Standards Institute (ETSI). They are the chaps responsible for developing all the mobile phones and phone networks we rely on. The hottest topic at the moment is 5G. With speeds over 100 times faster than the current network, 5G is key to other technological advances becoming a reality: autonomous vehicles for example. The data transfer rates possible with 5G mean that when sending messages to a vehicle travelling at 60 mph, the distance travelled would be approx 60cm as opposed to the 6.5m capable using 4G ‚Äî an improvement that could be the difference between life and death. Apple recently agreed to acquire Intel‚Äôs smartphone modem business together with a portfolio of Intel patents relating to wireless technology. Looking at Intel‚Äôs ETSI declarations relating to 5G standards over the last few years, we can see almost 600 live published families plus another 260+ unpublished applications filed in the period 2013‚Äì2019. No wonder Apple was interested. Even hotter than 5G would be the 100¬∞C water I am about to pour over a teabag to kick off the office afternoon ritual: cup of tea, two dark chocolate Hobnobs and The Times cryptic crossword. We‚Äôre in good company ‚Äî the Queen also takes tea every day at 4pm and, while Her Majesty is said to prefer Rich Tea biscuits, we all agree that a good cuppa mid-afternoon is the perfect way to reinvigorate body and mind ready for the final push into the evening But is there an agreed method of making a cup of tea; is there a standard? Believe it or not, yes! ISO 3103: Tea ‚Äî Preparation of liquor for use in sensory tests. (In fact, there are 34 tea-related ISO standards listed in their standards catalogue.) ISO 3103 specifies, among other things, 2g of tea per 100ml of water ( ¬± 2%) and brewing time of 6 mins!? It is not meant to define the proper method for brewing tea intended for general consumption, but rather to document a tea brewing procedure where meaningful sensory comparisons can be made. An example of such a test would be a taste-test to establish which blend of teas to choose for a particular brand or basic label in order to maintain a consistent tasting brewed drink from harvest to harvest. An agreed standard for how to make a ‚Äòproper‚Äô cup of tea is much harder to come by. Many have tried, below are some of our favourites: George Orwell ‚Äîin 1946 he penned an essay titled ‚ÄúA nice cup of tea‚Äù which has 11 rules, including rule 10. ‚Äúone should pour tea into the cup first. This is one of the most controversial points of all; indeed in every family in Britain, there are probably two schools of thought on the subject. The milk-first school can bring forward some fairly strong arguments, but I maintain that my own argument is unanswerable. This is that, by putting the tea in first and stirring as one pours, one can exactly regulate the amount of milk whereas one is liable to put in too much milk if one does it the other way round.‚Äù The late, great Christopher Hitchens agrees with many of Orwell‚Äôs rules and has several of his own, mainly centred around the recommendation to avoid tea altogether when in the USA. ‚ÄúIt is already virtually impossible in the United States, unless you undertake the job yourself, to get a cup or pot of tea that tastes remotely as it ought to. It‚Äôs quite common to be served a cup or a pot of water, well off the boil, with the tea bags lying on an adjacent cold plate. Then comes the ridiculous business of pouring the tepid water, dunking the bag until some change in colour occurs, and eventually finding some way of disposing of the resulting and dispiriting tampon surrogate. The drink itself is then best thrown away, though if swallowed, it will have about the same effect on morale as a reading of the memoirs of President James Earl Carter.‚Äù One person Hitch didn‚Äôt agree with is Yoko Ono. In his article in SLATE in 2011 titled: ‚ÄúHow to make a decent cup of tea‚Äù he scolds Yoko and John Lennon for the practice of putting the water in the cup before the teabag (I can imagine a Hell, John, and that‚Äôs how they make tea there!) So what is it, reader: MIF or TIF? Comment your preference below and follow our social media twitter.com www.linkedin.com We have a lot more to say about standards, tea and patents. For information on this and any other patent information study, please visit patently.com and email us at ask@patently.com. patently.com -- -- Certified QPIP, Patent data expert & tech enthusiast After work I'm a Spurs fan, Tigers fan, AFOL, Yognaught, GandDiva, Potterhead, and a lover of ATLA & LOTR Help Status About Careers Press Blog Privacy Terms Text to speech Teams

Title: Becoming a Mission Specialist: Piloting the Development of Safe Self-Driving Technology
Subtitle: By: Nick Wedge, Learning and Development at Uber ATG
Author: UberATG
Article: Sign up Sign in Sign up Sign in UberATG Follow -- 2 Listen Share Developing a self-driving vehicle is challenging, dynamic, and captivating, as there are changes and advances almost on a daily basis. Take a moment to consider what it‚Äôs like to be responsible for safely monitoring our developmental technology in the real world from behind the wheel. At Uber Advanced Technologies Group (ATG), that is the primary function of the Mission Specialist. As the pilots (driver‚Äôs seat) and co-pilots (passenger‚Äôs seat) of our developmental self-driving vehicles, they are just a handful of people who will experience the development of automated vehicle (AV) technology unlike anyone else in the world. The job requires them to continuously scan the operating environment, compare the vehicle‚Äôs behavior with their mental model of appropriate vehicle behavior, and correct any undesired behavior. Here‚Äôs the kicker: it‚Äôs only going to get more challenging as the technology improves and capabilities expand ‚Äî undesired behaviors become more subtle and infrequent requiring more vigilance. At Uber ATG we have the responsibility of maintaining (human) learning systems that can match a rapid development cadence ‚Äî to ensure that testing of AV technology in the real world is done safely and effectively. That‚Äôs the role of the Learning and Development Team. First, some context Having recently released our Safety Case Framework, you can see where our Mission Specialist education efforts fit (G1.3.1) in supporting our claim that our self-driving vehicles are acceptably safe to operate on public roads. Not only is Mission Specialist training a part of our safety case for testing activities with a Mission Specialist, but the team responsible for developing the curriculum is a part of the 40+ person multi-disciplinary Safety Team at Uber ATG, giving us the opportunity to represent operational needs and perspective to the entire organization. While the scope of the Learning and Development Team has evolved over the years to meet the unique needs of those piloting and co-piloting our self-driving vehicles, the team continues to support all test operations, both at the track and on the road. The responsibilities of a Mission Specialist are safety-critical and we have designed our training programs to reflect that. Before they join the team, Mission Specialists go through a screening process to ensure they have a current driver's license and clean record. Then they must be internally certified to safely and effectively supervise a self-driving vehicle through an in-depth training regime. These trainings are designed to ensure that the Mission Specialist has the information, knowledge and support that they need to succeed in their role. Throughout a Mission Specialist‚Äôs career, they will be expected to maintain this internal certification to carry out their responsibilities, which requires continuous education and yearly recertifications. Below are some key focus areas of our programs that help Mission Specialists receive and maintain their certifications. Understanding the Mission Before Mission Specialists get behind the wheel of an Uber developmental self-driving vehicle, they spend their first week learning about the organization and how the work they do supports our mission to bring safe, reliable self-driving transportation to the world. We believe that, as educators, we are responsible for our learners‚Äô understanding of the impact their work has on the company‚Äôs success. It‚Äôs also easier to train learners who find meaning and take pride in their work. Becoming A Best-in-Class Driver Not everyone personally drives a Volvo XC90 Sport Utility Vehicle ‚Äî the base vehicle we currently use to test our self-driving system. It stands to reason then that it‚Äôs important to familiarize our Mission Specialists with our modified development vehicle on its own, without self-driving capabilities enabled. Mission Specialists spend time getting certified solely to operate our self-driving cars manually. This gives us the opportunity to focus on subjects such as: Anyone piloting or co-piloting the vehicle while in self-driving will have to complete this certification, which means passing a series of in-classroom and in-vehicle assessments. Understanding the AV System Aside from familiarity with the vehicle itself, we spend a considerable amount of time educating Mission Specialists about how and why the vehicle is making the decisions it is. By taking Mission Specialists through the detailed data flows from the sensors of the vehicle to the controls that execute a trajectory or behavior, we create a more prepared pilot and co-pilot. Mission Specialists gain a strong practical understanding of the complete development program and process that Uber ATG undertakes giving them an advanced understanding of self-driving technology. All of the topics that are introduced in-classroom are also reinforced in-vehicle, giving us the opportunity to take a learned concept and put it into action on the track. This helps ensure that our Mission Specialists can anticipate vehicle behavior and maintain safe operations from both positions; the pilot through manual controls, and co-pilot through system oversight. Training Through Faults At Uber ATG, Mission Specialists are systematically exposed to random faults injected by the vehicle‚Äôs self-driving system (such as a sudden lane departure), and environmental factors (such as unexpected road users entering the roadway). They are tested on their ability to respond to the worst possible situations. This type of training helps ensure that they have the appropriate reaction time and execute the appropriate correction maneuver. Mission Specialists are first introduced to Basic Fault Injection Tests, which include very simple faults at low speed without outside actors or environmental factors. These injections occur during straight-line driving and are designed to introduce the learner to vehicle behaviors during a fault, such as lane drifting. Basic fault injection is a stepping stone to more complex Scenario Fault Injection Tests that represent possible situations seen out in the real world. The situations tested with a Scenario fault injection add the complexity of different road infrastructure, such as intersections, and actors, such as pedestrians and cyclists simulated using robots. Staying Relevant and Effective The Learning and Development team participates actively in the software development process. This means our team has a process for anticipating and managing change from software, operational policy, or operational design domain, which captures the specific conditions under which our self-driving system will operate, including where and when. When the development process, autonomy (or human) performance, a safety concern, or another avenue indicates that amendments to our training program are required, the team ensures new hire programs stay relevant. This updated training extends to current Mission Specialists by way of in-vehicle, in-classroom, computer-based training, or in a simple pre-shift brief. What‚Äôs more, all of our training content is reviewed twice a year by the Learning and Development team, internal subject matter experts, and members of the broader Safety Team. These results are collected, analyzed, presented to the organization as evidence of our programs‚Äô effectiveness, and serve as a rationale for the changes we make to our curricula. Maintaining Certifications Aside from having to pass a number of in-classroom and in-vehicle assessments, Mission Specialists participate in two key programs to maintain their certifications: Recertification and Refresh training. Recertification Training measures Mission Specialist performance on a yearly basis and ensures continued, high-performance piloting and co-piloting skills. Regardless of a Mission Specialist‚Äôs performance or time in role, they are expected to complete Uber ATG‚Äôs Autonomy Recertification program. This program provides an opportunity for Mission Specialists to relearn skills that are rarely used in practice, such as fault injection and emergency maneuver exercises. Refresh Training is conducted in response to time out of vehicle, a minor infraction/breach of policy, or when we identify other training opportunities that can improve Mission Specialist performance. Refresh opportunities ensure that, with the right performance diagnostic (infractions, time out of vehicle, performance reviews), Mission Specialists are given the best chance to succeed. Building Distrust in the System As our self-driving vehicle capabilities and performance increase over time, one may think that a Mission Specialist‚Äôs job gets easier. However, monitoring a system that fails less frequently over time is even more challenging than one that fails often. The reality is that a Mission Specialist who may have seen the vehicle stop at the same stop sign a thousand times before cannot presume that it will stop the next time. That is why the Learning and Development team‚Äôs goal, above all, is to develop a healthy level of distrust in the self-driving system. Organization-Wide Safety Management System Education As Uber ATG‚Äôs Safety Management System (SMS) begins to take shape, the Learning and Development team is widening its scope to ensure the broader organization understands how it contributes to safety, including how to use safety reporting tools, determine how safety-related decisions are made and who makes them, manager/leadership responsibilities within our SMS, and more. With guidance from our Safety Case Framework, we will deploy complementary educational initiatives across the company, including hosting company-wide workshops on topics such as Safety Ownership and Risk-Based Thinking. Preparing for the Future: Remote Operations As we look toward the future, the Learning and Development team aims to continue to support Uber ATG‚Äôs business needs, and supporting Remote Operations is a big part of that. While we will always support the in-vehicle Mission Specialist in whatever future scope they have, we are working closely with product and engineering teams to consider training needs for Remote Operators outside of the vehicle, focused on assisting the Rider and Autonomy when no one is behind the wheel of a self-driving car. Uber ATG has made a huge commitment to supporting Mission Specialists and has empowered the Learning and Development team to be an influential force within the organization. Having Mission Specialists in our vehicles is a crucial step to delivering a fully self-driving vehicle. This post only scratches the surface of the training that we undertake and we will continue to share our work so that we can move forward as an industry together. -- -- 2 We are rethinking the future of transportation. Title: Bring Paper Back to the Classroom
Subtitle: Paper has fallen to the wayside. We need to bring it back.
Author: Jennifer Osborne
Article: Sign up Sign in Sign up Sign in Member-only story Jennifer Osborne Follow The Startup -- 6 Share My daughter has been struggling to learn to read, so I have started working with her at home to prevent her falling further behind. As a high school teacher, I literally have no clue how to teach little people to read, so I first tried a hefty book targeted towards teaching phonics via handwriting and speak aloud exercises. My daughter became quickly bored with the repetition, so her teacher suggested I tried an online reading app called Reading Eggs. The app is highly engaging and also teaches using phonics, which is research-supported, and my daughter loves earning ‚Äúeggs‚Äù at the end of each level. But while she might be learning to read the letters, words, and sentences, she is certainly not learning to write letters, words, and sentences. I actually had to go on a full-fledged hunt around my house for actual paper and a pen, so she could practice writing down the words she was learning. Learning via the internet and apps is certainly more engaging but at what cost to learning? -- -- 6 Get smarter at building your thing.
