Title: Is the digital skill transition a gender transition?
Subtitle: Written by European Young Innovators Forum (EYIF)
Author: European Young Innovators Forum (EYIF)
Article: Sign up Sign in Sign up Sign in European Young Innovators Forum (EYIF) Follow -- Listen Share The spread of digital is now having a massive impact on the way work is organised and structured. Workers must acquire new skills to remain competitive in the labour market, while new jobs emerge. When it comes to Information and Communication Technology (ICT), women remain an important part of the workforce, representing 23,4% of the entrepreneurs in the sector. The number of women in this field shows that the digital transition has struck, even in a traditionally male sector. The digital sector has slowly appeared but is blowing up. Indeed, most innovation or noticeable breakthroughs are directly linked to technology. Technology has started being used in very precise areas but tends to be enlarged in all sectors. Missing the digital transition would end in missing various job opportunities. In fact, in 2015 about 5,8% of workers were employed in the digital sector but all working sectors are now using technology, therefore, dealing with technology is basically no longer an option. However, statistics show that 25% of European men and 27% of European women still have no or low digital skills. Furthermore, most people working in the ICT sector are men. Only 16,7% are female ICT specialists. This takes its origin from two factors. First, there are not as many women as men studying ICT related subjects (24 out of 1000) and out of these 24 only 6 will work in this field. Second, only 0,4% of girls expect to work in ICT. In fact, the European Institute for Gender Equality (EIGE) underlines that ‚Äúby age 15, girls and boys already have different levels of confidence and skills in the use of digital devices [‚Ä¶]. For example, most boys confronted with a problem with digital devices start solving it on their own or they feel more comfortable than girls in using digital devices they are less familiar with‚Äù. One question appears to be pressing: How can women be part of the digital transition? For many people, technology in its entirety is a masculine area. And in order to maximise chances for a woman to work in this sector, it is necessary to deconstruct all negative stereotypes. The main instrument to achieve this objective is education, which allows targeting multiple goals: it will help in deconstructing all preconceived ideas but also in democratising the access of the sector. With the aim of tackling the lack of women in the ICT sector and of giving better access to it, the EU has launched the Digital Opportunity traineeships scheme. This pilot project has emerged to give students and recent graduates the opportunity to strengthen skills in different ICT areas like AI, Cyber Security, Coding, etc. This initiative is implemented through universities and the Erasmus+ programme and will make students acquiring the maturity and the experience to be competitive. All students or graduates can apply in their home university and can have the access to all offers on the online platform or through the university career office. The EU has even launched the Digital Skill Award to promote the most innovative project that proves excellent digital skills. It is also a good way to reveal local initiatives that are not well promoted. Being nominated and awarded with the Digital Skill Award validates the quality of the project. For example, in the category Education, the ‚ÄúAdopt a School!‚Äù project aims to familiarise primary school students with technology by creating partnerships between schools and Romanian IT professionals. All activities are mentored by professional volunteers. This project helps to link entrepreneurs and the future workforce. Even if the pupils won‚Äôt be soon in the labour market, it gives them a brief overview of certain possibilities linked to the profession. Also, it provides them with some initial knowledge of technology. Having digital skills is not an asset anymore but an absolute necessity to access the labour market. Education is the main instrument policy makers want to promote in order to boost ICT sector skills and to enlarge its accessibility. This field should be considered by young people as a possible career option since it is estimated that 500 000 vacancies will be unfilled by 2020 in the ICT sector. The main aspects that would help to minimise the gender gap in the ICT sector is the sector itself. According to statistics, women are looking for flexibility in their work and this becomes the main reason why women start a career in entrepreneurship. The flexibility provided by the ICT sector is an asset to push better gender equality in the sector. Moreover, according to the EIGE, implementing more women in technological areas would generate an imrpovement in GDP of ‚Ç¨ 820 billion by 2050. The Commissioner Mariya Gabriel has announced that several programmes will be launched to work on expanding the presence of women in the ICT sector. From a policy level, Bulgaria is a very good example of successful combination between European, governmental and local initiatives since women represent about 35% of the ICT sector ‚Äî the highest rate across Europe. The workforce is facing new work structures and has to adapt to the new challenges introduced by the digital sphere. It must embrace the digital world to reinforce work capacity and competitiveness. Multidisciplinary skills are needed as far as digital skills are needed in all job sectors. The digital knowledge of workers must improve in parallel with the modernisation of the industry. The transition must act on both sides. It is a simultaneous improvement from both machines and the human capital. Either of them works without the other one. To this purpose, programmes are offered to workers to understand the skills required for new technologies. As briefly shown, Europe has launched many initiatives in order to solve problems related to the digital transition. By educating and giving people a chance to be familiar with the digital world, Europe can tackle the number of people without any technical skills and level up the number of women working in the ICT sector. -- -- EYIF is the leading foundation for youth innovation across Europe. We give a voice to the community of innovators and mentors. Here you can read their stories. Help Status About Careers Press Blog Privacy Terms Text to speech Teams

Title: Stadia: La nueva entrop√≠a de Google
Subtitle: No nos perdamos, Google no es un ente altruista.
Author: Daniel Garc√≠a Miranda
Article: Sign up Sign in Sign up Sign in Daniel Garc√≠a Miranda Follow Igeneris -- Share Otra vez Google ha puesto en pr√°ctica su dominio en esto de los ‚Äújuegos‚Äù digitales para hacer acto de presencia y acaparar toda la atenci√≥n del mundo, no sin fama, no sin motivos, sobre todo con motivos. Lo ha hecho con la misma marcialidad y pericia que aquel chulo de barrio, que nos destrozaba a todos al Street Fighter o Mortal Kombat en los recres. Sabiendo que lo tiene muy f√°cil para ganar. Esta vez en el mundo del gaming. Mientras que en el panorama actual dos de los tres grandes protagonistas, Sony y Microsoft, se dejan querer hablando de sus nuevas improntas para el a√±o que viene, PlayStation 5 y Xbox Scarlett, (el tercero es el PC üòé), Google ha presentado Stadia, su servicio de streaming de videojuegos abstra√≠do completamente de comodities como los Blu-Rays o dispositivos f√≠sicos inmuebles. Vaya locura, ¬øeh? Sin duda alguna este momento es el m√°s adecuado y se est√°n dando una serie de condiciones especificas: la vida de las √∫ltimas consolas de PlayStation y Xbox llegan a su final, su p√∫blico objetivo -cada vez m√°s amplio seg√∫n avanzan los a√±os- es conocedor y consumidor de servicios streaming, ademas de que est√° preparado para un cambio de plataforma de videojuegos. En resumidas cuentas, tiene al p√∫blico entrenado para consumir servicios de streaming y listo para cambiar. Adicionalmente a esto, tenemos entre manos un sector que lleva m√°s de treinta a√±os tremendamente sustentado en dogmas que demandan ser quebrados, dogmas que apuntalan una situaci√≥n de quietud y cautividad: hasta ahora escog√≠as una consola y te subordinabas al listado de t√≠tulos comunes a todas las principales consolas, as√≠ como a una suerte de t√≠tulos exclusivos de la consola electa -n√≥tese el concepto de suerte-. Con Stadia hablamos de desordenar un statu quo, hablamos de introducir un alto nivel de caos, hasta el punto de generar una crisis positiva en un negocio anquilosado, hablamos de cambiar un sector de productos por un sector de servicios‚Ä¶ y todos sabemos lo que pasa cuando enfrentamos a una empresa que promociona producto frente a otra que promociona servicios‚Ä¶ Solo miremos atr√°s y recordemos en el ‚Äúda√±o‚Äù que hizo Napster. Si adem√°s tenemos en cuenta que el mundo del gaming, por lo general, se rige casi-casi por un paradigma de ‚Äúsuma cero‚Äù, similar al del mundo de los hinchas del f√∫tbol, donde el que tiene la Plei defenestra a la Equisb√≥s y al Pec√©, la apuesta del gigante californiano viene a hablarnos de lo que nos gusta, ignorando ese dogma y yendo m√°s all√°: el jugador. ¬°Por fin! Quedan en la retina hechos que son objeto de atenci√≥n, seguramente de aprendizaje para Google, y que despuntan dentro de un modelo harto replicado: casos como Steam, con m√°s de 50 mill√≥nes de usuarios y con 1,6 millones de compras mensuales. O el primer MMORPG importante: World of Warcraft (WoW) que manejaba cifras medias 5 millones de usuarios al a√±o durante m√°s de 10 en un modelo de suscripci√≥n de cerca de 13 ‚Ç¨/mes. O sin ir m√°s lejos los efectos econ√≥micos de los battle royale abanderados por Fortnite, con unos ingresos mensuales de unos 300 millones de d√≥lares en compras. Tambi√©n es rese√±able el anunci√≥ que hizo Apple en su WWDC del 2017 en el que, junto con su flamante nuevo iOS11, hablaba de un redise√±ado AppStore con foco en el gaming. Esto es importante: solo en Espa√±a, en el a√±o 2017, se gener√≥ una facturaci√≥n de 1.359 millones de ‚Ç¨ seg√∫n el Anuario de la AEVI (Asociaci√≥n Espa√±ola del Videojuego). Una aut√©ntica pasada para un sector con un segmento de edad que solo crece. Lo dec√≠a al principio de este art√≠culo y lo digo de nuevo: sobran los motivos para Google. Las cifras, o los motivos, son tan demoledoras que uno se pregunta por qu√© se ha tardado tanto en lanzar algo as√≠, por qu√© nadie ha decidido en invertir en grandes capacidades computacionales para destrozar un axioma: es necesario comprar un dispositivo -consola, ordenador, etc.- para jugar a los videojuegos. Al margen de los intentos previos de los otros players, la realidad es absolutamente compleja: es necesaria una inversi√≥n descomunal para abordar algo como Stadia, lo cual hace que solo unos pocos titanes empresariales y tecnol√≥gicos pudieran hacerlo. Y precisamente porque algunos de los titanes han posados sus ojos en el mundo del streaming -Amazon o Apple son claros ejemplos- las circunstancias para Google eran id√≥neas: ahora o nunca. Sus cifras, en el aspecto t√©cnico, son aplastantes: la capacidad de procesamiento de Stadia es superior a la suma de sus principales competidores en esto de los videojuegos, PlayStation y Xbox, juntas. Google nos dice que nos olvidemos de una vez por todas de comprar soportes f√≠sicos para disfrutar de un producto que va a acabar de convertir en servicio. Va a normalizar y convertir un ecosistema de producto en un universo de servicio. Pero no todo es tan bonito, me temo: uno de los requisitos t√©cnicos de Stadia es el ancho de banda que requiere, lo que hace que algunos pa√≠ses puedan verse penalizados. Hablamos de 30Mbps, es decir, unos 105Gb de tr√°fico a la hora. Son unas cifras muy elevadas, sobre todo si nos ponemos emp√°ticamente en el lugar de los proveedores de servicios de internet (ISP). Si nos ponemos a pensar en los costes extra de ancho de banda soportados por parte de Telef√≥nica o Vodafone una vez que Stadia rinda al 100%, podr√≠amos estar hablando de la criptonita de la neutralidad de red; sobre todo teniendo en cuenta la exposici√≥n que hizo Cesar Alierta ex-Presidente de Telef√≥nica, en el 2014 ¬°Esto es otro debate! La propuesta de valor de Google es l√≥gica y ambiciosa: Stadia empodera al jugador c√≥mo siempre se debi√≥ hacer, ofreci√©ndole jugar en streaming, donde √©l quiera: en un m√≥vil, en la tele, en un tablet, en un ordenador, independientemente de d√≥nde est√©, necesitando solo un mando que puede conectar v√≠a Wi-Fi. Se empodera porque el jugador ya no tiene que mirar de soslayo a la consola que no decidi√≥ comprarse y ver c√≥mo salen t√≠tulos exclusivos para ella, eso est√° abocado a desaparecer. ‚ÄòDamas y caballeros, ¬°las reglas del juego han cambiado!‚Äô Olv√≠dese el jugador de actualizar su consola o PC, de necesitar un desembolso de unos 400‚Ç¨ cada 4‚Äì5 a√±os en una nueva m√°quina, de gastarse 60 √≥ 70 euros cada vez que sale un videojuego, de pasar varias horas actualizando ese juego reci√©n comprado, olv√≠dese de eso: encienda su mando, elija el t√≠tulo y juegue al juego que quiera.‚Äô ‚ÄúStadia ser√° una nueva categor√≠a‚Äù, pensar√°n muchos. Yo no lo creo, la verdad, creo m√°s bien que asistimos a una nueva demostraci√≥n de la segunda ley de la termodin√°mica, en la que Google, una vez m√°s, es el catalizador de esa entrop√≠a. Bendito caos. Bendito desorden. Si te ha gustado el art√≠culo puedes suscribirte aqu√≠ a nuestra newsletter quincenal en la que mandamos solo 3‚Äì4 art√≠culos que nos parecen interesantes. Alguno suele ser nuestro, muchos otros no. Sin spam, prometido: ¬°Quiero suscribirme! -- -- Dise√±amos y hacemos realidad negocios, servicios y productos digitales que solucionan los retos m√°s complejos de nuestros clientes a trav√©s de la innovaci√≥n y la tecnolog√≠a. Digital Advisor. BlockChain Advisor. Tech Innovation. Rompo cosas. Technology Director @ Grupo Veterinario Kitican Help Status About Careers Press Blog Privacy Terms Text to speech Teams

Title: How Much Will a New Prime Minister Affect Business?
Subtitle: Don‚Äôt let politics hijack your business. Take charge of your own success.
Author: Pete Anniss
Article: Sign up Sign in Sign up Sign in Pete Anniss Follow The Startup -- Listen Share Regardless of your opinion of Brexit, I don‚Äôt believe anyone can say that UK and EU politics has been boring over the past couple of years. During this time of unprecedented uncertainty and disruption, as a UK based company, it forces us to take a step back and take a hard look at what we do when the sands under our feet are shifting day to day. Datum has manufacturing sites in the UK and US, a new location in Poland, as well as an office in Singapore. Within our UK-based business, our exports to the EU are a large part of our operations. Naturally, like any good business, we have contingency plans to mitigate the complications of any border disruption caused by Brexit with our facility in Poland. But the larger question is the future lifetime of ongoing business and manufacturing within the UK. There are many different viewpoints espoused by the new candidates for prime minister that will have varying long-term effects for the UK‚Äôs position and ongoing trade relationships around the world. If we look at actions that the large manufacturers have taken, we see firms such as Ford warning that a no-deal Brexit would be ‚Äòcatastrophic,‚Äô and Honda announcing plans to close its manufacturing plant in Swindon, UK. Many of these press releases, along with others, have been flagged as propaganda but the signals have not been positive for the UK manufacturing outlook. You can stifle the conversation, but the effects do not go away. There are so many possible outcomes from this political situation, and our viewpoint has always been to influence and control what we can, instead of waste time and money on things we cannot influence. Rather than complain about what might happen, we will set ourselves up in a position that we can thrive in any situation. At Datum, we constantly concentrate on creating things that people need and doing it better than anyone else. Our main market, surface mount technology (SMT), is constantly driven by miniaturisation and designing printed circuit boards (PCB) that give freedom to developers to create the new fancy phone or smart watch and the technology of the future. With this in mind, we have developed processes that open up the possibilities from a design perspective by increasing the accuracy of the products we provide. In doing this we have reduced the risk to future business from political uncertainty by taking charge of our own success and doing things nobody else can do. This will mean that, in the future, the value that we provide will be something that the market cannot get from anybody else. Even with the best talent and technology, we can never control politics or politicians; they will always be unpredictable. But we can control and influence our own capabilities. For a business to succeed you need customers, and you will only have customers if you provide something that they need ‚Äî investing into our products, processes, and innovations that help our customers is where we choose to invest. And it‚Äôs going to pay off many times over. -- -- Get smarter at building your thing. Follow to join The Startup‚Äôs +8 million monthly readers & +772K followers. European Director at Datum Alloys Help Status About Careers Press Blog Privacy Terms Text to speech Teams

Title: What It‚Äôs Like to Lose $1 Million in an Online Dating Scam
Subtitle: As dating sites and social apps proliferate, so, too, do scams
Author: The Cut
Article: Sign up Sign in Sign up Sign in Member-only story The Cut Follow The Cut -- 8 Share As told to Katie Heaney In 2018, the Federal Trade Commission received more than 21,000 reports about online romance scams, totaling $143 million in losses. As the number of dating sites and social media apps has gone up, so too has the number of romance scams reported ‚Äî from 17,000 in 2017, 11,000 in 2016, and 8,500 in 2015. Last year, the median loss reported was $2,600, which is seven times higher than the median loss for other forms of fraud tracked by the FTC. Most affected are people over the age of 70, for whom the median loss rose to $10,000. Online romance scammers work individually and in teams, often creating fake profiles using real people‚Äôs photographs in order to form close (if internet-based) relationships with unsuspecting victims, whom they eventually ask for money ‚Äî because they‚Äôre overseas in the military, because they‚Äôre sick, because they‚Äôre trying to buy plane tickets home, etc. Given victims‚Äô presumed complicity in these scams (because, technically, their money is given voluntarily), and the resulting stigma, it‚Äôs likely that online relationship scams are much more prevalent than even FTC reports suggest. The Cut spoke to the victim of one such scam, Debby Montgomery‚Ä¶ -- -- 8 Showing the world what women are made of. Showing the world what women are made of Help Status About Careers Press Blog Privacy Terms Text to speech Teams

Title: This Drone Is a Real Life Thor‚Äôs Hammer
Subtitle: Written by Cameron Coward
Author: Cameron Coward
Article: Sign up Sign in Sign up Sign in Cameron Coward Follow -- Listen Share In Marvel‚Äôs Thor, the titular character is a powerful Norse god portrayed by the equally-powerful Chris Hemsworth. Thor has many magical, super-human abilities, but it‚Äôs his hammer Mj√∂lnir that is particularly iconic. In-universe, the hammer can only be lifted by Thor, returns to him when summoned, and can be used to conjure storms and lightning. In short, it‚Äôs a nerd fantasy weapon on par with a light saber, and on the FliteTest YouTube channel they‚Äôve turned it into a working drone. This project was broken down into two major steps: constructing a replica of Thor‚Äôs hammer, and making it fly. The body of the hammer is hollow, and was made mostly from foam board that was cut by hand and then hot-glued together. However, the initial version wasn‚Äôt optimal for flight, and had to be completely redesigned and rebuilt. A coat of paint really sells the appearance, and they even made some armor to look like Thor‚Äôs garb. It was then time to make the hammer fly. It has a fairly standard drone setup that was made with common off-the-shelf components. The main challenge was to get enough air moving through the props to provide the thrust to fly. To do that, they integrated air ducts to channel the air through the hammer. With that work done, the hammer flies remarkably well for something so big and bulky, and the FliteTest team can now role-play as Thor whenever they want. -- -- Author, writer, maker, and a former mechanical designer. www.cameroncoward.com @cameron_coward Help Status About Careers Press Blog Privacy Terms Text to speech Teams

Title: Powerless to resist: Why creative industries cannot ignore the revolution of the Finite State
Subtitle: Creative Business: A contradiction in terms
Author: Jorge Ramirez
Article: Sign up Sign in Sign up Sign in Jorge Ramirez Follow -- Listen Share For companies or departmental business units where creativity is central to the purpose of generating value, there are two words that when in conjunction may seem a bit of a contradiction: Creative Business. The ideas conveyed by this phrase can seem incompatible. Those tasked with a managerial role in a company where creativity is a central activity are likely to understand what I mean. Whether it is web design and digital content creation or more traditional specialisms like advertising or graphic design, the act of creativity can be difficult to summon on command. It‚Äôs not like accounting, where you have a set of numbers and you apply some rules to achieve a result. The talents of creative people can‚Äôt necessarily be turned on like a tap. It‚Äôs not like maths where you simply punch numbers into a calculator. You can set up some processes and put your creatives into an environment that might be helpful to stimulate creativity, but there‚Äôs no guarantee as to how long it might take and how good the result is likely to be. It is this unpredictable nature of the creative process and the quality of the result that does not marry up well with the need for businesses to get things done in set time frames and to a consistent and repeatable standard. This seeming incompatibility is also reflected in the attitudes of creative people to rules. Creatives tend to see fixed ways of doing things, such as the strict rules that define processes, as bureaucratic. In the view of many creatives, such an approach kills spontaneity and gets in the way of creativity. In short, it ties them up in red tape and cramps their creative style. Despite this, creative businesses flourish by setting creativity free within a commercial environment. At the heart of a creative workflow sits the process of iteration and review. Working to a creative brief, collaboration within the creative company is the mechanism by which work is produced and reviewed, with changes requested and made. Additional cycles of review and iteration may be made until the output is perfected. Internal review is often required with changes requested by senior creatives, Project Managers (PMs) and Account Directors (ADs). Frequently, PMs and ADs take ownership of client-side relationships and filter communication between creatives and the clients. However, as successful as this approach is, it is not without a downside. It is inefficient and labour intensive, soaking up time because it requires manual tasks to manage and steer the passage of work through the process flow. At scale, with dozens of live projects and hundreds of creative documents across design routes and versioning, the precise position of every piece of work in the process flow is difficult to track and monitor. File sharing for drafts or final signed-off artwork files is critical in creative business. Email is of course the tool of choice, but it is far from ideal. It becomes flooded with attachments and filing often creates two different filing systems ‚Äî one for the written email content and one for the creative documents. Creative files are often large, (hundreds of MB or several GB in the case of videos or high res images) and so rendering email useless. In these scenarios, creative teams might turn to free platforms for file sharing. Again, this is far from ideal. With considerations like confidentiality and GDPR, using public cloud services is not best practice and may actually send out the wrong message about your creative enterprise. Clients pay good money for creativity and for some, such practices undermine the perception of value and reflect poorly on your business. Enterprise Content Management (ECM) is a class of software that enables companies to take control of document and file management. There are a multitude of solutions out there designed to solve the problem. However, not all are suited to creative environments, due to being overly complex or too rigid and inflexible. The best approach helps you to look beyond managing creative documents to let you handle process workflows as well. A good way of modelling document and process flows uses a simple system of circles, which represent a document or a process stage; and arrows, which indicate the actions that transition documents or take process flows from stage to stage. This is the finite-state machine (FSM) technique. Take a look at the simple example of daily feeding. A circle represents a state which the machine can be in at a given moment. An arrow that goes from state A to state B represents an action that can change the machine to state B, providing its current state is A. States are usually named as status descriptors (‚Äòhungry‚Äô, ‚Äòsated‚Äô) and transitions are usually named as action descriptors (‚Äòeat‚Äô) or events (‚Äò5 hours passed‚Äô): Figure 1. Sample Finite State Machine Diagram: Daily feeding Say we use an FSM diagram to define the workflow of iteration and review in a creative environment. The design document can only be at one of a defined number of stages at a time. The stages could be ‚ÄòBeing designed, ‚ÄòCreative director reviewing‚Äô, ‚ÄòSent to client‚Äô and ‚ÄòClient accepted‚Äô. The actions which transition the design document between these stages would be, ‚ÄòSend to creative director, ‚ÄòChanges needed‚Äô, ‚ÄòSend to client‚Äô, ‚ÄòClient says OK‚Äô: Figure 2. Sales Creative Process workflow using FSM Diagram Drag and drop tools simplify the modelling and design of document management and process workflows. This allows each creative business to define and order stages and actions in a way that is best suited to the way it wants to work. Where it integrates office process automation technology, ECM really comes into its own, saving a great deal of time. A key feature is automatic actioning of any transition based on given conditions. For example, when a document has spent X days at a given stage, a reminder is sent to the person responsible for moving it to the next stage. Such automated actions can be applied whenever a given condition is met. This way, creatives, creative directors, PMs and ADs do not have to concern themselves with repetitive tasks and only need to interact with the software when human intervention is needed. Layering in additional tools such as a metadata search, a PDF engine, digital signing and automated email enhances the power of a system, helping prevent important steps in managing creative documents and process workflows falling through the cracks. Ideally, with the system in the cloud, it brings the potential for additional capabilities and benefits. Secure cloud storage helps to protect intellectual property. This is an enabler of file sharing with clients and third parties by using web portals and secure direct download links. Security features might include password protection, expiry date, https and complete activity log and tracking with alerts, (such as when a client downloads a file). The corporate identity can be shown at all stages improving your client experience and your brand image. With app or browser interfaces there is also the potential to perform creative document management tasks with a single click on mobile devices. Generally, this helps smaller and growing creative companies as well as long-established creative enterprises to achieve a more polished and professional approach to document management and workflow. An appropriate FSM-based application that has been well thought out provides greater efficiency and certainty for managing creative projects. It helps to eliminate uncomfortable questions such as, ‚ÄúWho has been sent what and when?!‚Äù and so much of the time-soak and delay that occurs during iteration and review cycles. With an appropriate cloud solution, managing creative documents through their entire lifecycle and defining process workflows in a way that meets the demands of today‚Äôs creative enterprises have never been easier. Jorge Ramirez is the founder and CEO of R2Docuo. -- -- Jorge Ramirez is the CEO of https://www.r2docuo.com/, a cloud-based document management software made for business. It permits all types of knowledge from cars, equipment, sensible devices, and different daily subjects to be remotely accessible. IoT‚Äôs strength contributes to a lot of connected globe with improved living standards. The project demonstrates wonderful potential for the continuing growth of intelligent systems in an exceedingly broad spectrum of areas, like government agencies, agriculture. Fleet and plus management is one in all the sectors within which the IoT is reworking because it has ne‚Äôer been before, by linking cars, resources, providers, mechanics, conductors, and management. Fleet carriers have frequently been troubled to realize company goals at lower expenses whereas satisfying compliance necessities in ever-stricter security and economic setting. it‚Äôs not solely essential however conjointly a tough job to strike Associate in Nursing equilibrium between completely different variables, together with energy consumption, driver potency, automobile coupling, and road governance. because of the net of things technology, which might link facilities and data apps, fleet activities became greener, safer, and conjointly more cost-effective. Title: Mining and Staking, Simply Explained
Subtitle: We try to demystify what mining and staking is, in simple words.
Author: RockX
Article: Sign up Sign in Sign up Sign in RockX Follow RockX -- Listen Share To many newcomers or regular people who are not technically-inclined, understanding how the technology works can be a daunting task. In this article, we will quickly cover what a blockchain is, what makes it tick, and what mining and staking is. A database, in the most general sense, is computer structure that organize the collection of data. Companies rely on databases to store, manage, and retrieve information in order to power their applications. In other words, when a user sets up an account on an application, interacts with it, and transacts on it, all that information is stored in the company‚Äôs databases. In this situation, the control of the database lies with the administrators, meaning all access and permission must be maintained by a central authority. The administrator owns the master copy of all information collected on the application. The blockchain, simply put, is a database. It allows for the storage and retrieval of information for every user and transaction on the network. However, unlike a traditional database, blockchains do not rely on a central authority or administrator to maintain the database or process transactions. Instead, information is processed and stored across a global network of numerous machines, also known as nodes, each maintaining its own version of the database. This structure allows different people across the network to share information without the need of a central administrator. Essentially, there is no central point of failure in a blockchain; even if any node goes down, the blockchain remains unaffected and transactions can continue to be processed. Since there are numerous nodes maintaining its own version of the database, the blockchain needs to have a method to ensure that all nodes are synced to reflect a single state of truth for new transactions and wallet balances. This method is called a consensus mechanism. Once all nodes on the network have reached consensus, transactions cannot be censored and altered. Proof of Work (PoW) is a popular consensus mechanism first adopted by Bitcoin in 2008. For PoW blockchains, the consensus process is known as mining and some nodes are known as miners. To create and add a new group of transactions in a ‚Äúblock‚Äù to the blockchain, miners would compete to complete transactions by solving complex mathematical puzzles that is built into the algorithm. What miners are essentially doing is to guess a 64-digit hexadecimal number, called a hash, that is less than or equal to the target hash. Using sophisticated mining hardware, a miner spews out hashes at a tremendous rate until they come to a solution. The first miner to determine the solution gets to create that block and broadcast it to the rest of the network. In return, a block reward, in the form of newly created cryptocurrency, is released or ‚Äúmined‚Äù to that miner as a reward. All other miners will verify that the block is valid, then proceed to add that block to their version of the blockchain, and move on to compete for the next block of transactions. The probability of a miner solving the puzzle is equal to the miner‚Äôs computing power in proportion to the total hash rate of the blockchain network. The more computing power a miner possesses, the higher the chance of them mining the next block. The bitcoin blockchain, for example, currently has a difficulty of more than 12 trillion. That means the chance of a computer producing a hash below the target is 1 in 12 trillion. In order to be the victorious miner, hashes have to be spewed out at an incredibly fast rate. This is the main reason why bitcoin mining requires such an immense amount of energy and extremely efficient mining equipment. The difficulty of the bitcoin blockchain is adjusted every 2016 blocks, or roughly every 2 weeks, with the goal of keeping the rate of generating a new block at about roughly 10 minutes. The more miners there are competing for a solution, the more difficult the problem will become. Conversely, when computational power is taken off of the network, the difficulty adjusts downward to make mining easier. In simpler words, in a fiercely competitive open network, the miner who invests in more specialized mining hardware and has access to cheap power will likely derive more rewards from the network. Staking was first introduced in 2012 by Sunny King and Scott Nadal as a concept for the proof of stake (PoS) consensus algorithm in a cryptocurrency called Peercoin. There are variations in protocol design across different PoS blockchains but the general idea behind PoS consensus is that those who own the largest stakes in the network i.e. holding the most coins, are most likely to have vested interest to secure the network and deter fraudulent behaviour. Unlike a PoW system where users compete on computing power to mine new blocks, PoS blockchains use algorithms to randomly determine who gets to mine the next block. Typically, this assignment is based on the size of the stake committed by a user: The bigger the stake, the more likely a user will be selected to mine the next block. Instead of getting block rewards, users receive transaction fees as a reward for committing and locking up their coins. Compared to mining, staking requires much lesser energy and specialized hardware to participate. Because of this, staking is seen as a more environmentally-friendly consensus protocol. Also, because of the design of the consensus mechanism, PoS blockchains enjoy higher scalability and speed of consensus, meaning transactions on PoS blockchains can be processed faster and cheaper than PoW blockchains. There are many other consensus mechanisms being developed in other blockchain systems right now, such as Proof of Authority, delegated Proof of Stake, and Practical Byzantine fault-tolerant Mechanism. While they vary greatly in their approach, these consensus mechanisms have a common goal: To build an affordable, accessible, and open network where people can exchange value globally, free from censorship, oppression, and surveillance. You can participate in the blockchain industry by mining and staking on RockX. Don‚Äôt worry about the technical implementation and the hardware requirements: we have reinvented how users can get involved in a secure, user-friendly, and hassle-free manner. We are opening RockX up for community access soon. Stay updated by following us: Website: www.rockx.comTwitter: www.twitter.com/rockx_official -- -- RockX is bridging the gap to the digital asset economy. RockX is a digital assets platform that offers risk-adjusted crypto investment for the masses and allows users to compound their crypto holdings through mining, staking, and other DeFi products. Title: Race, Necropolitics, and the Human in an Age of Intelligent Machines
Subtitle: Published in What‚Äôs at Stake in a Fourth Industrial Revolution?
Author: What‚Äôs at Stake in a 4th Industrial Revolution?
Article: Sign up Sign in Sign up Sign in What‚Äôs at Stake in a 4th Industrial Revolution? Follow What‚Äôs at Stake in a Fourth Industrial Revolution? -- Listen Share This post is by Sylvester A. Johnson, Professor and Director of the Center for Humanities at Virginia Tech. In July of 2016, the Dallas Police Department set a precedent when officers deployed a Remotec robot to detonate one pound of C4 explosive in order to kill an African American suspect, Micah Johnson, who was suspected in the shooting deaths of five police officers. When news first broke that a robot designed for warfare against military enemies abroad had been deployed to kill a civilian shooting suspect, chiefs of police throughout the country immediately affirmed the killing and noted they possessed similar robots and would have taken the same action. For decades, science fiction films and books have conjured futuristic scenarios of robots and other intelligent machines killing humans or running amok. So, this killing in 2016 came as a shock to many casual observers accustomed to associating intelligent machines with fiction. For those who have been following the dizzying pace of developing AI robots and machines‚Äô intelligence, however, things are less surprising. For everyone, the fact that intelligent machines have now begun to play a role in matters of life and death opens a new chapter in the history of relations between humans and technology. It exposes the fragility of common assumptions about technology, race, and agency. And it implies that the domain of technology and necropolitics ‚Äî administering death and brutality ‚Äî will have to be theorized anew in an age of intelligent machines.[1] We are indebted to Achille Mbembe for theorizing what he has named necropolitics, the vertical assemblages of power affecting the ‚Äúgeneralized instrumentalization of human existence and the material destruction of human bodies and populations.‚Äù Moving beyond Michel Foucault‚Äôs theorization of biopolitics ‚Äî along with Agamben‚Äôs analysis of bare life and Carl Schmitt‚Äôs theorization of the political ‚Äî Mbembe urges that we interpret sovereignty and the nomos (the basis for ‚Äúright‚Äù) of our contemporary world through the lens of social data concerning the technologies of death, and political will to destroy populations of highly vulnerable people.[2] The robotic killing of Micah Johnson echoes the historical and enduring pattern of racial disparity in policing. Experts have repeatedly demonstrated that this pattern is a continuing form of lethal violence that US police departments use to engage Black civilians. (Consider, by contrast, that municipal police pursuing the White shooting suspect Dylan Roof swaddled him in a bullet-proof vest for protection after Roof murdered en masse a group of Black parishioners in South Carolina.)[3] Johnson, furthermore, was by no means the first suspect to create a violent stand-off with municipal police, but he will now stand in memory as the first US citizen on domestic soil to be targeted and killed by means of a state-deployed robot.[4] Why should we query the relationship between Artificial Intelligence (AI) and necropolitics? Succinctly, we live at a time when the furthest aspirations of military research in AI and human enhancement (synthetic biology and human-machine hybrids) are transforming the ability to alter our humanity and surveil target populations. What once seemed an unlikely convergence between questions of human identity and national security has now become imminent. In this context, the so-called new materiality ‚Äî to which scholars of religion have become attuned ‚Äî gains new urgency and prompts important rejoinders. The provenance of the most far-reaching and impactful AI machines and human enhancement technology is militarism, particularly understood as that greater complex of military-industrialism that links up elite levels of military executives, defense contractors, research universities, global commercialism (particularly weapons sales), technological corporations, and private banks. The race to achieve human-level intelligence in weaponized AI has emerged as a global pursuit, in tandem with plans for highly engineered biological human soldiers who might be combined with machines using implants, exoskeletons, and even methods of synthetic biology. Early results of these ambitions include brain-computer-interface (BCI) architectures. One application joins a human to a machine-learning system. This system then monitors a soldier‚Äôs brain, signaling to accelerate human analysis of surveillance video feeds. Other BCI applications restore motor and cognitive capacity to injured soldiers using brain chip implants. Autonomous weapons systems already exhibit capacities far greater than that of the Remotec used to kill Micah Johnson. Lockheed Martin‚Äôs AI-enabled joint air-to-ground missile (JAG-M) features ‚Äúfire and forget‚Äù technology. Once a fighter pilot launches the missile, the JAG-M missile does the rest, allowing the pilot to ‚Äòforget about it‚Äô and move on to another task while the missile interprets its video feed, distinguishes its target from the larger environment, plans its own course and angle of attack, and changes its navigation course on the fly to neutralize the target‚Äôs evasion tactics. It is currently considered unconstitutional in the United States for weaponized AI to kill human targets without a human participating in making the decision to kill (a human ‚Äúin the loop‚Äù). This should not elide the fact, however, that multiple autonomous weapons systems already exist with this capability. So, the technology is ahead of the policy. And it would be irresponsible to assume that the continuing development of autonomous weapons will be tamed by the current version of our legal theory. This is complicated by the fact that national security paradigms have thrived on the perception of racial threat to reinscribe militarism as an expansive canopy traversing both domestic and foreign domains. The internment of Japanese Americans; the deployment of the FBI‚Äôs COINTELPRO against Black liberation activists, the Chicano movement, and the American Indian movement; and the counter-terrorism measures that target Muslims as an inherent threat to the nation and the racial civilization of the West ‚Äî all evidence that state enemies are perceived beyond and within national borders.[5] This is why civilian policing has become increasingly integral to counter-terrorism operations. As military research yields more advanced forms of weaponized AI and human enhancement, the repercussions for racially targeted domestic subjects appear ominous. This is true especially in light of the militarized policing that national security practices have normalized since the 1960s. Such was, after all, the point behind the Dallas Police Department‚Äôs decision ‚Äî along with that of other police departments throughout the nation ‚Äî to acquire military robots for civilian policing. The increasing stockpile of weaponized AI by police departments is not for foreign enemies but for domestic targets. There is yet another dimension to this subject that will demand critical attention as well: the humanization of machines. Humans are rapidly accelerating the pace at which intelligent machines become more capable of performing cognitive functions ‚Äî thinking and reasoning. Deep Mind‚Äôs AlphaGo algorithm is a widely noted example, producing unprecedented insights into what is perhaps the world‚Äôs most complicated board game and easily surpassing the most skilled players. IBM‚Äôs Project Debater is another, able to listen and respond in real-time to humans debating a topic to provide a richly data driven and shrewdly formed counter-argument on a given topic. Given the influential philosophical tradition that asserts thinking and reasoning are central to human identity, the advance of intelligent machines is raising novel concerns about the relationship between people and intelligent machines. At the heart of these questions are the debates over what it means to be human, whether machines can become human, and to what extent this will intersect with established practices of racialization.[6] Various writers, from Sylvia Wynter to Ray Kurzweil, have examined the category of the human in ways that interface with the implications of AI. Wynter has critiqued the long history of Europeans developing a racial conception of the human being by defining White men as the ideal human type, and all others as less than the ideal ‚Äî i.e., less human or not human. She argues that the European tradition of interpreting biological science has been a preeminently racist enterprise, which promotes White supremacism by locating evidence for race in the body. Wynter has examined neuroscience in order to explain how sociogenic factors (social reality, intersubjectivity, etc.) can change the way bodies actually work. And she emphasizes that sociogenic (i.e., socially derived or constructed) and phylogenic (i.e., biological) factors are equally central to constituting humans.[7] Wynter‚Äôs intervention should lead us to develop a more critical approach to the ‚Äúhuman‚Äù in the ‚Äúhumanization‚Äù of machines. As the human category is burdened by racial and colonial freight (the category has frequently functioned to distinguish among races, those fully human versus others), we could only naively regard the humanization of machines as a raceless enterprise. It is precisely on this score that Kurzweil‚Äôs assessment of human ontology becomes so useful. Kurzweil is completely uncritical of the racial architecture of science and politics. In fact, he has been rightly critiqued for his utopian view of technology: he assumes, for instance, that structurally-engineered racial disparity and necropolitics will play no role in the future of technology. His robust engagement with an informational paradigm for interpreting human ontology, however, is productively wed to the critique of race that Wynter advances. That is, by emphasizing informational capacity as central to not only humans, but also machines ‚Äî and more expansively, the material entities of the universe ‚Äî the interventions of Kurzweil and Wynter together enable an approach to assessing the human-object binary that contravenes the Platonic inheritances of Western epistemology; material no longer seems so foreign to informational capacity. Rather, it emerges as the means of that capacity.[8] If informational capacity ‚Äî the ability to embody or contain, relay, and manipulate information to produce knowledge, thinking and reasoning‚Äìis foundational for what we have called human experience, then it becomes firmly debatable that informational machines are perhaps already becoming human. The rapid ascent of intelligent machine systems witnessed over the past decade is surely a harbinger of things to come. It is most likely that we will meet with a continuing wave of unprecedented advances in technology capacity. The military-industrialism that continues to spawn the most ambitious AI applications and human-machine hybridization will not only produce socially beneficial technologies, but will also deepen the necropolitics that has shaped race governance. This, in tandem with the racial politics guiding the imagination of the human template for humanizing machines, presents a daunting challenge to those who might wish to instantiate a different politics for our human future, one not rooted in instrumentalizing disparity, death, and destruction of vulnerable populations. This will be the grand challenge for the race-critical guidance of technology in the years to come. [1] Kevin Sullivan, Tom Jackman and Brian Fung, ‚ÄúDallas Police Used a Robot to Kill. What Does That Mean for the Future of Police Robots?‚Äù The Washington Post, July 21, 2016. https://www.washingtonpost.com/national/dallas-police-used-a-robot-to-kill-what-does-that-mean-for-the-future-of-police-robots/2016/07/20/32ee114e-4a84-11e6-bdb9-701687974517_story.html, accessed 9/14/2016. [2] Achille Mbembe, ‚ÄúNecropolitics,‚Äù Public Culture 15, no. 1 (2003): 11‚Äì40. Mbembe further theorizes the architecture or race in the digital future of necropolitics in the opening to his Critique de la raison negre (Paris: La D√©couverte, 2013). [3] Dylan roof was eventually convicted of murder in December 2016 and was sentenced to death. https://www.theguardian.com/us-news/2017/jan/10/dylann-roof-sentenced-to-death-charleston-church-shooting. [4] Racialized practices of policing and incarceration have been repeatedly documented by expert studies since the 1800s (Ida B. Wells Barnett produced multiple expos√©s of such). The perduring practice of state racism in law enforcement is a major factor for understanding the necropolitical implications of using AI designed for warfare in context of domestic policing. Representative studies include Khalil Muhammad, The Condemnation of Blackness: Race, Crime, and the Making of Modern Urban America (Cambridge: Harvard University Press, 2010); Michelle Alexander, The New Jim Crow: Mass Incarceration in the Age of Colorblindness (New York: New Press, 2012); Paul Butler, Chokehold: Policing Black Men (New York: New Press, 2017); and Andrea Ritchie, Invisible No More: Police Violence Against Black Women and Women of Color (Boston: Beacon Press, 2017). In 2011, the US military used a drone to kill Anwar al-Awlaki, a US citizen residing in Yemen at the time. Al-Awlaki became the first US citizen to be targeted and killed in an ‚Äúextra-judicial‚Äù assassination, as he was classified as a terrorist and thus denied due process. See H. Jefferson Powell, Targeting Americans: The Constitutionality of the U.S. Drone War (New York: Oxford University Press, 2016). [5] Karen Alonso, Korematsu v. United States : Japanese-American Internment Camps (Springfield, IL: Enslow, 1998). Ward Churchill Jim Vander Wal, The COINTELPRO papers : Documents from the FBI‚Äôs Secret Wars against Dissent in the United States (Cambridge: South End Press, 2002). [6] Fei-Yu Wang et al, ‚ÄúWhere Does AlphaGo Go: From Church-Turing Thesis to AlphaGo Thesis and Beyond‚Äù IEEE/CAA Journal of Automatica Sinica 3, no. 2 (April 2016): 113‚Äì20. [7] Sylvia Wynter, ‚ÄúUnsettling the Coloniality of Being/Power/Truth/Freedom: Towards the Human, Afer Man, Its Overrepresentation ‚Äî An Argument,‚Äù CR: New Centennial Review 3, no. 3 (2003): 257‚Äì37. [8] Ray Kurzweil, The Singularity is Near: When Humans Transcend Biology (New York: Viking, 2005). -- -- A collection of papers from a workshop on the 4th Industrial Revolution A workshop exploring and critically examining the idea of the 4th Industrial Revolution. Title: The Future of Storytelling
Subtitle: Written by VRD Europe
Author: VRD Europe
Article: Sign up Sign in Sign up Sign in VRD Europe Follow -- Listen Share The immersive nature of XR is a challenge to those accustomed to creating narratives in traditional media. Films, theatrical productions and art works are written, directed and created as if the audience is looking through a window from one particular point of view. XR, on the other hand, is a completely 360 experience. Creators must become elaborate world builders, filling a larger space and considering an audience who could be looking anywhere at any given time. How can XR break away from these traditional writing perspectives and break the boundaries of 2D narrative? How are sensory and synesthetic tools used for storytelling with multi-sensory design? VR narrative goes beyond the hardware and software itself. It extends to the environment and atmosphere where the experience takes place in both the real and virtual world. Pulling from leading innovators in VR storytelling in 2019, we will explore a 360 experience, an interactive narrative and a live experience that demonstrate the future of storytelling in the immersive medium. 360 VR 360 VR has been critiqued as mimicking the 2D medium of film. What‚Äôs different? However, when 360 VR is used to grant perspective in stunning 360 visuals that accentuates presence in the narrative, it is highly effective. In Everest- The VR Film Experience, Sherpa Tenji attempts to climb Mt Everest without the use of bottled oxygen. His journey is captured by cameraman Jon Griffith with 8K 3D Ambisonic Audio Virtual Reality. It‚Äôs one of the few 360 experiences that truly tempts viewers to look up to wonder at the highest elevations on Earth, and down into the abyss of ice and snow and dangerous crags. By capturing the climbers and the greatness of the mountains in life size- viewers are invited to be a part of the ascent. Much of this effect would have been lost if not for the great attention to audio. Without life-like clear and spatial audio, 360 video can feel flat and distant. Howling winds, the steady crunch of snow under the climbers‚Äô shoes, strained breath and words of encouragement were so real and near that it was easy to cross arms across one‚Äôs body during this experience as if to protect from the frigid winds. Interactive and Non-linear Eleven Eleven, an original science fiction immersive narrative by SYFY and NBCUniversal International Networks, is an original multilinear narrative experience designed in every purpose for VR and AR storytelling. It‚Äôs a science-fiction narrative with multiple characters who are on a race against the clock as a planet ticks down to its final moments. Inspired by immersive theatre, the experience features multiple storylines running simultaneously on a common timeline- in real-time. Three distinct modes are available for the audience to have complete agency as an observer. Story Mode enables the viewer to attach to a main character and automatically follow them as a passive audience. Explore Mode is an active role where the audience can freely explore the world to follow secondary characters and search for clues to uncover the mystery of the world‚Äôs end. Finally, Goddess Mode empowers the audience to be omnipresent and view the world as a 3D board game of sorts where the entire narrative unfolds in a ‚Äòtable top‚Äô version of the story. With original music by Bleeding Fingers designed as a spatial score, a character‚Äôs individual soundtrack changes dynamically based on the users position- seamlessly mixing with an alternate character‚Äôs scores as a user navigates between stories. ‚ÄúIn a traditional TV show or film, every viewer sees the same frame, at the same time, every time and the composer creates a musical soundtrack to suit. With Eleven Eleven, since we have no idea where users will be looking at any given moment, it posed a unique challenge when composing the score. We decided to create a ‚ÄúSpatial Score‚Äù for each character that fluidly adjusts in volume based on a users‚Äô proximity to that character,‚Äù wrote Mehrad Noori, Director, Global Programming, NBCUniversal International Networks and Creator and Executive Producer of Eleven Eleven. Storytelling With Live VR The music and tech group Miro Shot is the first to tour a live VR concert, looking at the future of live entertainment with immersive tech. The story? Worldbuilding with future tech. What does VR mean in live performance? The group began staging DIY versions of their VR performances while based in an east London warehouse in 2017. ‚ÄúWe‚Äôd fill the building with smoke and blend the atmosphere of a gig with the sense of being physically present in the non-physical world that VR gives you,‚Äù said Miro Shot‚Äôs lead creative Roman Rappak. In a typical Miro Shot show the audience enter a room filled with projection mapping, dry ice, and atmospheric lighting. Once seated in VR headsets, the audience experience an audiovisual journey of virtual landscapes, live feeds of the concert, wind-fans, haptic seats and custom scents, all soundtracked by the band. Miro Shot is looking at immersive experience beyond the VR headset. Theatrical elements such as smoke, wind, temperature, projection mapping and more are a part of developing a new world for the music to enhance the narrative, both live and virtual. VR in these shows goes beyond what is seen in the headset. The pass-through camera enables the audience to see each other at times, to be connected to the physical space, and then to experience the world of the music itself, transitioned to a new reality. Researchers are also paying close attention to VR and music in a live setting. In Kent Bye‚Äôs podcast ‚ÄúNeuroscience & VR: Music, Body Sway, & Synchrony at the Institute for Music and the Mind,‚Äù he speaks with Laurel Trainor, Director of McMaster Institute for Music and the Mind. Trainor reveals that when people experience a live music concert together, they are more connected to each other as their brains are doing the same thing at the same time. These social cues gives us a sense of belonging and demonstrate the importance of people being physically synchronized with one another for social group dynamics. Music accentuates this feeling as people move to music together. When people move in synchronization- they feel inherently feel more connected. FoST at VR Days Europe In the Future of Storytelling, attendees will learn from leading visual storytellers as they showcase their works and explain the processes behind their creation. This year at VR Days join: Joris Weijdom, lecturer at HKU University of the Arts Utrecht and researcher and designer of mixed-reality experiences focusing on interdisciplinary creative processes and performativity; independent interactive story architect Michel Reilhac; Satore Studio‚Äôs creative director Tupac Martir; Double Eye Studio‚Äôs Kiira Benzing and more. -- -- VR Days is Europe‚Äôs biggest Virtual Reality Festival in Amsterdam. Three days of demos, speakers, film, and celebrations. November 13‚Äì15, 2019. Help Status About Careers Press Blog Privacy Terms Text to speech Teams

Title: New ways of collaboration. I3SIXTY digital flipchart product review.
Subtitle: Written by Anna Makovnikova
Author: Anna Makovnikova
Article: Sign up Sign in Sign up Sign in Anna Makovnikova Follow -- Listen Share At the beginning of my blog, I have promised not only to discuss the nuances of remote working but also to review some specific examples of technologies that allow to perform it more efficiently. Disclaimer: the mention of specific companies and products by me is not sponsored and/or not paid for. I write about what seems relevant to me and worthy of attention. If one day ads appear in my blog, I will definitely inform about this in advance. Today I would like to tell you about the new product from i3-Technologies ‚Äî i3SIXTY, which has been recently announced during Integrated Systems Europe (ISE) exhibition in Amsterdam. Considering my unquenchable interest in all the developments that are related to group remote collaboration, I have been following i3-Technologies for a long time, whose team creates cool innovative solutions that are applicable both in any business and in education. They create products that are needed by the market, integrating the latest technological achievements of the industry and finding them an elegant application within the framework of the task. Sometimes the birth of such products lies on the surface, but it is i3-Technologies that manages to put them into practice and fill them with useful features. It seems to me that this is exactly what happened with i3SIXTY ‚Äî a mobile and interactive digital flipchart. When I got inspired by its video presentation and shared it with my husband, he slapped himself on the forehead and exclaimed: ‚ÄúThis is brilliant! And it‚Äôs so simple that I don‚Äôt understand why no one had thought of it before!‚Äù In fairness, it should be noted that among the advanced business solutions I have already met a digital flipchart, namely Samsung Flip, that the company presented at the Consumer Electronics Show last year. Using Flip, up to four different participants can introduce their content or annotate directly on the screen at the same time using either their fingers or a dual-sided pen. The device is compatible through both wireless connectivity and USB, PC and mobile ports. I particularly liked the feature of rolling stream providing 20 pages of writing space, with embedded search functionalities available to instantly direct participants to specific content. And of course, Flip display can configure to portrait or landscape orientations to suit any meeting needs. However, with i3SIXTY, the i3-Technologies team went an extra mile, turning the digital flipchart, offering a 90-degree rotation of the display, into a full-fledged collaboration tool not only within one meeting room but also to interact with a remote team. To do this, the device is equipped with an integrated camera and dual mic, and it comes with a pre-installed Zoom application (my favourite one!) for video-conferencing. In addition to the usual writing on the whiteboard, i3SIXTY allows you to open the Web browser, take notes over the image, make a screenshot and then open it next to the other flipchart pages! And when the meeting is over, the work can be not only sent by email or transferred to an external device but also saved as a QR code, having scanned which each participant receives his pdf version of the file. How cool is that?! I think it‚Äôs better to learn more about the functions of i3SIXTY first hand by looking at the presentation of the company‚Äôs product manager. At the same time, on this video you can clearly see how easy it is to use the device so that it will not take months of training :) Of course, i3SIXTY is intended primarily for working with groups on the spot, because for a full-fledged remote collaboration it lacks the functionality to directly interact with the content for those who watch the presentation on the screen through a conference connection. However, for such tasks, there are other technological solutions with specially installed software, both in i3-Technologies and in other companies, about which I will definitely tell you another time. But if we are talking about large companies, where employees are regularly trained, about coworking and coliving spaces, about training centers, and so on, the advantages of switching from paper flipcharts and whiteboards to their digital counterparts are obvious. Imagine a trainer who should conduct a leadership seminar for the employees of several companies. Having rented any room he likes and that can comfortably accommodate the planned number of participants, he, using i3SIXTY, would be able to conduct training for all participants in the room, and also connect through Zoom those who for some reason could not attend his training in person. At the same time, the recordings on his flipchart would be simultaneously broadcast on the screens of remote participants, and in the end, using a microphone, they would be able to participate in a general discussion of the topic. The application of this technological solution in schools and universities is also endless. After all, it is possible to connect to the learning process even those who for some reason temporarily or permanently have switched to homeschooling. Every day I encounter the preconceptions about the introduction of principles and practices of remote work in modern international companies. And no matter how long their journey to the opportunity to work with employees around the world would be, when this happens, the best technologies, including i3SIXTY or Zoom, will already be there. What other solutions for the efficient work and interaction of the distributed teams are in the current business arsenal, I will be happy to tell you in the following articles. Stay tuned! -- -- Remote work ambassador. Citizen of the world. https://www.linkedin.com/in/makovnikova/ Help Status About Careers Press Blog Privacy Terms Text to speech Teams

Title: Virtual Reality and Augmented Reality Explanation
Subtitle: Another thing Augmented Reality
Author: Bilal Rao
Article: Sign up Sign in Sign up Sign in Bilal Rao Follow -- Listen Share Virtual Reality and Augmented Reality: Here we are talking about the hottest two technologies going around these days. The massive increase in their use has set their charts very high. They have been getting a lot of hype and one simply has to experience it to understand and appreciate it. Virtual reality definition: ‚ÄúBeing something in effect, though not in actual or in fact‚Äù It allows the user to interact with a virtual world right from the comfort of your living rooms. Virtual reality benefits are widely appreciated and very often come in handy. It is a computer-generated simulation or placement of one‚Äôs environment. It is designed to fool your senses and the unconscious mind as it cannot tell the difference in what‚Äôs a reality and what‚Äôs imagination. Virtual Reality environments can feel like your own reality. Virtual reality labs also exist in universities for an understanding of the limits of our brain‚Äôs perception. This is how virtual reality for education is being used. Virtual reality in health care is also a thing. For example, it is helpful for patients in cognitive behavior therapy. Virtual reality therapy can be used to diagnose and treat psychological conditions. On the other hand, virtual games, it‚Äôs apps also have a great amount of population under its influence. It requires specific hardware which not everyone owns such as a virtual reality headset. However virtual reality‚Äôs future is very bright and this technology surely has a long way to go. Augmented reality definition: ‚ÄúTo increase or to add ‚Äú It allows people to add digital elements into their actual environment. It is an enhancement of your real world with a set of magical virtual objects. Virtual objects can appear on windows, information can appear on walls. Just as if you were giving an augmented reality presentation. Augmented reality technologies have upgraded within years and augmented reality devices are within our reach. You most probably have interacted with augmented reality without even realizing it. I‚Äôm referring to social apps such as Pok√©mon go, Snapchat and Instagram yeah, we all have been there. Augmented reality for education is also quite liked as it gives the students a greater perspective. Augmented reality in construction is also an important tool as it gives the constructers the exact area and preview of the object or building they wish to build. Just like this, it has helped businesses on a whole new level. It has created a platform for businesses to come in contact with their clients. For example, if you wish to buy something lets say some shoes or furniture. Augmented reality will help, you can view the couch in your living room and see how it looks before purchasing it. The same goes for the shoes you can see how it looks, what size you fit etc. All of this within your comfort zone. Google Maps helps you navigate; you can view the direction on your smartphone easily giving you a clear picture of where you are driving. Augmented reality future also has a long way to go as it has become part of our daily lives and is quite beneficial in every aspect. For more information on new emerging technology, VR and AR and much more, explore our website FistFullTechnology. We are updating this website time by time with new content. ‚ÄúIf done right these technologies show incredible potential by passing through your attraction, AR and VR experiences will come in place‚Äù -- -- I am a student and have an interest in new emerging technology and how they are impacting the world.
