Title: How to choose expansion joint material
Subtitle: Written by Vexcoltindia
Author: Vexcoltindia
Article: Sign up Sign in Sign up Sign in Vexcoltindia Follow -- Listen Share Expansion joints refer to as movement joints copy such parts in our bodies as they extend and contract as required. These developments add to a structure‚Äôs general solidness. They work in bisecting a structure, similar to a structure, and making a hole. The hole is then filled to reestablish the structure and to twofold its capacity to withstand physical injuries. They are additionally utilized on building destinations to neutralize seismic action just as assistance secure the structure while different parts are worked around it. They ensure against solid breezes, hazardous temperatures, and other physical events that could influence the quality of a structure and its sturdiness. Temperature changes such as high heat causes the materials in a structure to grow and these joints check this extension by contracting. Doing so reestablishes harmony by re-packing the materials inside a hole to their unique size. At the point when temperatures dip under solidifying building materials can tighten. The extension at that point powers these materials to re-extend. The capacity of extension joints to enlarge and restricted controls structures‚Äô hole sizes, along these lines diminishing the requirement for fixes and other support methods. Side-strolls, scaffolds, railroads, and numerous structures use them for their pressure alleviating characteristics. Enormous air conduits use them to control changes in temperature. They are likewise found in funnels, where they help settle developments between discrete pieces of a structure. The expansion joint material ought to be versatile. Nonetheless, you ought not limit yourself to elastic, froth or other such substances. Keep in mind, the hole or mutually gave does not surpass in excess of an inch if there should be an occurrence of extremely enormous structures. Despite what material is being utilized, joints ought to be set in the middle of segments of a few structures for included help as they are pliable and versatile. The Expansion joints have altered what number structures are manufactured today. They lessen fix and support costs, consequently taking into account a more noteworthy assorted variety of structures to be constructed. They have demonstrated to have helpful characteristics that can withstand the many negative impacts that climate and different powers of nature posture to a structure‚Äôs general wellbeing and dependability. -- -- Help Status About Careers Press Blog Privacy Terms Text to speech Teams

Title: Teaching for the Future of VR
Subtitle: Published in Tech Trends
Author: Alice Bonasio
Article: Sign up Sign in Sign up Sign in Member-only story Alice Bonasio Follow Tech Trends -- Share The London College of Communication is teaching VR skills for the future immersive industry. Anyone with their finger on the pulse of immersive technology or even someone with a passing interest in all the subtle flavours of MR will be aware that immersive experiences are the future for many industries. There is simply no question about this, from entertainment to manufacturing and education, immersive tech is rewriting the rules faster than the actual hardware is developing. Right now, as a range of industries begin to realise the potential of immersive experiences the MR skills gap is yawning and unless we teach the next generation the right skills, that gap will continue to grow. Tech Trends has visited some of the relatively few, excellent, higher education immersive teaching facilities around the globe, notably the awesome Full Sail University VR Lab in sunny Florida but it turns out we need not look so far from home. Last year the London College of Communication, situated just south of the Thames at Elephant and Castle, launched their first VR specific course, and the LCC MA in VR is just the start. The MA Virtual Reality (VR) at London College of Communication provides the opportunity to explore and develop the application of VR technologies across filmmaking, visual effects (VFX), animation, games and immersive augmented reality (AR)‚Ä¶ -- -- Showcase for the latest disruptive technology that is changing the education landscape globally Technology writer for FastCo, Quartz, The Next Web, Ars Technica, Wired + more. Consultant specializing in VR #MixedReality and Strategic Communications Help Status About Careers Press Blog Privacy Terms Text to speech Teams

Title: Fulham Appoints Industry Expert Antony Corrie President & CEO
Subtitle: Written by Star One PR
Author: Star One PR
Article: Sign up Sign in Sign up Sign in Star One PR Follow -- Listen Share Bob Howard-Anderson named advisor to the lighting supplier‚Äôs Board of Directors. Hawthorne, CA, USA ‚Äî Fulham Co., Inc., a leading supplier of lighting components and electronics for commercial and specialty applications, has announced the appointment of Antony Corrie as President and CEO. Current President and CEO Bob Howard-Anderson was named an advisor to the company‚Äôs Board of Directors. ‚ÄúThe lighting market continues to be incredibly dynamic with significant opportunities and adding a leader with multi-decade experience in the industry is invaluable to Fulham,‚Äù said Howard-Anderson. ‚ÄúAntony is a proven leader who can direct Fulham successfully through its next phase of life.‚Äù Prior to joining Fulham, Corrie was President, Worldwide Sales for Harvard Technology, a supplier of energy efficient connected lighting solutions. He joined Harvard in 2012 after more than 18 years with Future Electronics, including time with its European subsidiary FAI Electronics. Corrie has a bachelor‚Äôs degree in Electrical and Electronic Engineering from The Manchester Metropolitan University. ‚ÄúFulham has an incredible customer set, team and history,‚Äù said Corrie. ‚ÄúThe company is a leader in the fast-growing Exit Emergency market, has an exciting portfolio of award-winning products beginning to ship, and I believe will continue to enhance and grow its market position. Now in its 25th year, I look forward to leading the company‚Äôs next phase.‚Äù Howard-Anderson, who joined Fulham in 2013, has driven the company‚Äôs transition from providing primarily Fluorescent, Induction and other legacy technologies to providing an industry-leading portfolio of innovative LED Drivers, Exit/Emergency, and Light Engine products and technologies, which now makeup the majority of Fulham‚Äôs sales. New processes he implemented aid in shortening time-to-market, R&D efficiency as well as expanded the company‚Äôs presence in Europe and the Exit/Emergency and emerging Lighting Control markets. For more information, visit http://www.fulham.com. About FulhamFulham Co., Inc. is a leading global provider of intelligent, socially-conscious sustainable commercial lighting components and electronics for use in commercial general lighting, parking structure, signage, horticultural, UV and other applications. The company develops and manufactures a variety of award-winning LED and emergency products, lighting controls, as well as legacy products across multiple lighting platforms. Fulham sells its lighting solutions worldwide through original equipment manufacturers (OEMs) and electrical equipment distribution channels. Headquartered in Hawthorne, Calif., the company has sales and/or manufacturing facilities in the Europe, China, and India. For more information, visit http://www.fulham.com, @FulhamUSA or @FulhamEurope. Media Contact:Andy FirchauMarketing ManagerFulham Co., Inc.Phone: +1 (323) 779‚Äì2980, ext. 1252afirchau@fulham.comhttp://www.fulham.com -- -- Help Status About Careers Press Blog Privacy Terms Text to speech Teams

Title: 10 Military Technology That Has Made Its Way To The Consumer Market
Subtitle: 10 Military Technology That Has Made Its Way To The Consumer Market | Tech Blog
Author: Saurav Bhattacharjee
Article: Sign up Sign in Sign up Sign in Saurav Bhattacharjee Follow -- Listen Share www.viainsider.com Military, the group of men and women responsible for the protection of a nation and its general population. So, its no wonder most of the technological revolutions started their journey from being a program for the military. In this blog we will get to know 10 such technological achievements which had begun as a military prototype and is now a part of our daily life. THE INTERNET The Internet or the World Wide Web was not always what we see today. On the current day, what we see is a refined network which connects the entire world and is made consumer friendly. However, its origin is traced back to the World War II era. It was the Cold War that led to the need for ARPANET(Advanced Research Projects Agency Network ) formed by the U.S. Governments ARPA(Advanced Research Projects Agency), currently functioning as DARPA(Defense Advanced Research Projects Agency) and the beginning of the modern Internet. It was originally developed by the U.S. to make communication between universities, research labs, and defense department convenient and secure, especially during the event of a war, back in 1977. For years to come, it was only accessible to academic and military elites. Finally, in early 80s, ARPANET was split into civilian and military domains. In the next decade, the civilian network was open for commercial use, which lead to the rise of local ISPs (Internet Service Providers). In the same decade, rudimentary browsers were developed, which made things more accessible to the general public. The rest is history, as the power of Internet disrupted traditional communications systems, mainstream media, and businesses. GLOBAL POSITIONING SYSTEM (GPS) GPS is so common that every smartphone uses it to find its location. However, it was in the 1960s, that the DoD (Department of Defense) developed the original Global Positioning System, as a successor to radio-based navigation systems. The idea was to use satellites to determine a user‚Äôs position on Earth by measuring his or her distance from three peripheral satellites in a process known as Trilateration. The system would require 24 satellites. While the system became fully operational in March 1994, it captured the public‚Äôs interest long before then. It was originally used for military purposes, such as giving submarines accurate positions for missiles launched. This system was perfect for keeping soldiers safe on the battlefield but also for identifying targets, improving mapping, tracking plane trajectories and more. President Ronald Reagan ordered GPS to be made available to civilians once it was completed in 1983, while President Bill Clinton later declared that the highest quality GPS signal should be available as well. READ ALSO Technology is Transforming Travel and Tourism Industry GOOGLE STREET VIEW In 1978, DARPA‚Äôs Cybernetic Technology Office funded a project, called the Aspen Movie Map, where a group of MIT researchers mapped Aspen, Colorado with 16 mm stop-frame cameras, using cameras mounted on cars not unlike the vehicles Google uses to create Street View. The military took interest in the mapping to improve training simulations. Google asserts that Street View originated in a project at Stanford University. And by now, much of the planet has been photographed and mapped. Not only is Street View used by the military to simulate combat situations and for other applications, but the public as well. Today, people can experience the world without leaving their home. AUGMENTED REALITY During World War II, Royal Air Force (RAF) planes were equipped with gyro gunsights. This rudimentary AR sight helped the British pilots shoot the Nazi Luftwaffe aircraft‚Äôs with better accuracy. On the German side, similar technology was being developed by Zeiss, which now provides optics for Nokia phones. In coming years, RAF and its allies added radar information to the gunsight, which meant that the pilots no longer had to look down at the instrument panel for radar information and then scan the sky for enemies through the plane‚Äôs windscreen. In the 60s, Hughes Aircraft company introduced helmet mounted displays, first implemented by the South African Air Force. Recently, it captured the imagination of the masses after Microsoft introduced complex Augmented Reality headset, HoloLens. Game developers such as Niantic made the HUD tech mainstream by introducing it on smartphones. In short, the AR tech has come a long way from fighting Nazis to capturing imaginary creatures on a phone. JET ENGINE Air travel may seem to be much maligned these days, but it could have been worse if it wasn‚Äôt for the invention of the Jet Engine. The design was being worked on in the 1920s by an inventor, Frank Whittle. However, it didn‚Äôt get put into use until the Second World War by both the Allies and the Axis powers. In 1944 the world‚Äôs first jet-fighter aircraft took to the skies in the form of the Messerschmitt Me 262. READ ALSO Top Futuristic Technology will turn in to Realistic In the years that followed, jet engine technology continued to improve, with the development and advancement of things such as pressurized cabins (planes were beginning to fly higher) and air traffic control ‚Äî things that play a key role in modern-day air travel. DIGITAL CAMERA The Digital Camera technology was originally used in early spy satellites where they were used to capture high-resolution aerial images of enemy installations. The technology progressed in the military sphere, especially during the Cold War and in the 1970s the first self-contained Digital Camera was created. This early technology would take years to progress into the DSLRs we use today. Today, digital photography is everywhere, even in our pockets. DRONES Nowadays drones are such a common sight that regulating them has become a headache for governments and there are all sorts of consumer drones available, whether flying for fun or for professional photography and videography. Although, it was in 1863 that a New York City inventor Charles Perley patented a hot air balloon that functioned as an Unmanned Aerial Bomber, during the U.S. Civil War. UAVs(Unmanned Aerial Vehicles) would not be used again by the military until the development of radio control at the turn of the 20th century. Along with increased number of military operations, drones are also used in a wide range of commercial applications, including crop growth monitoring and watering, surveying, film-making, law enforcement, and personal enjoyment by hobbyists. RADAR An acronym for Radio Detection and Ranging, this system uses radio waves to find speed, altitude, range, and direction of moving objects like planes, ground vehicles, missiles, etc. developed before World War II for military research and development. Today, it‚Äôs used for a variety of purposes, both military and civilian, including air traffic control, weather forecasting, and in auto-car technology. Inadvertently, it was discovered that microwaves transmitted from radar equipment during WWII could also cook food, which led to the post-war creation of the microwave oven. READ ALSO The Mobile App Revolution has just Begun in 2019 COMPUTERS The original technology for computers was a lot more archaic than it is today. The original computers used punch cards and mechanical looms to solve problems. The technology improved at greater speed during World War II though, when an Electronic Digital Programmable Computer named Colossus was invented by Alan Turing to help decipher Hitler‚Äôs infamous Enigma code. The technology decreased the estimated duration of the war, playing a small part of helping the Allies win the war and kick-started the age of the modern digital computer. In the following decade, technology improved vastly and shrunk greatly, with computers, now fitting even in our pockets. BOEING 747 Boeing is one of the world‚Äôs largest weapons manufacturers. The Boeing 747 commercial airliner is perhaps the company‚Äôs most iconic product. Like most commercial jets in use today, the 747‚Äôs design is based on the Boeing 707, which in turn, can be traced to the Boeing 367‚Äì80. This model, nicknamed the Dash 80, was developed in secrecy by Boeing and unveiled in 1954. The plane was originally meant to test the long-range jet engine technology and was intended to be sold as a military tanker transport. Today, versions of the 747 are used by most major commercial airliners as well as by the military, including a version used as Air Force One. IN RETROSPECTION So, it does not take a foreseer to know what the future developments in technology in the commercial market may be. All it does take is a bit of insight into the military based technology currently being developed and voila, the future lies before your eyes. We really appreciate you stopping by and hanging with us! The best part of what we do is getting to connect with people. Please be one of those people and find us online and say hi!. Do stay connected with us to know similar kinds of Interesting Information. Help your friends to know what you know now by sharing this Blog. -- -- Entrepreneur at Via Insider. Title: Technology in today's hotel room
Subtitle: What do guests expect these days?
Author: Ben Schleef
Article: Sign up Sign in Sign up Sign in Ben Schleef Follow -- Listen Share Technology has moved at an incredible pace over the past decade. It touches so many aspects of our lives at work and also in private. Back in the days, when things were at a much slower pace, hotels were in a position to deliver technology to people which they could not have at home. Being it internet connections or solutions on TVs in hotel rooms like Pay-per-view. I remember the days when content providers were shipping hard-disks to hotels to update the content locally. The disks were highly encrypted to make sure no one can steal the latest movies and take them home. Times have changed. Technology at our homes or even in our pockets is far more advanced now. In most cases, hotels don‚Äôt offer any Pay-per-view content anymore. Everything is connected today. So it is only logical that guests first and foremost need a brilliant internet connection which works seamlessly and provides bandwidth to allow them to use any kind of services on the internet. But apart from an internet connection, what else do guests expect today in their hotel room in regards to technology? Lately, I heard many times, research is telling the hospitality industry that guests want the same technology they have at their homes. I doubt if that research is true or representative and if you really can or should trust that. If I had asked people what they wanted, they would have said faster horses. ‚Äî Henry Ford Even if true that doesn‚Äôt mean that it makes sense or is practical to have the same technology in the hotel room. I believe every home of guests is different. Let‚Äôs talk about TV. Does every guest at home has an LG or Samsung TV? Chances are not too bad that they don‚Äôt and in a hotel, you can implement all different kinds of TV models. Smart speaker? Alexa? Google Home? Siri? Which one would a guest prefer and which one would be rejected to be used? Furthermore, all technology at home is customized to work in a way you expect it. With your WiFi at home. With your credentials at home. I believe it is not only extremely hard to match the same setup in a hotel room but also to meet things like data protection and privacy. What choices do I have as a guest to opt-in or opt-out? Let‚Äôs take a step back from technology for a second and still assume the guest expects the same as they were at home. The same bed? The same shower? The same pillows. The list of non-technology items could go on and on. Funny that no one ever talks about them but very specifically about technology. I deeply believe that guests are very smart and they know and figure out that they can‚Äôt have the same stuff as they have at home because they only stay a couple of days. At least for me, the word GUEST already indicates that they are not permanently in the hotel as otherwise, we would maybe call them RESIDENTS. Does that mean hotels should not care about technology in hotel rooms? They should care about it but in a way that is smart and seamless to match the requirements of its environment. Mistakes I see a lot are that hotels are trying to take the products, which are for the consumer market, and somehow squeeze them into hotels. In almost all cases that don‚Äôt end up in a happy end. Do you know what kind of people work in a hotel? You guessed it‚Ä¶hoteliers! It would be not fair to compare hotels to technology companies but lately, I got the feeling that people do. How do hotels then bring smart and seamless technology solutions to their rooms? Just to make that clear‚Ä¶you won‚Äôt find the answer to that in this article but let me share my thoughts on this. I mentioned already that hotels are not technology companies. What does it mean? They are not in a position to develop technologies themselves as they don‚Äôt have all these kinds of almost unlimited resources like Google, Apple, Amazon, etc. Hotels need to carefully consider which technology overall to ride. They have to be smart about their decisions on that matter and can‚Äôt follow any trend. Whatever technology they choose in the end, it needs to allow them to be flexible. Let‚Äôs dive a little deeper and see how it potentially could look like. I believe instead of pumping the hotel rooms with technology turn it upside down. Almost all guests bring the technology with them in their pockets. And it is a fact that by each generation these devices get more and more powerful. Let‚Äôs start the journey with the first point of getting the devices connected. That should not be too hard as guests WANT to have an internet-connection. I think it is almost not worth to mention that the internet should be free of charge, high-speed-bandwidth and bundled with a super easy and stable way of getting online. During that process, you could potentially already wire-up the device to the TV in the room in case the guest wants to stream their content to the TV. For content streaming, I would always prefer a system that is platform-independent but based on apps as especially popular apps run on both major platforms, iOS and Android, and allow streaming. Sure some basics have to be in place like WiFi or a TV. Going further from here things get a bit more interesting. Talking for instance about ‚ÄúMobile Key‚Äù. Instead of getting a keycard for your room you get a digital ‚ÄúMobile Key‚Äù on your phone which allows you to open the door. The door look needs to support that feature overall in the first place and you would need to have a hotel app in which a guest would receive such key. Do you see the flexibility here? If guests don‚Äôt want a ‚ÄúMobile Key‚Äù you could still issue them a normal keycard. I believe a dedicated hotel app can drive the technology further but lets the guest decide. The hotel app, if used by a guest, could be used as a remote control for the TV but there is always the regular control in the room. You offer a choice here. Instead of Alexa, Google Home or other smart speakers, you could integrate that into your hotel app. The guest can decide to use that feature or disable it. Independent of what you would like to control in a hotel room with a smart speaker, you are independent of the speaker hardware, you give the guest a choice and can even customize the language of the virtual speaker or let the guest decide because the hotel app knows from the device the language of a guest. And always consider flexibility. If your virtual speaker in the app can control the lights, for instance, you have the alternative of the light switch to the guest. Another thing might be that you can order services like food or other things within the app. If guests don‚Äôt want to use it they can still pick up the phone or maybe you the same options on the TV to be selected. The point is to focus on solutions that ideally are very light, easy to use and hardware-independent but flexible through software. I have mentioned some examples and ideas in which direction people in hotels should think regarding technology and some of them are not easy to get them done. It boils down to the point of carefully decide about the technologies to ride as a hotel company. We admire those fantastic and easy solutions which are offered to customers by Amazon, Google, Apple, Samsung, etc. Although they are easy to use, people don‚Äôt know how much heavy lifting it takes in the background by those companies to make them look easy and user-friendly for the customer. That is the magic trick of those companies and the reason why they are at the top. Hotels will be never in a position to do such heavy lifting but they don‚Äôt have to. Their main purpose is a different one. Hotels need to be smart about technology and make their bet of the right ‚Äútechnology horses‚Äù to ride to meet demands from guests. Finally, I would also like to mention the hotels which are the smaller, the privately owned, the family ones. The ones which don‚Äôt belong to one of the global hotel chains of this world and can‚Äôt even afford to spend any resource in technology. I believe having the basics like internet-connection and a simple TV is possible for almost everyone. All other fancy kinds of things I mentioned like an app, virtual speaker, mobile keycard, etc. Does every hotel need to have them? For me, there are two other things which make hotels very much unique and decides if guests will book them. One is the location of the hotel. It is a very unique feature that only one hotel can have at a time. Even if you build another hotel next door it is a slightly different location. The other more important one is people. Some would wonder why all the other items you can think of are not unique to a hotel. It is more or less an open market for every hotel. Everyone can buy the same comfy beds, same nice wall paintings, the same shiny tiles in the bathroom or even the same TV model. So what makes a hotel unique is not the technology or interior of a hotel but the people working there. Some would argue that even this is an open market because every hotel has access to the same resources on the market. And I would agree to that 100%. The difference it makes is how you treat the people you hire, how you inspire them, how you give them a safe environment to come to work each and every day. That creates the hotel guests want to stay in because humans are also social animals and they can sense if during check-in the receptionist is only processing or really welcome them to their home. A guest can sense if the employees you meet on the floor say ‚ÄúHello‚Äù because they have been told so or they want to. That makes the difference and drives loyalty so guests stay with hotels again even if they don‚Äôt can afford the latest technology in the room. -- -- Just a guy like all others in this world Help Status About Careers Press Blog Privacy Terms Text to speech Teams

Title: Bitparax, Instant Crypto Currency Exchange Service Provider Platform
Subtitle: Written by Yeni Hasli
Author: Yeni Hasli
Article: Sign up Sign in Sign up Sign in Yeni Hasli Follow -- Listen Share Cryptocurrency is a digital currency that was successfully issued by Blockchain technology, which is now widely used by the public. So that it will make users think repeatedly to make the exchange. The exchange rate of crypto is highly influenced by market conditions, which if many users use the currency, the exchange rate of that currency will increase. Likewise, fiat currencies require financial authorities to monitor fiat currencies, which are carried out so that the value of fiat currencies is stable and there is no inflation. Where the crypto currency also requires financial authority, however, the financial authority will only function as a medium that provides information on the exchange rates of various types of crypto money and also as a media that provides crypto currency exchange services such as Bitparax. In addition, another benefit to be gained is that users who make payments using Bitparax tokens will also get a 30% cost reduction by simply pressing the toggle button on the Bitaparax platform website settings. The Bitparax platform also provides various types of crypto currency exchanges that are most commonly used and have high exchange rates, such as Bitcoin, Bitcoin V, Bitcoin Gold, Cream, Digibyte, Dogecoin, Ethereum, Fenniecoin, iBitHub, Litecoin, Parax, UFO, USDT, USDT , Waves, Stellar Classic, Ripple and Zilliqa. Title: Can Capitalism Be Compassionate?
Subtitle: The Finterra Publication
Author: David Swinburne
Article: Sign up Sign in Sign up Sign in Home About  A technology-based company, FINTERRA is innovative, dynamic, collaborative and promotes community‚Ä¶  David Swinburne Follow The Finterra Publication -- Listen Share The global economy can be confusing and terrifying according to a recent NewsUSA article. The article opines that Financial experts, policy makers, and everyday citizens want to know: How will government policies impact our families and what can we do about it? It sites a recent book, ‚ÄúBroken Capitalism: This is How We Fix it,‚Äù by Ferris Eanfar and explains the state of the global economy and its key problems in a straightforward, accessible style. ‚ÄúWhen the 10 largest corporations on Earth have more combined economic power than 92 percent of all countries on Earth combined, the 50 largest financial corporations control wealth equal to 90 percent of Earth‚Äôs GDP [gross domestic product], the richest 1 percent of humans have more wealth than 99 percent of the world combined, and the eight richest humans have more wealth than the bottom 50 percent of Earth‚Äôs entire population combined . . . it‚Äôs safe to say humanity is in trouble,‚Äù Mr. Eanfar says. Mr. Eanfar‚Äôs work is based on over 20 years of unique experience in economics, financial technologies (‚ÄúFinTech‚Äù), blockchain/cryptocurrency development, artificial intelligence, and military and government affairs. Three key points in the book deal with issues of defining value, following a vision, and managing innovation. Value: The book notes that money is not value itself; it represents value. Rather than focusing on money alone, he advises organizations to focus on the way value flows through their stakeholder ecosystems, which benefits all parties in the long run. Blockchain and smart contracts are still in the early stages of a 20 if not 50-year adoption and maturation cycle. Some have compared it to 1994 and the web ‚Äî Brian Behlendorf, Hyperledger Vision: ‚ÄúIn business and in life, having ‚Äòvision‚Äô is about accurately assessing current reality, defining steps to achieve specific goals, and building a bridge between vision and reality based on discipline and effective execution,‚Äù says Eanfar. Innovation: Artificial intelligence, cryptocurrency, and other technological innovations can be used for good or ill. A chapter of the book is dedicated to the impact of artificial intelligence [AI] on government and the economy. ‚ÄúWhen lightning-fast A.I. controls the political and economic apparatus of countries through their automated manipulation of social media and web-based information channels, humans won‚Äôt be able to easily differentiate between policy outcomes that serve their interests and policy outcomes that serve those who control the A.I. and their political patrons in the government,‚Äù he says. It is these 3 areas that FINTERRA seeks to drive innovation in dealing with real world problems for both Global Industry and for socio-economic benefit of the worlds disadvantaged. About FINTERRA FINTERRA is a start-up FinTech company, specialising in harnessing and building solutions aimed at Global use cases and problem statements that are built on the GALLACTIC blockchain platform, positioning FINTERRA to be a global leader in next generation FinTech, providing ‚ÄúSocial Solutions for Blockchain‚Äù. FINTERRA has satellite offices and teams across Singapore, Kuala Lumpur, Hong Kong, Abu Dhabi and New York. -- -- A technology-based company, FINTERRA is innovative, dynamic, collaborative and promotes community growth, whilst advocating for mass adoption of blockchain technology globally, serving as a ‚ÄúSocial Solution for Blockchain‚Äù. Title: IoT: the human-machine interaction that unlocks new opportunities
Subtitle: The Internet of Things can be explained as the connection of devices to the internet using various software and sensors to enable communication and the exchange of data with one another. In other words, IoT makes the worldwide open to endless virtual opportunities and connections.
Author: Rick Blaisdell
Article: Sign up Sign in Sign up Sign in Rick Blaisdell Follow -- Listen Share The definition below might make you think that this technology available is only used in just a few industries. In fact, the IoT network is used in all sectors, giving them the opportunity to connect and monitor various devices and sensors, making people‚Äôs jobs more manageable as they don‚Äôt have to perform manual tasks that can be controlled remotely. How are things evolving with IoT? In the infographic below I highlighted facts and figures about the current status of IoT, the future predictions, as well as some technical details on how it functions. Are you part of this endless virtual network? How did that change your life? Leave your comment in the section below. Title: Vai na Web programa ‚ÄúTinder‚Äù do voluntariado com estudantes de Stanford
Subtitle: Published in vainaweb
Author: Vai Na Web
Article: Sign up Sign in Sign up Sign in Vai Na Web Follow vainaweb -- Share Match4Action √© um aplicativo que promete acelerar o impacto social, conectando volunt√°rios e iniciativas sociais no mundo todo. Iniciativa foi pensada na Calif√≥rnia e desenvolvida nas favelas do Rio por estudantes do Vai na Web Essa semana, 22 de abril, o Vai na Web colocou no ar, com abrang√™ncia global, o aplicativo Match4Action, uma esp√©cie de ‚ÄúTinder do Voluntariado‚Äù. O sistema conecta volunt√°rios com iniciativas sociais ao redor do mundo. O app foi idealizado por alunos de forma√ß√£o executiva, da Universidade de Stanford, e foi desenvolvido no Brasil, pelos estudantes de programa√ß√£o do Vai na Web, moradores de duas favelas no Rio de Janeiro: Complexo do Alem√£o e Morro dos Prazeres. A hist√≥ria do Match4Action surgiu no final de 2017, quando um grupo de alunos de diferentes pa√≠ses, da Universidade de Stanford, se reuniram para discutir e trocar informa√ß√µes sobre voluntariado e iniciativas de impacto social. ‚ÄúPercebemos que por mais que cada um fizesse um trabalho volunt√°rio, a nossa contribui√ß√£o para o mundo seria uma gota d¬¥√°gua no oceano. T√≠nhamos que pensar em como impactar milh√µes de forma exponencial‚Äù, explica Helio Mosquim, cofundador da ONG Match4Action. ‚ÄúInicialmente, o Match4Action foi desenhado especialmente para pessoas da √°rea corporativa, que desejavam encontrar oportunidades de voluntariado s√©rias e confi√°veis para ajudar quem precisasse. Quando conhecemos o Vai na Web, enxergamos que pod√≠amos ir mais al√©m‚Äù, lembra a brasileira Claudia Akel, membro do Match4Action e idealizadora do Impact Social Movement, situado em Miami, nos Estados Unidos, onde mora atualmente. Com um trabalho de design thinking dentro de algumas empresas se constatou que o movimento unilateral de conectar volunt√°rios corporativos e associa√ß√µes n√£o era o suficiente. Era preciso ser mais flex√≠vel e acess√≠vel ‚ÄúUma intera√ß√£o mais eficiente e profunda poderia surgir se pessoas f√≠sicas, de um modo geral, tivessem autonomia para atuar na sociedade, criando iniciativas de impacto para o seu bairro, cidade e at√© mesmo estado‚Äù, explica Aline, cofundadora do Vai na Web e executiva da empresa de tecnologia 1STi. O Vai na Web foi ‚Äúmatch‚Äù perfeito e o grande passo para dar vida para essa ideia. Os estudantes programaram o aplicativo, que foi apresentado na Universidade Stanford, no m√™s de mar√ßo deste ano. A representante da equipe, a jovem Evelyn Mendes e Aline Fr√≥es foram at√© Palo Alto, na Calif√≥rnia, apresentar a primeira vers√£o do sistema para os membros do Match4Action. ‚ÄúO desenvolvimento desse app foi muito al√©m do c√≥digo. Os estudantes foram respons√°veis pela investiga√ß√£o do problema ‚Äî junto ao time do M4A -, cria√ß√£o do design, desenvolvimento do frontend, backend, gest√£o do time, desenvolvimento √°gil e lideran√ßa‚Äù, explica Aline Fr√≥es. ‚ÄúFoi um incr√≠vel trabalho em equipe, que nos trouxe muito desafios e, ao mesmo tempo, muita satisfa√ß√£o! O app mostra a capacidade t√©cnica do Vai na Web de desenvolver software de qualidade. Eu tenho muito orgulho em fazer parte dessa hist√≥ria, que s√≥ est√° come√ßando‚Äù, aponta Evelyn Mendes. Como funciona o Match4Action? O aplicativo, que tem uma design bastante intuitivo, √© inspirado no Tinder, app de relacionamento. Os usu√°rios podem se cadastrar como volunt√°rios ou organiza√ß√µes sociais. A partir da√≠, eles podem pesquisar uma iniciativa existente compat√≠vel ao seu interess ou criar a sua pr√≥pria iniciativa, reunindo pessoas para defender causas relevantes. Todas as iniciativas publicadas na plataforma est√£o alinhadas com algumas dos 17 Objetivos do Desenvolvimento Sustent√°vel (Global Goals 2030), atribu√≠das pela ONU. Tanto as institui√ß√µes, como as pessoas f√≠sicas podem construir um perfis alinhado com os objetivos: igualdade de g√™nero, educa√ß√£o de qualidade, fome zero, erradica√ß√£o da pobreza, entre outros. ‚ÄúO Macth4Action nos permite criar uma rede de pessoas em todo o mundo que deseja fazer o bem, onde quer que esteja e sempre que poss√≠vel. Assim aceleramos o impacto social de uma maneira que n√£o teria sido poss√≠vel sem a tecnologia‚Äù, explica um dos membros do Match4Action, Saskia Verraes, da Nova Zel√¢ndia. A primeira vers√£o do aplicativo vai atender as √°reas de atua√ß√£o dos membros fundadores: S√£o Paulo e Rio de Janeiro; regi√£o de S√£o Francisco e Miami (EUA), al√©m de algumas √°reas da Nova Zel√¢ndia. ‚ÄúEstamos nesse processo piloto para que possamos aprender com as demandas dos usu√°rios e evoluirmos por meio da facilita√ß√£o em larga escala, gerando grande impacto social‚Äù, explica Mosquim que ressalta a compet√™ncia do time do Vai na Web. ‚ÄúUma ideia s√≥ tem valor quando ganha forma e se torna realidade. O time do VNW tornou um sonho realidade e vem nos permitindo gerar resultados verdadeiramente profundos.‚Äù Por enquanto, o aplicativo Match4Action est√° dispon√≠vel apenas em ingl√™s. Mas j√° √© poss√≠vel baix√°-lo nas lojas para Android e iOS. Vai na Web Criado em 2017, o Vai na Web, oferece educa√ß√£o digital avan√ßada e valores humanos para jovens de 16 a 29 anos de duas favelas do Rio de Janeiro: Complexo do Alem√£o e Morro dos Prazeres. O programa j√° formou mais de 200 estudantes, muitos desses jovens j√° est√£o empregados na √°rea de tecnologia e inseridos em cursos de ensino superior. Al√©m de ser focado em linguagens de programa√ß√£o, o VNW dedica 25% do treinamento para o desenvolvimento de habilidades socioemocionais, onde os estudantes aprendem comunica√ß√£o n√£o-violenta, eleva√ß√£o coletiva e diversidade. Por Mayhara Nogueira Para conhecer mais detalhes do trabalho do Vai na Web, acesse o nosso perfil no Instagram, Facebook ou Twitter. -- -- O Vai na Web √© um movimento de alta tecnologia e impacto social que amplia as capacidades humanas e requalifica a for√ßa de trabalho para encarar os desafios da Ind√∫stria 4.0. Acesse www.vainaweb.com.br O Vai na Web √© um movimento de alta tecnologia e impacto social que amplia as capacidades humanas e as requalifica para encarar os desafios da ind√∫stria 4.0. Title: Perception is no longer enough‚Ä¶Data has to take the lead
Subtitle: Digital Leaders
Author: Digital Leaders
Article: Sign up Sign in Sign up Sign in Home Newsletter About  Thoughts on leadership, strategy and digital transformation across all sectors. Articles first‚Ä¶  Digital Leaders Follow Digital Leaders -- Listen Share Written by Jason Turner, Director, Data2Action With nearly 25 years operational experience, I‚Äôve been lucky to lead some significant transformational change programmes. Whilst conventional thinking and previous experience have certainly played their part, my latter foray into industries and technology unknown, has often challenged my own approach and paradigms. Are previous experiences and knowledge a guarantee of future success or do Leaders need more ammunition? I think it‚Äôs safe to say that most of us recognise the unprecedented culture of change we now find ourselves in. Everyday emerging technologies are reforming and disrupting markets and this is placing new pressures on Leaders to act quickly to either protect their positions or seize new opportunities. Never has change been so pronounced and whilst choosing the right technology is a key driver to success, the ability and behaviour of the leader is often overlooked yet it is a critical success factor. Lack of clear vision and poor stakeholder engagement often results in some of the best solutions being relegated to the bin. As human beings, we have a tendency to rely heavily on our experiences, emotions and memories when analysing activity. When combined, these make up our perceptions and often shape our decision making. Combined with ‚Äòafter the event‚Äô management information, we all too often rely on our perceptions to help us predict what will happen in the future and use this to shape technology development. However in such a fluid and rapidly changing economy, relying on the past to predict the future simply isn‚Äôt enough. Where does this leave the Leader? As a species we are adept to change, and as we break new ground in terms of technological advancements, most would welcome the opportunity it brings. The birth of the internet was the platform to connect systems and as a result, we now find ourselves in a world where we are being presented with more and more data. Technology developments mean that the speed and variety in which this is being presented is relentless and as mere mortals, we simply cannot ingest this, thus the monumental rise of analytics. However data in its ‚Äònatural state‚Äô is often pretty worthless, it is the ability to question and harness the power of data that presents the greatest results. This is where businesses of the future are now flourishing. We are awash with research. 90% of the worlds data has been created in the last 2 years alone yet 80% of business data is going unused. Furthermore, research highlights that becoming more data centric leads to greater innovation, agility, opportunity and efficiency. However it has been found that most business decisions do not have a basis of fact (ie data) and thus we allowing our paradigms and perceptions to influence our decision. Are leaders truly making the transition from perception to data driven leadership? Its an old saying yet it is even more prevalent in todays world. Our team help business leaders solve specific problems such as using data to drive loyalty, improve efficiency, reduce costs or manage risks. However we consistently see the absence of basic data disciplines. Without available, accurate and actionable data sets, wisdom cannot be attained and such strategic imperatives will be left unsupported. In addition, in a world of digital transformation, the absence of effective data sets to help inform the leader often results in technology deployment that fails to deliver. How can you implement a solution when there was little clarity as to the specific objectives you were trying to achieve. We often see this in the implementation of CRM solutions. Often bought ‚Äòout of the box‚Äô, the provider gives a whole host of benefits but what does the Organisation wish to accomplish and are they all truly engaged? How many times do the solutions then fail to deliver and yet often the solution is to purchase further technology and the cycle begins again! So how do leaders make the transition and harness the value data can bring? Our three key steps to leveraging greater value for your business would be: Originally published at https://digileaders.com on July 12, 2019. -- -- Thoughts on leadership, strategy and digital transformation across all sectors. Title: Google Game Builder Hints at No-Code Game Development
Subtitle: Dice Insights
Author: Nick Kolakowski
Article: Sign up Sign in Sign up Sign in Home About  We report on tech job trends, new technologies, and much more.  Member-only story Nick Kolakowski Follow Dice Insights -- 1 Share If you‚Äôve ever tried to develop a video game, you know it‚Äôs a tough process. For starters, it‚Äôs a programming challenge; and on top of that, you need to be creative enough to build something that folks actually want to play. With a new platform, Google is trying to abstract away much of the coding from game development, allowing developers to focus on the creative aspect. This platform, known as Game Builder, is still in prototype, but it shows how gaming could become the next tech segment to embrace the ‚Äúno- and low-code‚Äù paradigm. (It‚Äôs also similar in some ways to Grasshopper, Google‚Äôs user-friendly attempt to teach programming newbies the basics of JavaScript.) Game Builder relies on a visual programming system where you drag-and-drop cards in order to construct the game‚Äôs actions. Those with some programming knowledge can build customized cards with JavaScript, and there are APIs and 3D models so that you can populate your game‚Äôs environment with active characters and settings. (Google has lots of 3D models available on its Poly repository.) This prototype is fully featured, allowing developers to focus on the granular elements of their levels (such as‚Ä¶ -- -- 1 We report on tech job trends, new technologies, and much more. Title: February ‚Äô19 | Consumer Experience Workstream
Subtitle: CX Release Package
Author: CX Workstream
Article: Sign up Sign in Sign up Sign in CX Workstream Follow Consumer Experience Workstream -- 1 Listen Share The Consumer Experience (CX) Workstream has put together a release package for public sharing and community feedback. This update includes links to the Phase 1 CX Report, CX Standards outline, and Consent Flow Prototypes, which will live in the reports section of consumerdatastandards.org.au. This post also highlights key recommendations and considerations, as well as details on the 2 week feedback period that will close at 5pm on Friday March 15. Please read this post in addition to reviewing the Phase 1 CX Report, CX Standards, and Consent Flow Prototypes. Links to each item can be found below in the relevant section. This report covers the findings and preliminary recommendations from several rounds of research conducted by Tobias, CHOICE, and Data61. The first draft of the CX Standards will be based on these recommendations and community feedback. PDF: https://drive.google.com/file/d/1OIRuDI0k2zQLMpRBP4Nu6od3w4vS4J0S/view?usp=sharing Google Doc:https://docs.google.com/presentation/d/1oA4d1T22FEg_i79mX8HlFHONStE93T4-3gctkm1Wh0I/edit?usp=sharing Data61 updated Phase 1 prototypes to incorporate recommendations and other considerations. The basis of these recommendations are in the Phase 1 CX Report. These prototypes cover two use cases: Applying for Credit and an Accounting Tool. These use cases are not indicative of what will be prioritised or provided for in the standards; they were chosen for research purposes. NB ‚Äî The InVision (clickable) prototypes may lack some interaction. If the interaction doesn‚Äôt appear to be working, clicking/tapping the screen will reveal a transparent blue ‚Äòhot-spot‚Äô to guide you. Apply for Credit Prototype (Data recipient: aBank; Data holder: ABC Bank) PDF: https://drive.google.com/file/d/197424OMrUb8wzHCNEG4dCyXSo2KYD9v3/view?usp=sharing InVision Prototype: https://invis.io/STQLQSU645P#/348930756_1-0-_Credit-ABank-_Loading Accounting Tool Prototype (Data recipient: The Accounting Tool; Data holder: ABC Bank) PDF: https://drive.google.com/file/d/1ObBR4Se7xIQJT2Dly1EFZQUA9YbvlHV0/view?usp=sharing InVision Prototype: https://invis.io/VUQLQWFP8AM#/348914615_1-0-_Accounting_Tool-_Loading This is the basic structure that we are proposing for the CX Standards. The first draft of the CX Standards will be based on the Phase 1 CX Report recommendations and community feedback, and as such the current CX Standards will be populated with content in later phases. We welcome feedback on the structure, what you feel we should/shouldn‚Äôt include, and what you feel should/shouldn‚Äôt be within our purview. PDF: https://drive.google.com/file/d/17o9P0gMgCZHvQ80JcjM2XRY9AnuiE1Hm/view?usp=sharing Google Doc: https://docs.google.com/presentation/d/1k1ibcy6ibkcu1eR_KPhKNLjuphT-htWr5LjUp_7R-kA/edit?usp=sharing The key areas of this update that require particular attention include: Some broader recommendations that need to be considered are listed below. These recommendations will be incorporated into the CX Standards pending review and wider consultation. 1. Basic purpose of data sharing to be shared with the data holder Based on our research, we recommend that the data holder receive the basic purpose of data sharing as part of the authorisation request. The current understanding of revocation is that revoking data sharing would cancel any associated product/service. This recommendation will allow consumers to better understand the consequences of revoking authorisation, including which services/products they may be cancelling. We believe this would go some way in mitigating revocation confusion (which was an issue) and would provide a more informed experience than revoking authorisation to e.g. ‚ÄòaBank‚Äô with no context or other information. This recommendation is not in the Phase 1 CX Report but is being made in anticipation of further revocation needs; it is yet to be fully tested, but including the purpose of data sharing in Phase 1 Consent Flow testing did assist with comprehension during authorisation flows. This recommendation has been discussed with ACCC but needs to be considered further, including by information security professionals and the wider community. 2. Standardised communication of consent duration We recommend that the duration of consent be communicated in standardised time-based units e.g. x minutes, x hours, x days, x months. This recommendation is specific to ongoing consent, but the research indicates value for consent duration generally as participant interpretation of ‚Äòonce-off‚Äô and ‚Äòone-off‚Äô were very inconsistent. We also recommend that month-based consent durations align to calendar dates rather than number of days. For example, if consent was granted for 12 months on January 1st 2019, it should expire on January 1st 2020. 3. Provide multi-channel revocation Participants indicated they would overwhelmingly choose to revoke their consent via phone, in-person, or email. At present, digital dashboards are proposed as the only means of revocation. We recommend that data holders and data recipients provide non-digital and email channels as initial contact points that can then guide consumers to digital channels to complete the revocation process themselves. The research indicates this is an important recommendation that will make revocation accessible and allow consumers who may not be digital-first users, but may provide consent physically (e.g. facilitated in-person requests) to initiate revocation in their preferred manner. This will be especially important for building trust, CDR adoption, and to protect the reputation of CDR if any unexpected developments lead to consumers seeking consent revocation. 4. Provide multi-channel communications We recommend that data recipients and data holders provide additional communications to consumers such as a downloadable Consent Receipt, email confirmations, and other information including how to review and manage data sharing or where to go to raise a complaint or report misuses of data. This will allow consumers to have a verified source of truth rather than being required to recall or record the terms of their agreement themselves. These communications may form part of a notifications framework. 5. What to disclose at a minimum to satisfy the ‚Äòunambiguous disclosure‚Äô Rule (7.13(d)) There should be a clear understanding of what constitutes ‚Äòunambiguous disclosure‚Äô of data use. To satisfy the ‚Äòunambiguous disclosure‚Äô Rule (7.13d) research results favour that data recipients clearly state: 6. Accessibility We recommend that the Consent Model reflects the WCAG2.1 guidelines and/or the GOV.AU content guide, but recognise that further work needs to be done to develop an accessible Consent Model standard. Further work should include testing readability, keyboard-only use, screen readers, text to speech, and possibly extending CX Standards to include other accessible formats like visual aids. This work would extend to those who have delegates, require a translator, or are assisted/requested in person to provide consent digitally but may not be digital or English literate. 7. Next steps For Phase 1, the CX Workstream engaged with participants considered to be vulnerable or in vulnerable circumstances, including those in financial distress and those with accessibility needs. A diverse range of participants was sought so that a wide range of scenarios and needs could be better understood to inform the development of accessible CX Standards. While Phase 1 fulfilled many of the requirements for the Consent Flow, there are some known edge gaps in consumer representation, accessibility, scenarios, and other requirements that would benefit from deeper investigation to develop a comprehensive Consent Model. Recruited participants for Phase 1, for example, did not include many younger participants (under 29), and this was skewed towards those who had experienced financial distress, and late adopters of technology. This has given us insight into some of these more critical needs for the CDR, and addressing these will facilitate CDR adoption more widely. There is a potential benefit to recruiting more Early Adopters in any agreed upcoming work as they are expected to participate in the CDR regime first and will have needs for seamless integration. ACCC and Data61 are currently exploring the need to conduct further research based on the Phase 1 CX Report recommendations, broader considerations, and other program requirements. This will consider, where applicable, further research and testing for a version 2 of the Consent Flow (consent, authenticate, authorise), including any potential proposed redirect flows. Further work being considered is expected to explore consent/authorisation management and revocation, re-authorisation, joint accounts, 90 day notification(s), and communicating accreditation. This work may also expand to accommodate the energy and telecommunication sectors. Although it is not Data61‚Äôs remit, this research will inevitably generate insights about consumer trust and privacy that will be communicated outward. The CX Workstream is currently putting draft RFPs together to help identify further research and further validate the CX Standards; achieve additional consumer representation; provide standardised and necessary guidance on consent to data recipients and data holders; and facilitate consumer adoption of the CDR so its value can be realised. There will be a 2 week community consultation period that will close on Friday, March 15th at 5:00pm. Feedback received during this time will be considered for incorporation into a first draft of the CX Standards. You can provide feedback via email, specifying the document, page, and component you‚Äôre referring to; via comments on PDFs; or in comments on Google Docs. You can find links to these documents in the relevant sections above. Please provide concise and actionable feedback wherever possible, and focus on the validity of the recommendations and/or the implications of findings and recommendations. We also welcome feedback on the scope of this work, the focus, and the usefulness of these presentations. You can sign up to our mailing lists here; find past updates here; and find other information on the Consumer Data Standards website. The other technical workstreams also have an online presence on GitHub. If you would like to participate in any of our discussions across the four streams or provide any feedback, you can do so via email to cdr-data61@csiro.au. Best regards, The CX Workstream -- -- 1 Updates from the Consumer Experience (CX) Workstream. We‚Äôre developing standards for the Consumer Data Right to provide consumers with a trusted and usable data sharing experience. Title: Tokoin to Support MSMEs‚Äô Acceleration of Hong Kong‚Äôs Trading and Tourism Industry
Subtitle: Written by Tokoin Official
Author: Tokoin Official
Article: Sign up Sign in Sign up Sign in Tokoin Official Follow -- 23 Listen Share Tokoin visited Hong Kong as the first country in our global roadshow to introduce Tokoin‚Äôs platform. As one of the world‚Äôs leading international financial centers, Hong Kong relies its economy on service-oriented businesses, as characterized by low taxation, almost-free port trade, and a well-established international financial market. Hong Kong‚Äôs global trading has been flourishing for being supported by its convenient supply chain industry, as well as its shipping and logistics type of business. In the late 20th century, Hong Kong was ranked as the seventh largest port in the world and second only to New York and Rotterdam in terms of container throughput. Not only well-known for its trading industry, Hong Kong is also popular for its tourism industry as it is one of the major pillars of the economy of Hong Kong. In 2016 alone, tourism industry contributed to around 5% of Hong Kong‚Äôs GDP and employed around 258.900 people, accounting for about 7% of total employment. In 2017, total visitor arrivals rebounded by 3.2% over 2016 to 58.5 million, of which overnight arrivals rose by 5.0%. The Mainland continued to be the largest source market of Hong Kong, accounting for around 76% of our visitors. The total number of visitors soared further by 9.6% in the first quarter of 2018 over the same period in 2017, mainly bolstered by 12.6% growth in Mainland arrivals. Tokoin aims to support the industrial sector with targeted utilization of its use cases. Particularly for Hong Kong, logistics and property use cases will be beneficial for MSMEs which often find it difficult to expand their business by opening a new branch and for business people who have the need for convenient access to their supply chain business needs. Tokoin can bring together the convenient ‚Äòmeet-the-needs‚Äô concept between Tokoin‚Äôs users and its partners. Providing easy access to business expansion opportunities, Tokoin can help its users obtain the credibility in a valuable data record as their collateral. As a platform which optimizes blockchain technology to establish a valid identity for and reputation of MSMEs, Tokoin offers a solution that allows Tokoin‚Äôs users to establish a trusted profile with security for all stakeholders in the ecosystem. Currently, in the world of MSMEs, there is one complex issue which cannot be solved easily, which is that the need for transaction data capture causes a roadblock in the MSMEs system itself. By leveraging blockchain which emphasizes on its decentralized capability to give incentives to users who contribute to the network, Tokoin plays its role by providing the correct data. The replication multitude of transactions could be made within minutes yet guarantee data integrity needed by MSMEs. This way, they could leverage their business in a sustainable way. By using blockchain, it also means that Tokoin implements encryptions that enable the system to transact faster but also more securely. Tokoin carries missions to help MSMEs in building a trusted profile with integrity, providing a virtual ledger for each user‚Äôs transaction, eliminating financial inclusion barriers, and increasing economic capabilities of the whole MSME ecosystem. Title: Are Running Watches Worth It For Casual Runners?
Subtitle: I was on the fence about buying a running watch, but six months ago I took the plunge.
Author: Benya Clark
Article: Sign up Sign in Sign up Sign in Member-only story Benya Clark Follow -- Share I was on the fence for quite a while about whether to buy a running watch: On one hand, I‚Äôm a casual runner, not going particularly quickly or entering races. On the other hand, I was having trouble with my pace, and using a phone to track my runs was becoming cumbersome. Also, I knew that if I was going to get a running watch, built-in GPS would be an essential feature for me, which meant I‚Äôd be spending at least $100 on the watch. Last December, I finally decided to get one after they went on sale for Christmas. After six months of running with it, my only regret is that I didn‚Äôt buy one sooner. Even as a casual runner, the benefits of a running watch have been huge for me. The first thing that I noticed was that my runs were much more comfortable without lugging around my cellphone. I‚Äôve always liked tracking my runs, but before getting a running watch, this meant carrying my cellphone with me at all times so that I could use a tracking app. -- -- I‚Äôm a lawyer turned writer from North Carolina. I write about sobriety, mental health, and more. Subscribe to my weekly newsletter at exploringsobriety.com. Help Status About Careers Press Blog Privacy Terms Text to speech Teams

Title: FLXO Is a Tool for Soft Robotics Exploration
Subtitle: Written by Jeremy S. Cook
Author: Jeremy S. Cook
Article: Sign up Sign in Sign up Sign in Jeremy S. Cook Follow -- Listen Share As Amitabh Shrivastava puts it, soft robotics is an exciting emerging field where robotic actuators are made not from rigid materials, but are instead designed to flex and adapt to their surroundings under pneumatic or hydraulic control. Exciting, yes; but as this technology is in its infancy, if you want to tinker with soft robotics, you need to design your actuators, source materials, and actually fabricate your device, creating a bottleneck to exploration. To address this need, Shrivastava has created FLXO, a series of prefabricated soft actuators which can be constructed on a standard 3D printer. They‚Äôre meant to integrate directly into the VEX robotics system, though with 3D-printed adapters, one could presumably use them anywhere. A variety of motions are shown in GIF form on his website ‚Äî including a linear actuator, bending actuator, and devices that combine 45 or 90 degree twists with linear motion. Build details appear to be thin at this point, so hopefully they‚Äôll be revealed soon. If you‚Äôre wondering how to actually get pneumatic power to these soft robotic contraptions, he‚Äôs actually got a solution for that (almost) ready to go. As we reported earlier Shrivastava is now crowdfunding a Programmable Air platform that facilitates Arduino pneumatic control. -- -- New Posts on Substack: https://techadjacent.substack.com/ Help Status About Careers Press Blog Privacy Terms Text to speech Teams

Title: Shared Machine Learning: Ant Financial‚Äôs Solution For Data Privacy
Subtitle: Published in SyncedReview
Author: Synced
Article: Sign up Sign in Sign up Sign in Synced Follow SyncedReview -- Listen Share Growing public awareness and concerns over data privacy are pushing tech companies to explore new ways to advance machine learning models without centralizing people‚Äôs personal data. One of the world‚Äôs largest financial companies, Alibaba subsidiary Ant Financial, recently introduced Shared Machine Learning (SML) as their solution for data privacy. Ant Financial has spent two years on the research and development of SML as a learning paradigm that can aggregate and process multiparty information while protecting the privacy of individual participants. Current data protection technologies are either based on Trusted Execution Environment (TEE) or Multiparty Computation (MPC) systems. TEE indicates a secure area for a third-party processor that protects data with confidentiality and integrity. Examples include SGX from Intel, SEV from AMD, and Trust Zone from ARM. MPC on the other hand is an emerging subfield of cryptography that jointly computes a function over data from different parties while keeping the data private. A recent example is federated learning, a distributed method Google introduced in 2017 to train models on a large corpus of decentralized data. Ant Financial‚Äôs SML solution combines TEE and MPC for applications in banking, insurance, and commerce. SML uses Intel‚Äôs SGX technology in its foundation layer and is compatible with other TEE implementations. The SGX-based SML method supports both online prediction and offline training. Online prediction models have a higher requirement for stability in load balancing, failover, and dynamic capacity expansion. One of the key technologies for improving stability is clustering, but conventional clustering solutions are not applicable on SGX. This prompted Ant Financial to design a new distributed online service framework as shown below. Unlike conventional clustering methods, in the SML framework each service will register and maintain a heartbeat connection with the ClusterManager (CM). This framework is able to: The framework supports a variety of commonly used prediction algorithms including LR, GBDT, and Xgboost; and enables prediction on encrypted data from multiple parties. In offline training, the SGX-based SML framework is compatible with Xgboost using LibOsOcclum and a home-grown distributed networking system to support data fusion and distributed training. Ant Financial is currently also using this solution to migrate TensorFlow. TEE-based shared machine learning on multiparty data works as follows: Ant Financial‚Äôs MPC-based SML framework has three layers: The MPC-based SML framework supports popular algorithms including LR, GBDT, GNN, etc. Below is the training process: The specific architecture of the training engine is shown below: Ant Financial also identified a couple of major differences between federated learning and shared machine learning: More information is available (in Mandarin) in this Ant Financial tech post.
