Title: Technology
Subtitle: Written by Vikash Chauhan
Author: Vikash Chauhan
Article: Sign up Sign in Sign up Sign in Vikash Chauhan Follow -- Listen Share Technology is the sum of techniques, skills, methods, and processes used in the production of goods or services or in the accomplishment of objectives, such as scientific investigation. Technology can be the knowledge of techniques, processes, and the like, or it can be embedded in machines to allow for operation without detailed knowledge of their workings. Systems (e. g. machines) applying technology by taking an input, changing it according to the system‚Äôs use, and then producing an outcome are referred to as technology systems or technological systems. The simplest form of technology is the development and use of basic tools. The prehistoric discovery of how to control fire and the later Neolithic Revolution increased the available sources of food, and the invention of the wheel helped humans to travel in and control their environment. Developments in historic times, including the printing press, the telephone, and the Internet, have lessened physical barriers to communication and allowed humans to interact freely on a global scale. Technology has many effects. It has helped develop more advanced economies (including today‚Äôs global economy) and has allowed the rise of a leisure class. Many technological processes produce unwanted by-products known as pollution and deplete natural resources to the detriment of Earth‚Äôs environment. Innovations have always influenced the values of a society and raised new questions in the ethics of technology. Examples include the rise of the notion of efficiency in terms of human productivity, and the challenges of bioethics. Philosophical debates have arisen over the use of technology, with disagreements over whether technology improves the human condition or worsens it. Neo-Luddism, anarcho-primitivism, and similar reactionary movements criticize the pervasiveness of technology, arguing that it harms the environment and alienates people; proponents of ideologies such as transhumanism and techno-progressivism view continued technological progress as beneficial to society and the human condition. -- -- Help Status About Careers Press Blog Privacy Terms Text to speech Teams

Title: Few Years More‚Ä¶
Subtitle: Written by Franck Vinchon
Author: Franck Vinchon
Article: Sign up Sign in Sign up Sign in Franck Vinchon Follow -- Listen Share Transhumanism is an international cultural/intellectual movement that aims to transform the human conditions by developing and making widely available sophisticated technologies to greatly enhance and transform human intellect and physiology. The most common transhumanist thesis is that human beings may eventually be able to transform themselves into different beings with abilities so greatly expanded from the current condition as to merit the label of post human beings. Julian Huxley came up with this word, animated by a family tendency to reinvent the future, with his brother Aldous. That may lead us to be defeating the odds of life for sure from now on, to beat death in the next steps. The human desire to acquire new capacities is as ancient as our species itself. We have always sought to expand the boundaries of our existence, be it socially, geographically or mentally. There is a tendency in at least some individuals always to search for a way around every obstacle and limitation to human life and happiness. We don‚Äôt even talk about all the eminent people that approached this theory through the centuries: Sumerians, Taoists, Greeks, Albertus Magnus, Thomas Aquinas, Giovanni Pico della Mirandola, Isaac Newton, Thomas Hobbes, John Locke, Immanuel Kant, the Marquis de Condorcet and more recently Elon Musk, Dmitry Itskov, Ray Kurzweil and his boss Larry Page in the company Calico. Let‚Äôs be honest, the process is definitely in process, and limited only by the primitive nature of our existing interface tools ‚Äî our body capabilities for instance. We already carry around devices that collect and store all the information we need, supplement whatever lacks we may have and provide us with access to information sources from around the world in a snap. Quite naturally, this has raised the question of whether or not increasing reliance on such devices and applications is affecting our natural intelligence. A study at Columbia University demonstrated that subjects were significantly less likely to remember information that they knew they could easily access again using a search engine. Is this proof of diminishing mental capacity? Why commit to memory something you can easily access otherwise? Engineers and scientists may no longer be able to regurgitate many of the formula they use on a regular basis, but they don‚Äôt have to. Not if they understand what the results mean and how to apply them. Using media to amplify our capabilities has been going on ever since our distant ancestors. And certain skills may indeed be diminished when a new medium emerges to serve the same function with greater efficiency, much in the way that written histories supplanted the oral traditions of earlier cultures. Whether or not increasing reliance on digital media and mobile devices compromises our innate capabilities is a question no one can answer. Some people have a natural sense of direction; their capabilities may well be enhanced by the access to additional information. What ‚Äòsingularity‚Äô speaks to is bypassing the sensory interface tools we now employ in favor of direct access between the mind and digital media and possibilities. It‚Äôs pointless to grieve over the loss of learned skills once they have limited relevance. Infinitely more important is the potential impact that new and enhanced human capabilities will have on society. The most apparent of these will be the difference in ability between those with the desire and financial strength to embrace the new technology and those who do not. This divide will very likely be manifest along socioeconomic, religious and generational lines. Will those who refuse or lack the resources to take advantage of neural augmentation be able to coexist, let alone compete, with those who embrace it? Are we prepared to address the conflicts certain to arise when some members of society share this digital version of opportunities while others do not? What about the ability to perform complex calculations in seconds, or retrieve information instantaneously? Neural augmentation promises to level the playing field among those who accept it by compensating for individual cognitive deficits. Ironically, it also has the potential of creating an immense rift between those who enjoy its advantages and those who do not. As far as marketing fields is concerned, it is impossible to predict what effects singularity might have on communication. The first thing we understand is that ‚Äòimmortality‚Äô sells. The numerous companies created so far, all in different aspects of the evolution, are aiming to make incredible business along the way. But we need to admit that marketing is again slightly behind when you see all the evolution done so far. At its most basic level, marketers and advertisers concern themselves with instilling a particular message in the heads of people to whom it has relevance. We achieve this through the use of engagement and entertainment, and frequent exposure through a variety of media. How will ‚Äòsingularity‚Äô affect the way marketing agencies use media? Will it alter the ways in which advertisements are integrated with people‚Äôs existing information-gathering habits? With enhanced mental capacity and capability, and instantaneous access to global networks, will the concept of entertainment for those so enhanced change radically? Will mass media and digital advertising continue to be relevant for those with neural augmentation? Marketing and advertising will certainly continue to exist, but we will face larger issues to find the formats they take social and psychological change that result from the singularity. And we tend to forget about the brands themselves in this new paradigm that will definitely shape the next generation‚Äôs behaviors and beliefs. The brands will have to adapt to a new world, not only in the way they talk to people and deliver their messages but also in product development ‚Äî corporations will have to create new offers to match the new people‚Äôs expectations, we will have to dig deeper in micro-tribes depending on their new capabilities and advancements, the brands will have to change their promise to make sure their brands continue to be relevant to a new ‚Äòenhanced‚Äô world. And we don‚Äôt start to think now about the new brands or the new products that will have to address new needs, brands will have to adapt to this ‚Äòsuperhuman‚Äô world ‚Äî and maybe one day, facing the possibility to never die. Whether it happens soon or in hundreds years, the integration of enhanced human beings with marketing, advertising and media will clearly define the next stage in human evolution and establish the future direction of our socio-political and cultural systems. -- -- Founder Neon42, sports & entertainment-inspired marketing, brands and innovation consulting. Multi-awarded. Show runner, music addict, story maker, hardcore fan Help Status About Careers Press Blog Privacy Terms Text to speech Teams

Title: The End of Moore's Law
Subtitle: Written by Ariq
Author: Ariq
Article: Sign up Sign in Sign up Sign in Ariq Follow -- Listen Share Our day to day lives are driven on the performance of technology. Whether it be through a car, a laptop, or even the device you are using to view this now, technology is so commonplace that it seems easy to forget the power these devices grant us are the press of a button. Anything that is computerized are created using semiconductors. Semiconductors are substances that conduct electricity and have partial properties of both conductors and non-conductors. These devices can be created individually, but many more are found embedded in integrated circuits (IC). This is essentially the brain behind the hardware we use daily. The shrinking of semiconductors and transistors have powered the past 50 years of advances in computing ‚Äî but we have reached a point where such innovations are coming to a halt. Enter Moore‚Äôs Law. Moore‚Äôs Law is named after Intel cofounder Gordon Moore. He observed in 1965 that transistors were shrinking so fast that every year twice as many could fit onto a chip, and in 1975 adjusted the pace to a doubling every two years. The chip industry has kept Moore‚Äôs prediction alive, with Intel leading the charge. And computing companies have found plenty to do with the continual supply of extra transistors. Intel announced their first stumble by pushing back its next transistor technology, with features as small as 10 nanometers, from 2016 to late 2017. Not only are there delays, but the company has also decided to increase the time between future generations. A technology roadmap for Moore‚Äôs Law maintained by an industry group, including the world‚Äôs largest chip makers, is being scrapped. Intel has suggested silicon transistors can only keep shrinking for another five years. What does this mean for you? Well Moore‚Äôs law is the essentially the reason why every new generation of smartphones and or laptops are thinner and faster than the previous. Without that constant innovation, our devices won‚Äôt have that new ‚Äúredesign‚Äù as often as we‚Äôve been receiving them. But not all is lost! To power the next generation of electronics, scientists are looking to rely on new concepts like quantum computing and neuromorphic computing. These technologies are able to perform computations in new ways that can be integrated theoretically or physically. -- -- Help Status About Careers Press Blog Privacy Terms Text to speech Teams

Title: Google T5 Explores the Limits of Transfer Learning
Subtitle: Published in SyncedReview
Author: Synced
Article: Sign up Sign in Sign up Sign in Synced Follow SyncedReview -- 2 Listen Share A Google research team recently published the paper Exploring the Limits of Transfer Learning with a Unified Text-to-Text Transformer, introducing a novel ‚ÄúText-to-Text Transfer Transformer‚Äù (T5) neural network model which can convert any language problem into a text-to-text format. The T5 model demonstrated state-of-the-art performance on GLUE, SQuAD, and CNN/Daily Mail datasets; and scored an impressive 88.9 on the SuperGLUE language benchmark ‚Äî just a fraction short of the 89.8 human baseline. Paper Abstract: Transfer learning, where a model is first pre-trained on a data-rich task before being fine-tuned on a downstream task, has emerged as a powerful technique in natural language processing (NLP). The effectiveness of transfer learning has given rise to a diversity of approaches, methodology, and practice. In this paper, we explore the landscape of transfer learning techniques for NLP by introducing a unified framework that converts every language problem into a text-to-text format. Our systematic study compares pre-training objectives, architectures, unlabeled datasets, transfer approaches, and other factors on dozens of language understanding tasks. By combining the insights from our exploration with scale and our new ‚ÄúColossal Clean Crawled Corpus‚Äù, we achieve state-of-the-art results on many benchmarks covering summarization, question answering, text classification, and more. To facilitate future work on transfer learning for NLP, we release our dataset, pre-trained models, and code. (arXiv) Synced invited Samuel R. Bowman, an Assistant Professor at New York University who works on artificial neural network models for natural language understanding, to share his thoughts on the ‚ÄúText-to-Text Transfer Transformer‚Äù (T5) framework. How would you describe the ‚ÄúText-to-Text Transfer Transformer‚Äù (T5) framework? T5 is an extremely large new neural network model that is trained on a mixture of unlabeled text (the authors‚Äô huge new C4 collection of English web text) and labeled data from popular natural language processing tasks, then fine-tuned individually for each of the tasks that they authors aim to solve. It works quite well, setting the state of the art on many of the most prominent text classification tasks for English, and several additional question-answering and summarization tasks as well. The most obvious new idea behind this work is that it is a text-to-textmodel: During training, the model is asked to produce new text as an output, even for training tasks that would normally be modeled as classification and regression tasks with much simpler kinds of output. However, this idea seems to have been chosen out of engineering convenience, and there‚Äôs no evidence that it‚Äôs necessary for the results they‚Äôve seen. Instead, what makes this work successful (and impressive) is that the authors took many of the best ideas from a number of recent works in NLP and did an extremely good job at rigorously testing and refining each idea as they added it. This yielded both a very well-tuned model and a lot of insights into the fine-grained design decisions that go into training a large general-purpose neural network on language. Why does this research matter? T5 represents the latest in a sequence of five or ten papers from the last couple of years on the same basic idea: training large neural networks on large amounts of unlabeled text, then fine-tuning them on labeled text for specific tasks. This series of papers has found that by refining and scaling that idea, we can achieve far better performance on most language understanding tasks than the typical NLP researcher might have thought possible. T5 claims the state of the art on more than twenty established NLP tasks. It‚Äôs extremely rare for a single method to yield consistent progress across so many tasks. That list includes most of the tasks in the GLUE and SuperGLUE benchmarks, which have caught on as one of the main measures of progress for applied language understanding work of this kind (and which my group helped to create). On many of these task datasets, T5 is doing as well as human crowdworkers, which suggests that it may be reaching the upper bound on how well it is possible to do on our metrics. What impact might this work bring to the field? I suspect that T5 will have a similar practical impact to many of the previous milestones in this line of work, like ELMo, OpenAI GPT, BERT, and RoBERTa: Many engineers who work on language understanding tasks in English will start to use a pretrained T5 model as a starting point for building systems, and many NLP researchers will work to identify and push past the limitations of the T5 model. Can you identify any bottlenecks in the research? From the perspective of researchers who want to use T5, its size is a huge obstacle: The full model is more than thirty times the size of established general-purpose NLP models like BERT, and these earlier models were already big enough to be difficult and expensive to use on commodity GPU hardware. I suspect that the existence of this model will help push more users toward Google‚Äôs Cloud TPU product, which was used for the experiments in the paper, and I suspect that there will be a great deal of work over the next year to try to reproduce this level of performance in smaller models. (Google‚Äôs ALBERT, which also came out recently, suggests some ways that we might make the target-task training process more efficient, and the NLP community has been increasingly interested in test-time model compression to speed up inference and better enable mobile applications.) From my perspective as someone interested in evaluation and fair competitions, the success of T5 presents another puzzle. Anyone who spends time using modern NLP systems, including systems built on other recent state-of-the-art networks like RoBERTa, will recognize that these systems are brittle, and often fail in un-human-like ways. Language understanding isn‚Äôt solved, even on well-studied languages like English, and even when we use tremendous resources. However, models like T5 are now showing human-level test set performance on most of the tests that the community has been using to measure understanding. If we want to be able to establish fair benchmarks that encourage future progress toward robust, human-like language understanding, we‚Äôll need to get better at creating clean, challenging, and realistic test datasets. Finally, and most importantly, models trained on large text datasets reliably learn a variety of human biases around things like race, gender, and nationality. For example, our SuperGLUE diagnostic tool (based on Winogender Schemas from Rachel Rudinger) shows that these models will often correctly classify sentences that involve stereotypical situations, like a a conversation between male doctor and a female nurse, but then fail on nearly identical sentences that break those stereotypes, like one with a female doctor and a male nurse. These biases mean that it‚Äôs often illegal or unethical to use models like T5 in products, or at least requires product engineers to do a great deal of difficult and task-specific debiasing work. Finding reliable and task-independent methods for reducing and controlling these biases is a huge open problem for NLP right now. Can you predict any potential future developments related to this research? This is a strange and exciting time to be working on NLP. The progress that we have made over the last few years has made it seem more and more urgent (and less and less crazy) to start talking about what it would mean to solvelanguage understanding. We clearly aren‚Äôt there yet, and it‚Äôs not possible to completelysolve language understanding without building a complete humanlike AI, but new building blocks like transformer neural networks, huge text datasets, and carefully-designed semi-supervised learning methods are starting to seem close. It doesn‚Äôt seem like we‚Äôve yet hit the limits of how well these methods can do. The paper Exploring the Limits of Transfer Learning with a Unified Text-to-Text Transformer is on arXiv. Related dataset, pre-trained models, and code are available here. About Prof. Samuel R. BowmanSam Bowman has been an assistant professor at NYU since 2016, when he completed PhD with Chris Manning and Chris Potts at Stanford. At NYU, Sam is jointly appointed between the new school-level Center for Data Science, which focuses on machine learning; and the Department of Linguistics. He is also a co-PI of the CILVR machine learning lab and an affiliate member of the Courant Institute‚Äôs Department of Computer Science. Sam‚Äôs research focuses on data, evaluation techniques, and modeling techniques for sentence and paragraph understanding in natural language processing; and on applications of machine learning to scientific questions in linguistic syntax and semantics. Sam organized a twenty-three person research team at JSALT 2018 and has received a 2015 EMNLP Best Resource Paper Award, a 2017 Google Faculty Research Award, and a 2019 SEM Best Paper Award. Title: Flutter Design Patterns: 0 ‚Äî Introduction
Subtitle: Introduction to a series of articles about OOP design patterns and their implementation in Dart and Flutter
Author: Mangirdas Kazlauskas
Article: Sign up Sign in Sign up Sign in Mangirdas Kazlauskas Follow Flutter Community -- 10 Listen Share Hi, I am Mangirdas, a software engineer and Flutter enthusiast from Lithuania. I have been following the Flutter journey since its version of 0.10.2 but realized that I have not contributed to the Flutter community, yet. So I am more than intrigued to introduce a new article series ‚Äî Flutter Design Patterns. In the series, I will do my best to describe OOP design patterns, their implementation in Dart programming language and appliance when developing applications using Flutter. Update 2022‚Äì09‚Äì15: I moved this blog to my personal website. For a better reading experience, up to date articles, interactive code examples and some extra content FOR FREE, check kazlauskas.dev. In each article of the series, I will overview a design pattern, implement it using Dart programming language, prepare a practical (if possible) example in Flutter and add it to the Flutter Design Patterns mobile application. The theoretical part about design patterns would be heavily based on the ‚ÄúGang of Four‚Äù (GoF) book ‚ÄúDesign Patterns: Elements of Reusable Object-Oriented Software‚Äù, which, in my opinion, is one of the most iconic software engineering books about software design patterns. This book contains more than 20 different OOP design patterns, so you can expect more than 20 articles in the series! I will do my best to be consistent and publish a new article to the series weekly. Hmm, ok, maybe I have jumped straight to the point but did not explain what is this series about‚Ä¶ OOP stands for ‚ÄúObject-Oriented Programming‚Äù. In simple words, it is a programming paradigm that uses the idea of objects to represent data and methods to manipulate that data. This idea lets software engineers write code that represents the real-world objects, the data they contain and their relations with other objects via corresponding code structures. If you have already written some code using Dart or any other OOP programming language (C#, C++, Java just to name a few), probably you saw and used classes, defined properties and/or methods inside of those classes, created class instances and operated with them, specified relations between different objects/classes ‚Äî that‚Äôs nothing less than Object-Oriented programming! OOP design pattern is a typical solution to a common problem in software design. In the GoF book, the purpose of a design pattern is described like this: A design pattern names, abstracts, and identifies the key aspects of a common design structure that make it useful for creating a reusable object-oriented design. A software design pattern is not about solving specific UI/UX problems (as it could look from first sight by noticing the word design), it is more about the code structure which is like a blueprint to solve a particular object-oriented design problem, issue in your code. By applying these patterns, you can speed up the development process, write code that is more flexible, reusable. However, the most difficult part of these patterns is to understand the main idea behind them, to identify places in your code where these patterns could be applied and which problems could be resolved. But that‚Äôs what this series is all about ‚Äî to introduce and provide the basics of several design patterns to help you choose the right one for your specific problem. As I have already mentioned, by introducing a new design pattern per article, I will also build a Flutter Design Patterns mobile application and expand its design patterns library step-by-step. Of course, this application is open-source and its code is already available on Github for all of you! The application consists only of three different screens ‚Äî the main menu, design patterns‚Äô category screen and design pattern‚Äôs screen. I hope you have noticed a little heartbeat animation in the main menu, as well as page transitions and content animations, which provide some dynamic to the application (I have spent a few hours implementing them, so, please, notice me senpai). To demonstrate how the application displays design patterns, I have created a new branch in the repository. I will not merge it to the master branch later (it is only for demonstration purposes), but by using these changes I will explain how a new design pattern could be (and will be!) added to the application. First of all, a new data object should be added to the assets/data/design_patterns.json containing information about the design pattern (id, title, description and route): Then a markdown file must be added to the assets/markdown folder with the same name as the previously set id in the design pattern‚Äôs JSON. This markdown would contain information about the design pattern ‚Äî usually, code snippets with some explanation on how the pattern is implemented. After providing a markdown file, the design pattern should be implemented and its example widget for the design pattern‚Äôs screen should be prepared. For this example, I have created a simple Hello World widget (introduction.dart): Finally, a new route should be added to router.dart file by adding the route name to the DesignPatternRoutes class (it should match with the route value in the design pattern‚Äôs JSON file) and adding a new DesignPatternDetails widget with a previously created example (lines 25‚Äì32): That‚Äôs all! After these steps, a new design pattern is available in the Flutter Design Patterns library: If I have missed something, do not hesitate to ask or just check the code by yourself, it is open and free for use! I hope this article encouraged you to learn more about OOP, design patterns or programming in general. New articles are on their way so stay tuned and happy coding! üëè Press the clap button below to show your support and motivate me to write better!üí¨ Leave a response to this article by providing your insights, comments or wishes for the series.üì¢ Share this article with your friends, colleagues on social media.‚ûï Follow me on Medium.‚≠ê Star the Github repository. www.twitter.com -- -- 10 Articles and Stories from the Flutter Community Google Developer Expert for Flutter & Dart | Read the blog for free on kazlauskas.dev | Let's stay in touch - https://twitter.com/mkobuolys Help Status About Careers Press Blog Privacy Terms Text to speech Teams

Title: Feeling Blue? This AI Will Text You a Confidence-Building Pick-Me-Up
Subtitle: PC Magazine
Author: PCMag
Article: Sign up Sign in Sign up Sign in Home About  PC Magazine: redefining technology news and reviews since 1982.  PCMag Follow PC Magazine -- Listen Share SMS your #mood, and Blue Fever‚Äôs AI responds with video texts intended to lift your spirits and build confidence. We spoke with co-founders Lauren Tracy and Greta McAnany. By S.C. Stuart In the days before the internet, emo teens retreated to bedrooms, put the needle on the vinyl, and listened to The Smiths (or whatever got you through the night). But now, staring at the ceiling or scribbling in a journal is replaced by a constant stream of carefully curated social media feeds, which can be confusing for teens in that tricky developmental stage of identity formation. Can technology, the very thing contributing to these feelings of inadequacy and FOMO, help young people cope? At PCMag, we‚Äôve tested a few emotionally aware concepts, from the listening network 7 Cups and an AI trained on relationship drama to Facebook Messenger and cartoon penguin therapists. More recently, we checked out Blue Fever, a service that sends mood-mending video texts on demand. A Techstars graduate, Blue Fever is currently part of USC‚Äôs Viterbi Startup Garage, an early-stage incubator for deep technology and AI-enabled companies. Here‚Äôs how Blue Fever works: Once you‚Äôve signed up, all you do is SMS your #mood to the service, and its AI tries to get you back on track with funny, empowering, enlightening, or just downright mad moments. We tried it, and it‚Äôs like having a friend (with some serious machine learning in its non-bio-based cortex) who doesn‚Äôt mind being bothered with your stuff at 4 a.m. We spoke with co-founders Lauren Tracy and Greta McAnany to find out more. Here are edited and condensed excerpts from our conversation. Lauren and Greta, what‚Äôs the concept behind Blue Fever? [GM] Over the past few years, we‚Äôd both noticed that the internet is moving from search-based retrieval, then social media browsing, to a more self-medicating, always-on consumption experience. We all spend hours binging on Netflix or mindlessly scrolling through our IG feeds, but this behavior isn‚Äôt conscious. We‚Äôre all looking for something, but not finding it. [LT] So we wanted to build an AI platform that provides an on-demand emotionally satisfying solution. Especially to underserved audiences, like teens and young women, who really need positive images to build confidence. [GM] We launched in June 2017, pivoted our business model and focus through incubation at Techstars, and are now building out our product, platform, and growing the audience. Blue Fever is a personal AI that delivers cool content? [GM] Yes. And the emphasis is on ‚Äúpersonal‚Äù ‚Äî not ‚Äúpersonalized‚Äù ‚Äî that‚Äôs an important distinction. Browsers can track my cookies and see what I‚Äôm watching, buying, or doing, and target ads at me. But that‚Äôs not really personal. Good point. The ads Google serves to me make me laugh (mostly). But when I tried out Blue Fever, I texted my #mood (#meh, as it happened to be) and got something which did, in fact, make me smile.  [LT] And you didn‚Äôt have to search for it. Blue Fever‚Äôs AI knows what to serve up. An empathetic but not a therapy AI? [GM] Right. Because, sure, Blue Fever might be therapeutic, but we‚Äôre not building a therapy tool. Our empathetic AI is more like a good, slightly older friend who curates the internet for you, based on your self-reported emotional state. Explain how you‚Äôre training the Blue Fever AI algorithm. [LT] We looked at whether we wanted to pull from other models, other curation types, particularly from other industries like music, gaming, movies. Then we realized that we needed to build our own. [GM] Mostly because so much of the work done to date isn‚Äôt aimed at our primary audience due to input bias. [LT] Right. Our Blue Fever formula is conversational AI, scaled off of the Dialogflow platform, developed at Google. We started with human-to-human interaction, feeding the neural net with IRL messaging, chat, talk, responses; teaching the AI the right 13- to 20-year-old female vernacular, and letting it learn from there. Authenticity is key. When I interviewed Stanford professor Dr. Alison Darcy, founder of Woebot, she talked about ‚Äúfeeding‚Äù her AI on geek speak like Doctor Who and Battlestar Galactica so 20-something young males could relate.  [GM] Absolutely. Our value system is built entirely on the trust of our users. We don‚Äôt have a product without that. [LT] The technology enables us to build this trust, but it learns from human input and is constantly undergoing validation. Your AI platform is ‚Äúhuman-in-the-loop‚Äù then? Constantly monitored by bio-based beings to make sure Blue Fever is communicating properly? [LT] Actually, instead of ‚Äúhuman-in-the-loop AI,‚Äù we call it ‚ÄúHai‚Äù [for] human artificial intelligence. You incubated Blue Fever at Techstars. What did you learn most there about running a startup?  [GM] Techstars was a real turning point for us as entrepreneurs. I like to say we went in as ‚Äúmedia founders,‚Äù because our original business model was about creating content, but we emerged from Techstars as true tech founders. Our mentors there, particularly Anna Barber [Managing Director, Techstars LA], kept hammering this message home to us: ‚ÄúThink about the problem in a new way, use tech to solve it.‚Äù [LT] So we did. And by the time we left Techstars, we‚Äôd evolved Blue Fever from a content play into a messaging platform with an AI component. We were in Anna‚Äôs first cohort of early stage companies, and she treated like us tech entrepreneurs from day one. ‚ÄúYou have a clear grasp of the problem, and a vision for how to solve it, and I‚Äôm going to bet on you,‚Äù [she said]. Her attitude made all the difference. Aside from your support from USC Viterbi Startup Garage, who are your investors and what was it about your elevator pitch that they really got? [GM] We have several early-stage investors. When Jesse Draper, founding partner of Halogen Ventures, heard our pitch about delivering personal messaging using AI, she said, ‚ÄúYou‚Äôre going to fix the problems in the media industry, I‚Äôm in.‚Äù Another big supporter is BlueRun Ventures. They liked our approach towards Gen Z, and their emotional lives. Their feedback was along the lines of: ‚ÄúWe see these two founders and they‚Äôre passionate and hungry. We‚Äôre going to back them.‚Äù How much did they give you, and what‚Äôs your revenue model? [LT] We‚Äôre not ready to talk numbers yet. We will ‚Äî hopefully in Q1 2020. Right now, we‚Äôre focusing on scaling up the product and getting it right. Can you share sign-up figures, or is too early for that too? [GM] What we can say, right now, is we‚Äôve got users in all 50 states and have handled a volume of 3 million messages via our platform. Short-form content is becoming a ‚Äúthing‚Äù in Hollywood now, not just inside YouTube. According to sources, Jeffrey Katzenberg and Meg Whitman are looking to spend $1 billion on ‚Äúbite-sized‚Äù items by 2025 at Quibi. [GM] The transition makes sense. Our lives have changed as services have become automated. For example, I used to drive everywhere, now I use rideshare. I used to cook, now I get delivery. We‚Äôre left with small moments which are perfect for short-form content. [LT] Which makes it even more important to have those small content moments curated especially for you, and for how you‚Äôre feeling. Are you expanding your core product to go further than teens/young women? [GM] Not right now. But that is the eventual goal. We are focused on building this for young women because they‚Äôre underserved with good, confidence-building, mood-mending content right now. And, as a business we want to start with a clear target market to differentiate ourselves. Finally, what‚Äôs next for you?  [LT] We‚Äôre heading to SXSW soon to speak on a panel on the tech, industry and enterprise track [on March 9]. [We‚Äôve been before but] this is our first time going as ‚Äútech co-founders.‚Äù [GM] Which feels really cool. Read more: ‚ÄúHow to KonMari Your Way to a Happier Digital Life‚Äù Originally published at www.pcmag.com. -- -- PC Magazine: redefining technology news and reviews since 1982. Title: My Content List #9 | Tues 7/30
Subtitle: Articles
Author: James R. Shecter
Article: Sign up Sign in Sign up Sign in James R. Shecter Follow -- Listen Share Note: I first learned of the following series of facts from Tom Friedman‚Äôs ‚ÄòThank You for Being Late‚Äô (which I‚Äôve ranted about before)‚Ä¶ If you‚Äôve heard me relay these before (note: I was, and still am, so amazed by this that I initially shared with damn near anyone who would listen), trust me it‚Äôs worth another read and an additional ponder‚Ä¶ SO, we know China is a far more technologically advanced society than the US. From its Black Mirror-esque surveillance state to its use of e-payment services (AliPay, WePay, and other near-Venmo equivalents), they leave us in the dust in far more tech-centric domains than is comfortable to admit. Double-clicking on the cashless aspect for a second, consider this: I‚Äôve seen estimates that 45‚Äì65% of daily transaction volume in China runs through those e-payment services. Regardless of where exactly the proportion is, it dwarfs that of the United States which is circa-20% max. Day-to-day, people in China aren‚Äôt even carrying around wallets anymore; they‚Äôre just using QR codes on their phone to scan and pay. And just about every merchant, ranging from a luxury store to a bodega-type market, has a QR code for customers to scan on their phones to shuffle money through the ether to where payments are due. Naturally, Chinese street beggars caught on, and now they‚Äôre often seen carrying QR codes linked to their own accounts, so that a prospective passer-by can scan and send quickly rather than fumbling awkwardly for a wallet, bill, or change. Even beggars in China recognize the benefits of efficient payment systems! That blew my mind in itself, but that‚Äôs not it‚Ä¶ The craziest part of this anecdote is what the beggars do once they‚Äôve collected a few dozen QR codes from passerbys‚Äô donations. As Friedman explains, these beggars then turn around and flip the lists to data-hungry merchants/brands, so those companies can better target their inventory and advertising to the local demographic (by cross-referencing the ‚Äúanonymized‚Äù profiles of QR Codes). THINK ABOUT THAT! Chinese beggars are jockeying for positions in front of higher-end companies NOT JUST because they have more affluent clientele but because THOSE COMPANIES ARE MORE DATA HUNGRY AND THUS WILLING TO PAY MORE FOR LISTS OF BEGGAR-COLLECTED QR CODES! Beggars in China carving out an intermediary position in a newly created market. Data is the new gold, new oil, new everything‚Ä¶ Holy... A few of the pieces below ‚Äî about how anonymized data isn‚Äôt really anonymized, how the US being on its way towards a cashless society , how drop-shipping can be wildly profitable, the daily grinds of food app deliverymen ‚Äî re-summoned the significance of this anecdote. There are entirely new markets, arbitrage opportunities, middlemen, etc. springing up as a result of the ‚Äòdynamic interconnectedness‚Äô that epitomizes the contemporary business landscape. Opportunities arise with dizzying frequency for small niches and large TAM prospects alike, and people/business/ideas jump on those prospects even faster. So how do we keep up and stay current, so as not to become instantaneously outdated in our worldview and skillset? ‚ÄúBy reading Content Lists like this, of course!‚Äù James typed cheekily. Got something to contribute? Think my reasoning is flawed? Drop me a note; I‚Äôd love to hear from you! Follow me @James R. Shecter. Or don‚Äôt. Here‚Äôs Where You‚Äôll See It First. | NYTimes Three Questions About the Future of the Marvel Cinematic Universe | Rob Bricken / OneZero Manager Research Matters Even More Than You Think | Institutional Investor Shopify and the Power of Platforms | Stratechery Is Cannabis A Modern Gold Rush For California Real Estate? | Forbes Was the Automotive Era a Terrible Mistake? | New Yorker Ex-Corporate Lawyer‚Äôs Idea: Rein In ‚ÄòSociopaths‚Äô in the Boardroom | NYTimes The $60 Gadget That‚Äôs Changing Electronic Music | NYTimes Magazine ‚ÄòTrump‚Äôs Going to Get Re-elected, Isn‚Äôt He?‚Äô | Tom Friedman, NYTimes Healthcare startups struggle to navigate a business world that‚Äôs set up for them to fail | TechCrunch ‚ÄòShark Tank‚Äô Television Program‚Äôs ‚ÄòMr. Wonderful‚Äô Invests in Guitars | StockInvestor The Audio App That‚Äôs Transforming Erotica | New Yorker Safe Deposit Boxes Aren‚Äôt Safe | NYTimes My Frantic Life as a Cab-Dodging, Tip-Chasing Food App Deliveryman | NYTimes 10 Years of ‚ÄòShark Tank‚Äô ‚Äî The Show that Explains America | The Outline How Blackstone‚Äôs Chief Became $7 Billion Man | WSJ The I in We How did WeWork‚Äôs Adam Neumann turn office space with ‚Äúcommunity‚Äù into a $47 billion company? Not by sharing. | NYMag Elon Musk‚Äôs Hyperloop Hit a New Top Speed of 288 MPH. Title: Momo Challenge Is Everything That‚Äôs Wrong with the Internet
Subtitle: Written by Lance Ulanoff
Author: Lance Ulanoff
Article: Sign up Sign in Sign up Sign in Member-only story Lance Ulanoff Follow -- 3 Share The other night, my wife flipped her iPad screen toward me, flashing me an image of Momo. With its deep-set, marble eyes, black matted hair, rictus grin, and hybrid female/bird body, Momo is a deeply unsettling image. I instinctively turned my head and asked why she‚Äôd shown me that nightmare right before bed. Of course, why should I be spared? The image of Momo has appeared on Facebook, Twitter, YouTube, newspapers, online media, and local and national TV. It haunts every corner of media and social media and, according to reports, may be inspiring impressionable young minds to carry out horrifying acts of self-destruction. Except that‚Äôs not what‚Äôs really happening here. Momo is in reality ‚ÄúMother Bird,‚Äù a bizarre Japanese sculpture of indeterminate origin. ‚ÄúMomo‚Äù refers to another part of the Momo Challenge origin story. The image originally started appearing on the wildly popular Chinese Momo flirting app where it was shared widely as an example of something they call ‚ÄúKimo Kawa‚Äù or ‚Äúdisgusting but cute.‚Äù However, the Momo mythology didn‚Äôt take off, according to Know Your Meme, until 2017 when the image became associated with a WhatsApp number. Why you‚Äôd want to call that face I will never‚Ä¶ -- -- 3 Tech expert, journalist, social media commentator, amateur cartoonist and robotics fan. Title: How Creatrixe is embracing digital transformation culture and what startups can learn from it?
Subtitle: Written by Creatrixe
Author: Creatrixe
Article: Sign up Sign in Sign up Sign in Creatrixe Follow -- Listen Share Startups often face difficulty in embracing trends and transforming themselves to adapt to change. That‚Äôs because they‚Äôre in a growing phase and trying to implement a sustainable business model to survive in the industry. This is the era of Digital Transformation, it‚Äôs continuously evolving and here‚Äôs how Creatrixe adapted to it. Developing an agile mindsetTempering with corporate culture is one of the most difficult things to change but since startups are developing hence it‚Äôs still malleable. Some companies often fall short of growing, because the top tier in the corporate hierarchy is focused on numbers. Ther sole focus is on quantifiable metrics like Return on investment in a certain category. Creatrixe understood that it is just as important to invest resource in a culture that nourishes an agile mindset, as it is to invest in anything else. The management should be committed to digital transformation to build employees‚Äô skill and competence. Communication is the keyBuilding an inclusive environment is also important so before the big launch, get employees in the loop. Create a ‚Äúget-through-guide‚Äù or make time to explain processes to employees on ‚ÄúHOW‚Äù the company is implementing digital transformation and be open to suggestions; another way is to create a communication platform. We encourage employees to be a part of the launch of any project. Build a team from across the company to deliver it. Use Open Source TechnologyWe understood that the best way to adopt digital transformation is to adopt open source technology like cloud computing, Deep machine learning, real-time analytics etc. These solutions are cheaper than intractable software licensing agreements. The combination of operations and innovation will prove to be a catalyst for transformation even if maintaining sustainable business operations is a priority. Customer is KingRemember: Customer and CRM are the two most important critical factors for your business. If you want to be the top option for your customers, you have to make them the center of every decision you make. The bigger companies have transformed through data-driven action. They have included inferred data from interactions with their customers in their corporate culture. This helps in understanding the customer more. We optimize user experience and keep it in mind while executing any related task and make an inventory of the data. Be it their comments on a certain design or the functionality of a certain API. It seems difficult and time-consuming but it is necessary to learn and grow. TransparencyMake the customer experience and feedback transparent to the people involved. It‚Äôs more difficult in a bigger company when sensitive and confidential data is involved. But if regulated data (which is necessary to share) is disclosed to stakeholders, it can help your transformation journey like ours. -- -- Help Status About Careers Press Blog Privacy Terms Text to speech Teams

Title: In defence of quibbling‚Äî tech ethics process not principles
Subtitle: Written by Miranda Marcus
Author: Miranda Marcus
Article: Sign up Sign in Sign up Sign in Miranda Marcus Follow -- Listen Share The other day I was listening to an episode of Revisionist History podcast by Malcolm Gladwell about 16th Century maritime insurance and baseball doping. The connection he drew was pretty tenuous. But it was interesting. Essentially Gladwell explores the method of Casuistry for solving ethical dilemmas for new problems. Casuistry is a process of reasoning created by the Jesuits. A very brief synopsis of this method would be that one examines this novel problem not by applying general moral principles, but by establishing a ‚Äòstandard case‚Äô (the word casuistry derives from the Latin noun casus meaning ‚Äúcase‚Äù or ‚Äúoccurrence‚Äù), which has a clear moral outcome. One then creates a rigorous taxonomy to define where the similarities lie and where the points of difference are. Essentially it is comparative analysis for ethics. It‚Äôs also used as a kind of philosophical slur to imply quibbling and equivocation in the face of tough moral decisions, but this doesn‚Äôt seem to phase Malcolm. He spends the episode applying the casuist method to a famous baseball doping scandal looking at how one evaluates modern growth hormone technologies in comparison to traditional surgical techniques. In the process, he demonstrates what it is to equivocate in an applied and compellingly practical manner. More specifically, he demonstrates how the casuist method can be used to inform on the morality of new problems. Now, I‚Äôm not about to pretend I really know anything about moral philosophy, and I definitely don‚Äôt know anything about Jesuits, but listening to the episode made me reflect on the current state of conversations relating to the risk of new technologies manifesting unintended negative consequences. We are facing a whole load of NEW and juicy problems. Problems like how to effectively moderate the line between freedom of speech and hate speech or how to deal with deepfakes. We have never encountered these problems in these ways before. So far, we have pretty much produced a stream of endlessly similar yet slightly rivalrous sets of principles which are then pretty unilaterally criticised for being too general and therefore not very useful. Gladwell makes the solid point that when it comes to a new problem, you can‚Äôt solve it by speaking to a principle. Principles don‚Äôt help because they are the product of past experience. In a new situation, you‚Äôre in uncharted territory and therefore you must proceed on a case by case basis. A general rule applies generally and the more you descend into the particulars, it is no longer a general rule. Take, for example, the problem of virtual reality‚Äôs psychological impact. Studies indicate that experiencing a VR simulation in an avatar which is of a different race to ones own can have a dramatic impact on the users racial bias, as in they were less bias to other races. Of course immersing your two primary cognitive senses entirely obviously has a profound neurological experience! This is why VR can be so effective as a treatment for PTSD and potentially have many other incredibly positive uses, but also could be preset a risk for misuse, manipulation and abuse. One of the largest commercial audiences for VR technologies are children and adolescents playing video games whose brains are highly plastic and responsive. Having a technology which is potentially this emotionally powerful is a new problem but VR is like any tool- it can be used well or not so well. It‚Äôs not about banning the tool, it‚Äôs about understanding the risk, uses, and impacts in an applied manner. So whilst I am not saying there is no value in the principles work, we don‚Äôt need any more principles, we need to get our hands dirty. We need to foreground the critical method for understanding and evaluating the development and use of new technologies. Unilateral notions of good and bad won‚Äôt cut it. Finding and developing ways that we can consistently and transparently understand these new problems is of vital importance. There are hundreds of years of moral philosophy and critical methods for understanding the world, so let‚Äôs use that knowledge. -- -- Acting Head BBC News Labs / Wellcome Trust Data For Mental Health Research. ex Open Data Institute. Writes about data, design, digital, and anthropology. Help Status About Careers Press Blog Privacy Terms Text to speech Teams

Title: 7 Indian Startups that made it to Crunchbase: 50 Hot Tech List
Subtitle: Written by LAFFAZ
Author: LAFFAZ
Article: Sign up Sign in Sign up Sign in LAFFAZ Follow -- 1 Listen Share Crunchbase released its ‚Äô50 Hot Tech Companies‚Äò list on June 20 ‚Äî inculcating startups filtered on the basis of the following criteria: Funding raised between $5 million to $20million in first half of 2019 and not exited via IPO or acquisition. India being the 2nd largest startup ecosystem in the world after US, made it to the second place in terms of the number of startups listed in this top 50 Hot Tech companies list too. Let‚Äôs know about these startups‚Ä¶ Disclaimer: These startups have been listed in the descending order of funding amount raised by these startups till the date of publication of this article. BharatPe is a QR code-based payment app for offline retailers and businesses. The New Delhi-based company also recently announced short-term credit options for merchants. ‚ñ∏ Category: Apps, FinTech, Payments, QR Codes ‚ñ∏ Founded: 2018 ‚ñ∏ Founders: Ashneer Grover, Shashvat Nakrani ‚ñ∏ Total funding: $92.5 Million ‚ñ∏ Key Investors: Insight Partners, BEENEXT, Sequoia Capital India ‚ñ∏ Platform: BharatPe.com Spinny is a tech-powered new age used car buying platform enabling trustworthy and hassle-free transactions in used cars. ‚ñ∏ Category: E-Commerce, E-Commerce Platforms, Internet, Retail ‚ñ∏ Founded: 2015 ‚ñ∏ Founders: Mohit Gupta, Niraj Singh, Ramanshu Mahaur ‚ñ∏ Total funding: $18.2 Million ‚ñ∏ Key Investors: Accel, SAIF Partners, Blume Ventures ‚ñ∏ Platform: Spinny.com India‚Äôs largest social commerce platform, Wooplr is a free & easy way to start an online store used by 200K+ store owners. ‚ñ∏ Category: E-Commerce, Fashion, Social Network, Social Shopping ‚ñ∏ Founded: 19 Apr, 2018 ‚ñ∏ Founders: Ankit Sabharwal, Arjun Zacharia, Praveen Rajaretnam, Soumen Sarkar ‚ñ∏ Total funding: $15.5 Million ‚ñ∏ Key Investors: Helion Venture Partners, Sistema Asia Fund, Astarc Ventures ‚ñ∏ Platform: wooplr.com QuickRide offers Carpooling, Bike pooling and Ride-sharing service through its mobile app. It connects commuters traveling in the same direction in real time. ‚ñ∏ Category: Car Sharing, Mobile Apps, Ride Sharing, Travel ‚ñ∏ Founded: 2014 ‚ñ∏ Founders: Kmm Rao ‚ñ∏ Total funding: $14.3 Million ‚ñ∏ Key Investors: Naspers ‚ñ∏ Platform: quickride.in Freshtohome is an online retailer of fresh and chemical-free seafood and meat. Originally founded as ‚ÄòSeaToHome‚Äô in 2012 by Kochi, Kerala-based entrepreneur Mathew Joseph and got shut down in 2015. Relaunched by Shan Kadavil (the former India Head, Zynga Inc.) in 2016. ‚ñ∏ Category: Food and Beverage, Food Delivery, Online Portals ‚ñ∏ Founded: 01 Aug, 2016 ‚ñ∏ Founders: Shan Kadavil ‚ñ∏ Total funding: $11 Million ‚ñ∏ Key Investors: Kortschak Investments, L.P., CE Ventures (CEIIF) ‚ñ∏ Platform: Freshtohome Ftcash is one of India‚Äôs fastest growing financial technology venture, recognized by Forbes, which aims to empower micro-merchants and small businesses through financial inclusion using digital payments and loans. ‚ñ∏ Category: Apps, Banking, Financial Services, FinTech, Micro Lending, Mobile Payments, Payments ‚ñ∏ Founded: Jun, 2015 ‚ñ∏ Founders: Deepak Kothari, Sanjeev Chandak, Vaibhav Lodha ‚ñ∏ Total funding: $10.2 Million ‚ñ∏ Key Investors: Accion, FMO, 500 Startups, IvyCap Ventures ‚ñ∏ Platform: ftcash.com Fyle is an AI-powered digital transaction platform that focuses on business expense reporting and management for tech companies. It inculcates deep linking, deep learning features to manage transaction loads. ‚ñ∏ Category: Accounting, Business Information System, Business Travel, Finance, SaaS ‚ñ∏ Founded: 16 Feb, 2016 ‚ñ∏ Founders: Sivaramakrishnan Narayan, Yashwanth Madhusudhan ‚ñ∏ Total funding: $5.9 Million ‚ñ∏ Key Investors: Tiger Global Management, BEENEXT, Pravega Ventures ‚ñ∏ Platform: fylehq.com Also read: 4 MENA-based Startups in Crunchbase: 50 Hot Tech List 2019 Want to explore the whole list of 50 startups? Title: Healthcare 5.0 ‚Äî from Codes to Clinic
Subtitle: Published in DataDrivenInvestor
Author: Medgic
Article: Sign up Sign in Sign up Sign in Medgic Follow DataDrivenInvestor -- Listen Share Artificial Intelligence (AI) is indeed the transformational technology of our generation, and whilst its practicality in Healthcare is still yet to be fully felt ‚Äî real-life deployment and funding of promising AI startups are ever-growing. We predict that within the decade, Artificial Intelligence would be recognized as a complementary arm of healthcare ‚Äî and while it might not fully replace the traditional role of professionals, AI certainly can disrupt healthcare to become better, faster, cheaper and more accessible. The benefits of Medical AI in unprivileged communities cannot be overstated. AI could save lives (and your pockets) on a global scale. So in this emerging evolution from codes to clinic, which are the movers and shakers in this promising industry? We examine a few as they will, de facto, shape our future. https://aimi.stanford.edu/ Stanford University Stanford, California United States of America [Status] R&D-in-progress, Private University What they are working on: Radiology Deep Learning, Data Augmentation, X-ray/plain film analysis, volumetric film analysis Why they are promising: Stanford is a world-renowned higher learning institution with her own medical facilities. Comprising a famous faculty including the likes of Prof Curtis Langlotz, Stanford also has immense funding, manpower to fund their cutting edge research. Particularly impressive is the fact that Stanford organizes her own Medical Imagenet though the dataset is not yet made available to the public. Potential challenges: Deep Learning for radiology is perhaps not the easiest domain to tackle. The very fact that many radiology models require a volumetric assessment (eg: CT/MRI) and may not be clinically significant if interpreted by frame means that Stanford AIMI has quite a battle. Labeling in radiology is also another pandora box. Consolidation or frank pneumonia? To tackle this, Stanford AIMI will probably need to standardize and protocolize these labelings. 2. Medical Good Intelligence Company (MEDGIC) https://www.medgic.coMEDGIC East Coast Road Singapore [Status] Active, Non-Profit, Private Startup (Independent) What they are working on: Dermatology Deep Learning, Bayesian Network, Skin analysis, Skin Diagnosis, Skin Scanning, Detection of skin conditions Why they are promising: Probably the first and only on earth to tackle the entire spectrum of dermatological conditions (with pretty impressive accuracy for a start), Medgic is a non-profit startup which has resisted funding and to date remains strictly independent. It is made in Singapore by a team of doctors and computer scientists. The founder, Dr. R Lim has stated that funding from private funds ‚Äúwould make Medgic chase money‚Äù but ‚Äúthe real ROI is the number of lives we could change.‚Äù While Medgic is not rated as a medical device nor does it claim to be diagnostic or have any medical accuracy yet (pending clinical trials which would require larger funding), it is released as a general skin scanner, detector and analyzer to ‚Äúprovide general information for general purposes only‚Äù. Potential challenges: Being independent and small, the team will have a harder time marketing itself and making the technology known to the remote corners of the world. Language barriers are probably the next big challenge ‚Äî Medgic AI actually asks users about their skin condition ‚Äî and medical terminologies often are hard to translate. This is especially true as Medgic is trying to target unprivileged communities with poor access to healthcare. 3. Google AI https://ai.google/healthcare Google Mountain View, California United States of America [Status] R&D-in-progress, Private Corporation What they are working on: Retinography Deep Learning, Pathology Deep Learning Why they are promising: Google AI is no doubt the grandfather of Artificial Intelligence innovations. The world stood in awe as AlphaGo beat Kai Jie in the ancient Chinese game of Go back in 2017. Since then the team has been working on meaningful applications such as medical imaging (as above). The sky is indeed the limit for Google. Potential challenges: Pathology is an important area to disrupt but this field is relatively operator dependent. For example, pathology slides may differ significantly depending on the operator‚Äôs choice of, amount and combination of staining. Retinography similarly requires the use of a complex machine which many professionals might still not be skilled at. That being said, these are surmountable challenges which can be tackled over time. -- -- empowerment through data, knowledge, and expertise. subscribe to DDIntel at https://ddintel.datadriveninvestor.com Help Status About Careers Press Blog Privacy Terms Text to speech Teams

Title: Meet the RaisedBy.Us Junior Advisory Board
Subtitle: Connect with RaisedBy.Us on social. Follow us on Instagram, Twitter, LinkedIn, and Facebook.
Author: RaisedBy.Us
Article: Sign up Sign in Sign up Sign in RaisedBy.Us Follow -- Listen Share In addition to our Board of Directors, RaisedBy.Us is supported by a Junior Advisory Board. Comprised of 15 young leaders from a variety of backgrounds and industries, the Junior Board is responsible for executing new initiatives designed to raise awareness and support RBU‚Äôs work enabling social good throughout the New York tech ecosystem. Some examples include hosting spring‚Äôs Pause for a Cause event, directly supporting RBU Executive Director Matt Amalfitano, developing new resources, and more. Get to know the RaisedBy.Us Junior Advisory Board here. Day job: Commercial Revenue Strategy Analyst, PepsiCo On joining: Joining RaisedBy.Us presented a fantastic opportunity to help a startup scale while providing meaningful support to our community. RBU responsibilities: I have had the chance to create and organize our Junior Board alongside our CEO & Executive Director, Matt Amalfitano. Most memorable volunteer experience: Seeing our Junior Board work together to orchestrate our first event in spring 2019. It was impactful to see how our volunteered time, creativity, and hard work was put together to raise money and awareness for our community‚Äôs most pressing problems. For fun: In my spare time, I love exploring new places, finding new restaurants, and meeting passionate entrepreneurs and discussing their businesses and creative ideas. Day job: Investor, Partnership Fund for NYC On joining: I joined RBU to help early-stage founders develop tangible ways to support a culture around employee volunteerism and philanthropy. I‚Äôm a strong believer that this could be a powerful way to build community and increase employee and customer engagement long-term. RBU responsibilities: Most of my efforts have been focused around thinking about strategic ways to build partnerships with early-stage companies and founders and engage with investors and corporates that are interested in working with RBU. Most memorable volunteer experience: Art for Heart. I started a non-profit in high school to collaborate with other fellow artists to raise money for underprivileged children‚Äôs cardiac surgeries at the Children‚Äôs Hospital of Philadelphia. It was a great way to do something I love and give back to the community. For fun: Trapezing and taco crawls. Day job: Account Executive, Simon Data On joining: I joined RBU for two reasons: I know Matt Amalfitano to be a great person and leader. And because RBU helps to close the frustrating and omnipresent gap between wanting to do social good and actually doing it. RBU responsibilities: I‚Äôm helping to coordinate programming to raise awareness of RBU and its partner organizations. Most memorable volunteer experience: Working as a physical education coach at the Miami Learning Experience ‚Äî a school for children and adults with special needs. I learned that your time and a smile can go a long way. For fun: Writing music. Day job: Product Manager On joining: In high school and college, I was involved with volunteerism and had always connected those opportunities with my interest in women‚Äôs mentorship and empowerment. It wasn‚Äôt until I met Matt Amalfitano and started attending RBU events that I realized I could connect my interests in philanthropy and tech in a really meaningful way. I want to hold myself and my peers accountable to getting involved in our communities and making a difference inside and outside the office context. RBU responsibilities: At RBU, I coordinate developing our engagement and outreach strategy through programming and content. Most memorable volunteer experience: In high school, I used to work at Access, a women‚Äôs and children‚Äôs shelter in Akron, Ohio. Over the years volunteering there, I was able to forge such meaningful relationships with some of the strongest and most resilient women and their children that truly altered my perspective and values regarding women‚Äôs empowerment and early childhood development resources. For fun: Pinterest, sketching, and spending time with my loved ones. Day job: Content and Brand Manager, Lerer Hippeau On joining: I was involved with several volunteer organizations while in college but, after I graduated and moved to New York, I didn‚Äôt immediately jump back in. When I learned about how RBU works with the New York tech ecosystem, I was excited for the chance to use my voice and network to raise awareness for all the great work RBU facilitates here. RBU responsibilities: I‚Äôm managing content development, helping with social media, and assisting in event marketing efforts. Most memorable volunteer experience: During high school I traveled with a group to El Salvador and worked in a clinic where I assisted the doctors as they treated patients. I went a total of three times and the experience was truly life-changing. For fun: Cooking, baking, and reading fiction. Day job: Global Scaled Solutions Program Manager, Uber On joining: We can do so much good when we join together. RBU serves as an engine for that and I‚Äôm grateful to help support the team in their incredible work. RBU responsibilities: I‚Äôm supporting RBU event planning. Most memorable volunteer experience: After graduating from Duke University, I had the privilege of teaching high school English on the island of Pohnpei in Micronesia. They didn‚Äôt mention that when you sign up to become a volunteer teacher, you spend most of your time being the student. For fun: I teach mindfulness and emotional intelligence programs to organizations. Day job: Analyst, Evolution Media Capital On joining: Working in the New York tech industry has shown me the power of this community and its desire to make an impact. I believe that RBU is uniquely positioned to scale philanthropic giving in a way that could make a difference in this city and beyond. RBU responsibilities: I‚Äôm working on helping the team build an authentic, young, and enthusiastic community, focusing on potential collaborators in high-growth companies Most memorable volunteer experience: In college I worked with Patriot League alumni Paralympians to help raise funds for competitors ahead of the 2016 Paralympic Games in Rio. It was humbling and inspiring to hear the stories of the athletes, as well as the support of the Patriot League community. For fun: Triathlons. Day job: Investment Analyst, New Enterprise Associates (NEA) On joining: I joined RBU to help empower companies to give back to their communities. Building a culture of giving, volunteerism, and community action is not easy, and I believe in RBU‚Äôs ability to help companies achieve their goals in these fields. RBU responsibilities: I am working with the team on RBU‚Äôs model, as well as helping RBU source new companies to work with. Most memorable volunteer experience: I spent about a month volunteering at a group home for children in the British Virgin Islands where I built beds, cribs, and dressers. Getting to know the children living there was an incredible experience that I will always remember. For fun: Woodworking. Day job: Principal, Laconia On joining: At RBU, I‚Äôm excited to support a rapidly growing organization during the early days, especially at the intersection of technology and social good. RBU responsibilities: I‚Äôve had the opportunity to work with the junior board and CEO on business development and community-building for the broader RBU ecosystem. Most memorable volunteer experience: In college I was part of the Undergrad Stern Women in Business club, a student-run organization focused on professional, social, and community service events. The community service event calendar ranged from making care packages to children with cancer to writing letters to troops to hosting financial literacy events for students of underrepresented backgrounds, providing a wonderfully comprehensive view of the many ways we can volunteer our time, money, and energy. For fun: Billiards. Day job: Account Executive, Uber On joining: I joined RBU for the opportunity to give back to my community through its unique network of New York tech companies and not-for-profit organizations. RBU responsibilities: I‚Äôm the lead event coordinator for the RBU junior advisory board. Most memorable volunteer experience: In high school, I traveled to Bulgaria to work with children who were part of the country‚Äôs complicated adoption system. For fun: I enjoy exploring new cities in search of live music and great food. Day job: Associate, Latham & Watkins LLP On joining: I joined RBU because it presents an exciting, innovative way to give back to the community and improve corporate social responsibility in the tech industry. RBU responsibilities: I am assisting with event planning for RBU. Most memorable volunteer experience: I spent a day volunteering at an orphanage in Bulgaria when I was in high school. It was really cool to see how everyday activities from my childhood like playing with toys and eating candy all day had such a big impact on the kids. For fun: Playing drums. Day job: CEO, Bop Network On joining: I joined RBU to connect with like-minded people and raise awareness for worthy causes. RBU responsibilities: I assist with RBU‚Äôs event marketing. Most memorable volunteer experience: My most memorable volunteer experience was helping feed the homeless during the holiday season through the organization BBYO. For fun: My hobbies include seeing live music and reading. Day job: Chief of Staff, Headliner Labs On joining: It‚Äôs incredible to see how much impact the fastest growing tech companies in New York can have when united in creating social good. RBU responsibilities: I‚Äôm very excited to help develop RBU‚Äôs Ambassador Program and to get even more companies and people involved. Most memorable volunteer experience: Working on the 2018 Giving Tuesday Auction was very cool because of the responsibility I had in negotiating the platform fee for the auction. I loved seeing different tech companies donate so many different items (ie: Mets game with Ben Lerer, year‚Äôs supply of toilet paper from Boxed, Burrow loveseat, Knot Standard custom blazer, and more). For fun: Dog training. Day job: Marketing Manager, Darktrace On joining: Matt A‚Äôs dedication and leadership inspired me. Additionally, extending our social impact to the workplace, where we happen to spend the majority of our week, seemed untapped and a natural fit. We have the opportunity to add another layer to the giving-back ecosystem and that‚Äôs an exciting task. RBU responsibilities: Building our audience profile and implementing that knowledge into programming and prospecting. Most memorable volunteer experience: I used to volunteer every Friday in middle school at a local soup kitchen with Nikki Simon (fellow Junior Board Member) in New York. At a young age, we were exposed to the importance of giving back to those in need. For fun: I love connecting people and traveling. You can catch me reading the New York Times or looking for New York‚Äôs best burger. Day job: Treasury Sales Analyst, Bank of America Merrill Lynch On joining: Working at a large corporation, I have the advantage of a large volunteer network. I joined RBU to help give growing companies the same opportunities to give back to the community. RBU responsibilities: I am currently working on coming up with strategy and ideas for the upcoming RBU event. Most memorable volunteer experience: This winter I had the opportunity to volunteer with an organization called the The HOPE Program which supports job training, placement, and long-term career support. We conducted mock interviews and gave advice to men and women who were looking to renter the workforce after adversity. For fun: Eating and reading about food. Interested in learning more about how RaisedBy.Us enables high-impact workplace philanthropy? Visit our website or contact us directly. -- -- RaisedBy.Us, a not-for-profit organization, enables social good through employee giving, volunteerism and community events.
